headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hello, and thank you for listening for our commentary on first quarter results. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO; and I'm joined by Ken Lewis, our CFO. Market volatility continued this quarter, but we are confident we have the talent, discipline and foresight to con
componenttext:
Hello, and thank you for listening for our commentary on first quarter results. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO; and I'm joined by Ken Lewis, our CFO. Market volatility continued this quarter, but we are confident we have the talent, discipline and foresight to continue driving our long-term success. We have a long history of weathering periods like this and emerging stronger as a firm, well-positioned to benefit from the long-term trends driving global markets. Institutional flows rebounded, aided by $5.5 billion global macro mandate that funded in the quarter. Financial results were solid and profitability remained strong, as we implemented a number of cost savings initiatives that reduced year-over-year controllable expenses by 6%. In December, the Board of Directors declared a 20% increase to the regular dividend, which has more than doubled over the past 5 years and we continued our elevated share repurchase activity. In total, we repurchased 10.5 million shares, significantly more than offsetting issuance from long-term equity awards granted in the quarter. 
As Ken mentioned on our last call, while we are implementing a number of cost cutting initiatives this year, we're also investing in growth initiatives. In November, we appointed a new head of global ETFs to help shape and develop our offerings in the ETF space. In early January, we filed an SEC registration statement for an initial suite of strategic beta ETFs branded as Franklin Liberty Q. We believe the addition of strategic beta ETFs will compliment our existing active management product ranges and will offer our clients additional investment solutions and vehicles to construct their investment portfolios. Overall, the investment performance story was little changed from September. In aggregate, the majority of long-term mutual fund assets ranked in the top half of their respective peer groups. 
Fixed income funds continue to generate solid long-term relative performance track records, led by the global macro team, while equity and hybrid performance remains pressured as Franklin Income Fund represents roughly 30% of those assets.
We continue to educate advisors on the current positioning of our flagship funds and the prospective behind the portfolio manager's conviction, as these periods of volatility represent opportunities for patient long-term investors. New marketing materials were recently introduced to highlight 5 reasons why investors buy and hold Franklin Income Fund and why we believe Templeton Global Bond Fund represents a once-in-a-decade opportunity. Following the rollout, we have seen strong interest and engagement from clients. We are also pleased to note that MorningStar recently reiterated its bronze rating on the Franklin Income Fund. 
Assets under management ended the quarter at $764 billion, a 1% decrease from September. However, average assets under management were 5% lower at $782 billion.
The mix of assets under management by investment objective and sales region remained consistent with prior quarters. However, we experienced a gradual shift in assets towards institutional and high net worth clients that comprised 28% of assets under management, up from 26% 1 year ago. Long-term net outflows improved somewhat from last quarter to $20 billion due to increased sales and lower redemptions, which have improved since August. Market appreciation at $15 billion offset much of the outflows in the quarter.
Looking closer at flows by client type on Slide 11. From a retail perspective, we faced continued headwinds, particularly for our flagship funds in the U.S. and cross-border markets. U.S. retail redemptions remain elevated, due in large part to expected redemptions from our sub-advised variable annuity business that I mentioned last quarter. The client redeemed nearly $5 billion from its founding fund strategy, which impacted redemptions from U.S. equity, global equity and hybrid categories this quarter by roughly $1.6 billion each. Although the variable annuity business has been under pressure, it only represents about 6% of our assets under management today and we believe the potential exists for this business to resume its growth in the years ahead. As I mentioned last quarter, we're now offering a managed volatility fund for clients looking to reduce risk, as well as introducing new solutions-based products. International retail outflows eased a bit, due primarily to a decrease in redemptions from 3 of our largest cross-border funds: The Templeton Global Bond Fund, Global Total Return Fund and Asian Growth. Institutional sales have been strong year-to-date, due in large part to an Asian client that added a total of $5.5 billion to global macro mandate in the quarter. It's worth noting the client initially funded the mandate in October of $4.8 billion and added another $700 million, taking advantage of some market dislocations later in the quarter. 
We continue to emphasize the growth of our institutional presence globally by refining our value proposition and brand messaging, building and executing channel-specific strategies, investing in infrastructure to support customization and enhanced servicing and optimizing our product line up and pricing. Outflows from global equity strategies remain elevated this quarter, as improving flows in our emerging markets funds were offset by weaker flows from other global equity strategies, including the variable annuity redemption I mentioned. Meanwhile, our local asset management equity teams had another solid quarter, attracting over $300 million of net new flows, which continues a strong growth story that sometimes gets lost amongst the larger parts of the business. Global fixed income net outflows improved to $3.6 billion, due to a combination of increased sales and decreased redemptions. The improvement in redemptions was attributable to the cross-border versions of Templeton Global Bond and Global Total Return Funds that experienced lower redemptions overall this quarter, as well as large institutional redemptions that occurred in the prior quarter.
Sales growth was bolstered by the $5.5 billion global macro mandate that I already highlighted. U.S. equity strategies experienced decreased redemptions that led to moderating net outflows of $3.1 billion, despite slightly lower sales volumes. Like last quarter, U.S. equity flows were negatively impacted by further redemptions from our variable annuity business, including the $1.6 billion redemption I mentioned already, which had a similar impact on hybrid redemptions. Hybrid net new outflows increased to $5.6 billion, with most of that attributable to the Franklin Income Funds. Our K2 liquid alternative strategies continues to be another success story, as assets of both of the U.S. and cross-border fund eclipsed $1 billion at quarter end and continued to generate strong interest from clients. The follow up Franklin K2 Long-Short Credit Fund that launched last quarter has already been approved on 30 advisory and brokerage platforms and we're working on additional strategies that we plan to launch later this year.
Looking at Slide 14, tax-prefixed income funds experienced a strong improvement in redemptions that resulted in nearly break even flows. On a taxable side, a combination of slowing sales, increased redemptions and net exchanges out resulted in net new outflows of $2.5 billion. Funds managed by our high-yield team accounted for about half of the net outflows but increased only modestly from the prior quarter despite the pressure experienced by the high-yield market.
And now, I'll turn it over to Ken for our financial results.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg. Although lower assets under management and its associated revenue was a headwind, overall, financial results were solid as we implement cost savings initiatives and generated over $650 million in operating income for the quarter.Net income
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg. Although lower assets under management and its associated revenue was a headwind, overall, financial results were solid as we implement cost savings initiatives and generated over $650 million in operating income for the quarter.
Net income improved this quarter. It was almost $450 million and similarly, diluted earnings per share also increased to $0.74. Investment management fee revenue was down 6% this quarter, which was essentially in-line with the decline in average assets under management after excluding the impact of lower performance fees that were only $1.9 million this quarter. Similarly, the decline in assets, as well as the 13 % decline in commissionable sales reduced sales and distribution revenue, which was $478 million. Shareholder servicing fees also decreased this quarter and were $62 million. This was due primarily to lower assets under management and one less day this quarter. Other revenue decreased significantly over the prior quarter to $31 million. Changes in consolidated sponsor investment products drove most of the change here. However, this impact was largely offset in noncontrolling interests. Looking at expenses on Slide 18, total expenses decreased by 4%. Sales, distribution and marketing expense was $589 million, a decrease that was consistent with the decline in sales and distribution revenue. We did see a shift away from non-U.S. assets that generate these fees, which resulted in the net of sales and distribution to decrease, which is summarized in the appendix of the presentation. 
Compensation and benefits expense came in at $343 million and that was a 2% increase over the prior quarter. This reflected a decrease in variable compensation that was more than offset by increases in salary, wages and benefits, which included severance expense of $13 million. Last quarter, I provided guidance that we expected 2016 expense levels, excluding sales and distribution region expense, to be 3% to 4% below 2015 levels and that the realization of those savings could be deferred by execution costs.
Currently, we think that we'll realize savings at the upper end of that range and are looking for ways to increase that number. As a result, we expect to incur additional severance costs in future quarters. Next quarter, considering the normal seasonal increase in compensation and estimated severance, we expect a quarter-over-quarter increase in compensation expense of approximately 9% to 12%. We still anticipate year-over-year compensation expense savings of about 3%, inclusive of those charges.
Information systems and technology expense of $51 million reflected both seasonal factors and a number of expense reductions. Occupancy expense was $31 million but going forward, we expect the run rate for this item to look more like the fourth quarter of last year. General administrative and other expenses was down 1% this quarter. There were a number of reductions to advertising, promotional and traveling expenses. However, the mark-to-market of the liability related to the prior acquisition almost entirely offset the impact of those items.
As you can see on Slide 19, the operating margin remained strong at 37.2% this quarter but decreased a bit due to lower revenue. However, expense reductions mitigated margin compression to some extent. The tax rate was 31.2% this quarter and this was in line with prior guidance for the fiscal year, which we still believed to be a reasonable estimate for 2016. Moving on to other income net of noncontrolling interest was $27 million this quarter. The key driver of the change from last quarter was equity method investments that were a gain of $25 million and a reflection of the improvement in equity markets during the quarter.
Looking now at capital management, the board announced a 20% increase in the regular dividend this quarter, which has more than doubled over the past 5 years. As you can see, the compound annual growth rate of our dividend has substantially outpaced that of the peer group average over all time periods, included on Slide 22. Share purchase activity remained elevated as the stock remained under pressure, while volume slowed modestly. In fact, we repurchased 10.5 million shares in the quarter for a total cost of over $400 million, which significantly more than offset issuance from long-term equity awards.
Looking at the payout on Slide 24, the total payout for the trailing 12 months was $1.7 billion or 88% of net income. As this chart clearly illustrates, we've recently demonstrated a relative preference for share repurchase versus dividends given Ben's current valuation but the board remains committed to the long-term growth of the regular dividend.
That concludes my comments. We look forward to talking with you on the call later today.

At this time, we like to check the cooperative Franklin Resources' Chairman and CEO, Mr. Greg Johnson. Thank you. Mr. Johnson, you now begin.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining Ken Lewis and me to discuss first quarter earnings. Although we face a number of headwinds impacting investor performance and flows, we've been through periods like this before, and it's one of the reasons we value
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining Ken Lewis and me to discuss first quarter earnings. Although we face a number of headwinds impacting investor performance and flows, we've been through periods like this before, and it's one of the reasons we value diversification and a strong balance sheet. As we work through these challenges and maintain our focus on expense management, we will continue to invest in a number of long-term growth opportunities including strategic beta ETFs, liquid alternatives and related solutions while delivering our value-added services to a growing customer base around the world. 
And now, Ken and I will be happy to take your questions.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first question is from Michael Carrier a Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question is from Michael Carrier a Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, maybe first one for you, just on the flows in the quarter and the outlook, you had a few things in the prerecorded call, but sounds like the institutional business continues to gain some traction. Just wanted to get an update on maybe the pipeline a
componenttext: Greg, maybe first one for you, just on the flows in the quarter and the outlook, you had a few things in the prerecorded call, but sounds like the institutional business continues to gain some traction. Just wanted to get an update on maybe the pipeline and what you're seeing on that front, particularly given maybe some of the pressures in the market and where institutions are looking to put some money. And then on the retail side, it seems like the pressure on Franklin income and in global bond has been out there. It seems like there's more outreach to the client base. And just any kind of reaction to that?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Normal searchers with global ad and global equities, I think of note and what has happened over the last say 3 to 6 months, some of the pressure on global currencies affecting various countries and then looking for those countries to diversify, I think we
componenttext: Normal searchers with global ad and global equities, I think of note and what has happened over the last say 3 to 6 months, some of the pressure on global currencies affecting various countries and then looking for those countries to diversify, I think we're seeing more opportunities in the global bond space in Asia right now, as those currencies have been hit and with the further risks of some going down, just diversify a way from local currency. I think anytime you have periods where you face challenges and headwinds in performance, certainly a risk of environment that any income funds that have heavy high-yield exposure have been under pressure. We just want to make sure we communicate the value and really the appropriate kind of understanding of risking those funds. And when you get the kind of spreads that you have today from treasury, you do have room for even some defaults in those and still continue to do very well against treasury. So we think the markets have been under stress certainly in these areas, it's affected Franklin income fund, affects any high-yield funds, like our high income fund, and we just want to make sure that we continue to get as much information out there in handholding to help advisers deal with their clients right now.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say the pipeline -- the new opportunities in the pipeline will be more global bond opportunities like the win that we had in Asia over the quarter where you see more interest, whether it's cyber and wealth funds or government entities in div
componenttext: Well, I would say the pipeline -- the new opportunities in the pipeline will be more global bond opportunities like the win that we had in Asia over the quarter where you see more interest, whether it's cyber and wealth funds or government entities in diversifying from their own currencies that are under pressure right now.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, so the buyback activity has been, relative to history, has been pretty elevated the last 2 quarters. And I could essentially say that U.S. cash has remained unchanged. As a matter of fact it's remained unchanged year-over-year as well. So we've been
componenttext: Sure, so the buyback activity has been, relative to history, has been pretty elevated the last 2 quarters. And I could essentially say that U.S. cash has remained unchanged. As a matter of fact it's remained unchanged year-over-year as well. So we've been having plenty of U.S. cash generation to cover our needs.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Craig Siegenthaler of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: The next question is from Craig Siegenthaler of Crédit Suisse.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we do. And that's been a growing portion of our sales as more advisers have gone to the rapid advisory fee accounts.
componenttext: Yes, we do. And that's been a growing portion of our sales as more advisers have gone to the rapid advisory fee accounts.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you see even in the future of those transitioning from a low rate based to a high-class or a zero share, share class?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't. I think part of the reaction, again, I don't want to speak for Wandel but for us, it remains to be seen on the fiduciary rule which we have, I think we're expecting something out in 90 days on that. But we don't think it would affect in our exist
componenttext: I don't. I think part of the reaction, again, I don't want to speak for Wandel but for us, it remains to be seen on the fiduciary rule which we have, I think we're expecting something out in 90 days on that. But we don't think it would affect in our existing A shares an any way, and if there are different rules around use of those in advisory programs, we already have the no 12B-1 class available. So it would be easy. For us, it's up to the broker-dealers and advisers to interpret those rules to best fit their business models, but I think we have all the share classes that would do that right now.

componenttext: I don't right now. I think, I just looked at the number, the top of my head, we have about 40% of sales going to the no 12B-1 share class that's going from 30% of the priory year. I would still say our A share account is higher with the 12B-1 just due to our distribution model and our strong partnership with Edward Jones, which still favors that class.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Bill Katz with Citi group.
componenttext: The next question is from Bill Katz with Citi group.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, if I could side with you, you have given a little bit of updated expense guidance in the prerecorded call, I appreciate that. Can you talk a little bit about, I guess, some disclosures just skimming through the 10-Q, some of the disclosures were the
componenttext: Ken, if I could side with you, you have given a little bit of updated expense guidance in the prerecorded call, I appreciate that. Can you talk a little bit about, I guess, some disclosures just skimming through the 10-Q, some of the disclosures were the severance are occurring and if the markets -- what are your underlying assumptions for markets with this guidance? And, I guess, the markets continue to work themselves lower, what kind of incremental flexibility would you have to try to protect margins?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, well, regarding where the expenses have been incurred, I think geographically, maybe the majority of the expenses is U.S.-based. Across business lines, it hasn't -- we haven't really impacted the investment management section -- sector of our bus
componenttext: I think, well, regarding where the expenses have been incurred, I think geographically, maybe the majority of the expenses is U.S.-based. Across business lines, it hasn't -- we haven't really impacted the investment management section -- sector of our business. It's been spread out pretty much across the board other than investment management go though the assumptions regarding -- we talked about a target of 3% to 4%, and that was a few months ago. What this market volatility led us to conclude is that we should just be looking at all of our business and seeing where we can increase efficiencies, leverage efficiencies and that's what we're doing and that's going to be a theme for probably the next 9 months. And that's just based on the volatility, we're not assuming that markets going to be up or down, but it's obvious that they're volatile so we would be looking at our expenses closely.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So if the markets, just to clarify, if the markets were to sort of continue to work their way lower away from volatility, so then we're turning for a short term, is there more levers to pull to sort of protect the margin?
componenttext: So if the markets, just to clarify, if the markets were to sort of continue to work their way lower away from volatility, so then we're turning for a short term, is there more levers to pull to sort of protect the margin?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We think there are more levers to pull, but as I said, where looking at the entire business almost without regard to the markets. So it's just an opportunity for us to make sure that initiatives that we started years ago we still believe in, invest in thi
componenttext: We think there are more levers to pull, but as I said, where looking at the entire business almost without regard to the markets. So it's just an opportunity for us to make sure that initiatives that we started years ago we still believe in, invest in things that we believe and now and just tried to kind of reengineer all of our processes.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. Just to follow up, because, Greg, your thoughts here, very big picture, nice job of ancillary businesses, Q2 continues to grow, you're investing in smart data portfolio when you start him if you do have a lot of sizable flagship retail funds with
componenttext: Got you. Just to follow up, because, Greg, your thoughts here, very big picture, nice job of ancillary businesses, Q2 continues to grow, you're investing in smart data portfolio when you start him if you do have a lot of sizable flagship retail funds with some choppy sort of future performance. What measures are you taking to try and protect those assets in the retail channel? So corollary, any thoughts of maybe ambit of the marketing spend for just a waste of dollars just given the back half we are dealing here in?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it is a good question and one that's really performance driven like anything in this business and we're on our 10th year now, with growth outperforming value and you kind of look for a glimmer I have laid out there hope and certainly in January, t
componenttext: I think it is a good question and one that's really performance driven like anything in this business and we're on our 10th year now, with growth outperforming value and you kind of look for a glimmer I have laid out there hope and certainly in January, that's been a very choppy market, value did outperform growth for the first time. So that would be kind of the key driver to get more attention to some of these flagship funds that have been lagging, and we looked at some of the big laggers and even in January made some ground back with a rise in dividends mutual shares, mutual quest. We had a very strong January. So I think if that trend continues, that will be important. I think the other part, as Ken said, is really looking at our entire business and validating everything we're doing. And I think part of the changing distribution landscape advisers, looking at our industry and what they need differently, I think if you have redundancy with certain funds, or it's just not clear what that fund offers in the various category that advisors need, we may need to tune some of the lineup or merge some of the lineup, and that's something we really are looking at now. And that can drive some cost savings, ultimately, longer-term as well.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is from Michael Kim from Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: And the next question is from Michael Kim from Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first, Greg, on the prerecorded call, you highlighted some initiatives to better position the institutional business by building out some infrastructure, optimizing the product lineup. You also alluded to pricing. So just wondering if you can give us a
componenttext: So first, Greg, on the prerecorded call, you highlighted some initiatives to better position the institutional business by building out some infrastructure, optimizing the product lineup. You also alluded to pricing. So just wondering if you can give us a bit more color in terms of how you might be thinking about either the level or structure of fees in that channel and just kind of the potential impact from an economic standpoint as you move through that process.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's always a challenge on the pricing side to especially when you have funds in the marketplace and the sensitivity to making sure we have consistent pricing across. I think the comment was just more on the development that we've been doing also
componenttext: I think it's always a challenge on the pricing side to especially when you have funds in the marketplace and the sensitivity to making sure we have consistent pricing across. I think the comment was just more on the development that we've been doing also with the smart beta ETFs as I said before, I think it allows us to get lower-cost vehicles out there that have market beta at a much lower cost and that's going to be attracted to certain institutions as well as within our solutions and outcomes group. But I don't think there's anything really to call out on pricing side that we look at. I think we continue to study the markets and try to be competitive, and we all know the pressure on lower fees continues, and we were trying to meet that or develop new capabilities that don't conflict with some of the retail styles that we can build out capabilities.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful and then also on last quarter's call, I think you mentioned about 1/3 of the $17 billion and sort of the subadvisor variable annuity channel was at risk. So just following sort of the $5 billion redemption last quarter, does that suggest th
componenttext: That's helpful and then also on last quarter's call, I think you mentioned about 1/3 of the $17 billion and sort of the subadvisor variable annuity channel was at risk. So just following sort of the $5 billion redemption last quarter, does that suggest that sort of related AUM at risk from here is de minimis or immaterial at this point.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there's still probably another $5 billion at risk right now, with one of them. And from there, I think we have, today, low 40s, $42 billion in those subadvised assets like 6% of our base. I think at risk, I put another $5 billion for the changes t
componenttext: I think there's still probably another $5 billion at risk right now, with one of them. And from there, I think we have, today, low 40s, $42 billion in those subadvised assets like 6% of our base. I think at risk, I put another $5 billion for the changes that are taking place in that market. And, hopefully, the other side of that is we are, because of the buildout we have with our solutions group and some of the development, we just got our first mandated managed volatility funds. So that is an area that, hopefully, we can more than make up the loss of the $5 billion coming up.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ken Worthington of Montgomery JPMorgan.
componenttext: The next question is from Ken Worthington of Montgomery JPMorgan.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just first simply on the new marketing materials that you gave out on global bond and the income fund. When was that rolled out? And then you said in the prepared remarks that there was good engagement in interest by clients. What does that really mean? A
componenttext: Just first simply on the new marketing materials that you gave out on global bond and the income fund. When was that rolled out? And then you said in the prepared remarks that there was good engagement in interest by clients. What does that really mean? Are you actually seeing any indications that redemptions are slowing or sales are increasing?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we rolled it out right around the end of the year around January 1. So early to quantify any behavioral changes there. I think what you're trying to do is get the tools in the advisers hands so they can quickly sit down with their clients and walk
componenttext: I think we rolled it out right around the end of the year around January 1. So early to quantify any behavioral changes there. I think what you're trying to do is get the tools in the advisers hands so they can quickly sit down with their clients and walk them through logic on why you would stay put in a period where there's a lot of headlines around high-yield and stress in liquidity and make sure that they have a broad understanding of what is going on with those funds. I think the other point I would make is just around because I think that's the question I would look at as when would you see your are flagship flows returning, and I think when I look at the income fund, its long history and it's a well-diversified portfolio, but it's always one that doesn't fit neatly in any category. It will always have high-yield exposure, it will always be the highest yielding in its category. So it would be naturally a little bit more risky than its peer group. So you will expect to have periods where lags performance. I think the other side of fixed income, as I've said before, when the markets settle and high-yield settles and you have very attractive spreads to where certainly Treasuries are today, you have 6 plus yield on a fund that's done very well long-term. I think it's very easy to get momentum back in flows, a little bit easier than equity fund. Just the attractiveness of that coupon and the history and that's where I would expect to see a turn. I guess, really when the markets settle on the high-yield bond market settles in, I would expect to see that fund start to get and, hopefully, better sales.

componenttext: Yes, I think not only that relationship, but other institutional mandates in that market as well and it's a high profile relationship there that gives us better visibility in that market. componenttext: On the prerecorded, you mentioned you have global ETF and the registration of the strategic paid ETF. componenttext: I think the need, whether we use someone else's ETF for our own between our own lineup, we know we have the need for lower cost beta in outcome-oriented or solutions type product. So that's something that we feel we have an immediate place for those ETFs. And then I think it will take more time and marketing to develop more presence and probably a broader lineup but it's just our first step in the ones we think internally. We don't have to go out, and use somebody else's ETF, we can use the use and if there's some demand from the retail channel as well. I wouldn't try to quantify that right now, but enough immediately to make it meaningful to us.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then last quarter, you guys spoke about potential acquisitions. Just kind of wondering how the thought process there might have evolved, given how you look at repurchases and capital returns, what the stock price and then also the value of other
componenttext: Okay, and then last quarter, you guys spoke about potential acquisitions. Just kind of wondering how the thought process there might have evolved, given how you look at repurchases and capital returns, what the stock price and then also the value of other companies you might be looking to purchase there may be fill in to pursue gaps, is it better or worse than the last quarter and how are you guys thinking about that for the course of the year?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's unchanged, the strategy how we look at M&A, I don't think it's changed. I don't think the level of repurchase has changed that. As we always say, we say we're opportunistic. One of the factors is the share price and the market. But the other
componenttext: I think it's unchanged, the strategy how we look at M&A, I don't think it's changed. I don't think the level of repurchase has changed that. As we always say, we say we're opportunistic. One of the factors is the share price and the market. But the other factor is what are the uses of cash. If we were to identify a target, then we would probably skip back on the repurchases to balance it out. But we continue to look for opportunities in M&A, and that hasn't changed.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say, from my perspective, it's more probable just based on what's happened in the marketplace. Unfortunately, we've been sitting with a lot of cash and that puts you in a unique position, and I think with the selloff in a lot of asset managers and
componenttext: I would say, from my perspective, it's more probable just based on what's happened in the marketplace. Unfortunately, we've been sitting with a lot of cash and that puts you in a unique position, and I think with the selloff in a lot of asset managers and a selloff in currencies around the globe, the potential for doing something I think is a lot more attractive today, just looking at currency moves around the globe than it was before. So we are actively out there and are hopeful that something will come up, enhances the lineup and adds value long-term.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it is really all the above. I mean, it could be a large-scale that you get efficiencies from distribution and servicing. It could be parts expanding the high net worth business, it could be the solutions outcome, it could be real estate. There's a
componenttext: I think it is really all the above. I mean, it could be a large-scale that you get efficiencies from distribution and servicing. It could be parts expanding the high net worth business, it could be the solutions outcome, it could be real estate. There's a lot of areas that we're looking at but I think the probability of the right situation offshore even with Asia type finds that are very much at a favor right now, I think would look attractive to us long-term.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That would be great. And any additional -- I know in the last quarter's call, you were asked on DOL, and at that point, it didn't seem like you wanted to make many comments given it's not final. But now that we've got the rule in OMB, right, so we're a co
componenttext: That would be great. And any additional -- I know in the last quarter's call, you were asked on DOL, and at that point, it didn't seem like you wanted to make many comments given it's not final. But now that we've got the rule in OMB, right, so we're a couple of months most away from final, and it's expected to be largely unchanged. Do you have any sense of the extent to which this might impact your AUM through the broker sold channel?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think it's still too early, and I don't think it as an immediate impact. I think what it does is it has an impact on your future sales in those markets, and I think you're absolutely right. We have indication despite record comments and concerns rai
componenttext: No, I think it's still too early, and I don't think it as an immediate impact. I think what it does is it has an impact on your future sales in those markets, and I think you're absolutely right. We have indication despite record comments and concerns raised, it's something that looks like it's going to move pretty quickly and try to be enacted before next January and whether that results in lawsuits, I think that's still very much out there as a possibility to take this up. We are going to work with our partners and try to work through what will be a very complex transition to deal with this new rule. But I couldn't quantify what that means other than it's not a positive.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: The next question is from Brian Bedell with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a little bit more on the strategic beta initiative, I mean, first how substantial or what kind of breadth of product you want to ultimately develop in this area? And then if you could talk a little bit about the distribution game plan for the product
componenttext: Just a little bit more on the strategic beta initiative, I mean, first how substantial or what kind of breadth of product you want to ultimately develop in this area? And then if you could talk a little bit about the distribution game plan for the products and also is this partly in response to a potential deal, would these products be more attractive and you have in a fiduciary world?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think it is in response to the DOL rule, think it is just in response to where we see growth in needs in our lineup. And again, as I said before, it's getting a cheaper beta that doesn't conflict with your other funds will be important for us. I t
componenttext: I don't think it is in response to the DOL rule, think it is just in response to where we see growth in needs in our lineup. And again, as I said before, it's getting a cheaper beta that doesn't conflict with your other funds will be important for us. I think the question on how big this market and whether or not at some point, there is a vehicle that makes it more efficient than your typical 40 [ph] act transfer agent driven product I think those are all questions that are still very much out there so we just felt like business is too large for an asset management company to ignore. And whether it's again through acquisitions or organic growth, that's going to affect our plan on how we roll this out. We think it has to be a separate effort, but also part of you get the leverage from your existing wholesaler group as well. And how big, I think, again, we're starting kind of small, but we will continue to roll out or acquire new ones as we see fit. It's just kind of getting in that space and building a team there and growing it.

componenttext: Yes, I think I mentioned -- we talked about the subject before. That topic, regardless of market conditions, has come up over the years. And we've done a lot of analysis on it. componenttext: Of think it is not the change of you to look at it. The conclusion may or not be different at this time. There are very valid reasons for us to do some of these things in house. headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: And I would just add, again, in any environment, this is something that we would look at. And because of our structure and capabilities in lower cost regions like India, we're very cost competitive to the market in those services. If we are not, that's something that we have to consider. So we got those groups know, that's something we need to validate, continue to press cost down, they've done that effectively so it has really given us a reason to go out and outsource it.

componenttext: I think certainly the industry is exploring that space and looking at lower cost alternatives that can reach broader groups through digital marketing and capabilities that exist trying to get to the millennials in a different way than the traditional broker-dealer adviser model. So for us, that's another one that with the fin tech space and looking at global advisors is something that we certainly are studying, whether or not we need to acquire and wanted to build that capability, I think that's a question that we're looking at today. And I think the opportunity for the industry as distribution landscape changes as we go to more advisory driven models, this the traditional barriers between the broker-dealer fund sold the first is a direct group continue the road and disappear in a pretty quick pace. I think the opportunity is what does that mean for investment management firms. And I think that's why a lot of groups are looking at. And for us, as I mentioned, the partnership that we're doing with a large global bank and using our solutions capabilities targeting the emerging affluent market through digital marketing to existing customers in the bank. And that's very similar to what a global adviser can do. The sure funds that are multi-asset and have a lot of -- and they have other managers on Franklin top of them and we can do that. That's somewhat what a global advisor can deliver. And to me, there's not a lot of magic compared to what a global adviser can be versus a solutions group can do or anybody more than out. And I think that direct space, the vanguards and the traditional people in that space, Schwab, have a pretty good head start in dealing with that marketplace as far as robot adviser.

And I think as I said before, I think the feedback we're getting from institutional side in Asia is that opportunity Israel today and get another separate accounts in that space, but I don't know if I can quantify that.

componenttext: I think that's a perfect question to lead to our introduction of the fund that we just rolled out in the last year is our K2 long short credit bond. headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

Welcome to Franklin Resources' Earnings Commentary for the quarter ended December 31, 2015. Statements made in this commentary regarding Franklin Resources, Inc., which are not historical facts, are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements involve a number of known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from any future results expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements. 
These and other risks, uncertainties and other important factors are described in more detail in Franklin's recent filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including in the Risk Factors and MD&A sections of Franklin's most recent Form 10-K and 10-Q filings. This commentary was prerecorded.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hello, and thank you for listening to our commentary on first quarter results. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO; and I'm joined by Ken Lewis, our CFO. Market volatility continued this quarter, but we are confident that we have the talent, discipline and foresight to
componenttext:
Hello, and thank you for listening to our commentary on first quarter results. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO; and I'm joined by Ken Lewis, our CFO. Market volatility continued this quarter, but we are confident that we have the talent, discipline and foresight to continue driving our long-term success. 
We have a long history of weathering periods like this and emerging stronger as a firm, well-positioned to benefit from the long-term trends driving global markets. Institutional flows rebounded, aided by $5.5 billion global macro mandate that funded in the quarter. Financial results were solid and profitability remained strong as we implemented a number of cost savings initiatives that reduced year-over-year controllable expenses by 6%. 
In December, the Board of Directors declared a 20% increase to the regular dividend, which has more than doubled over the past 5 years, and we continued our elevated share repurchase activity. In total, we repurchased 10.5 million shares, significantly more than offsetting issuance from long-term equity awards granted in the quarter. 
As Ken mentioned on our last call, while we are implementing a number of cost-cutting initiatives this year, we're also investing in growth initiatives. In November, we appointed a new head of global ETFs to help shape and develop our offerings in the ETF space. And in early January, we filed an SEC registration statement for an initial suite of strategic beta ETFs branded as Franklin LibertyQ.
We believe the addition of strategic beta ETFs will complement our existing active management product ranges and will offer our clients additional investment solutions and vehicles to construct their investment portfolios. Overall, the investment performance story was little changed from September. In aggregate, the majority of long-term mutual fund assets ranked in the top half of their respective peer groups. 
Fixed income funds continue to generate solid long-term relative performance track records, led by the global macro team, while equity and hybrid performance remains pressured as Franklin Income Fund represents roughly 30% of those assets.
We continue to educate advisers on the current positioning of our flagship funds and the perspective behind the portfolio manager's conviction as these periods of volatility represent opportunities for patient long-term investors. New marketing materials were recently introduced to highlight 5 reasons why investors buy and hold Franklin Income Fund and why we believe Templeton Global Bond Fund represents a once-in-a-decade opportunity. 
Following the rollout, we have seen strong interest and engagement from clients. We're also pleased to note that Morningstar recently reiterated its bronze rating on the Franklin Income Fund. Assets under management ended the quarter at $764 billion, a 1% decrease from September. However, average assets under management were 5% lower at $782 billion.
The mix of assets under management by investment objective and sales region remained consistent with prior quarters. However, we experienced a gradual shift in assets towards institutional and high net worth clients that comprised 28% of assets under management, up from 26% 1 year ago. 
Long-term net outflows improved somewhat from last quarter to $20 billion due to increased sales and lower redemptions, which have improved since August. Market appreciation of $15 billion offset much of the outflows in the quarter.
Looking closer at flows by client type on Slide 11. From a retail perspective, we've faced continued headwinds, particularly from our flagship funds in the U.S. and cross-border markets. U.S. retail redemptions remained elevated, due in large part to expected redemptions from our sub-advised variable annuity business that I mentioned last quarter. 
The client redeemed nearly $5 billion from its founding fund strategy, which impacted redemptions from U.S. equity, global equity and hybrid categories this quarter by roughly $1.6 billion each. Although the variable annuity business has been under pressure, it only represents about 6% of our assets under management today, and we believe the potential exists for this business to resume its growth in the years ahead. As I mentioned last quarter, we're now offering a managed volatility fund for clients looking to reduce risk as well as introducing new solutions-based products. 
International retail outflows eased a bit, due primarily to a decrease in redemptions from 3 of our largest cross-border funds: the Templeton Global Bond Fund, Global Total Return Fund and Asian Growth. Institutional sales have been strong year-to-date, due in large part to an Asian client that added a total of $5.5 billion to global macro mandate in the quarter. It's worth noting the client initially funded the mandate in October with $4.8 billion and added another $700 million, taking advantage of some market dislocations later in the quarter. 
We continue to emphasize the growth of our institutional presence globally by refining our value proposition and brand messaging, building and executing channel-specific strategies, investing in infrastructure to support customization and enhanced servicing and optimizing our product lineup and pricing. 
Outflows from global equity strategies remained elevated this quarter, as improving flows in our emerging markets funds were offset by weaker flows from other global equity strategies, including the variable annuity redemption I mentioned. Meanwhile, our local asset management equity teams had another solid quarter attracting over $300 million of net new flows, which continues a strong growth story that sometimes gets lost amongst the larger parts of the business. 
Global fixed income net outflows improved to $3.6 billion, due a combination of increased sales and decreased redemptions. The improvement in redemptions was attributable to the cross-border versions of Templeton Global Bond and Global Total Return Funds that experienced lower redemptions overall this quarter as well as a large institutional redemption that occurred in the prior quarter.
Sales growth was bolstered by the $5.5 billion global macro mandate that I already highlighted. U.S. equity strategies experienced decreased redemptions that led to moderating net outflows of $3.1 billion, despite slightly lower sales volumes. Like last quarter, U.S. equity flows were negatively impacted by further redemptions from our variable annuity business, including the $1.6 billion redemption I mentioned already, which had a similar impact on hybrid redemptions. 
Hybrid net new outflows increased to $5.6 billion, with most of that attributable to the Franklin Income Funds. Our K2 Liquid Alternative Strategies continues to be another success story as assets of both the U.S. and cross-border fund eclipsed $1 billion at quarter end and continued to generate strong interest from clients. 
The follow-up Franklin K2 Long Short Credit Fund that launched last quarter has already been approved on 30 advisory and brokerage platforms, and we're working on additional strategies that we plan to launch later this year.
Looking at Slide 14. Tax-free fixed income funds experienced a strong improvement in redemptions that resulted in nearly breakeven flows. On the taxable side, a combination of slowing sales increased redemptions and net exchanges out resulted in net new outflows of $2.5 billion. 
Funds managed by our high-yield team accounted for about half of the net outflows, but increased only modestly from the prior quarter despite the pressure experienced by the high-yield market.
And now, I'll turn it over to Ken for our financial results.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg. Although lower assets under management and its associated revenue was a headwind, overall, financial results were solid as we implemented cost savings initiatives and generated over $650 million in operating income for the quarter.Net inco
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg. Although lower assets under management and its associated revenue was a headwind, overall, financial results were solid as we implemented cost savings initiatives and generated over $650 million in operating income for the quarter.
Net income improved this quarter and was almost $450 million. And similarly, diluted earnings per share also increased to $0.74. Investment management fee revenue was down 6% this quarter, which was essentially in line with the decline in average assets under management after excluding the impact of lower performance fees that were only $1.9 million this quarter. 
Similarly, the decline in assets as well as a 13 % decline in commissionable sales reduced sales and distribution revenue, which was $478 million. Shareholder servicing fees also decreased this quarter and were $62 million. This was due primarily to lower assets under management and one less day this quarter. Other revenue decreased significantly over the prior quarter to $31 million. Changes in consolidated sponsored investment products drove most of the change here. However, this impact was largely offset in noncontrolling interests. 
Looking now at expenses on Slide 18. Total expenses decreased by 4%. Sales, distribution and marketing expense was $589 million, a decrease that was consistent with the decline in sales and distribution revenue. We did see a shift away from non-U.S. assets that generate these fees, which resulted in the net of sales and distribution to decrease, which is summarized in the appendix of the presentation. 
Compensation and benefits expense came in at $343 million, and that was a 2% increase over the prior quarter. This reflected a decrease in variable compensation that was more than offset by increases in salary, wages and benefits, which included severance expense of $13 million. 
Last quarter, I provided guidance that we expected 2016 expense levels, excluding sales and distribution expense, to be 3% to 4% below 2015 levels and that the realization of those savings could be deferred by execution costs.
Currently, we think that we'll realize savings at the upper end of that range and are looking for ways to increase that number. As a result, we expect to incur additional severance costs in future quarters. Next quarter, considering the normal seasonal increase in compensation and estimated severance, we expect a quarter-over-quarter increase in compensation expense of approximately 9% to 12%. We still anticipate year-over-year compensation expense savings of about 3% inclusive of those charges.
Information systems and technology expense of $51 million reflected both seasonal factors and a number of expense reductions. Occupancy expense was $31 million, but going forward, we expect the run rate for this item to look more like the fourth quarter of last year. General, administrative and other expenses was down 1% this quarter. There were a number of reductions to advertising, promotional and travel expenses. However, the mark-to-market of a liability related to a prior acquisition almost entirely offset the impact of those items.
As you can see on Slide 19, the operating margin remained strong at 37.2% this quarter, but decreased a bit due to lower revenue. However, expense reductions mitigated margin compression to some extent. The tax rate was 31.2% this quarter, and this was in line with prior guidance for the fiscal year, which we still believe to be a reasonable estimate for 2016. 
Moving on to other income. Net of noncontrolling interest was $27 million this quarter. The key driver of the change from last quarter was equity method investments that were a gain of $25 million and a reflection of the improvement in equity markets during the quarter.
Looking now at capital management. The board announced a 20% increase in the regular dividend this quarter, which has more than doubled over the past 5 years. As you can see, the compound annual growth rate of our dividend has substantially outpaced that of the peer group average over all-time periods included on Slide 22. 
Share purchase activity remained elevated as the stock remained under pressure, while volume slowed modestly. In fact, we repurchased 10.5 million shares in the quarter for a total cost of over $400 million, which significantly more than offset issuance from long-term equity awards.
Looking at the payout on Slide 24. The total payout for the trailing 12 months was $1.7 billion or 88% of net income. As this chart clearly illustrates, we've recently demonstrated a relative preference for share repurchase versus dividends given BEN's current valuation, but the board remains committed to the long-term growth of the regular dividend.
That concludes my comments. We look forward to talking with you on the call later today.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, good morning, and thank you for joining Ken Lewis and me to discuss first quarter earnings. Although we face a number of headwinds impacting investment performance and flows, we've been through periods like this before, and it's one of the reasons w
componenttext:
Well, good morning, and thank you for joining Ken Lewis and me to discuss first quarter earnings. Although we face a number of headwinds impacting investment performance and flows, we've been through periods like this before, and it's one of the reasons we value diversification and a strong balance sheet. As we work through these challenges and maintain our focus on expense management, we will continue to invest in a number of long-term growth opportunities including strategic beta ETFs, liquid alternatives and related solutions while delivering our value-added services to a growing customer base around the world. 
And now, Ken and I are happy to take your questions.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question is from Michael Carrier of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, maybe first one for you, just on the flows in the quarter and the outlook, you hit on a few things on the prerecorded call, but it sounds like the institutional business continues to gain some traction. So just wanted to get an update on maybe the p
componenttext: Greg, maybe first one for you, just on the flows in the quarter and the outlook, you hit on a few things on the prerecorded call, but it sounds like the institutional business continues to gain some traction. So just wanted to get an update on maybe the pipeline and what you're seeing on that front, particularly given maybe some of the pressures in the market and where institutions are looking to put some money? And then on the retail side, it seems like the pressure on Franklin income and in global bond has been out there. It seems like there's more outreach to the client base, and just any kind of reaction to that?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Normal searchers with global ag and global equities. I think, of note, and what has happened over the last, say, 3 to 6 months, some of the pressure on global currencies affecting various countries and then looking for those countries to diversify, I thin
componenttext: Normal searchers with global ag and global equities. I think, of note, and what has happened over the last, say, 3 to 6 months, some of the pressure on global currencies affecting various countries and then looking for those countries to diversify, I think, we're seeing more opportunities in the global bond space in Asia right now, as those currencies have been hit and with a further risks of some going down just to diversify away from their local currency. I think the -- anytime you have periods where you face challenges and headwinds in performance, certainly a risk of environment that any income funds that have heavy high-yield exposure are going to be under pressure. And we just want to make sure we communicate the value and really the appropriate kind of understanding of risk in those funds. And when you get the kind of spreads that you have today from treasuries, you do have room for even some defaults in those and still continue to do very well against treasury. So we think the markets have been under stress certainly in these areas, it's affected Franklin income fund, it affects any high-yield funds, like our high income fund, and we just want to make sure that we continue to get as much information out there and handholding to help advisers deal with their clients right now.

componenttext: Well, I think the -- I would say the pipeline, the new opportunities in the pipeline would be more global bond opportunities like the win that we had in Asia over the quarter where you've seen more interest, whether it's cyber and wealth funds or government entities in diversifying from their own currencies that are under pressure right now.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. And then, Ken, just a quick one for you. Given the pace of the buybacks, I just wanted to see if you can give us an update on maybe the U.S. versus the non-U.S. cash balance and just given the level of cash flow that you're generating. What'
componenttext: Okay. Got it. And then, Ken, just a quick one for you. Given the pace of the buybacks, I just wanted to see if you can give us an update on maybe the U.S. versus the non-U.S. cash balance and just given the level of cash flow that you're generating. What's the outlook on buybacks?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So the buyback activity has been, relative to history, it's been pretty elevated the last 2 quarters. And I could essentially say that U.S. cash has remained unchanged. As a matter of fact, it's remained unchanged year-over-year as well. So we've be
componenttext: Sure. So the buyback activity has been, relative to history, it's been pretty elevated the last 2 quarters. And I could essentially say that U.S. cash has remained unchanged. As a matter of fact, it's remained unchanged year-over-year as well. So we've been having plenty of U.S. cash generation to cover our needs.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Craig Siegenthaler of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: The next question is from Craig Siegenthaler of Crédit Suisse.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to follow-up on the Waddell news yesterday, because you guys also have a high composition of A class mutual funds. So I'm just wondering, do you have any load-waived A that currently sit in fee-based accounts?
componenttext: I just want to follow-up on the Waddell news yesterday, because you guys also have a high composition of A class mutual funds. So I'm just wondering, do you have any load-waived A that currently sit in fee-based accounts?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We do. And that's been a growing portion of our sales as more advisers have gone to the wrap advisory fee accounts.
componenttext: Yes. We do. And that's been a growing portion of our sales as more advisers have gone to the wrap advisory fee accounts.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you see a need in the future of those transitioning from a load-waived A to a high class or a zero rev share class?
componenttext: Do you see a need in the future of those transitioning from a load-waived A to a high class or a zero rev share class?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't. I mean, I think, part of the reaction, like Ken, I don't want to speak for Waddell. But for us, it remains to be seen on the fiduciary rule which we have. I think we're expecting something out in 90 days on that. But we don't think it would affec
componenttext: I don't. I mean, I think, part of the reaction, like Ken, I don't want to speak for Waddell. But for us, it remains to be seen on the fiduciary rule which we have. I think we're expecting something out in 90 days on that. But we don't think it would affect our existing A shares in any way. And if there are different rules around use of those in advisory programs, we already have the no 12b-1 class available. So it would be easy. It's really -- I mean, for us, it's up to the broker-dealers and advisers to interpret those rules to best fit their business models, but I think we would have all the share classes that would do that right now.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: And then -- I don't know if you have this number handy, but if I look at your U.S. mutual fund business, do you have the mix that sits in fee-based accounts and the mix that sits in commission-based accounts?
