componenttext: I don't right now. I think, the -- I just looked at the number. On top of my head it said, right now, we have about 40% of sales going into the no 12b-1 share class and that's grown from 30% in the prior year. I would still say that our A share account is higher with the 12b-1 just due to our distribution model and our strong partnership with Edward Jones, that still favors that class.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And can I just add that it does also vary by fund and on that mix.
componenttext: And can I just add that it does also vary by fund and on that mix.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Bill Katz with Citigroup.
componenttext: The next question is from Bill Katz with Citigroup.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, fair to start with you. You had given a little bit of update expense guidance in the prerecorded call, I appreciate that. Can you talk a little bit about, I guess, some disclosures I was skimming through in the 10-Q, but some of the disclosure were t
componenttext: Ken, fair to start with you. You had given a little bit of update expense guidance in the prerecorded call, I appreciate that. Can you talk a little bit about, I guess, some disclosures I was skimming through in the 10-Q, but some of the disclosure were the severance are occurring and if the markets -- what are your underlying assumptions for markets with this guidance? And I guess, if the markets were to continue to sort of work themselves lower, what kind of incremental flexibility would you have to try and protect margins?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think -- well, regarding where the expenses have been incurred, I think, geographically, maybe the majority of the expense is U.S. based. Across business lines, it hasn't -- we haven't really impacted the investment management section -- sector of
componenttext: Well, I think -- well, regarding where the expenses have been incurred, I think, geographically, maybe the majority of the expense is U.S. based. Across business lines, it hasn't -- we haven't really impacted the investment management section -- sector of our business. It's been spread out pretty much across the board other than investment management. So the assumptions regarding -- we talked about a target of 3% to 4%, and that was a few months ago. What this market volatility has led us to conclude is that we should just be looking at all of our business and seeing where we can increase efficiencies, leverage efficiencies. And that's what we're doing and that's going to be a theme for probably the next 9 months. And that's just based on the volatility. We're not assuming that market is going to be up or down, but it's obvious that they're volatile so we need to be looking at our expenses closely.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So is there -- if the markets, I wanted to just clarify, if the markets were to sort of continue to work their way lower away from volatility, so then we're turning for the short term. Is there more levers to pull to sort of protect the margin?
componenttext: So is there -- if the markets, I wanted to just clarify, if the markets were to sort of continue to work their way lower away from volatility, so then we're turning for the short term. Is there more levers to pull to sort of protect the margin?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we think there are more levers to pull. But as I said, it's just -- we're looking at the entire business, almost, without regard to the markets. So it's just an opportunity for us to make sure that initiatives that we started years ago, we still bel
componenttext: Well, we think there are more levers to pull. But as I said, it's just -- we're looking at the entire business, almost, without regard to the markets. So it's just an opportunity for us to make sure that initiatives that we started years ago, we still believe in, invest in things that we believe in now and just try to kind of reengineer all of our processes.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. And just to follow-up, because -- Greg, your thoughts here, very big picture, you do a nice job on some of these ancillary businesses, K2 continues to grow, you're sort of investing in, I guess, smart beta portfolios. But when you step back and l
componenttext: Got you. And just to follow-up, because -- Greg, your thoughts here, very big picture, you do a nice job on some of these ancillary businesses, K2 continues to grow, you're sort of investing in, I guess, smart beta portfolios. But when you step back and look at your portfolio, you do have a lot of relatively a sizable flagship retail funds with some choppy sort of short, intermediate-term performance. What measures are you taking to try and protect those assets in the retail channel? And then sort of corollary, any thoughts of maybe amping up the marketing spend? Was that just sort of wasted dollars just given the back half we're dealing right now?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's a good question and one that is really performance driven like anything in this business. And we're on our 10th year now of growth outperforming value and you kind of look for a glimmer of light out there and hope. And certainly, in January,
componenttext: I think it's a good question and one that is really performance driven like anything in this business. And we're on our 10th year now of growth outperforming value and you kind of look for a glimmer of light out there and hope. And certainly, in January, that's been a very choppy market. Value did outperform growth for the first time. So I mean, that would be the kind of the key driver to get more attention to some of these flagship funds that have been lagging. And we looked at some of the big laggards and even in January made some ground back with our rising dividends, mutual shares, mutual quest. We had a very strong January. So I think if that trend continues, that will be important. I think the other part, as Ken said, is really looking at our entire business and validating everything we're doing. And I think part of the changing distribution landscape advisers, looking at our industry and what they need differently, I think the -- if you have redundancy with certain funds, or it's just not clear what that fund offers in the various category that advisers need, we may need to tune some of the lineup or merge some of the lineup. And that's something we really are looking at now. And that can drive some cost savings, ultimately, longer term as well.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is from Michael Kim of Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: And the next question is from Michael Kim of Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first, Greg, on the prerecorded call, you highlighted some initiatives to better position the institutional business by building out some infrastructure, optimizing the product lineup. You also alluded to pricing. So just wondering if you could give us
componenttext: So first, Greg, on the prerecorded call, you highlighted some initiatives to better position the institutional business by building out some infrastructure, optimizing the product lineup. You also alluded to pricing. So just wondering if you could give us a bit more color in terms of how you might be thinking about either the level or structure of fees in that channel and just kind of the potential impact from an economic standpoint as you move through that process.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's always a challenge on the pricing side to -- especially when you have funds in the marketplace and the sensitivity to making sure we have consistent pricing across. I think the comment was just more on the development that we've been doing. A
componenttext: I think it's always a challenge on the pricing side to -- especially when you have funds in the marketplace and the sensitivity to making sure we have consistent pricing across. I think the comment was just more on the development that we've been doing. Also, with the smart beta ETFs that I said before, I mean, I think, that allows us to get some lower-cost vehicles out there that have market beta at a much lower cost. And that's going to be attractive to certain institutions as well as within our solutions and outcome group. But I think the -- I don't think there's anything really to call out on the pricing side that we look at. I think we continue to study the markets and try to be competitive. And then we all know the pressure on lower fees continues. And we're trying to meet that or develop new capabilities that don't conflict with some of the retail styles that we can build out capabilities.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful. And then -- also on the last quarter's call, I think you mentioned about 1/3 of the $17 billion and sort of the sub-adviser variable annuity channel was at risk. So just following sort of the $5 billion redemption last quarter, doe
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful. And then -- also on the last quarter's call, I think you mentioned about 1/3 of the $17 billion and sort of the sub-adviser variable annuity channel was at risk. So just following sort of the $5 billion redemption last quarter, does that suggest that sort of related AUM at risk from here is de minimis or immaterial at this point?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that there is still probably another $5 billion at risk, right now, with one of them. But -- and from there, I think we have, today, low-40s, $42 billion in those sub-advised assets, so that's 6% of our base. And I think of risk, I'd put another $
componenttext: I think that there is still probably another $5 billion at risk, right now, with one of them. But -- and from there, I think we have, today, low-40s, $42 billion in those sub-advised assets, so that's 6% of our base. And I think of risk, I'd put another $5 billion for the changes that are taking place in that market. And hopefully, the other side of that is we are -- because of the build out we have with our solutions group and some of the development, and we just got our first mandate in our managed volatility funds, so that is an area that, hopefully, we can more than make up the loss of the $5 billion coming up.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ken Worthington of JPMorgan.
componenttext: The next question is from Ken Worthington of JPMorgan.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just, first, simply on the new marketing materials that you gave out on global bond and the income fund. When was that rolled out? And then you said in the prepared remarks that there was good engagement and interest by clients. What does that really mean
componenttext: Just, first, simply on the new marketing materials that you gave out on global bond and the income fund. When was that rolled out? And then you said in the prepared remarks that there was good engagement and interest by clients. What does that really mean? Are you actually seeing any indication that redemptions are slowing or sales are increasing?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we rolled it out right around the end of the year around January 1. So early to quantify any behavioral changes there. I think the -- what you're trying to do is get the tools in the advisers hands so they can quickly sit down with their clients a
componenttext: I think we rolled it out right around the end of the year around January 1. So early to quantify any behavioral changes there. I think the -- what you're trying to do is get the tools in the advisers hands so they can quickly sit down with their clients and walk them through the logic on why you would stay put in a period where there's a lot of headlines around high-yield and stress in liquidity and make sure that they have a broad understanding of what is going on with those funds. I think the other point I would make is just around, because I think that's the question that I would look at, is when would you see your flagship flows returning? And I think when I look at the income fund, its long history and it is a well-diversified portfolio, but it's always one that doesn't fit neatly in any category. It will always have high-yield exposure, it will always be the highest yielding in its category. So it would be naturally a little bit more risky than its peer group. So you will expect to have periods where it lags performance. I think the other side of fixed income, as I've said before, when the market settle and high-yield settles and you'll have very attractive spreads to where certainly treasuries are today, then you'll have a 6-plus yield on a fund that's done very well long term. I think it's very easy to get momentum back in flows, a little bit easier than equity fund. Just the attractiveness of that coupon and the history, that's where I would expect to see a turn. So I think it's really just when the market settle, when the high-yield bond market settles in, I would expect to see that fund start to get lower redemptions and hopefully, better sales.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then on the -- I guess, now $5.5 billion mandate which, I believe, all that funded this quarter, there was the initial amount then there was like a stub piece that was added. What is the potential here for more money being mandated from this in
componenttext: Great. And then on the -- I guess, now $5.5 billion mandate which, I believe, all that funded this quarter, there was the initial amount then there was like a stub piece that was added. What is the potential here for more money being mandated from this investor? It would seem like there's a lot of money out there, a change in strategy. I guess, my erroneous view is that, that was kind a onetime thing. But has this the potential to be the gift that keeps on giving here for a couple of years?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I think not only that relationship, but other institutional mandates in that market as well. And it's a high-profile relationship there that gives us better visibility in that market. So hopefully, we can extend that into a few more relationships
componenttext: Yes. And I think not only that relationship, but other institutional mandates in that market as well. And it's a high-profile relationship there that gives us better visibility in that market. So hopefully, we can extend that into a few more relationships. But it's one that we hope will grow.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ken Hill of Barclays.
componenttext: The next question is from Ken Hill of Barclays.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in the prerecorded comments, you mentioned the new head of global ETFs and then the registration of the strategic beta ETF. I'm just wondering if could talk a little bit more about how you're looking to package those with some of your active products a
componenttext: So in the prerecorded comments, you mentioned the new head of global ETFs and then the registration of the strategic beta ETF. I'm just wondering if could talk a little bit more about how you're looking to package those with some of your active products and what you're hearing from clients, maybe the demand for it ahead of a launch like that?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the need, whether we use someone else's ETF or our own, between our own lineup, we know we have the need for lower cost beta in outcome-oriented or solutions-type products. So that's something that we feel we have an immediate place for thos
componenttext: Well, I think the need, whether we use someone else's ETF or our own, between our own lineup, we know we have the need for lower cost beta in outcome-oriented or solutions-type products. So that's something that we feel we have an immediate place for those ETFs. And then, I think, it will take more time and marketing to develop more presence and probably a broader lineup. But it's just our first step into the ones that we think internally. We don't have to go out and use somebody else's ETF, we can use these and that there's some demand from the retail channel as well. I wouldn't try to quantify that right now, but enough immediately to make it meaningful to us.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then last quarter, you guys spoke about potential acquisitions. Just kind of wondering how the thought process there might have evolved given how you look at repurchases and capital returns with the stock price and then also the value of other c
componenttext: Okay. And then last quarter, you guys spoke about potential acquisitions. Just kind of wondering how the thought process there might have evolved given how you look at repurchases and capital returns with the stock price and then also the value of other companies you might be looking to purchase there to may be fill in perceived gaps maybe. Would that look better or worse than it did last quarter? And how are you guys thinking about that for the course of the year?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't -- I think its unchanged kind of the strategy, how we look at M&A, I don't think it's changed. I don't think the level of repurchases changes that. As we always say -- and we say we're opportunistic, one of the factors is the share price and th
componenttext: I wouldn't -- I think its unchanged kind of the strategy, how we look at M&A, I don't think it's changed. I don't think the level of repurchases changes that. As we always say -- and we say we're opportunistic, one of the factors is the share price and the market, but the other factor is what are the uses of cash. If we were to identify a target, then we would probably scout back on the repurchases to balance it out. But we continue to look for opportunities in M&A and that hasn't changed.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would say, from my perspective, it's more probable just based on what's happened in the marketplace. Unfortunately, we've been sitting with a lot of cash and that puts you in a unique position. And I think with the selloff in a lot of asset managers
componenttext: And I would say, from my perspective, it's more probable just based on what's happened in the marketplace. Unfortunately, we've been sitting with a lot of cash and that puts you in a unique position. And I think with the selloff in a lot of asset managers and a selloff in currencies around the globe, the potential for doing something, I think, is a lot more attractive today just looking at currency moves around the globe than it was before. So we are actively out there and are hopeful that something will come up that enhances the lineup and adds value long term.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Dan Fannon of Jeffries.
componenttext: The next question is from Dan Fannon of Jeffries.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: Ken, I guess a couple of specific modeling items, the G&A that you mentioned on the prerecorded call, there was a onetime item that boosted it. If you could give us a sense of what the starting point is normalized going forward?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think we would expect that line to be more like it was in 2015 on a quarterly basis than what it was this quarter. Maybe that implies -- I don't know the exact number of the item, but probably in the neighborhood of $10 million.
componenttext: Yes. I think we would expect that line to be more like it was in 2015 on a quarterly basis than what it was this quarter. Maybe that implies -- I don't know the exact number of the item, but probably in the neighborhood of $10 million.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I guess, just to follow-up on the last comment on M&A. Can you talk about some of the things that you find interesting whether it be from a product perspective, geography or is it just scale? Like how do we think about what you view as rea
componenttext: Okay. And then, I guess, just to follow-up on the last comment on M&A. Can you talk about some of the things that you find interesting whether it be from a product perspective, geography or is it just scale? Like how do we think about what you view as realistic in terms of adding to your existing suite of products?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's really all of the above. I mean, it could be a large scale that you get efficiencies from distribution and servicing. It could be parts expanding the high-net worth business, it could be the solutions outcome, it could be real estate. I mean,
componenttext: I think it's really all of the above. I mean, it could be a large scale that you get efficiencies from distribution and servicing. It could be parts expanding the high-net worth business, it could be the solutions outcome, it could be real estate. I mean, there's a lot of areas that we're looking at. But I think the probability of the right situation offshore even with Asia-type funds that are very much at a favor right now, I think would look attractive to us long term.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Brennan Hawken of UBS.
componenttext: The next question is from Brennan Hawken of UBS.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the comments you made about the, I think, you said 40% of the sales are in high class and the rest carry some kind of distribution. With the -- those that carry distribution, do you happen to have visibility into what portion is in ret
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the comments you made about the, I think, you said 40% of the sales are in high class and the rest carry some kind of distribution. With the -- those that carry distribution, do you happen to have visibility into what portion is in retirement accounts at this point?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I don't have that number. And obviously, that's the relevant one as far as the potential with the fiduciary rule. We can certainly get that for you.
componenttext: No. I don't have that number. And obviously, that's the relevant one as far as the potential with the fiduciary rule. We can certainly get that for you.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That would be great. And any additional -- I know in the last quarter's call, you were asked on DOL. And at that point, it didn't seem like you wanted to make many comments given its not final. But now that we've got the rule in OMB, right? So we're a cou
componenttext: That would be great. And any additional -- I know in the last quarter's call, you were asked on DOL. And at that point, it didn't seem like you wanted to make many comments given its not final. But now that we've got the rule in OMB, right? So we're a couple of months at most away from final, and it's expected to be largely unchanged. Do you have any sense of the extent to which this might impact your AOL -- your AUM rather, through the broker sold channel?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think it's still too early. And I don't think it as an immediate impact. I think what it does is it has an impact on your future sales in those markets. And I think you're absolutely right in every indication. Despite record comments and concerns ra
componenttext: No. I think it's still too early. And I don't think it as an immediate impact. I think what it does is it has an impact on your future sales in those markets. And I think you're absolutely right in every indication. Despite record comments and concerns raised, it's something that looks like it's going to move pretty quickly and try to be enacted before next January. And whether that results in lawsuits, I think, that's still very much out there as a possibility to take this up. But we are going to work with our partners and try to work through what will be a very complex transition to deal with this new rule. But I couldn't -- again, I couldn't quantify what that means other than it's not a positive.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Brian Bedell of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: The next question is from Brian Bedell of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a little bit more on the strategic beta initiative. I mean, first, how substantial or how -- what kind of breadth of product do you want to ultimately develop in this area? And then if you can talk a little bit about the distribution game plan for th
componenttext: Just a little bit more on the strategic beta initiative. I mean, first, how substantial or how -- what kind of breadth of product do you want to ultimately develop in this area? And then if you can talk a little bit about the distribution game plan for the products. And also, is this partly in response to potential DOL with these products? Obviously, it become more attractive in a DOL world, in a tighter fiduciary world.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I mean, I don't think it's in response to the DOL world. I think it's just in response to where we see growth and needs in our lineup. And again, as I said before, just getting a cheaper beta that doesn't conflict with your other funds will be importa
componenttext: No. I mean, I don't think it's in response to the DOL world. I think it's just in response to where we see growth and needs in our lineup. And again, as I said before, just getting a cheaper beta that doesn't conflict with your other funds will be important for us. I think the question on how big this market and whether or not at some point there is a vehicle that makes it more efficient than your typical 40 Act and transfer agent-type driven product, I think, those are all questions that are still very much out there. So we just felt like the business is too large for an asset management company to ignore. And whether it's, again, through acquisitions or organic growth, that's going to affect our plan on how we roll this out. We think it has to be a separate effort, but also part of you get the leverage from your existing wholesaler group as well. And how big? I think, again, we're starting kind of small, but we will continue to roll out or acquire new ones as we see fit. It's just kind of getting in that space and building a team there and growing it.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is there any desire to develop actively managed non-transparent ETFs like -- you have obviously a number of applications in the SEC for that. Did you leverage your own investment management products in...
componenttext: Is there any desire to develop actively managed non-transparent ETFs like -- you have obviously a number of applications in the SEC for that. Did you leverage your own investment management products in...

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that's a possibility that we are looking at. So I think that like everyone, we're studying that. And it's certainly a possibility to do that if the right -- you get the right regulatory relief on that. And if it it makes sense in that specifi

And it's certainly a possibility to do that if the right -- you get the right regulatory relief on that. And if it it makes sense in that specific vehicle, it's something we certainly would consider because there are efficiencies you can gain.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: And then just lastly on the -- pressure for you, Ken, on the costs. Obviously, if you -- regarding the flexibility, if we are on a longer-term difficult market environment, does it cause you to look at the outsourcing of fund accounting, administration and back office as one of those potential longer-term cost saves versus maybe looking at more deeply at the investment management segment of the business?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So -- and I think I've mentioned -- we talked about the subject before. That topic, regardless of market conditions, has come up over the years. And we've done a lot of analysis on it. But -- so I wouldn't say -- I think that market volatility, as I
componenttext: Yes. So -- and I think I've mentioned -- we talked about the subject before. That topic, regardless of market conditions, has come up over the years. And we've done a lot of analysis on it. But -- so I wouldn't say -- I think that market volatility, as I mentioned, has caused us to just look at our entire business, all the business processes, all the business lines and rationalize everything. And I would include outsourcing of any type.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: You would include that?

componenttextpreview: Okay. And yes, that's a little bit of a change from -- I mean, you guys, I think, have been more steadfast on keeping that in-house in the past. Is that sort of a little bit of a change in view? Or was it always something under consideration?
componenttext: Okay. And yes, that's a little bit of a change from -- I mean, you guys, I think, have been more steadfast on keeping that in-house in the past. Is that sort of a little bit of a change in view? Or was it always something under consideration?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, it's not the change of you to look at it. The conclusion may or not be different this time. There are very valid reasons for us to do some of these things in-house. Some of the -- our business is very customized and very difficult to outsou
componenttext: Well, I think, it's not the change of you to look at it. The conclusion may or not be different this time. There are very valid reasons for us to do some of these things in-house. Some of the -- our business is very customized and very difficult to outsource everything. So I don't know that philosophically we're going to -- we've changed what we think is important to our customers and our business so -- but we will look at it.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would just add, I mean, again, in any environment, this is something that we would look at. And because of our structure and capabilities in lower-cost regions like India, we're very cost competitive to the market in those services. If we were not,
componenttext: And I would just add, I mean, again, in any environment, this is something that we would look at. And because of our structure and capabilities in lower-cost regions like India, we're very cost competitive to the market in those services. If we were not, then that's something that we have to consider. So that -- those groups know that's something they need to validate, continue to press cost down, they've done that effectively. So it really hasn't given us a reason to go out and outsource it.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Robert Lee of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods.
componenttext: The next question is from Robert Lee of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions. Going back to the M&A question, I'm just curious, I mean, a couple of your peers have done some acquisitions in that. I guess, I'll call it the the Fintech space, so whether you want to call it robo-advisors or something else. And I'm just
componenttext: Two questions. Going back to the M&A question, I'm just curious, I mean, a couple of your peers have done some acquisitions in that. I guess, I'll call it the the Fintech space, so whether you want to call it robo-advisors or something else. And I'm just kind of curious, your thoughts about maybe not those specifically, but kind of your thoughts of opportunities to enhance or strategically position your business with acquisitions that maybe we wouldn't normally think about for you guys?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the -- certainly, the industry is exploring that space and looking at lower-cost alternatives that can reach broader groups through digital marketing and the capabilities that exist trying to get to the millennials in a different way than th
componenttext: Well, I think the -- certainly, the industry is exploring that space and looking at lower-cost alternatives that can reach broader groups through digital marketing and the capabilities that exist trying to get to the millennials in a different way than the traditional broker-dealer adviser model. So for us, that's another one that we -- with the Fintech space and looking at robo-advisors is something we certainly are studying. Whether or not we need to go acquire one or to build that capability, I think that's a question that we're looking at today. And I think the opportunity for the industry as distribution landscape changes, as we go to more advisory driven models, is the traditional barriers between a broker-dealer fund sold group versus the direct group continue to erode and disappear in a pretty quick pace. I think the opportunity is what does that mean for investment management firms. And I think that's why a lot of groups are looking at. And for us, I mentioned the partnership that we're doing with a large global bank and using our solutions capabilities targeting the emerging affluent market through digital marketing to existing customers in the bank. And that's very similar to what a robo-advisor can do. These are funds that are multi-asset and have a lot of different -- they have other managers than Franklin Templeton in them, and we can do that. That's somewhat what a robo-advisor can deliver. And to me, there's not a lot of magic over there, there to what a robo-advisor can do versus a solutions group can do or anybody modeling out. And I think the direct space, the Vanguards and the traditional people in that space, or Schwab, have a pretty good head start on dealing with that marketplace as far as robo-advisor.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then maybe just one follow-up, just trying to -- the macro business which, I guess, is housed within the global bond business. But I mean, that's a place you've got that big mandate, hopefully, more -- you've kind of talked about it as a
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then maybe just one follow-up, just trying to -- the macro business which, I guess, is housed within the global bond business. But I mean, that's a place you've got that big mandate, hopefully, more -- you've kind of talked about it as a place of success. Just kind of curious, could you kind of size maybe kind of how big that book of business kind of is? Kind of give us a feel for, in addition to this $5 billion-plus mandate kind of the growth trajectory of that?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I -- no, I mean, it would be very difficult. I think it's still -- well, it's called a global macro mandate from that group. It's really more aligned with your traditional global bond as a separate account. And I think the opportunity we still feel
componenttext: Well, I -- no, I mean, it would be very difficult. I think it's still -- well, it's called a global macro mandate from that group. It's really more aligned with your traditional global bond as a separate account. And I think the opportunity we still feel is a significant one. And I think there's just been some recent pressures around global currencies and a short-term lag in performance, but we still feel that that's kind of a pure alternative category to rates rising or equity markets dropping that it really does provide a nice cushion to a portfolio. So we think it's still -- has a every large potential in a market. And I think like last time, when did do well? It did well when the equity market sold off and other markets were under pressure and it had good relative standout numbers. And I think, when you have that, you'll see large flows there. And I think, as I said before, I think the feedback we're getting from the institutional side in Asia is that, that opportunity is real today in getting other separate accounts in that space. But I don't know if I can quantify that.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Eric Berg of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question is from Eric Berg of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: A number of your competitors in the alternative area have described the rapid widening of credit spreads in the energy area and in the high-yield area in general. And in the bottom market, in general, you have created just tremendous investment opportunit
componenttext: A number of your competitors in the alternative area have described the rapid widening of credit spreads in the energy area and in the high-yield area in general. And in the bottom market, in general, you have created just tremendous investment opportunities in the area of what they call stressed and distressed investing, rescue lending, these sorts of opportunities to invest in fixed income that is involving troubled companies, again, stressed or distressed. Understanding that your primary business is traditional investing, to what extent do you have the capability, the product capability and human resources to just bend this opportunity if, in fact, you take it -- if, in fact, you agree that it exists?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that's a perfect question to lead to our introduction of our -- the fund that we just rolled out in the last year is our K2 Long Short Credit Fund. And really, again, to meet that need in the alternative category, and we feel it really does
componenttext: Well, I think that's a perfect question to lead to our introduction of our -- the fund that we just rolled out in the last year is our K2 Long Short Credit Fund. And really, again, to meet that need in the alternative category, and we feel it really does offer a way to lower risk in a portfolio and really seize these opportunities that come because of stress in the marketplace, because of liquidity constraints and forced selling by some long-only holders that you want to have the ability to capture that on the other side. And that was a category, of one of many categories, but the one that we felt made the most sense to introduce now and we're just in the process of rolling that out to complement our 2-plus billion in the global macro space with K2.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: The next question is from Greggory Warren of Morningstar.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know we touched on share purchases a little bit here, but I'm just wondering what sort of capacity do you feel you have to make share repurchases this year? I mean, from a cash perspective, there are limitations given how much cash is held overseas. And
componenttext: I know we touched on share purchases a little bit here, but I'm just wondering what sort of capacity do you feel you have to make share repurchases this year? I mean, from a cash perspective, there are limitations given how much cash is held overseas. And you spent $400 million in the first quarter and arguably the stock is cheaper right now. Do you anticipate being able to spend as much in the current quarter? And what sort of quarterly run rate are we thinking about going forward?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would just say the quarterly run rate is dependent on several factors, many of which we've talked about today, M&A, share markets, et cetera. We continue to think the stock is a good value. We purchased shares in January. You can see that from our filin
componenttext: I would just say the quarterly run rate is dependent on several factors, many of which we've talked about today, M&A, share markets, et cetera. We continue to think the stock is a good value. We purchased shares in January. You can see that from our filing. And we don't -- we have many options in terms of capacity. So I don't see that as a near-term issue at all. I think future share repurchases are just dependent on many of the factors that we talked about previously.

componenttext: Just want to follow-up just for a moment just on the expense side of the equation here. And then how should we think about the run rate there into 2017 and the expenses coming through that?

componenttext: Yes. Your question was a little garbled, so I'm going to try to answer it. But if I didn't hear it right, please correct me. We will do some modeling in 2017. And as I said, we continue to look at all of the business lines and then once we come up -- if we have additional guidance, we'll provide that in future quarters, but it's an ongoing process.

componenttext: Sure. So we've had some staff reductions, that's part of it. We had voluntary retirement plan that we talked about in our filing. So those were the examples to date. And then looking forward, I did mention -- there's a question about outsourcing, but there's several things that we're looking at. We're looking at offices. We're looking at business lines. Of course, the variable compensation is a lever that we can use and did use this quarter to a degree. So all of those things are on the table.

componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Franklin Resources' Earnings Conference Call for the Quarter Ended December 31, 2015. 
Statements made in this conference call regarding Franklin Resources Inc. which are not historical facts are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements involve a number of known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from any future results expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements. These and other risks, uncertainties and other important factors are described in more detail in Franklin's recent filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including in the risk factors and MD&A sections of Franklin's most recent Form 10-K and 10-Q filings.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning. My name is Manny, and will be your call operator today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Franklin Resources' Chairman and CEO, Mr. Greg J
componenttext: Thank you. Good morning. My name is Manny, and will be your call operator today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Franklin Resources' Chairman and CEO, Mr. Greg Johnson. Thank you. Mr. Johnson, you now begin.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, good morning, and thank you for joining Ken Lewis and me to discuss first quarter earnings. Although we face a number of headwinds impacting investment performance and flows, we've been through periods like this before, and it's one of the reasons w
componenttext:
Well, good morning, and thank you for joining Ken Lewis and me to discuss first quarter earnings. Although we face a number of headwinds impacting investment performance and flows, we've been through periods like this before, and it's one of the reasons we value diversification and a strong balance sheet. As we work through these challenges and maintain our focus on expense management, we will continue to invest in a number of long-term growth opportunities including strategic beta ETFs, liquid alternatives and related solutions while delivering our value-added services to a growing customer base around the world. 
And now, Ken and I are happy to take your questions.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] The first question is from Michael Carrier of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] The first question is from Michael Carrier of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, maybe first one for you, just on the flows in the quarter and the outlook, you hit on a few things on the prerecorded call, but it sounds like the institutional business continues to gain some traction. So just wanted to get an update on maybe the p
componenttext:
Greg, maybe first one for you, just on the flows in the quarter and the outlook, you hit on a few things on the prerecorded call, but it sounds like the institutional business continues to gain some traction. So just wanted to get an update on maybe the pipeline and what you're seeing on that front, particularly given maybe some of the pressures in the market and where institutions are looking to put some money? 
And then on the retail side, it seems like the pressure on Franklin Income and in Global Bond has been out there. It seems like there's more outreach to the client base, and just any kind of reaction to that?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Audio Gap]normal searches with global ag and global equities. I think, of note, and what has happened over the last, say, 3 to 6 months, some of the pressure on global currencies affecting various countries and then looking for those countries to diver
componenttext:
[Audio Gap]
normal searches with global ag and global equities. I think, of note, and what has happened over the last, say, 3 to 6 months, some of the pressure on global currencies affecting various countries and then looking for those countries to diversify, I think, we're seeing more opportunities in the global bond space in Asia right now, as those currencies have been hit and with a further risks of some going down just to diversify away from their local currency. I think the -- anytime you have periods where you face challenges and headwinds in performance, certainly a risk off environment that any income funds that have heavy high-yield exposure are going to be under pressure. And we just want to make sure we communicate the value and really the appropriate kind of understanding of risk in those funds. And when you get the kind of spreads that you have today from treasuries, you do have room for even some defaults in those and still continue to do very well against treasury. So we think the markets have been under stress certainly in these areas, it's affected Franklin Income Fund, it affects any high-yield funds, like our high income fund, and we just want to make sure that we continue to get as much information out there and handholding to help advisers deal with their clients right now.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: Well, I think the -- I would say the pipeline, the new opportunities in the pipeline would be more global bond opportunities like the win that we had in Asia over the quarter where you've seen more interest, whether it's cyber and wealth funds or government entities in diversifying from their own currencies that are under pressure right now.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: Okay. Got it. And then, Ken, just a quick one for you. Given the pace of the buybacks, I just wanted to see if you can give us an update on maybe the U.S. versus the non-U.S. cash balance and just given the level of cash flow that you're generating. What's the outlook on buybacks?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So the buyback activity has been -- relative to history, it's been pretty elevated the last 2 quarters. And I could essentially say that U.S. cash has remained unchanged. As a matter of fact, it's remained unchanged year-over-year as well. So we've
componenttext: Sure. So the buyback activity has been -- relative to history, it's been pretty elevated the last 2 quarters. And I could essentially say that U.S. cash has remained unchanged. As a matter of fact, it's remained unchanged year-over-year as well. So we've been having plenty of U.S. cash generation to cover our needs.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to follow-up on the Waddell news yesterday, because you guys also have a high composition of A class mutual funds. So I'm just wondering, do you have any load-waived As that currently sit in fee-based accounts?
componenttext: I just want to follow-up on the Waddell news yesterday, because you guys also have a high composition of A class mutual funds. So I'm just wondering, do you have any load-waived As that currently sit in fee-based accounts?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We do. And that's been a growing portion of our sales as more advisers have gone to the wrapper advisory fee accounts.
componenttext: Yes. We do. And that's been a growing portion of our sales as more advisers have gone to the wrapper advisory fee accounts.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you see a need in the future of those transitioning from a load-waived A to a high class or a zero rev share class?
componenttext: Do you see a need in the future of those transitioning from a load-waived A to a high class or a zero rev share class?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't. I mean, I think, part of the reaction, like Ken, I don't want to speak for Waddell. But for us, it remains to be seen on the fiduciary rule which we have -- I think we're expecting something out in 90 days on that. But we don't think it would aff
componenttext: I don't. I mean, I think, part of the reaction, like Ken, I don't want to speak for Waddell. But for us, it remains to be seen on the fiduciary rule which we have -- I think we're expecting something out in 90 days on that. But we don't think it would affect our existing A shares in any way. And if there are different rules around use of those in advisory programs, we already have the no 12b-1 class available. So it would be easy. It's really -- I mean, for us, it's up to the broker-dealers and advisers to interpret those rules to best fit their business models, but I think we would have all the share classes that would do that right now.

componenttext: I don't right now. I think, the -- I just looked at a number. I would still say that our A share count is higher with the 12b-1 just due to our distribution model and our strong partnership with Edward Jones, that still favors that class.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, fair to start with you. You had given a little bit of update expense guidance in the prerecorded call, I appreciate that. Can you talk a little bit about, I guess, some disclosures I was skimming through in the 10-Q, but some of the disclosure were t
componenttext: Ken, fair to start with you. You had given a little bit of update expense guidance in the prerecorded call, I appreciate that. Can you talk a little bit about, I guess, some disclosures I was skimming through in the 10-Q, but some of the disclosure were the severance is occurring and if the markets -- what are your underlying assumptions for markets with this guidance? And I guess, if the markets were to continue to sort of work themselves lower, what kind of incremental flexibility would you have to try and protect margins?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think -- well, regarding where the expenses have been incurred, I think, geographically, maybe the majority of the expense is U.S. based. Across business lines, it hasn't -- we haven't really impacted the investment management section -- sector of
componenttext: Well, I think -- well, regarding where the expenses have been incurred, I think, geographically, maybe the majority of the expense is U.S. based. Across business lines, it hasn't -- we haven't really impacted the investment management section -- sector of our business. It's been spread out pretty much across the board other than investment management. So the assumptions regarding -- we talked about a target of 3% to 4%, and that was a few months ago. What this market volatility has led us to conclude is that we should just be looking at all of our business and seeing where we can increase efficiencies, leverage efficiencies. And that's what we're doing and that's going to be a theme for probably the next 9 months. And that's just based on the volatility. We're not assuming that market is going to be up or down, but it's obvious that they're volatile so we need to be looking at our expenses closely.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So is there -- if the markets, I wanted to just clarify, if the markets were to sort of continue to work their way lower away from volatility, so downward trending for the short term. Is there more levers to pull to sort of protect the margin?
componenttext: So is there -- if the markets, I wanted to just clarify, if the markets were to sort of continue to work their way lower away from volatility, so downward trending for the short term. Is there more levers to pull to sort of protect the margin?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we think there are more levers to pull. But as I said, it's just -- we're looking at the entire business, almost, without regard to the markets. So it's just an opportunity for us to make sure that initiatives that we started years ago, we still bel
componenttext: Well, we think there are more levers to pull. But as I said, it's just -- we're looking at the entire business, almost, without regard to the markets. So it's just an opportunity for us to make sure that initiatives that we started years ago, we still believe in, invest in things that we believe in now and just try to kind of reengineer all of our processes.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. And just to follow-up, be curious Greg, your thoughts here, very big picture, you're doing a nice job on some of these ancillary businesses, K2 continues to grow, you're sort of investing in, I guess, smart beta portfolios. But when you step back
componenttext: Got you. And just to follow-up, be curious Greg, your thoughts here, very big picture, you're doing a nice job on some of these ancillary businesses, K2 continues to grow, you're sort of investing in, I guess, smart beta portfolios. But when you step back and look at your portfolio, you do have a lot of relatively a sizable flagship retail funds with some choppy sort of short to intermediate-term performance. What measures are you taking to try and protect those assets in the retail channel? And then sort of corollary, any thoughts of maybe amping up the marketing spend or is that just sort of wasted dollars just given the back trouble we're dealing right now?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's a good question and one that is really performance driven like anything in this business. And we're on our 10th year now of growth outperforming value and you kind of look for a glimmer of light out there and hope. And certainly, in January,
componenttext: I think it's a good question and one that is really performance driven like anything in this business. And we're on our 10th year now of growth outperforming value and you kind of look for a glimmer of light out there and hope. And certainly, in January, that's been a very choppy market. Value did outperform growth for the first time. So I mean, that would be the kind of the key driver to get more attention to some of these flagship funds that have been lagging. And we looked at some of the big laggards and even in January made some ground back with our rising dividends, Mutual Shares, Mutual Quest. We had a very strong January. So I think if that trend continues, that will be important. I think the other part, as Ken said, is really looking at our entire business and validating everything we're doing. And I think part of the changing distribution landscape advisers, looking at our industry and what they need differently, I think the -- if you have redundancy with certain funds, or it's just not clear what that fund offers in the various category that advisers need, we may need to tune some of the lineup or merge some of the lineup. And that's something we really are looking at now. And that can drive some cost savings, ultimately, longer term as well.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question is from Michael Kim of Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: And the next question is from Michael Kim of Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first, Greg, on the prerecorded call, you highlighted some initiatives to better position the institutional business by building out some infrastructure, optimizing the product lineup. You also alluded to pricing. So just wondering if you could give us
componenttext: So first, Greg, on the prerecorded call, you highlighted some initiatives to better position the institutional business by building out some infrastructure, optimizing the product lineup. You also alluded to pricing. So just wondering if you could give us a bit more color in terms of how you might be thinking about either the level or structure of fees in that channel and just kind of the potential impact from an economic standpoint as you move through that process.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's always a challenge on the pricing side to -- especially when you have funds in the marketplace and the sensitivity to making sure we have consistent pricing across. I think the comment was just more on the development that we've been doing. A
componenttext: I think it's always a challenge on the pricing side to -- especially when you have funds in the marketplace and the sensitivity to making sure we have consistent pricing across. I think the comment was just more on the development that we've been doing. Also, with the smart beta ETFs that I said before, I mean, I think, that allows us to get some lower-cost vehicles out there that have market beta at a much lower cost. And that's going to be attractive to certain institutions as well as within our solutions and outcome group. But I think the -- I don't think there's anything really to call out on the pricing side that we look at. I think we continue to study the markets and try to be competitive. And then we all know the pressure on lower fees continues. And we're trying to meet that or develop new capabilities that don't conflict with some of the retail styles that we can build out capabilities.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful. And then -- also on the last quarter's call, I think you mentioned about 1/3 of the $17 billion and sort of the sub-adviser variable annuity channel was at risk. So just following sort of the $5 billion redemption last quarter, doe
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful. And then -- also on the last quarter's call, I think you mentioned about 1/3 of the $17 billion and sort of the sub-adviser variable annuity channel was at risk. So just following sort of the $5 billion redemption last quarter, does that suggest that sort of related AUM at risk from here is de minimis or immaterial at this point?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that there is still probably another $5 billion at risk, right now, with one of them. But -- and from there, I think we have, today, low-40s, $42 billion in those sub-advised assets, so that's 6% of our base. And I think of risk, I'd put another $
componenttext: I think that there is still probably another $5 billion at risk, right now, with one of them. But -- and from there, I think we have, today, low-40s, $42 billion in those sub-advised assets, so that's 6% of our base. And I think of risk, I'd put another $5 billion for the changes that are taking place in that market. And hopefully, the other side of that is we are -- because of the build out we have with our solutions group and some of the development, and we just got our first mandate in our Managed Volatility fund, so that is an area that, hopefully, we can more than make up the loss of the $5 billion coming up.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ken Worthington of JPMorgan.
componenttext: The next question is from Ken Worthington of JPMorgan.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just, first, simply on the new marketing materials that you gave out on Global Bond and the Income Fund. When was that rolled out? And then you said in the prepared remarks that there was good engagement and interest by clients. What does that really mean
componenttext: Just, first, simply on the new marketing materials that you gave out on Global Bond and the Income Fund. When was that rolled out? And then you said in the prepared remarks that there was good engagement and interest by clients. What does that really mean? Are you actually seeing any indication that redemptions are slowing or sales are increasing?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we rolled it out right around the end of the year around January 1. So early to quantify any behavioral changes there. I think the -- what you're trying to do is get the tools in the advisers hands so they can quickly sit down with their clients a
componenttext: I think we rolled it out right around the end of the year around January 1. So early to quantify any behavioral changes there. I think the -- what you're trying to do is get the tools in the advisers hands so they can quickly sit down with their clients and walk them through the logic on why you would stay put in a period where there's a lot of headlines around high-yield and stress in liquidity and make sure that they have a broad understanding of what is going on with those funds. I think the other point I would make is just around, because I think that's the question that I would look at, is when would you see your flagship flows returning? And I think when I look at the income fund, its long history and it is a well-diversified portfolio, but it's always one that doesn't fit neatly in any category. It will always have high-yield exposure, it will always be the highest yielding in its category. So it would be naturally a little bit more risky than its peer group. So you will expect to have periods where it lags performance. I think the other side of fixed income, as I've said before, when the markets settle and high-yield settles and you'll have very attractive spreads to where certainly treasuries are today, then you'll have a 6-plus yield on a fund that's done very well long term. I think it's very easy to get momentum back in flows, a little bit easier than an equity fund. Just the attractiveness of that coupon and the history, that's where I would expect to see it turn. So I think it's really just when the market settle, when the high-yield bond market settles in, I would expect to see that fund start to get lower redemptions and hopefully, better sales.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then on the -- I guess, now $5.5 billion mandate which, I believe, all that funded this quarter, there was the initial amount then there was like a stub piece that was added. What is the potential here for more money being mandated from this in
componenttext: Great. And then on the -- I guess, now $5.5 billion mandate which, I believe, all that funded this quarter, there was the initial amount then there was like a stub piece that was added. What is the potential here for more money being mandated from this investor? It would seem like there's a lot of money out there, a change in strategy. I guess, my erroneous view is that, that was kind a onetime thing. But is this the potential to be the gift that keeps on giving here for a couple of years?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I think not only that relationship, but other institutional mandates in that market as well. And it's a high-profile relationship there that gives us better visibility in that market. So hopefully, we can extend that into a few more relationships
componenttext: Yes. And I think not only that relationship, but other institutional mandates in that market as well. And it's a high-profile relationship there that gives us better visibility in that market. So hopefully, we can extend that into a few more relationships. But it's one that we hope will grow.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ken Hill of Barclays.
componenttext: The next question is from Ken Hill of Barclays.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in the prerecorded comments, you mentioned the new head of global ETFs and then the registration of the strategic beta ETF. I'm just wondering if could talk a little bit more about how you're looking to package those with some of your active products a
componenttext: So in the prerecorded comments, you mentioned the new head of global ETFs and then the registration of the strategic beta ETF. I'm just wondering if could talk a little bit more about how you're looking to package those with some of your active products and what you're hearing from clients, maybe the demand for it ahead of a launch like that?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the need, whether we use someone else's ETF or our own, between -- in our own lineup, we know we have the need for lower cost beta in outcome-oriented or solutions-type products. So that's something that we feel we have an immediate place fo
componenttext: Well, I think the need, whether we use someone else's ETF or our own, between -- in our own lineup, we know we have the need for lower cost beta in outcome-oriented or solutions-type products. So that's something that we feel we have an immediate place for those ETFs. And then, I think, it will take more time and marketing to develop more presence and probably a broader lineup. But it's just our first step into the ones that we think internally. We don't have to go out and use somebody else's ETF, we can use these and that there's some demand from the retail channel as well. I wouldn't try to quantify that right now, but enough immediately to make it meaningful to us.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then last quarter, you guys spoke about potential acquisitions. Just kind of wondering how the thought process there might have evolved given how you look at repurchases and capital returns with the stock price and then also the value of other c
componenttext: Okay. And then last quarter, you guys spoke about potential acquisitions. Just kind of wondering how the thought process there might have evolved given how you look at repurchases and capital returns with the stock price and then also the value of other companies you might be looking to purchase there to may be fill in perceived gaps maybe. Would that look better or worse than it did last quarter? And how are you guys thinking about that for the course of the year?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't -- I think its unchanged, kind of the strategy how we look at M&A, I don't think it's changed. I don't think the level of repurchases changes that. As we always say -- and we say we're opportunistic, one of the factors is the share price and th
componenttext: I wouldn't -- I think its unchanged, kind of the strategy how we look at M&A, I don't think it's changed. I don't think the level of repurchases changes that. As we always say -- and we say we're opportunistic, one of the factors is the share price and the market, but the other factor is what are the uses of cash. If we were to identify a target, then we would probably scale back on the repurchases to balance it out. But we continue to look for opportunities in M&A and that hasn't changed.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would say, from my perspective, it's more probable just based on what's happened in the marketplace. Fortunately, we've been sitting with a lot of cash and that puts you in a unique position. And I think with the selloff in a lot of asset managers a
componenttext: And I would say, from my perspective, it's more probable just based on what's happened in the marketplace. Fortunately, we've been sitting with a lot of cash and that puts you in a unique position. And I think with the selloff in a lot of asset managers and a selloff in currencies around the globe, the potential for doing something, I think, is a lot more attractive today just looking at currency moves around the globe than it was before. So we are actively out there and are hopeful that something will come up that enhances the lineup and adds value long term.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: The next question is from Dan Fannon of Jeffries.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: Yes. I think we would expect that line to be more like it was in 2015 on a quarterly basis than what it was this quarter. Maybe that implies -- I don't know the exact number of the item, but probably in the neighborhood of $10 million.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I guess, just to follow-up on the last comment on M&A. Can you talk about some of the things that you find interesting whether it be from a product perspective, geography or is it just scale? Like how do we think about what you view as rea
componenttext: Okay. And then, I guess, just to follow-up on the last comment on M&A. Can you talk about some of the things that you find interesting whether it be from a product perspective, geography or is it just scale? Like how do we think about what you view as realistic in terms of adding to your existing suite of products?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's really all of the above. I mean, it could be a large scale that you get efficiencies from distribution and servicing. It could be parts expanding the high-net worth business, it could be the solutions outcome, it could be real estate. I mean,
componenttext: I think it's really all of the above. I mean, it could be a large scale that you get efficiencies from distribution and servicing. It could be parts expanding the high-net worth business, it could be the solutions outcome, it could be real estate. I mean, there's a lot of areas that we're looking at. But I think the probability of the right situation offshore even with Asia-type funds that are very much out of favor right now, I think would look attractive to us long term.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
