With the -- those that carry distribution, do you happen to have visibility into what portion is in retirement accounts at this point?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I don't have that number. And obviously, that's the relevant one as far as the potential with the fiduciary rule. We can certainly get that for you.
componenttext: No. I don't have that number. And obviously, that's the relevant one as far as the potential with the fiduciary rule. We can certainly get that for you.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That would be great. And any additional -- I know in the last quarter's call, you were asked on DOL. And at that point, it didn't seem like you wanted to make many comments given its not final. But now that we've got the rule in OMB, right? So we're a cou
componenttext: That would be great. And any additional -- I know in the last quarter's call, you were asked on DOL. And at that point, it didn't seem like you wanted to make many comments given its not final. But now that we've got the rule in OMB, right? So we're a couple of months at most away from final, and it's expected to be largely unchanged. Do you have any sense of the extent to which this might impact your AOL -- your AUM rather, through the broker-sold channel?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think it's still too early. And I don't think it as an immediate impact. I think what it does is it has an impact on your future sales in those markets. And I think you're absolutely right in every indication. Despite record comments and concerns ra
componenttext: No. I think it's still too early. And I don't think it as an immediate impact. I think what it does is it has an impact on your future sales in those markets. And I think you're absolutely right in every indication. Despite record comments and concerns raised, it's something that looks like it's going to move pretty quickly and try to be enacted before next January. And whether that results in lawsuits, I think, that's still very much out there as a possibility to take this up. But we are going to work with our partners and try to work through what will be a very complex transition to deal with this new rule. But I couldn't -- again, I couldn't quantify what that means other than it's not a positive.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Brian Bedell of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: The next question is from Brian Bedell of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a little bit more on the strategic beta initiative. I mean, first, how substantial or how -- what kind of breadth of product do you want to ultimately develop in this area? And then if you can talk a little bit about the distribution game plan for th
componenttext: Just a little bit more on the strategic beta initiative. I mean, first, how substantial or how -- what kind of breadth of product do you want to ultimately develop in this area? And then if you can talk a little bit about the distribution game plan for the products. And also, is this partly in response to potential DOL would these products, obviously become more attractive in a DOL world, in a tighter fiduciary world.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I mean, I don't think it's in response to the DOL world. I think it's just in response to where we see growth and needs in our lineup. And again, as I said before, just getting a cheaper beta that doesn't conflict with your other funds will be importa
componenttext:
No. I mean, I don't think it's in response to the DOL world. I think it's just in response to where we see growth and needs in our lineup. And again, as I said before, just getting a cheaper beta that doesn't conflict with your other funds will be important for us. I think the question on how big this market and whether or not at some point there is a vehicle that makes it more efficient than your typical 40 Act and transfer agent-type driven product, I think, those are all questions that are still very much out there. So we just felt like the business is too large for an asset management company to ignore. And whether it's, again, through acquisitions or organic growth, that's going to affect our plan on how we roll this out. We think it has to be a separate effort, but also part of you get the leverage from your existing wholesaler group as well. 
And how big? I think, again, we're starting kind of small, but we will continue to roll out or acquire new ones as we see fit. It's just kind of getting in that space and building a team there and growing it.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is there any desire to develop actively managed non-transparent ETFs, fixed ETF, obviously a number of applications in the SEC for that to leverage your own investment management products in...
componenttext: Is there any desire to develop actively managed non-transparent ETFs, fixed ETF, obviously a number of applications in the SEC for that to leverage your own investment management products in...

componenttext: Yes. I think that's a possibility that we are looking at. So I think that like everyone, we're studying that. And it's certainly a possibility to do that if the right -- you get the right regulatory relief on that. And if it makes sense in that specific vehicle, it's something we certainly would consider because there are efficiencies you can gain.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just lastly on the -- question for you, Ken, on the costs. Obviously, if you -- regarding the flexibility, if we are in a longer-term difficult market environment, does it cause you to look at the outsourcing of fund accounting, administration an
componenttext: And then just lastly on the -- question for you, Ken, on the costs. Obviously, if you -- regarding the flexibility, if we are in a longer-term difficult market environment, does it cause you to look at the outsourcing of fund accounting, administration and back office as one of those potential longer-term cost saves versus maybe looking at more deeply at the investment management segment of the business?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So -- and I think I've mentioned -- we talked about the subject before. That topic, regardless of market conditions, has come up over the years. And we've done a lot of analysis on it. But -- so I wouldn't say -- I think that market volatility, as I
componenttext: Yes. So -- and I think I've mentioned -- we talked about the subject before. That topic, regardless of market conditions, has come up over the years. And we've done a lot of analysis on it. But -- so I wouldn't say -- I think that market volatility, as I mentioned, has caused us to just look at our entire business, all the business processes, all the business lines and rationalize everything. And I would include outsourcing of any type.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: You would include that?
componenttext: You would include that?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would include that, yes, we will look at that again.
componenttext: I would include that, yes, we will look at that again.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And yes, that's a little bit of a change from -- I mean, you guys, I think, have been more steadfast on keeping that in-house in the past. Is that sort of a little bit of a change in view? Or was it always something under consideration?
componenttext: Okay. And yes, that's a little bit of a change from -- I mean, you guys, I think, have been more steadfast on keeping that in-house in the past. Is that sort of a little bit of a change in view? Or was it always something under consideration?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, it's not the change of you to look at it. The conclusion may or not be different this time. There are very valid reasons for us to do some of these things in-house. Some of the -- our business is very customized and very difficult to outsou
componenttext: Well, I think, it's not the change of you to look at it. The conclusion may or not be different this time. There are very valid reasons for us to do some of these things in-house. Some of the -- our business is very customized and very difficult to outsource everything. So I don't know that philosophically we're going to -- we've changed what we think is important to our customers and our business so -- but we will look at it.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would just add, I mean, again, in any environment, this is something that we would look at. And because of our structure and capabilities in lower-cost regions like India, we're very cost competitive to the market in those services. If we were not,
componenttext: And I would just add, I mean, again, in any environment, this is something that we would look at. And because of our structure and capabilities in lower-cost regions like India, we're very cost competitive to the market in those services. If we were not, then that's something that we have to consider. So that -- those groups know that's something they need to validate, continue to press cost down, they've done that effectively. So it really hasn't given us a reason to go out and outsource it.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Robert Lee of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods.
componenttext: The next question is from Robert Lee of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions. Going back to the M&A question, I'm just curious, I mean, a couple of your peers have done some acquisitions in that. I guess, I'll call it the fintech space, so whether you want to call it robo-advisors or something else. And I'm just kind
componenttext: Two questions. Going back to the M&A question, I'm just curious, I mean, a couple of your peers have done some acquisitions in that. I guess, I'll call it the fintech space, so whether you want to call it robo-advisors or something else. And I'm just kind of curious, your thoughts about maybe not those specifically, but kind of your thoughts of opportunities to enhance or strategically position your business with acquisitions that maybe we wouldn't normally think about for you guys?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the -- certainly, the industry is exploring that space and looking at lower-cost alternatives that can reach broader groups through digital marketing and the capabilities that exist trying to get to the millennials in a different way than th
componenttext: Well, I think the -- certainly, the industry is exploring that space and looking at lower-cost alternatives that can reach broader groups through digital marketing and the capabilities that exist trying to get to the millennials in a different way than the traditional broker-dealer adviser model. So for us, that's another one that we -- with the fintech space and looking at robo-advisors is something we certainly are studying. Whether or not we need to go acquire one or to build that capability, I think that's a question that we're looking at today. And I think the opportunity for the industry as distribution landscape changes, as we go to more advisory driven models, is the traditional barriers between a broker-dealer fund sold group versus the direct group continue to erode and disappear at a pretty quick pace. I think the opportunity is what does that mean for investment management firms. And I think that's why a lot of groups are looking at. And for us, I mentioned the partnership that we're doing with a large global bank and using our solutions capabilities targeting the emerging affluent market through digital marketing to existing customers in the bank. And that's very similar to what a robo-advisor can do. These are funds that are multi-asset and have a lot of different -- they have other managers than Franklin Templeton in them, and we do that. That's somewhat what a robo-advisor can deliver. And to me, there's not a lot of magic or there, there to what a robo-advisor can do versus a solutions group can do or anybody modeling out. And I think the direct space, the Vanguards and the traditional people in that space, or Schwab, have a pretty good head start on dealing with that marketplace as far as robo-advisor.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then maybe just one follow-up, just trying to -- the macro business which, I guess, is housed within the global bond business. But I mean, that's a place you've got that big mandate, hopefully, more -- you've kind of talked about it as a
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then maybe just one follow-up, just trying to -- the macro business which, I guess, is housed within the global bond business. But I mean, that's a place you've got that big mandate, hopefully, more -- you've kind of talked about it as a place of success. Just kind of curious, could you kind of size maybe kind of how big that book of business kind of is? Kind of give us a feel for, in addition to this $5 billion-plus mandate kind of the growth trajectory of that?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I -- no, I mean, it would be very difficult. I think it's still -- while it's called a global macro mandate from that group. It's really more aligned with your traditional global bond as a separate account. And I think the opportunity we still feel
componenttext: Well, I -- no, I mean, it would be very difficult. I think it's still -- while it's called a global macro mandate from that group. It's really more aligned with your traditional global bond as a separate account. And I think the opportunity we still feel is a significant one. And I think there's just been some recent pressures around global currencies and a short-term lag in performance, but we still feel that that's kind of a pure alternative category to rates rising or equity markets dropping that it really does provide a nice cushion to a portfolio. So we think it's still -- has a very large potential in a market. And I think like last time, when did do well? It did well when the equity markets sold off and other markets were under pressure and it had good relative standout numbers. And I think, when you have that, you'll see large flows there. And I think, as I said before, I think the feedback we're getting from the institutional side in Asia is that, that opportunity is real today in getting other separate accounts in that space. But I don't know if I can quantify that.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Eric Berg of RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question is from Eric Berg of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: A number of your competitors in the alternative area have described the rapid widening of credit spreads in the energy area and in the high-yield area in general. And in the bond market, in general, you have created just tremendous investment opportunitie
componenttext: A number of your competitors in the alternative area have described the rapid widening of credit spreads in the energy area and in the high-yield area in general. And in the bond market, in general, you have created just tremendous investment opportunities in the area of what they call stressed and distressed investing, rescue lending, these sorts of opportunities to invest in fixed income that is involving troubled companies, again, stressed or distressed. Understanding that your primary business is traditional investing, to what extent do you have the capability, the product capability and human resources to participate in this opportunity if, in fact, you take it -- if, in fact, you agree that it exists?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that's a perfect question to lead to our introduction of our -- the fund that we just rolled out in the last year is our K2 Long Short Credit Fund. And really, again, to meet that need in the alternative category, and we feel it really does
componenttext: Well, I think that's a perfect question to lead to our introduction of our -- the fund that we just rolled out in the last year is our K2 Long Short Credit Fund. And really, again, to meet that need in the alternative category, and we feel it really does offer a way to lower risk in a portfolio and really seize these opportunities that come because of stress in the marketplace, because of liquidity constraints and forced selling by some long-only holders that you want to have the ability to capture that on the other side. And that was a category, of one of many categories, but the one that we felt made the most sense to introduce now and we're just in the process of rolling that out to complement our $2-plus billion in the global macro space with K2.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016

componenttext: I know we touched on share purchases a little bit here, but I'm just wondering what sort of capacity do you feel you have to make share repurchases this year? I mean, from a cash perspective, there are limitations given how much cash is held overseas. And you spent $400 million in the first quarter and arguably the stock is cheaper right now. Do you anticipate being able to spend as much in the current quarter? And what sort of quarterly run rates are we thinking about going forward?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would just say the quarterly run rate is dependent on several factors, many of which we've talked about today, M&A, share markets, et cetera. We continue to think the stock is a good value. We purchased shares in January. You can see that from our filin
componenttext: I would just say the quarterly run rate is dependent on several factors, many of which we've talked about today, M&A, share markets, et cetera. We continue to think the stock is a good value. We purchased shares in January. You can see that from our filing. And we don't -- we have many options in terms of capacity. So I don't see that as a near-term issue at all. I think future share repurchases are just dependent on many of the factors that we talked about previously.

We will do some modeling in 2017. And as I said, we continue to look at all of the business lines and then once we come up -- if we have additional guidance, we'll provide that in future quarters, but it's an ongoing process.

componenttext:
Sure. So we've had some staff reductions, that's part of it. We had voluntary retirement plan that we talked about in our filing. So those were the examples to date. 
And then looking forward, I did mention -- there's a question about outsourcing, but there's several things that we're looking at. We're looking at offices. We're looking at business lines. Of course, the variable compensation is a lever that we can use and did use this quarter to a degree. So all of those things are on the table.

Good morning. My name is Melissa, and I will be your call operator today. [Operator Instructions]
As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Franklin Resources Chairman and CEO, Mr. Greg Johnson. Mr. Johnson, you may begin.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, good morning, and thank you for joining Ken Lewis and me to discuss the company's second quarter. Although we continued to experience net outflows in the March quarter, the nature of the mid-quarter market rebound marked an encouraging transition fo
componenttext:
Well, good morning, and thank you for joining Ken Lewis and me to discuss the company's second quarter. Although we continued to experience net outflows in the March quarter, the nature of the mid-quarter market rebound marked an encouraging transition for us, as many of the weakest-performing sectors in 2015 were among the strongest performers in the quarter. 
As the quarter progressed, investment performance of many of our key strategies improved, as did redemption trends. Overall, our financial results were solid as we continued to exercise expense discipline, notwithstanding some notable onetime items that are discussed in more detail on our 10-Q, which was also filed this morning. 
Now Ken and I are happy to take your questions.

componenttext: Sure. We did have an impairment charge in G&A that was about 30. That was offset a little bit by contingent liability. So those were the 2 major large lumpiness in the G&A account.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: I guess, in the context of -- last quarter, we had 3% to 4% expense decline for the year, and now you're saying 3%. What were the variables in terms of that change?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, one of them was that impairment charge. We weren't counting on that in the 3% to 4% guidance. And also, looking out for the remaining quarters for the year, we might have another nonrecurring charge in the fourth quarter, although that could roll in
componenttext: Well, one of them was that impairment charge. We weren't counting on that in the 3% to 4% guidance. And also, looking out for the remaining quarters for the year, we might have another nonrecurring charge in the fourth quarter, although that could roll into the first quarter as well. So those were 2 things that weren't known last quarter that we're factoring in as well as there's a lot of moving parts to this when we're rationalizing business lines and departments and all that. So we're just refining our estimate.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, obviously, a lot has been discussed already. I mean, it affects a huge part of the industry. I think, for us, it's difficult to get an exact number on the amount of assets that it potentially could affect, but we did our best. And with omni
componenttext: Well, I think, obviously, a lot has been discussed already. I mean, it affects a huge part of the industry. I think, for us, it's difficult to get an exact number on the amount of assets that it potentially could affect, but we did our best. And with omnibus accounts, that's a little bit tricky. But we estimate it affects about $130 billion of our assets. I think we're probably a little bit lower than most because of our heavy concentration in retail assets offshore as well as municipal bond funds and the fact that the key area around 401(k  tends to be in the U.S. growth, and that's an area where we don't have huge penetration. So I think overall, a little bit lower, but like everybody in the industry, very concerned about and still trying to understand what 1,000-page document means to our business. And that's really where we're focused today is working with our advisers, working with outside legal assistants and really making sense of the proposal. I think the good news is that some of the most unworkable items have been adjusted, but obviously, a very difficult rule that will eliminate advice to many people that need it most, and that's smaller end of the market.

componenttext: I guess, my first question, I'm just curious if it's -- I mean, you have a couple of new initiatives underway. You mentioned the next step strategies in the prepared remarks. And I know you've obviously taken some steps in the EPS market. Can you really kind of update us on maybe where you are with both of those with -- and then, particularly, next step maybe kind of flushing that out what -- what the opportunity is there. And is that part of the relationship you have with globally with Citi?

componenttext: Yes, I mean, that is. And it's addressing that area of the market using technology and trying to penetrate those that may not be large enough to be able to get individual help or advice. So it does address a new market for us. I think, our partnership, a lot of that was based on our global reach and the fact that we can help them get marketing message out in markets like Asia and Latin America, where Citi has such a strong reach. I think that will take a while to develop, but it is up and running now. The other area's just around the alternatives and multi-alternatives, and we continue to extend our capabilities there with the long short credit and Global Macro fund that was recently introduced and then our Liberty shares ETF, which will be available in June. And we expect to continue to build out that line as well, and those are just a few of the newer initiatives.

componenttext: Yes. I mean, we are seeing that. componenttext: Just want to come back to the impairment you took on K2. I guess that's been an area of growth for you, so I'm a little surprised to see the impairments. componenttext: Sure. So the impairment wasn't related to K2 in total. componenttext: Yes. I mean, I'd have said I wouldn't make much of that decision. I doubt they do anything in what we would call loaded sales. And everybody looks at the A shares and assumes paying commission for us. It's now less than 9% of our sales, have a commission on them. And we are in traditional, what you'd call, I guess, load-based firm. So for Schwab, that's -- I would say, it's a nonevent that they're not doing exits. It's probably less than 1% of their sales. And the world, as we know, continues to move towards fee-based. And with the fiduciary changes probably more with R6 or shares the don't have a 12b-1 fees associated with them, you'll see more and more of that.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: And when you say 9%, that means kind of all commissions, frontload, Toby 1s, et cetera?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Kim with Sandler O'Neill + Partners.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, Greg, I know you called out the 2 mobile equity institutional redemptions that totaled $1.8 billion, but it sounds like there were some other lumpy institutional redemptions related to allocation changes and/or sovereign wealth fund redemptions. So
componenttext: First, Greg, I know you called out the 2 mobile equity institutional redemptions that totaled $1.8 billion, but it sounds like there were some other lumpy institutional redemptions related to allocation changes and/or sovereign wealth fund redemptions. So just wondering if you could sort of provide any more color on maybe the size of those losses and/or the strategies impacted. And any sense of sort of the residual AUM that might be at risk for further attrition?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the -- there's probably another -- there were 2 accounts that total 1.8 global equities, one middle eastern sovereign wealth and another in Australia doing a rebalancing of the global equity. And then really, only -- there was only 2 large gl
componenttext: Yes. I think the -- there's probably another -- there were 2 accounts that total 1.8 global equities, one middle eastern sovereign wealth and another in Australia doing a rebalancing of the global equity. And then really, only -- there was only 2 large global equity that were about $300 million a piece in Canada. It's interesting. I think, looking at quarter-to-quarter, the global equity was actually -- while, the net number was very high out, it was mostly due to these institutional redemptions. The retail trend is actually better. And I think the retail trend is important, too, to call out just in general, that it was a lot better than the prior quarter, with redemptions declining as well during kind of a choppy quarter. It's really the institutional quarter-over-quarter change in flows that masked, I think, some of the improved trends within the retail side, especially the hybrid side. Nothing else to really, I think, call out on the large institutional.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just come back to M&A. Any color on what you're seeing across the landscape in terms of pricing and/or competition, particularly in light of the our recent rebound in the markets, I guess? Been hearing anecdotally that maybe the pipeline is
componenttext: Okay. And then just come back to M&A. Any color on what you're seeing across the landscape in terms of pricing and/or competition, particularly in light of the our recent rebound in the markets, I guess? Been hearing anecdotally that maybe the pipeline is starting to pick up, if you will.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would just jump in. I think that's right. I think when you're kind of in market lows and volatile periods, you don't really see a lot, and I think that's been kind of true that there hasn't been a ton of M&A activity. And as markets rebound, I thi
componenttext: Well, I would just jump in. I think that's right. I think when you're kind of in market lows and volatile periods, you don't really see a lot, and I think that's been kind of true that there hasn't been a ton of M&A activity. And as markets rebound, I think people start thinking about it. So I think that's fair. I don't know if we could say specifically that we've seen that, but that certainly has been the case historically.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I agree. We haven't seen any specific changes in the trends. I mean, there are a number of targets out there that's always being rumored to sell and whatnot. And perhaps, some of those are changing from not actionable to actionable. But we haven't re
componenttext: Yes, I agree. We haven't seen any specific changes in the trends. I mean, there are a number of targets out there that's always being rumored to sell and whatnot. And perhaps, some of those are changing from not actionable to actionable. But we haven't really seen a pickup in opportunities.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Worthington with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Worthington with JPMorgan.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gross sales across the board look weak over a multi quarter-to-quarter period, and that's driven by both cyclical and secular issues. Are ETS, in these multi-asset products, do they have big enough potential over, say, the next 3 to 5 years to offset the
componenttext: Gross sales across the board look weak over a multi quarter-to-quarter period, and that's driven by both cyclical and secular issues. Are ETS, in these multi-asset products, do they have big enough potential over, say, the next 3 to 5 years to offset the redemptions that Franklin is facing? And if those products don't have the potential, what's your next step into kind of driving the business back to possible organic growth?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's hard. No, I think all multi-assets are huge category that continues, I think, to garner more attention in the distribution channels. And I think for a lot, it makes a lot of sense. I would look at the organic growth rate trends are more
componenttext: Well, I think it's hard. No, I think all multi-assets are huge category that continues, I think, to garner more attention in the distribution channels. And I think for a lot, it makes a lot of sense. I would look at the organic growth rate trends are more -- the flagship areas like the income fund, which somewhat has been multi-asset before people started calling it that, you've seen a pretty strong rebound in 2 quarters of performance. And that can translate pretty quickly into organic growth if these trends continue that have really been moving the last -- that last couple of months. And we have seen that fund move from just a fund lone, $3.5 billion in net outflows in the prior quarter to 1.9 this quarter. And that continues to improve. So that's always been a big driver of net flow. I think the global bond one is a little bit harder, different category and not -- while it's doing better with some of the emerging currencies, I think the duration and rate's continuing to decline. It needs a backup and rates. If the rates back up, that will see significant organic growth, I think, pretty darn quickly because it will be one of the few funds that will do well in that environment. So I think you continue to bring new products out there and hope you catch on in a way that you can go. But certainly, the multi-asset category is a huge one. You've seen what's happened in Europe with it. So there is the reason why it can't happen here in the U.S. as well.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Hill with Barclays.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just had one on repurchases. So you guys have come -- had a few really strong quarters of repurchases, but I'm assuming some of that was opportunistic in nature. I'm just wondering how to thing about that moving forward. And kind of what level your stock
componenttext: Just had one on repurchases. So you guys have come -- had a few really strong quarters of repurchases, but I'm assuming some of that was opportunistic in nature. I'm just wondering how to thing about that moving forward. And kind of what level your stock price might cause you to purchase more or purchase less from U.S. cash perspective.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I think I was anticipating I might get this question. Looking back at our history over last 8 or 9 quarters, and I think the message that I want to give is that our strategy for repurchases is consistent. I don't see anything today that would cau
componenttext: Sure. So I think I was anticipating I might get this question. Looking back at our history over last 8 or 9 quarters, and I think the message that I want to give is that our strategy for repurchases is consistent. I don't see anything today that would cause us to change what we've done historically. And sure, it's definitely, in terms of activity, ramped up when the prices declined in the opposite. But we continue to believe in the stock. We continue to be -- and we'll continue to be opportunistic.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just as a follow-up. I know you guys mentioned, in the prior quarter call, expanding into some of the local markets. I think Poland was the one you mentioned. Just wondering the strategic rationale for that type of investments on a smaller
componenttext: Okay. And then just as a follow-up. I know you guys mentioned, in the prior quarter call, expanding into some of the local markets. I think Poland was the one you mentioned. Just wondering the strategic rationale for that type of investments on a smaller market versus maybe some of your key geographic centers on the distribution front.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's a question of resources being taken away from some of the bigger markets because of our initiatives in a smaller one. I think we have always felt that part of the competitive edge we have is our presence in all these different markets.
componenttext: Well, I think it's a question of resources being taken away from some of the bigger markets because of our initiatives in a smaller one. I think we have always felt that part of the competitive edge we have is our presence in all these different markets. And for us, Poland is also one of our operations and servicing centers for Europe, and we have a lot of employees that have a strong presence there. And it is a growing middle class in that market. And you take markets like in Taiwan that, for us, years ago, some of the would say, "Why are you bothering with that?" But they can become very meaningful if you have an early dominant position. So it's not taking away any resources for us. It's just continuing to build out that retail capability where it makes sense. And you add it all up, and it can be very meaningful.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Carrier with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Carrier with Bank of America.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, on the prerecorded call, you just mentioned as the market rebounded, both performance in redemptions were showing signs of improvement. Just wanted to get some color on what you saw. And then, I think, sometimes, when you look at the 1-year and the
componenttext: Greg, on the prerecorded call, you just mentioned as the market rebounded, both performance in redemptions were showing signs of improvement. Just wanted to get some color on what you saw. And then, I think, sometimes, when you look at the 1-year and the 3-year performance, you've mentioned when some of the larger funds are maybe just under the 50 percentile [ph]. So just wanted to get any color on the larger funds. Is there any kind of approaching the threshold to see the performance start to pick up?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think it is significant because I would look at the first 2 months of this last quarter as -- in a risk of environment, where it was the underperformance was getting worse every day. And just the last 6, 7 weeks, it's been probably the best
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think it is significant because I would look at the first 2 months of this last quarter as -- in a risk of environment, where it was the underperformance was getting worse every day. And just the last 6, 7 weeks, it's been probably the best overall performance. And we talked about some of the concentrated exposures that we have overall as a firm. But I think, that to me, it's almost also a leading indicator of the market, where we're saying, "Hey, it's been 10 years of this growth value cycle, and all of a sudden, value is starting to outperform." And you look at even emerging markets that had a better quarter of the value was up 7.5%, and growth was up 3.3%. So you have -- I think, the turnaround and what people have been looking for, whether it's currencies doing better, a broad oil obviously rebounding, and that affects probably 4 major groups performance right now with the energy exposure and also the high yield exposure and income fund. I think all of that can turn pretty quickly. I don't know exactly which ones are right. I didn't have a look at that to say, the 3-year number, who is within 2 percentages points of that. But the more important number is the market kind of gets the drivers for our bigger funds. And I think for a first time in a while, we're getting some wind behind us as far as the relative performance goes.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And you can you just -- a quick follow-up. Just on the impairment. I think you mentioned there was maybe an offset. Just want to try to understand maybe what the net impact was on maybe the G&A line, just to understand from what that build off. And
componenttext: Okay. And you can you just -- a quick follow-up. Just on the impairment. I think you mentioned there was maybe an offset. Just want to try to understand maybe what the net impact was on maybe the G&A line, just to understand from what that build off. And I then I think you also mentioned about $20 million in performance fees. So I know it is hard to predict, but maybe just in terms of locks  when you typically realize the outlook there.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Maybe it's better to so just give you what we're thinking about in terms of G&A going forward. We do think that, that line is going to come down a little bit. So we're not expecting a lot of upward pressure there, keeping in mind that there's a lot
componenttext: Sure. Maybe it's better to so just give you what we're thinking about in terms of G&A going forward. We do think that, that line is going to come down a little bit. So we're not expecting a lot of upward pressure there, keeping in mind that there's a lot of market-driven items that go through that line. So assuming a flat market, we just generally expect for the remainder of the year for that expense to come down from where it's been in the last 2 quarters. So I mean, I'm not avoiding your question. It's just that I don't want to, like, waste all the time with in and out of the accounting details. But generally speaking, we're thinking for G&A and other to come down a little bit from where it's been the last 2 quarters for the rest of the year.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just on the performance fees?

componenttextpreview: Sorry. Yes, the performance fees, yes, they are hard to predict. And they, in fact, were $20 million. If I think about it in terms of seasonality, typically, we might have a little bump up next quarter. So I mean, it wouldn't be unusual for us to see some
componenttext: Sorry. Yes, the performance fees, yes, they are hard to predict. And they, in fact, were $20 million. If I think about it in terms of seasonality, typically, we might have a little bump up next quarter. So I mean, it wouldn't be unusual for us to see some performance fees next quarter. And then the fourth quarter, typically we don't have too much.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Harris with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Harris with Wells Fargo.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: A larger question, big picture question, I guess, on the flows. If you look at this quarter relative to last, things got a little worse, but we've talked about some of the drivers, institutional impact and so on. But also, I guess there's another impact,
componenttext: A larger question, big picture question, I guess, on the flows. If you look at this quarter relative to last, things got a little worse, but we've talked about some of the drivers, institutional impact and so on. But also, I guess there's another impact, and that's the market selling off as much as it did in the first part of the quarter. And so I'm wondering, I know this is probably hard to gauge of frame up, but how much impact you guys think that had on the flows? And I guess, what I'm getting at is if we sort of didn't have this many blowup in the market, might the flow picture have looked even better than actually what occurred?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it would. I mean, I don't think there's any question it was -- when the market sell off to a 10% down through the first couple of months. And generally, what is a very strong month is January. So I -- it's always very hard to say what would
componenttext: Well, I think it would. I mean, I don't think there's any question it was -- when the market sell off to a 10% down through the first couple of months. And generally, what is a very strong month is January. So I -- it's always very hard to say what would it mean, what would the number look like. But certainly, it definitely had an impact on us, especially, as I said for us, I mean, the positions that we have and with the dollar, oil and energy, value growth, everything kind of moving the wrong way for the first couple of months, that didn't help in key areas where we had the largest assets. We've seen the impact, and redemptions were actually a little bit lower for the quarter, which is kind of counterintuitive a little bit, but grow sales dropped quite a bit. And that's what generally happens when you get in that really volatile out period.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And then a follow-up question on the taxable U.S. fixed income business. Still outflowing there. Can you just speak to that? Is that primarily a performance issue? And if so, what's the driver?
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And then a follow-up question on the taxable U.S. fixed income business. Still outflowing there. Can you just speak to that? Is that primarily a performance issue? And if so, what's the driver?

componenttextpreview: The U.S. taxable?
componenttext: The U.S. taxable?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think part of it was just the high-yield exposure. And for us, having a fair amount of assets in the high-yield area and the overexposure to energy there, I mean, that led to some of the outflows.
componenttext: Well, I think part of it was just the high-yield exposure. And for us, having a fair amount of assets in the high-yield area and the overexposure to energy there, I mean, that led to some of the outflows.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Bedell from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Bedell from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe Greg, just go back to the $130 billion [ph] of assets that you thought were at risk from the Department of Labor perspective. If you could just stratify the 401(k) part of that. I think we were estimating less than $20 billion of that would be 401(k
componenttext: Maybe Greg, just go back to the $130 billion [ph] of assets that you thought were at risk from the Department of Labor perspective. If you could just stratify the 401(k) part of that. I think we were estimating less than $20 billion of that would be 401(k). And then if the rest of that is IRA-related, are you just looking at the accounts that are with brokers in that regard? So would IRA assets be higher than that overall? And then is there -- to any extent you think pricing dynamic might change in a post-DOL world, would that influence some decisions, longer-term decisions, on changing pricing structures in your funds, including 12b-1?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, as I said, I wish we had an exact number because it's a little bit hard to collect, and we did our best to collect from various sources. And I think the 401(k) specific number, which mostly is investment-only the business, is about $31 billio
componenttext: Yes. I mean, as I said, I wish we had an exact number because it's a little bit hard to collect, and we did our best to collect from various sources. And I think the 401(k) specific number, which mostly is investment-only the business, is about $31 billion, $30 billion, somewhere in that range. So it's [indiscernible] are probably in the 70 to 100 range, I guess, is our best estimate there. And I think when you say it, I wouldn't say it's at risk. I mean, I think, there's clearly -- it means there's going to be some changes in how they're serviced and how we service and how we deliver through the adviser community. And still a lot of work to be done there. We have the share classes already in place that are being used today, and some of that could moved to those types of classes. We think the net result will be -- there will be more motion of money, and we want to make sure, first and foremost, that we're doing everything with our advisers to make sure that the burden, we could help them manage this huge change.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful color. And then, I think, Greg, on the last quarter, you mentioned there were some larger variable annuity accounts that still we're doing allocation changes. And I thought you said there was one that liked it was susceptible [indiscernible
componenttext: That's helpful color. And then, I think, Greg, on the last quarter, you mentioned there were some larger variable annuity accounts that still we're doing allocation changes. And I thought you said there was one that liked it was susceptible [indiscernible]. I don't think they came in -- correct me if I'm wrong, but did that come in this quarter? Or is that something that still remains a potential redemption?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That got moved back for a while, I think, probably, 6 to 9 months from hitting this quarter. So we'll keep you posted. We'll get better color. But I think so hanging out there.
componenttext: Yes. That got moved back for a while, I think, probably, 6 to 9 months from hitting this quarter. So we'll keep you posted. We'll get better color. But I think so hanging out there.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Alex Blostein with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Alex Blostein with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So one more on the DOL, if I may. So speaking through -- obviously, the rule is still fresh, and I'm assuming we're all kind of collecting information from your distribution channels on how things will continue. But when you take a step back, the $100-plu
componenttext: So one more on the DOL, if I may. So speaking through -- obviously, the rule is still fresh, and I'm assuming we're all kind of collecting information from your distribution channels on how things will continue. But when you take a step back, the $100-plus billion, as I'm assuming it's grandfather and obviously because the sales already occurred, but taking a step back, do you guys see performance will be a much bigger kind of point of influence on the way financial advisers decide how to allocate assets from here? And I guess, the reason I'm asking is if a fund underperforms for a brief period of time, is there a greater risk for from your contract versus what we experienced in the past?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I just think it's early to speculate on those types of thoughts. And obviously, it'd be nice to have clear rules. And here, we don't, in a lot of cases, the suitability and standard and how it's enforced and risks in how advice is delivered. I thi
componenttext: I mean, I just think it's early to speculate on those types of thoughts. And obviously, it'd be nice to have clear rules. And here, we don't, in a lot of cases, the suitability and standard and how it's enforced and risks in how advice is delivered. I think a lot of that has to be bettered and figured out and a lot of legal fees to get there. And then you are still did have some exposure in doing it. So even the question of figuring out performance and what time period is the right one, and at the end of the day, anybody can question an underperforming fund versus an index during any given period. And I think those are the questions that we have to somehow address. I think, at the end of the day, a lot of it is always performance-driven, and more than ever, today, you have more consultants involved in the selection of the platform. So I think that has been in place for a while. And regardless of a fiduciary that rule, I think it's just a trend we are a lot of 401(k) plans having strong kind of consultants helping pick the options, I think, that, that performance will always be critical.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Just a follow-up on expenses. You guys have done a good job maintaining margins at the current levels and keeping expenses well-managed despite the severance and a few other onetimers kind of running the numbers. Just curious, if you were to ki
componenttext: All right. Just a follow-up on expenses. You guys have done a good job maintaining margins at the current levels and keeping expenses well-managed despite the severance and a few other onetimers kind of running the numbers. Just curious, if you were to kind of strip all that out and say, "Okay, the baseline is maybe a little bit over $2 billion for the year," how much more room do you guys have to drive the nondistribution expense lower into the next 12 months or so, assuming markets are flat?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we're at the point -- I think there is room. I think there's room to drive the expenses down more in a number of different areas. Kind of what's left, though, is a little bit more complicated to sit through and come up with definitive plans.
componenttext: Yes, I think we're at the point -- I think there is room. I think there's room to drive the expenses down more in a number of different areas. Kind of what's left, though, is a little bit more complicated to sit through and come up with definitive plans. So it's going to take a little bit longer to execute those cost savings than the ones we've done so far. And there's -- but that doesn't mean that there's not more room to trim expenses. It's just going to be harder to see that impact in the P&L in the short term. This will take longer.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Cyprys from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Cyprys from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Just wondering if you could elaborate a little bit more just on your last point on some of those additional expense savings that could come through that -- that could take a little bit longer, what some of them might be. I think, in the past, you referred to potentially greater outsourcing. Just any updates on that? And just generally, how are you thinking about additional action that you can take on the expense side?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's more just looking at the way we do things and challenging our business processes that may have been set up when the business environment was different and just seeing if there's ways we can leverage technology to do things smarter and better
componenttext: I think it's more just looking at the way we do things and challenging our business processes that may have been set up when the business environment was different and just seeing if there's ways we can leverage technology to do things smarter and better and more efficiently and gain more scale. And when you start, that's the point I'm trying to make. When you start to take that approach, it gets a bit more challenging and time-consuming to go through in that. But those are the type of things. So specific lines of business perhaps, specific functions, just are we -- is our processes best-in-class right now? Or can it be improved? That's what we're looking at.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And then just as a follow-up, just turning to M&A. Just curious how active the dialogue has been on the M&A side. And to what extent you've gotten close in a deal. And if that's the case, sort of what's the hangup? And if you could just talk
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And then just as a follow-up, just turning to M&A. Just curious how active the dialogue has been on the M&A side. And to what extent you've gotten close in a deal. And if that's the case, sort of what's the hangup? And if you could just talk more broadly as to your M&A strategy. What sort of AUM ordeal value magnitude you think makes the most sense, characteristics that you're looking for right now.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you know there's different ways at looking at M&A. You can -- I mean, we never start with, okay, we need an AUM target, so let's look at targets that have that assets under management and consolidate. It's more of a strategic-driven approach. And wi
componenttext: Well, you know there's different ways at looking at M&A. You can -- I mean, we never start with, okay, we need an AUM target, so let's look at targets that have that assets under management and consolidate. It's more of a strategic-driven approach. And with that, you have to marry with what the supply is and what the targets bring to the table. So every one -- every single deal that we look for the strategic rationale tends to be bespoke and adjusted for that target. So very difficult to generalize, like, in terms of AUM targets or specifics.

componenttext: I think there would be perhaps more of a desire than -- or a want than a need, but we would still focus on that. And I think that, that's a lesson that we've learned during the last 2 downturns, that it's human nature, when times are good, to kind of relax the first strings and do things, do the nice to haves. But I think as a firm, we've grown up and realized that we need to be disciplined so that we don't get into those situations, where we have to have massive layoffs and disruptive the business. So...

And we've always felt like there are times when we have to continue to invest to be strategic, to do M&A, to bring out new products. I mean, I think it's a changing world. And just trying to cut your way to maintaining margins, you'll be out of business at some point.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Franklin Resources' Earnings Commentary for the Quarter Ended March 31, 2016. Statements made in this commentary regarding Franklin Resources, Inc., which are not historical facts, are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Priv
componenttext:
Welcome to Franklin Resources' Earnings Commentary for the Quarter Ended March 31, 2016. 
Statements made in this commentary regarding Franklin Resources, Inc., which are not historical facts, are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements involve a number of known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from any future results expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements. These and other risks, uncertainties and other important factors are described in more detail in Franklin's recent filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including in the Risk Factors and MD&A sections of Franklin's most recent Form 10-K and 10-Q filings. This commentary was prerecorded

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hello, and thank you for listening our commentary on second quarter results. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO; and I'm joined by Ken Lewis, our CFO.  The March quarter began with continued challenges for our business as global equities got of to the worst start in t
componenttext:
Hello, and thank you for listening our commentary on second quarter results. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO; and I'm joined by Ken Lewis, our CFO.  The March quarter began with continued challenges for our business as global equities got of to the worst start in the New Year since the depths of the global financial crisis. Many markets and then rebounded sharply from mid-February lows to finish the quarter in positive territory. This rebound also marked encouraging transition for us as many of our weakest performing sectors and regions of 2015 were among the strongest performers in the quarter. And several of our key strategies benefited from this location. 
Longer-term performance remains mixed with the relative underperformance of some of our larger strategies still weighing aggregate asset we did perform in numbers and flows. However, we did start to see some encouraging signs in the form of improved performance, as well as improved redemption trends as the quarter progressed. 
Financial results for the quarter were solid, as we continued to exercise expense disciplines despite some notable one-time items. The firm also demonstrated strong capital management returning nearly $1.9 billion to shareholders over the past 12 months. 
We continue to invest in future growth opportunities such as the recent expansion of our multi-asset solution capabilities with a new customized, open architecture offering that enables global financial institutions to address the needs of their specific global investor base, in area, where we've seen strong strong interest and momentum. 
This quarter, we also continued to build out our local asset management capabilities with a launch of a new polish fund umbrella after receiving our license from a local regular last quarter. The fund launch is a natural evolution of our business in Poland. We've had a presence since 1997 and we're today, we have 3 offices and more than 700 employees. 
Looking at aggregated long-term investment performance on Slide 6, relative performance remain mixed across the organization, but we're encouraged by some recent performance trends. Franklin Income Fund for example, benefited from broad-based strength across equity holdings, traditionally defensive activity sectors such as utilities, energy and telecoms that offer high dividend yields rallied in the wake lower rates and higher energy prices. The fund has seen a strong improvement in performance, ranking in the top quartile against it's peer groups for the trailing 3 and 6 month period and Morningstar respectively. 
Other Franklin strategies also generated strong performance. Franklin rising dividends for example, outperformed nearly all category peers in the benchmark during the quarter. And we're already seeing an increase across our U.S. retail distribution teams. 
Emerging market strategies, including the Templeton Asian growth fund delivered strong absolute and relative returns in the quarter. Global international fixed income performance also improved this quarter, with at least 90% of the assets in the category exceeding the peer group median for the 5 and 10-year periods. 
Looking now at assets under management, monthly average assets were $737 billion for the quarter and ending assets of $743 billion. Thanks to the market rebound at the end of the quarter. 
The mix of assets by investment objective on Slide 9 remained essentially unchanged again this quarter. 
Looking at the change in assets under management on Slide 10, lower sales and elevated redemptions continue to be a long-term new outflows that were $24 billion this quarter. Market appreciation was about $4 billion and this was due to flattish market returns for the quarter and a foreign exchange benefit of about $5 billion. 
Retail sales continued to be challenging given ongoing volatility, concerns of energy prices and performance; however, strong near-term performance trends did contribute to improved retail redemptions that decline 20% from the prior quarter. Most of the changes in U.S. retail many of our largest funds saw improving trends in net new flows. 
Institutional net flows were hit harder this quarter, due to large part to a handful of lumpy redemptions. Most of these redemptions were outside of our control such as model allocation changes and other clients needs to raise liquidity. 
Global equity strategies remained too net outflows this quarter as improving flows for simple funds for more than offset by institutional redemptions. The 2 largest redemptions totaled $1.8 billion, but were not performance related. 
Global international fixed income outflows increased due to lower sales, but most of that was a result of the large institutional funding of $5.5 billion in the prior quarter. 
Net new flows of our Templeton Global Bond Fund and return funds generally reflected that of overall retail flows, with outflows of the U.S. registered funds improving somewhat, while cross border outflows increased moderately. 
U.S. equity and hybrid funds both experienced improved net new flows due mainly to increasing redemptions. In the hybrid category, Franklin income flows improved with sales up 13% and redemptions down 17%, which nearly cut outflows in half compared to last quarter. 
fund sales improved notably this quarter resulting in a return to positive net new flows as investors started to recognizing the benefit of less volatile tax rebounds. Redemptions in U.S. taxable fixed income strategies eased this quarter led by our U.S. government fund that returned to positive net new flows. Now I'll hand it over to Ken for financial results

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg. Although, the lower assets under management were a headwind this quarter, financial results remain solid. The company generated $537 million in operating income and net income of $360 million. Diluted earnings per share was $0.61, a decrea
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg. Although, the lower assets under management were a headwind this quarter, financial results remain solid. The company generated $537 million in operating income and net income of $360 million. 
Diluted earnings per share was $0.61, a decrease of 18% from the prior quarter, which was 2% better than the decline and net income to our continued stock repurchase activity. 
On Slide 17, total revenue for the quarter declined 8% to $1.6 billion. Investment and management fees of $1.1 billion the decline in revenue due to the lower average assets under management and the shorter quarter. 
While simple monthly average assets under management declined by just under 6%, daily average assets under management actually decreased by almost 8%. The shorter quarter further reduced investment management fees, but this was more than offset by performance fees of about $20 million. 
Additionally, having fewer days to earn revenue decreased average effective fee dates slightly as did market volatility. In fact, the rate would have been almost the basis point higher if or calculated using daily average assets under management in startup simple monthly. 
Sales and distribution fees were $437 million and this was consistent with the decline in assets and sales as great discussed, as well as the impact of the shorter quarter. Shareholders servicing fees were $262 million and were essentially flat over the prior quarter. 
Lower dividends from consolidated progress decreased other revenue, which was $20 million this quarter, but most of this was offset in noncontrolling interest as Slide 27 illustrates. 
Overall, expenses declined this quarter by 3% due mostly to the decline in sales and distribution expense, which was $532 million. The decline in the asset and sales-based portion of this expense was consistent with the lower assets and sales was formed;, however, slide 26 illustrates a decline in non-U.S. assets caused the asset basics expense to decrease at a greater rate than the asset base revenue. 
When combined with an accounting adjustment of reduce the amortization of deferred sales commissions by about $5 million, net sales and distribution fees increased by about $15 million this quarter. Compensation and benefits expense was $374 million, which was towards the low lower end of prior guidance.  Included in this line was $40 million of severance cost from the voluntary separation plan we offered U.S. employees, as well as other workforce reduction efforts. 
Additionally, the season of resumption of payroll taxes impacted second quarter compensation expense. Information systems and technology expensive declined slightly to $50 million that we do expect to see seasonal uptick through the back half of the fiscal year. 
Occupancy expense of $33 million was a bit lower-than-expected due to additional cost savings that we're budgeting for this line to trend upward over the next two quarters. General, administrative and other expense was $88 million this quarter and while we made additional reductions to advertising, travel and entertainment expenses, there are number of one-time items creating some noise here this quarter. Longer-term, we expect this expense to moderate a bit and some seasonal increase in the fourth quarter and the year-over-year change being essentially flat. 
Looking more broadly, we now anticipated overall year-over-year decline in expenses, excluding sales and distribution vision expenses to be closer to 3%. The fiscal year-to-date operating margin pulled back to 35.3% due primarily to lower revenues, but also from some large one-time items this quarter. The tax rate increased a bit this quarter due to a shift in end the mix towards the U.S. and was 32.2% for the fiscal year-to-date period. We are currently assuming the similar income mix for the remainder of the year and some discrete items would impact very income in quarters and for those reasons we now expect the fiscal year-to-date to follow within 31.5% to 32.5%. 
Looking now at Slide 20. Investment and other income net of noncontrolling interests was $12.5 million this quarter, realized gains and available for sales investments and an increase in trading investments were largely offset by losses from equity method investments, and a negative foreign exchange impact of about $10 million. 
Looking now at capital management. This quarter represented another attractive period for share repurchases as the average share price continued to decline. In fact, we repurchased about 9.6 million shares in the quarter for a total of almost $340 million. Cumulative repurchases over the last 5 years have added compound average annual accretion to investors of 2.5%, which is, of course, and net of dilution the end of employees, which come favorably to other U.S. asset managers. Importantly, we maintain considerable financial flexibility with respect to potential acquisitions, dividend growth and our aggressive share repurchase activity. 
Repurchases and the steadily increasing dividend combined for a total payout of nearly $1.9 billion over the trailing 12 months, which represents a payout ratio of over 100%. And that concludes our comments this morning. We look forward to talking with you on the call later today.
