headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Okay, perfect. And then on the DOL, can you speak to Schwab's decision to stop selling loaded funds today from the standpoint of your own exposure to them, if at all? And then more broadly, what that could mean for your sales, in particular, if that
componenttext: Yes. Okay, perfect. And then on the DOL, can you speak to Schwab's decision to stop selling loaded funds today from the standpoint of your own exposure to them, if at all? And then more broadly, what that could mean for your sales, in particular, if that becomes a trend for the broader distribution world?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I should say I wouldn't make much of that decision. I doubt they'd do anything in what we -- what you call loaded sales. And everybody looks at the A shares sales and assumes somebody's paying commission. For us, it's now less than 9% of our
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I should say I wouldn't make much of that decision. I doubt they'd do anything in what we -- what you call loaded sales. And everybody looks at the A shares sales and assumes somebody's paying commission. For us, it's now less than 9% of our sales, have a commission on them, and we are traditional, what you'd call, I guess, load-based firm. So for Schwab, that's an -- I would say it's a nonevent that they're not doing that because it's probably less than 1% of their sales. And the world, as we know, continues to move towards fee-based. And with the fiduciary changes probably more with R6 or shares the don't have 12b-1 fees associated with them, you'll see more and more of that.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So when you -- and you say 9%, that means kind of all commissions frontload, 12b-1s, et cetera?
componenttext: So when you -- and you say 9%, that means kind of all commissions frontload, 12b-1s, et cetera?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's 9% of U.S. commissionable sales.
componenttext: That's 9% of U.S. commissionable sales.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Kim with Sandler O'Neill + Partners.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Kim with Sandler O'Neill + Partners.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, Greg, I know you called out the 2 mobile equity institutional redemptions that totaled $1.8 billion, but it sounds like there were some other lumpy institutional redemptions related to allocation changes and/or the sovereign wealth fund redemptions
componenttext: First, Greg, I know you called out the 2 mobile equity institutional redemptions that totaled $1.8 billion, but it sounds like there were some other lumpy institutional redemptions related to allocation changes and/or the sovereign wealth fund redemptions. So just wondering if you could sort of provide any more color on maybe the size of those losses and/or the strategies impacted? And any sense of sort of the residual AUM that might be at risk for further attrition?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the -- there's probably another -- out of -- there were 2 accounts that were -- that totaled $1.8 billion global equities, one Middle Eastern sovereign wealth and another in Australia doing a rebalancing of the global equity. And then really,
componenttext: Yes, I think the -- there's probably another -- out of -- there were 2 accounts that were -- that totaled $1.8 billion global equities, one Middle Eastern sovereign wealth and another in Australia doing a rebalancing of the global equity. And then really, only -- there was only 2 other large global equity that were about $300 million apiece in Canada. It's interesting, I think, looking at quarter-to-quarter, the global equity was actually -- while the net number was very high out, it was mostly due to these institutional redemptions. The retail trend is actually better. And I think the retail trend is important, too, to call out just in general, that it was a lot better than the prior quarter, with redemptions declining as well during kind of a choppy quarter. It's really the institutional quarter-over-quarter change in flows that masked, I think, some of the improved trends within the retail side, especially the hybrid side.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful.
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nothing else to really, I think, call out on the large institutional ones.
componenttext: Nothing else to really, I think, call out on the large institutional ones.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just to come back to M&A, any color on what you're seeing across the landscape in terms of pricing and/or competition, particularly in light of the recent rebound in the markets, I guess? Been hearing anecdotally that maybe the pipeline is
componenttext: Okay. And then just to come back to M&A, any color on what you're seeing across the landscape in terms of pricing and/or competition, particularly in light of the recent rebound in the markets, I guess? Been hearing anecdotally that maybe the pipeline is starting to pick up, if you will.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, I would just -- Ken can jump in. I think that's right. I think when you're kind of in market lulls and volatile periods, you don't really see a lot. And I think that's been kind of true that there hasn't been a ton of M&A activity. And as ma
componenttext: Well, I mean, I would just -- Ken can jump in. I think that's right. I think when you're kind of in market lulls and volatile periods, you don't really see a lot. And I think that's been kind of true that there hasn't been a ton of M&A activity. And as markets rebound, I think that people start thinking about it. So I think that's fair. I don't know if we could say specifically that we've seen that, but that certainly has been the case historically. And I’ll ask Ken...

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I agree. We haven't seen any specific changes in the trends. I mean, there are a number of targets out there that are always being rumored to sell and whatnot. And perhaps some of those are changing from nonactionable to actionable but we haven't rea
componenttext: Yes, I agree. We haven't seen any specific changes in the trends. I mean, there are a number of targets out there that are always being rumored to sell and whatnot. And perhaps some of those are changing from nonactionable to actionable but we haven't really seen a pick-up in opportunities.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Worthington with JP Morgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Worthington with JP Morgan.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gross sales across the board look weak over multi-quarter period, and that's driven by both cyclical and secular issues. Are ETFs in these multi-asset products, do they have big enough potential over, say, the next 3 to 5 years to offset the redemptions t
componenttext: Gross sales across the board look weak over multi-quarter period, and that's driven by both cyclical and secular issues. Are ETFs in these multi-asset products, do they have big enough potential over, say, the next 3 to 5 years to offset the redemptions that Franklin is facing? And if those products don't have the potential, what's your next step into kind of driving the business back to positive organic growth?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's hard to ever know. I think multi-asset is a huge category that continues, I think, to garner more attention in the distribution channels. And I think for a lot, it makes a lot of sense. I would look at the organic growth rate trends are
componenttext: Well, I think it's hard to ever know. I think multi-asset is a huge category that continues, I think, to garner more attention in the distribution channels. And I think for a lot, it makes a lot of sense. I would look at the organic growth rate trends are more the flagship areas like the income fund, which somewhat is -- has been a multi-asset before people started calling it that. You've seen a pretty strong rebound in 2 quarters of performance, and that can translate pretty quickly into organic growth if these trends continue that have really been moving the last -- that last couple of months. And we have seen that fund move from just the fund alone, $3.5 billion in net outflows in the prior quarter to $1.9 billion this quarter. And that continues to improve. So that's always been a big driver of net flows. I think the global bond one is a little bit harder, a different category. And not -- while it's doing better with some of the emerging currencies, I think the duration and rate's continuing to decline. It needs a back-up in rates. And if rates back up, that will see significant organic growth, I think, pretty darn quickly because it'll be one of the few funds that will do well in that environment. So I think you continue to bring new products out there and hope you catch on in a way that you can grow. But certainly, the multi-asset category is a huge one. And you've seen what's happened in Europe with it. So there's no reason why that can't happen here in the U.S. as well.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Hill with Barclays.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just had one on repurchases. So you guys have come -- had a few really strong quarters of repurchases, but I'm assuming some of that was opportunistic in nature. I'm just wondering how to think about that moving forward and kind of what level your stock
componenttext: I just had one on repurchases. So you guys have come -- had a few really strong quarters of repurchases, but I'm assuming some of that was opportunistic in nature. I'm just wondering how to think about that moving forward and kind of what level your stock price might cause you to purchase more or purchase less from a U.S. cash perspective.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I think I was anticipating I might get this question. Looking back at our history over the last 8 or 9 quarters, and I think the message that I want to give is that our strategy for repurchases is going to -- is consistent. I don't see anything t
componenttext: Sure. So I think I was anticipating I might get this question. Looking back at our history over the last 8 or 9 quarters, and I think the message that I want to give is that our strategy for repurchases is going to -- is consistent. I don't see anything today that would cause us to change what we've done historically. And sure, it's definitely in terms of activity ramped-up when the prices declined in the opposite, but we continue to believe in the stock. We continue to be -- and we'll continue to be opportunistic.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just as a follow-up, I know you guys mentioned in the pre-recorded call expanding into some of the local markets. I think Poland was the one you mentioned. Just wondering the strategic rationale for that type of investment in a smaller mark
componenttext: Okay. And then just as a follow-up, I know you guys mentioned in the pre-recorded call expanding into some of the local markets. I think Poland was the one you mentioned. Just wondering the strategic rationale for that type of investment in a smaller market versus maybe some of your key geographic centers on the distribution front.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's a question of resources being taken away from some of the bigger markets because of our initiatives in a smaller one. I think we have always felt that part of the competitive edge we have is our presence in all these different markets.
componenttext: Well, I think it's a question of resources being taken away from some of the bigger markets because of our initiatives in a smaller one. I think we have always felt that part of the competitive edge we have is our presence in all these different markets. And for us, Poland is also a -- one of our operations and servicing centers for Europe, and we have a lot of employees that have a strong presence there. And it is a growing middle class in that market. And you take markets like a Taiwan that, for us, years ago, somebody would have said, "Why are you bothering with that?" But they can become very meaningful if you have an early dominant position. So it's not taking away any resources for us. It's just continuing to build out that retail capability where it makes sense. And you add it all up, and it can be very meaningful.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Carrier with Bank of America.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, on your -- the pre-recorded call, you just mentioned as the market rebounded, both performance and redemptions were showing signs of improvement. I just wanted to get some color on what you saw. And then, I think, sometimes, when you look at the 1-y
componenttext: Greg, on your -- the pre-recorded call, you just mentioned as the market rebounded, both performance and redemptions were showing signs of improvement. I just wanted to get some color on what you saw. And then, I think, sometimes, when you look at the 1-year and the 3-year performance, yes, you've mentioned when some of the larger funds are maybe just under the 50 percentile. So I just wanted to get any color on the larger funds, if they're kind of approaching that threshold to see the performance start to pick up.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think it is significant because I would look at the first 2 months of this last quarter as -- in a risk off environment, where it was -- the underperformance was getting worse every day. And just the last 6, 7 weeks, it's been probably the
componenttext:
Yes, I mean, I think it is significant because I would look at the first 2 months of this last quarter as -- in a risk off environment, where it was -- the underperformance was getting worse every day. And just the last 6, 7 weeks, it's been probably the best overall performance. And we talked about some of the concentrated exposures that we have overall as a firm. But I think, that, to me, it's almost also a leading indicator to the market, where we're saying, "Hey, it's been 10 years of this growth value cycle, and all of a sudden, value is starting to outperform." And you look at even emerging markets that had a better quarter. Value was up 7.5% and growth was up 3.3%. 
So you have, I think, the turnaround and what people have been looking for, whether it's currencies doing better, a broad oil, obviously, rebounding, and that affects probably 4 major groups’ performance right now with the energy exposure and also the high-yield exposure and income fund. I think all of that can turn pretty quickly. I don't know exactly which ones are right. I didn't -- I haven't looked at that to say, the 3-year number, who is within 2 percentage points or that. But I think the more important number is the market kind of gets the drivers for our bigger funds. And I think for the first time in a while, we're getting some wind behind us as far as the relative performance goes.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And you can you just, Ken, a quick follow-up. Just on the impairment, I think you mentioned there was maybe an offset. I just wanted to try to understand maybe what the net impact was on maybe the G&A line, just to understand from what to build off.
componenttext: Okay. And you can you just, Ken, a quick follow-up. Just on the impairment, I think you mentioned there was maybe an offset. I just wanted to try to understand maybe what the net impact was on maybe the G&A line, just to understand from what to build off. And then I think you also mentioned about $20 million in performance fees. So I know those are hard to predict, but maybe just in terms of locks or when you typically realize those, the outlook there.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Maybe it's better to so just give you what we're thinking about in terms of G&A going forward. We do think that, that line is going to come down a little bit. So we're not expecting a lot of upward pressure there, keeping in mind that there's a lot
componenttext: Sure. Maybe it's better to so just give you what we're thinking about in terms of G&A going forward. We do think that, that line is going to come down a little bit. So we're not expecting a lot of upward pressure there, keeping in mind that there's a lot of market-driven items that go through that line. So it's assuming a flat market. We just generally expect for the remainder of the year for that expense to come down from where it's been in the last 2 quarters. So I mean, I'm not avoiding your question. It's just that I don't want to, like, waste all the time with in and out accounting details. But generally speaking, we're thinking for G&A and other to come down a little bit from where it's been the last 2 quarters for the rest of the year.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then just on the performance fees?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just on the performance fees?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry. Yes, the performance fees, they -- yes, they are hard to predict. And they're, in fact, worth $20 million. If I think about it in terms of seasonality, typically, we might have a little bump-up next quarter. So I mean, it wouldn't be unusual for us
componenttext: Sorry. Yes, the performance fees, they -- yes, they are hard to predict. And they're, in fact, worth $20 million. If I think about it in terms of seasonality, typically, we might have a little bump-up next quarter. So I mean, it wouldn't be unusual for us to see some performance fees next quarter. And then the fourth quarter, typically, we don't have too much.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Harris with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Harris with Wells Fargo.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: A larger question -- big-picture question, I guess, on the flows. If you look at this quarter relative to last, things got a little worse, but we've talked about some of the drivers, the institutional impact and so on. But also, I guess there's another im
componenttext: A larger question -- big-picture question, I guess, on the flows. If you look at this quarter relative to last, things got a little worse, but we've talked about some of the drivers, the institutional impact and so on. But also, I guess there's another impact, and that's the market selling off as much as it did in the first part of the quarter. And so I'm wondering, I know this is probably really hard to gauge or frame up, but how much impact do you guys think that had on the flows? And I guess, what I'm getting at is if we sort of didn't have this many blow-up in the market, might the flow picture have looked even better than actually what occurred?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it would. I mean, I don't think there's any question. It was -- when the markets sell off to a 10% down through the first couple of months, that -- in, generally, what is a very strong month is January. So I -- it's always very hard to say w
componenttext: Well, I think it would. I mean, I don't think there's any question. It was -- when the markets sell off to a 10% down through the first couple of months, that -- in, generally, what is a very strong month is January. So I -- it's always very hard to say what would it mean, what would the number look like, but certainly, it definitely had an impact, and especially, as I said, for us. I mean, the positions that we had and with the dollar, oil and energy, value growth, everything kind of moving the wrong way for the first couple of months, that didn't help in the key areas where we have the largest assets. And we've seen the impact, and redemptions were actually a little bit lower for the quarter, which is kind of counterintuitive a little bit, but gross sales dropped quite a bit. And that's what generally happens in that -- when you get in that really volatile period.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, okay. And a follow-up question on the taxable U.S. fixed income business. Still outflowing there. Can you speak to that? Is that a -- is that primarily a performance issue? And if so, what's the driver?
componenttext: Got it, okay. And a follow-up question on the taxable U.S. fixed income business. Still outflowing there. Can you speak to that? Is that a -- is that primarily a performance issue? And if so, what's the driver?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: The U.S. taxable?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think part of it was just the high-yield exposure. And for us, having a fair amount of assets in the high-yield area and the overexposure to energy there, I mean, that led to some of the outflows.
componenttext: Well, I think part of it was just the high-yield exposure. And for us, having a fair amount of assets in the high-yield area and the overexposure to energy there, I mean, that led to some of the outflows.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Bedell with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Bedell with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe Greg, just go back to the $130 billion of assets that you said were at risk from the Department of Labor perspective. If you could just stratify the 401(k) part of that. I think we were estimating less than $20 billion of that would be 401(k). And t
componenttext: Maybe Greg, just go back to the $130 billion of assets that you said were at risk from the Department of Labor perspective. If you could just stratify the 401(k) part of that. I think we were estimating less than $20 billion of that would be 401(k). And then if the rest of that is IRA-related, are you just looking at the accounts that are with brokers in that regard? So would IRA assets be higher than that overall? And then is there -- to any extent you think pricing dynamics might change in a post-DOL world, would that influence some decisions, longer-term decisions, on changing pricing structures in your funds, including 12b-1s?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, as I've said, I wish we had an exact number because it's a little bit hard to collect. And we did our best to collect from various sources. And I think the 401(k) specific number, which mostly is investment-only business, is about $31 billion
componenttext: Yes. I mean, as I've said, I wish we had an exact number because it's a little bit hard to collect. And we did our best to collect from various sources. And I think the 401(k) specific number, which mostly is investment-only business, is about $31 billion, $30 billion, somewhere in that range. So it's -- and IRAs are probably in the $70 billion to $100 billion range, I guess, is our best guesstimate there. And I think when you say it, it -- I wouldn't say it's at risk. I mean, I think, there's clearly -- it means there's going to be some changes in how they're serviced and how we service and how we deliver through the adviser community, and still a lot of work to be done there. We have the share classes already in place that are being used today, and some of that could move to those types of classes. We think the net result will be -- there will be more motion of money, and we want to make sure, first and foremost, that we're doing everything with our advisers to make sure that the burden, we can help them manage this huge change.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful color. And then, I think, Greg, on the last quarter particularly, you mentioned there were some larger variable annuity accounts that still were doing allocation changes. And I thought you said there was one that looked like it was suscepti
componenttext: That's helpful color. And then, I think, Greg, on the last quarter particularly, you mentioned there were some larger variable annuity accounts that still were doing allocation changes. And I thought you said there was one that looked like it was susceptible to coming in that -- I don't think they came in the -- correct me if I'm wrong, but did that come in the -- this quarter? Or is that something that still remains a potential redemption?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That got moved back for a while. I think probably 6 to 9 months from hitting this quarter. So we'll keep you posted when we get better color. But it's still -- I think still hanging out there.
componenttext: Yes. That got moved back for a while. I think probably 6 to 9 months from hitting this quarter. So we'll keep you posted when we get better color. But it's still -- I think still hanging out there.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Alex Blostein with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Alex Blostein with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So one more on the DOL, if I may. So speaking through -- obviously, the rule is still fresh, and I'm assuming we're all kind of collecting information from various distribution channels on how things will continue. But when you take a step back, the $100-
componenttext: So one more on the DOL, if I may. So speaking through -- obviously, the rule is still fresh, and I'm assuming we're all kind of collecting information from various distribution channels on how things will continue. But when you take a step back, the $100-plus billion, as I'm assuming it's grandfathered and obviously because the sales already occurred. But taking a step back, do you guys think performance will be a much bigger kind of point of influence on the way financial advisers decide how to allocate assets from here? And I guess, the reason I'm asking is if a fund underperforms for a brief period of time, is there greater risk for redemptions other than the new contract versus what we've experienced in the past?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I just think it's early to speculate on those types of thoughts. And obviously, it'd be nice to have clear rules. And here, we don't, in a lot of cases, the suitability and standard and how it's enforced and risks in how advice is delivered. And I
componenttext: I mean, I just think it's early to speculate on those types of thoughts. And obviously, it'd be nice to have clear rules. And here, we don't, in a lot of cases, the suitability and standard and how it's enforced and risks in how advice is delivered. And I think a lot of that has to be vetted and figured out. And a lot of legal fees to get there. And then you're still going to have some exposure in doing it. So even the question of figuring out performance and what time period is the right one, and at the end of the day, anybody can question an underperforming fund versus an index during any given period. And I think those are the questions that we have to somehow address. I think, at the end of the day, a lot of it is always performance-driven. And more than ever, today, you have more consultants involved in the selection of the platform. So I think that has been in place for a while. And regardless of a fiduciary rule, I think that was just the trend where a lot of the 401(k) plans having strong kind of consultants helping pick the options, I think, that, that performance will always be critical.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then, Ken, just some follow-up on expenses. You guys have done a good job maintaining margins at the current levels and keeping expenses well-managed despite the severance and a few other onetimers kind of running through the numbers. Just
componenttext: All right. And then, Ken, just some follow-up on expenses. You guys have done a good job maintaining margins at the current levels and keeping expenses well-managed despite the severance and a few other onetimers kind of running through the numbers. Just curious if you were to kind of strip all that out and say, "Okay, the baseline is maybe a little bit over $2 billion for the year," how much more room do you guys have to drive the nondistribution expenses lower into the next 12 months or so, assuming markets are flat?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we're at the point -- I think there's room. I think there's room to drive the expenses down more in a number of different areas. Kind of the -- what's left, though, is a little bit more complicated to sift through and come up with definitive
componenttext: Yes, I think we're at the point -- I think there's room. I think there's room to drive the expenses down more in a number of different areas. Kind of the -- what's left, though, is a little bit more complicated to sift through and come up with definitive plans. So it's going to take a little bit longer to execute those cost savings than the ones we've done so far. And -- but there's -- but that doesn't mean that there's not more room to trim expenses. It's just going to be harder to see that impact in the P&L in the short term. It’s going to take longer.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Cyprys from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Cyprys from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wondering if you could elaborate a little bit more just on your last point on some of those additional expense savings that could come through, that could take a little bit longer, what some of them might be. I think in the past, I mean, you referred
componenttext: Just wondering if you could elaborate a little bit more just on your last point on some of those additional expense savings that could come through, that could take a little bit longer, what some of them might be. I think in the past, I mean, you referred to potentially greater outsourcing. Just any updates on that? And just generally, how you're thinking about additional action that you can take on the expense side.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's more just looking at the way we do things and challenging our business processes that may have been set up when the business environment was different and just seeing if there's ways we can leverage technology to do things smarter and better
componenttext: I think it's more just looking at the way we do things and challenging our business processes that may have been set up when the business environment was different and just seeing if there's ways we can leverage technology to do things smarter and better and more efficiently and gain more scale. And when you start, that might -- that's the point I'm trying to make. When you start to take that approach, it gets a bit more challenging and time-consuming to go through and vet. But those are the type of things. So specific lines of business perhaps, specific functions, just are we -- is our processes best-in-class right now or can they be improved? That's what we're looking at.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And then just as a follow-up, just turning to M&A. Just curious how active the dialogue has been on the M&A side. And to what extent have you gotten close on a deal? And if that's the case, sort of what's been the hang-up? And if you could j
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And then just as a follow-up, just turning to M&A. Just curious how active the dialogue has been on the M&A side. And to what extent have you gotten close on a deal? And if that's the case, sort of what's been the hang-up? And if you could just talk more broadly as to your M&A strategy. What sort of AUM or deal value magnitude do you think makes the most sense and characteristics that you're looking for right now?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you know there's different ways of looking at M&A. You can -- I mean, we never start with, okay, we need an AUM target so let's look at targets that have that assets under management and consolidate. It's more of a strategic-driven approach. But tha
componenttext: Well, you know there's different ways of looking at M&A. You can -- I mean, we never start with, okay, we need an AUM target so let's look at targets that have that assets under management and consolidate. It's more of a strategic-driven approach. But that, you have to marry with what the supply is and what the targets bring to the table. So every one -- every single deal that we look for the strategic rationale tends to be bespoke and adjusted for that target. So very difficult to generalize, like, in terms of the AUM targets or specifics.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just on the activity of the dialogue, have you gotten close on anything? And what's sort of been the hang-up, if you have?
componenttext: Okay. And just on the activity of the dialogue, have you gotten close on anything? And what's sort of been the hang-up, if you have?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, we have dedicated people that are out there looking at the industry. And I wouldn't say anything’s been close, and we probably wouldn't mention that anyway. But we're going to continue to look. And as we said on the last call, it continues to be
componenttext: I mean, we have dedicated people that are out there looking at the industry. And I wouldn't say anything’s been close, and we probably wouldn't mention that anyway. But we're going to continue to look. And as we said on the last call, it continues to be a priority with the offshore cash to utilize that in a way that enhances shareholder value. And that's really what we're trying to do.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And looking back, if -- there's one common theme for why deals weren't done. It tended to be cultural fit.
componenttext: Okay. And looking back, if -- there's one common theme for why deals weren't done. It tended to be cultural fit.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Eric Berg with RBC.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Eric Berg with RBC.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the area of expenses, or in the area of expenses, would you say that if the equity market weren't this volatile as it has been, and if equity prices were higher, not off where they are compared with a year ago, would you still say that given the state
componenttext: On the area of expenses, or in the area of expenses, would you say that if the equity market weren't this volatile as it has been, and if equity prices were higher, not off where they are compared with a year ago, would you still say that given the state of the business, what's going on in your industry, that there would still be a need to lower expenses?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there would be perhaps more of a desire than -- or a want than a need, but we would still focus on that. And I think that, that's a lesson that we've learned through the last 2 downturns is that it's human nature, when times are good, to kind of r
componenttext: I think there would be perhaps more of a desire than -- or a want than a need, but we would still focus on that. And I think that, that's a lesson that we've learned through the last 2 downturns is that it's human nature, when times are good, to kind of relax the purse strings and do things, do the nice-to-haves. But I think as a firm, we've grown up and realized that we need to be disciplined so that we don't get into those situations where we have to have massive layoffs or something in the downturn and disrupt the business. So...

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: But I would also add. I mean, your question, just beyond what are the obvious issues the active manager faces in today's marketplace with -- and changes in the distribution model and regulatory environment even in a robust environment, you'd probably, yes
componenttext: But I would also add. I mean, your question, just beyond what are the obvious issues the active manager faces in today's marketplace with -- and changes in the distribution model and regulatory environment even in a robust environment, you'd probably, yes, be looking for more efficiencies, but I'd also say you don't cut your way to prosperity. And we have always felt like there are times when we have to continue to invest, to be strategic, to do M&A, to bring out new products. I mean, I think it's a changing world. And just trying to cut your way to maintaining margins, you'll be out of business at some point.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if I could just have a little discussion with you, following up on the matter of share classes and the DOL. I find it almost a full-time job keeping track of share classes. A, B, C, R, L, I, adviser class, investor class, admiral class. It goes on and
componenttext: And if I could just have a little discussion with you, following up on the matter of share classes and the DOL. I find it almost a full-time job keeping track of share classes. A, B, C, R, L, I, adviser class, investor class, admiral class. It goes on and on. The lexicon differs by company. I'm wondering whether one of you could maybe make it a little bit easier for us by offering any general comments you think hold true as to what is going to happen here. In other words, are there -- can we say just as a general statement that irrespective of what the share class is called, A, B, C, R, L, I, whatever, that lower expense ratio share classes will be doing better as a result of DOL? That's what I'm sort of looking for, some general guidance on how to think about this.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think that's right. I don't -- I think there's more pressure, especially for newer business, to utilize what we call an R6 class. But again, I think it -- there's still a lot of work to be done before you can draw any conclusions on how fas
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think that's right. I don't -- I think there's more pressure, especially for newer business, to utilize what we call an R6 class. But again, I think it -- there's still a lot of work to be done before you can draw any conclusions on how fast that'll move. And certainly, you can conclude that the lower end of the market will be more passive robo and less people-intensive or advice-driven. That's just -- that -- those conclusions you can kind of draw. How quickly the pace moves to specific classes, I think, as you said, there's a lot of work to be done in the meantime before you can just say x percent is going to be there at this -- by this date.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of John Dunn with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of John Dunn with Evercore ISI.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Yes. Okay, and just one last one. It looks like, for some of the larger funds that have been underperforming, that short-term performance is starting to bleed into the 3- and 5-year numbers. Any large platforms or consultants that may be more focused on those longer-term numbers that you could be worried about right now?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you always worry about that. But as I said earlier, I think what people -- the -- if you can understand that performance in relation to the market, simple, whether it's value growth or different exposures in portfolios, and then look at more near
componenttext: I think you always worry about that. But as I said earlier, I think what people -- the -- if you can understand that performance in relation to the market, simple, whether it's value growth or different exposures in portfolios, and then look at more near term, and just I don't think I've seen a better 6-week period of relative performance for our flagship holdings. And so that's going to bleed in pretty quickly, too, when you have 500, 800 basis points of outperformance in a 6-week period. That's going to help pretty quickly. And I think that's the momentum, certainly, with Templeton Energy dollar. More recently, some financials. All of that moves the numbers pretty quickly. So I would be more encouraged about the 6-week trend than I would worrying about bleeding into the 3 and 5 because that's going to be more important. And as I said, that will bleed in, too, pretty quickly.

componenttext: Yes. I mean, it's a great question, and I don't -- I couldn't tell you how much in terms of quantifying risk. I think we did our best in a -- for us, in a world where we have omnibus and assets we don't see to come up with fair guesstimate around how much is in 401(k) and how much is an IRAs, and we didn't include VA. That number's probably $180 billion of exposed assets, breaking out between about $50 billion in VAs and $28 billion in 401(k) investment only, and the rest in IRAs. So I don't think there's a big -- certainly, there's more risk that an average account because of the changes that are being imposed on the industry, but I don't know how I could possibly quantify that right now, Bill.

Good morning. My name is Melissa, and I will be your call operator today. [Operator Instructions]
As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the call over to Franklin Resources Chairman and CEO, Mr. Greg Johnson. Mr. Johnson, you may begin.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, good morning, and thank you for joining Ken Lewis and me to discuss the company's second quarter. Although we continue to experience net outflows in the March quarter, the nature of the mid-quarter market rebound marked an encouraging transition for
componenttext:
Well, good morning, and thank you for joining Ken Lewis and me to discuss the company's second quarter. Although we continue to experience net outflows in the March quarter, the nature of the mid-quarter market rebound marked an encouraging transition for us as many of the weakest-performing sectors in 2015 were among the strongest performers in the quarter. 
As the quarter progressed, investment performance of many of our key strategies improved, as did redemption trends. Overall, our financial results were solid as we continued to exercise expense discipline, notwithstanding some notable onetime items that are discussed in more detail on our 10-Q, which was also filed this morning. 
Now Ken and I are happy to take your questions.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttextpreview: Sure. We did have -- we had an impairment charge in G&A. That was about $30 million. That was offset a little bit by contingent liability. So those were the 2 major large lumpiness in the G&A account.
componenttext: Sure. We did have -- we had an impairment charge in G&A. That was about $30 million. That was offset a little bit by contingent liability. So those were the 2 major large lumpiness in the G&A account.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, in the context of -- last quarter, we had 3% to 4% expense decline for the year. And now you're saying 3%. What were the variables in terms of that change?
componenttext: I guess, in the context of -- last quarter, we had 3% to 4% expense decline for the year. And now you're saying 3%. What were the variables in terms of that change?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, one of them was that impairment charge. We weren't counting on that in the 3% to 4% guidance. And also looking out for the remaining quarters for the year, we might have another nonrecurring charge in the fourth quarter, although that could roll int
componenttext: Well, one of them was that impairment charge. We weren't counting on that in the 3% to 4% guidance. And also looking out for the remaining quarters for the year, we might have another nonrecurring charge in the fourth quarter, although that could roll into the first quarter as well. So those were 2 things that weren't known last quarter that we're factoring in, as well as there's a lot of moving parts to this when we're rationalizing business lines and departments and all that. So we're just refining our estimate.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Great. I guess, and then, Greg, as my follow-up, if you could talk about the DOL, and the final rules are out, and how you guys are thinking about that.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think a lot, obviously, has been discussed already. I mean, it affects a huge part of the industry. I think, for us, it's difficult to get an exact number on the amount of assets that it potentially could affect, but we did our best. And with omni
componenttext: Well, I think a lot, obviously, has been discussed already. I mean, it affects a huge part of the industry. I think, for us, it's difficult to get an exact number on the amount of assets that it potentially could affect, but we did our best. And with omnibus accounts, that's a little bit tricky. But we estimate it affects about $130 billion of our assets. I think we're probably a little bit lower than most because of our heavy concentration in retail assets offshore as well as municipal bond funds and the fact that the key area around 401(k) tends to be in U.S. growth, and that's an area where we don't have huge penetration. So I think overall, a little bit lower, but like everybody in the industry, very concerned about and still trying to understand what a 1,000-page document means to our business. And that's really where we're focused today is working with our advisers, working with outside legal assistants and really making sense of the proposal. I think the good news is that some of the most unworkable items have been adjusted, but obviously, a very difficult rule that will eliminate advice to many people that need it most, and that's the smaller end of the market.

componenttext: Yes, I mean, that is. And it's addressing that area of the market using technology and trying to penetrate those that may not be large enough to be able to get individual help or advice. So it does address a new market for us. I think our partnership, a lot of that was based on our global reach and the fact that we can help them get marketing message out in markets like Asia and Latin America, where Citi has such a strong reach. I think that will take a while to develop, but it is off and running now. The other area is just around the alternatives and multi-alternatives, and we continue to extend our capabilities there with the long short credit and Global Macro fund that was recently introduced, and then our Liberty shares ETF, which will be available in June, and we expect to continue to build out that line as well. And those are just a few of the newer initiatives.

componenttext: I just want to come back to the impairment you took on K2. I guess that's been an area of growth for you so I'm a little surprised to see the impairments. componenttextpreview: Sure. So the impairment wasn't related to K2 in total. It was related to a specific component of the K2 business, which would have been the old business contracts that we put a value on. And so we were just adjusting that value based on there have been a
componenttext: Sure. So the impairment wasn't related to K2 in total. It was related to a specific component of the K2 business, which would have been the old business contracts that we put a value on. And so we were just adjusting that value based on there have been a couple of redemptions and there have been sales that haven't met the original projections. So that's way we impaired it. So it's just that one stream of business, if you will, not the entire enterprise.

componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think we still view it, as you said, in a strong area of growth, and we're going to continue to look at expanding the product line in less traditional types of investments. So we're -- whether it's M&A or building it organically, that's certainly part of our plan.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And just as a follow-up. You had mentioned in your pre-recorded call, maybe just happenstance, but you listed deals first within your use of cash, cash flow. So wondering if you step back, how do you think about capital management priorities given when we stock recovery versus going out to business? And within M&A, what kind of things are you looking at?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that it might have been happenstance. Probably that order -- that ordering, I don't think it was intentional. And I say that because it -- nothing has changed in our strategy, our capital management strategy. I mean, we don't say the stock is
componenttext: Yes. I think that it might have been happenstance. Probably that order -- that ordering, I don't think it was intentional. And I say that because it -- nothing has changed in our strategy, our capital management strategy. I mean, we don't say the stock is up or down so now we’ll place more or less emphasis on M&A. They're all kind of independent decisions. And we're continuing to focus on M&A -- evaluate M&A opportunities. That hasn't changed.

componenttext: Yes. Okay, perfect. And then on the DOL, can you speak to Schwab's decision to stop selling loaded funds today from the standpoint of your own exposure to them, if at all? And then more broadly, what that could mean for your sales, in particular, if that becomes a trend for the broader distribution world?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I should say I wouldn't make much of that decision. I doubt they'd do anything in what we -- what you call loaded sales. And everybody looks at the A shares sales and assumes somebody's paying commission. For us, it's now less than 9% of our
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I should say I wouldn't make much of that decision. I doubt they'd do anything in what we -- what you call loaded sales. And everybody looks at the A shares sales and assumes somebody's paying commission. For us, it's now less than 9% of our sales, have a commission on them, and we are traditional, what you'd call, I guess, load-based firm. So for Schwab, that's an -- I would say it's a nonevent that they're not doing that because it's probably less than 1% of their sales. And the world, as we know, continues to move towards fee-based. And with the fiduciary changes probably more with R6 or shares the don't have 12b-1 fees associated with them, you'll see more and more of that.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, Greg, I know you called out the 2 mobile equity institutional redemptions that totaled $1.8 billion, but it sounds like there were some other lumpy institutional redemptions related to allocation changes and/or the sovereign wealth fund redemptions
componenttext: First, Greg, I know you called out the 2 mobile equity institutional redemptions that totaled $1.8 billion, but it sounds like there were some other lumpy institutional redemptions related to allocation changes and/or the sovereign wealth fund redemptions. So just wondering if you could sort of provide any more color on maybe the size of those losses and/or the strategies impacted? And any sense of sort of the residual AUM that might be at risk for further attrition?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the -- there's probably another -- out of -- there were 2 accounts that were -- that totaled $1.8 billion global equities, one Middle Eastern sovereign wealth and another in Australia doing a rebalancing of the global equity. And then really,
componenttext: Yes, I think the -- there's probably another -- out of -- there were 2 accounts that were -- that totaled $1.8 billion global equities, one Middle Eastern sovereign wealth and another in Australia doing a rebalancing of the global equity. And then really, only -- there was only 2 other large global equity that were about $300 million apiece in Canada. It's interesting, I think, looking at quarter-to-quarter, the global equity was actually -- while the net number was very high out, it was mostly due to these institutional redemptions. The retail trend is actually better. And I think the retail trend is important, too, to call out just in general, that it was a lot better than the prior quarter, with redemptions declining as well during kind of a choppy quarter. It's really the institutional quarter-over-quarter change in flows that masked, I think, some of the improved trends within the retail side, especially the hybrid side.

componenttext: Okay. headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Well, I mean, I would just -- Ken can jump in. I think that's right. I think when you're kind of in market lulls and volatile periods, you don't really see a lot. And I think that's been kind of true that there hasn't been a ton of M&A activity. And as markets rebound, I think that people start thinking about it. So I think that's fair. componenttext: Yes, I agree. We haven't seen any specific changes in the trends. I mean, there are a number of targets out there that are always being rumored to sell and whatnot. And perhaps some of those are changing from nonactionable to actionable but we haven't really seen a pick-up in opportunities.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Worthington with JP Morgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Worthington with JP Morgan.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gross sales across the board look weak over multi-quarter period, and that's driven by both cyclical and secular issues. Are ETFs in these multi-asset products, do they have big enough potential over, say, the next 3 to 5 years to offset the redemptions t
componenttext: Gross sales across the board look weak over multi-quarter period, and that's driven by both cyclical and secular issues. Are ETFs in these multi-asset products, do they have big enough potential over, say, the next 3 to 5 years to offset the redemptions that Franklin is facing? And if those products don't have the potential, what's your next step into kind of driving the business back to positive organic growth?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's hard to ever know. I think multi-asset is a huge category that continues, I think, to garner more attention in the distribution channels. And I think for a lot, it makes a lot of sense. I would look at the organic growth rate trends are
componenttext: Well, I think it's hard to ever know. I think multi-asset is a huge category that continues, I think, to garner more attention in the distribution channels. And I think for a lot, it makes a lot of sense. I would look at the organic growth rate trends are more the flagship areas like the income fund, which somewhat is -- has been a multi-asset before people started calling it that. You've seen a pretty strong rebound in 2 quarters of performance, and that can translate pretty quickly into organic growth if these trends continue that have really been moving the last -- that last couple of months. And we have seen that fund move from just the fund alone, $3.5 billion in net outflows in the prior quarter to $1.9 billion this quarter. And that continues to improve. So that's always been a big driver of net flows. I think the global bond one is a little bit harder, a different category. And not -- while it's doing better with some of the emerging currencies, I think the duration and rate's continuing to decline. It needs a back-up in rates. And if rates back up, that will see significant organic growth, I think, pretty darn quickly because it'll be one of the few funds that will do well in that environment. So I think you continue to bring new products out there and hope you catch on in a way that you can grow. But certainly, the multi-asset category is a huge one. And you've seen what's happened in Europe with it. So there's no reason why that can't happen here in the U.S. as well.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: I just had one on repurchases. So you guys have come -- had a few really strong quarters of repurchases, but I'm assuming some of that was opportunistic in nature. I'm just wondering how to think about that moving forward and kind of what level your stock price might cause you to purchase more or purchase less from a U.S. cash perspective.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So I think I was anticipating I might get this question. Looking back at our history over the last 8 or 9 quarters, and I think the message that I want to give is that our strategy for repurchases is going to -- is consistent. I don't see anything t
componenttext: Sure. So I think I was anticipating I might get this question. Looking back at our history over the last 8 or 9 quarters, and I think the message that I want to give is that our strategy for repurchases is going to -- is consistent. I don't see anything today that would cause us to change what we've done historically. And sure, it's definitely in terms of activity ramped-up when the prices declined in the opposite, but we continue to believe in the stock. We continue to be -- and we'll continue to be opportunistic.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just as a follow-up, I know you guys mentioned in the pre-recorded call expanding into some of the local markets. I think Poland was the one you mentioned. Just wondering the strategic rationale for that type of investment in a smaller mark
componenttext: Okay. And then just as a follow-up, I know you guys mentioned in the pre-recorded call expanding into some of the local markets. I think Poland was the one you mentioned. Just wondering the strategic rationale for that type of investment in a smaller market versus maybe some of your key geographic centers on the distribution front.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's a question of resources being taken away from some of the bigger markets because of our initiatives in a smaller one. I think we have always felt that part of the competitive edge we have is our presence in all these different markets.
componenttext: Well, I think it's a question of resources being taken away from some of the bigger markets because of our initiatives in a smaller one. I think we have always felt that part of the competitive edge we have is our presence in all these different markets. And for us, Poland is also a -- one of our operations and servicing centers for Europe, and we have a lot of employees that have a strong presence there. And it is a growing middle class in that market. And you take markets like a Taiwan that, for us, years ago, somebody would have said, "Why are you bothering with that?" But they can become very meaningful if you have an early dominant position. So it's not taking away any resources for us. It's just continuing to build out that retail capability where it makes sense. And you add it all up, and it can be very meaningful.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, on your -- the pre-recorded call, you just mentioned as the market rebounded, both performance and redemptions were showing signs of improvement. I just wanted to get some color on what you saw. And then, I think, sometimes, when you look at the 1-y
componenttext: Greg, on your -- the pre-recorded call, you just mentioned as the market rebounded, both performance and redemptions were showing signs of improvement. I just wanted to get some color on what you saw. And then, I think, sometimes, when you look at the 1-year and the 3-year performance, yes, you've mentioned when some of the larger funds are maybe just under the 50 percentile. So I just wanted to get any color on the larger funds, if they're kind of approaching that threshold to see the performance start to pick up.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think it is significant because I would look at the first 2 months of this last quarter as -- in a risk off environment, where it was -- the underperformance was getting worse every day. And just the last 6, 7 weeks, it's been probably the
componenttext:
Yes, I mean, I think it is significant because I would look at the first 2 months of this last quarter as -- in a risk off environment, where it was -- the underperformance was getting worse every day. And just the last 6, 7 weeks, it's been probably the best overall performance. And we talked about some of the concentrated exposures that we have overall as a firm. But I think, that, to me, it's almost also a leading indicator to the market, where we're saying, "Hey, it's been 10 years of this growth value cycle, and all of a sudden, value is starting to outperform." And you look at even emerging markets that had a better quarter. Value was up 7.5% and growth was up 3.3%. 
So you have, I think, the turnaround and what people have been looking for, whether it's currencies doing better, a broad oil, obviously, rebounding, and that affects probably 4 major groups’ performance right now with the energy exposure and also the high-yield exposure and income fund. I think all of that can turn pretty quickly. I don't know exactly which ones are right. I didn't -- I haven't looked at that to say, the 3-year number, who is within 2 percentage points or that. But I think the more important number is the market kind of gets the drivers for our bigger funds. And I think for the first time in a while, we're getting some wind behind us as far as the relative performance goes.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And you can you just, Ken, a quick follow-up. Just on the impairment, I think you mentioned there was maybe an offset. I just wanted to try to understand maybe what the net impact was on maybe the G&A line, just to understand from what to build off. And then I think you also mentioned about $20 million in performance fees. So I know those are hard to predict, but maybe just in terms of locks or when you typically realize those, the outlook there.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Maybe it's better to so just give you what we're thinking about in terms of G&A going forward. We do think that, that line is going to come down a little bit. So we're not expecting a lot of upward pressure there, keeping in mind that there's a lot
componenttext: Sure. Maybe it's better to so just give you what we're thinking about in terms of G&A going forward. We do think that, that line is going to come down a little bit. So we're not expecting a lot of upward pressure there, keeping in mind that there's a lot of market-driven items that go through that line. So it's assuming a flat market. We just generally expect for the remainder of the year for that expense to come down from where it's been in the last 2 quarters. So I mean, I'm not avoiding your question. It's just that I don't want to, like, waste all the time with in and out accounting details. But generally speaking, we're thinking for G&A and other to come down a little bit from where it's been the last 2 quarters for the rest of the year.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just on the performance fees?

componenttextpreview: Sorry. Yes, the performance fees, they -- yes, they are hard to predict. And they're, in fact, worth $20 million. If I think about it in terms of seasonality, typically, we might have a little bump-up next quarter. So I mean, it wouldn't be unusual for us
componenttext: Sorry. Yes, the performance fees, they -- yes, they are hard to predict. And they're, in fact, worth $20 million. If I think about it in terms of seasonality, typically, we might have a little bump-up next quarter. So I mean, it wouldn't be unusual for us to see some performance fees next quarter. And then the fourth quarter, typically, we don't have too much.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Harris with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Harris with Wells Fargo.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: A larger question -- big-picture question, I guess, on the flows. If you look at this quarter relative to last, things got a little worse, but we've talked about some of the drivers, the institutional impact and so on. But also, I guess there's another im
componenttext: A larger question -- big-picture question, I guess, on the flows. If you look at this quarter relative to last, things got a little worse, but we've talked about some of the drivers, the institutional impact and so on. But also, I guess there's another impact, and that's the market selling off as much as it did in the first part of the quarter. And so I'm wondering, I know this is probably really hard to gauge or frame up, but how much impact do you guys think that had on the flows? And I guess, what I'm getting at is if we sort of didn't have this many blow-up in the market, might the flow picture have looked even better than actually what occurred?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it would. I mean, I don't think there's any question. It was -- when the markets sell off to a 10% down through the first couple of months, that -- in, generally, what is a very strong month is January. So I -- it's always very hard to say w
componenttext: Well, I think it would. I mean, I don't think there's any question. It was -- when the markets sell off to a 10% down through the first couple of months, that -- in, generally, what is a very strong month is January. So I -- it's always very hard to say what would it mean, what would the number look like, but certainly, it definitely had an impact, and especially, as I said, for us. I mean, the positions that we had and with the dollar, oil and energy, value growth, everything kind of moving the wrong way for the first couple of months, that didn't help in the key areas where we have the largest assets. And we've seen the impact, and redemptions were actually a little bit lower for the quarter, which is kind of counterintuitive a little bit, but gross sales dropped quite a bit. And that's what generally happens in that -- when you get in that really volatile period.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
