componenttext: Well, I think part of it was just the high-yield exposure. And for us, having a fair amount of assets in the high-yield area and the overexposure to energy there, I mean, that led to some of the outflows.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Bedell with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Bedell with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe Greg, just go back to the $130 billion of assets that you said were at risk from the Department of Labor perspective. If you could just stratify the 401(k) part of that. I think we were estimating less than $20 billion of that would be 401(k). And t
componenttext: Maybe Greg, just go back to the $130 billion of assets that you said were at risk from the Department of Labor perspective. If you could just stratify the 401(k) part of that. I think we were estimating less than $20 billion of that would be 401(k). And then if the rest of that is IRA-related, are you just looking at the accounts that are with brokers in that regard? So would IRA assets be higher than that overall? And then is there -- to any extent you think pricing dynamics might change in a post-DOL world, would that influence some decisions, longer-term decisions, on changing pricing structures in your funds, including 12b-1s?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, as I've said, I wish we had an exact number because it's a little bit hard to collect. And we did our best to collect from various sources. And I think the 401(k) specific number, which mostly is investment-only business, is about $31 billion
componenttext: Yes. I mean, as I've said, I wish we had an exact number because it's a little bit hard to collect. And we did our best to collect from various sources. And I think the 401(k) specific number, which mostly is investment-only business, is about $31 billion, $30 billion, somewhere in that range. So it's -- and IRAs are probably in the $70 billion to $100 billion range, I guess, is our best guesstimate there. And I think when you say it, it -- I wouldn't say it's at risk. I mean, I think, there's clearly -- it means there's going to be some changes in how they're serviced and how we service and how we deliver through the adviser community, and still a lot of work to be done there. We have the share classes already in place that are being used today, and some of that could move to those types of classes. We think the net result will be -- there will be more motion of money, and we want to make sure, first and foremost, that we're doing everything with our advisers to make sure that the burden, we can help them manage this huge change.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful color. And then, I think, Greg, on the last quarter particularly, you mentioned there were some larger variable annuity accounts that still were doing allocation changes. And I thought you said there was one that looked like it was suscepti
componenttext: That's helpful color. And then, I think, Greg, on the last quarter particularly, you mentioned there were some larger variable annuity accounts that still were doing allocation changes. And I thought you said there was one that looked like it was susceptible to coming in that -- I don't think they came in the -- correct me if I'm wrong, but did that come in the -- this quarter? Or is that something that still remains a potential redemption?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That got moved back for a while. I think probably 6 to 9 months from hitting this quarter. So we'll keep you posted when we get better color. But it's still -- I think still hanging out there.
componenttext: Yes. That got moved back for a while. I think probably 6 to 9 months from hitting this quarter. So we'll keep you posted when we get better color. But it's still -- I think still hanging out there.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Alex Blostein with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Alex Blostein with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So one more on the DOL, if I may. So speaking through -- obviously, the rule is still fresh, and I'm assuming we're all kind of collecting information from various distribution channels on how things will continue. But when you take a step back, the $100-
componenttext: So one more on the DOL, if I may. So speaking through -- obviously, the rule is still fresh, and I'm assuming we're all kind of collecting information from various distribution channels on how things will continue. But when you take a step back, the $100-plus billion, as I'm assuming it's grandfathered and obviously because the sales already occurred. But taking a step back, do you guys think performance will be a much bigger kind of point of influence on the way financial advisers decide how to allocate assets from here? And I guess, the reason I'm asking is if a fund underperforms for a brief period of time, is there greater risk for redemptions other than the new contract versus what we've experienced in the past?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I just think it's early to speculate on those types of thoughts. And obviously, it'd be nice to have clear rules. And here, we don't, in a lot of cases, the suitability and standard and how it's enforced and risks in how advice is delivered. And I
componenttext: I mean, I just think it's early to speculate on those types of thoughts. And obviously, it'd be nice to have clear rules. And here, we don't, in a lot of cases, the suitability and standard and how it's enforced and risks in how advice is delivered. And I think a lot of that has to be vetted and figured out. And a lot of legal fees to get there. And then you're still going to have some exposure in doing it. So even the question of figuring out performance and what time period is the right one, and at the end of the day, anybody can question an underperforming fund versus an index during any given period. And I think those are the questions that we have to somehow address. I think, at the end of the day, a lot of it is always performance-driven. And more than ever, today, you have more consultants involved in the selection of the platform. So I think that has been in place for a while. And regardless of a fiduciary rule, I think that was just the trend where a lot of the 401(k) plans having strong kind of consultants helping pick the options, I think, that, that performance will always be critical.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then, Ken, just some follow-up on expenses. You guys have done a good job maintaining margins at the current levels and keeping expenses well-managed despite the severance and a few other onetimers kind of running through the numbers. Just
componenttext: All right. And then, Ken, just some follow-up on expenses. You guys have done a good job maintaining margins at the current levels and keeping expenses well-managed despite the severance and a few other onetimers kind of running through the numbers. Just curious if you were to kind of strip all that out and say, "Okay, the baseline is maybe a little bit over $2 billion for the year," how much more room do you guys have to drive the nondistribution expenses lower into the next 12 months or so, assuming markets are flat?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we're at the point -- I think there's room. I think there's room to drive the expenses down more in a number of different areas. Kind of the -- what's left, though, is a little bit more complicated to sift through and come up with definitive
componenttext: Yes, I think we're at the point -- I think there's room. I think there's room to drive the expenses down more in a number of different areas. Kind of the -- what's left, though, is a little bit more complicated to sift through and come up with definitive plans. So it's going to take a little bit longer to execute those cost savings than the ones we've done so far. And -- but there's -- but that doesn't mean that there's not more room to trim expenses. It's just going to be harder to see that impact in the P&L in the short term. It’s going to take longer.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Cyprys from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Cyprys from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wondering if you could elaborate a little bit more just on your last point on some of those additional expense savings that could come through, that could take a little bit longer, what some of them might be. I think in the past, I mean, you referred
componenttext: Just wondering if you could elaborate a little bit more just on your last point on some of those additional expense savings that could come through, that could take a little bit longer, what some of them might be. I think in the past, I mean, you referred to potentially greater outsourcing. Just any updates on that? And just generally, how you're thinking about additional action that you can take on the expense side.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's more just looking at the way we do things and challenging our business processes that may have been set up when the business environment was different and just seeing if there's ways we can leverage technology to do things smarter and better
componenttext: I think it's more just looking at the way we do things and challenging our business processes that may have been set up when the business environment was different and just seeing if there's ways we can leverage technology to do things smarter and better and more efficiently and gain more scale. And when you start, that might -- that's the point I'm trying to make. When you start to take that approach, it gets a bit more challenging and time-consuming to go through and vet. But those are the type of things. So specific lines of business perhaps, specific functions, just are we -- is our processes best-in-class right now or can they be improved? That's what we're looking at.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And then just as a follow-up, just turning to M&A. Just curious how active the dialogue has been on the M&A side. And to what extent have you gotten close on a deal? And if that's the case, sort of what's been the hang-up? And if you could j
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And then just as a follow-up, just turning to M&A. Just curious how active the dialogue has been on the M&A side. And to what extent have you gotten close on a deal? And if that's the case, sort of what's been the hang-up? And if you could just talk more broadly as to your M&A strategy. What sort of AUM or deal value magnitude do you think makes the most sense and characteristics that you're looking for right now?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you know there's different ways of looking at M&A. You can -- I mean, we never start with, okay, we need an AUM target so let's look at targets that have that assets under management and consolidate. It's more of a strategic-driven approach. But tha
componenttext: Well, you know there's different ways of looking at M&A. You can -- I mean, we never start with, okay, we need an AUM target so let's look at targets that have that assets under management and consolidate. It's more of a strategic-driven approach. But that, you have to marry with what the supply is and what the targets bring to the table. So every one -- every single deal that we look for the strategic rationale tends to be bespoke and adjusted for that target. So very difficult to generalize, like, in terms of the AUM targets or specifics.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just on the activity of the dialogue, have you gotten close on anything? And what's sort of been the hang-up, if you have?
componenttext: Okay. And just on the activity of the dialogue, have you gotten close on anything? And what's sort of been the hang-up, if you have?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, we have dedicated people that are out there looking at the industry. And I wouldn't say anything’s been close, and we probably wouldn't mention that anyway. But we're going to continue to look. And as we said on the last call, it continues to be
componenttext: I mean, we have dedicated people that are out there looking at the industry. And I wouldn't say anything’s been close, and we probably wouldn't mention that anyway. But we're going to continue to look. And as we said on the last call, it continues to be a priority with the offshore cash to utilize that in a way that enhances shareholder value. And that's really what we're trying to do.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And looking back, if -- there's one common theme for why deals weren't done. It tended to be cultural fit.
componenttext: Okay. And looking back, if -- there's one common theme for why deals weren't done. It tended to be cultural fit.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Eric Berg with RBC.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Eric Berg with RBC.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the area of expenses, or in the area of expenses, would you say that if the equity market weren't this volatile as it has been, and if equity prices were higher, not off where they are compared with a year ago, would you still say that given the state
componenttext: On the area of expenses, or in the area of expenses, would you say that if the equity market weren't this volatile as it has been, and if equity prices were higher, not off where they are compared with a year ago, would you still say that given the state of the business, what's going on in your industry, that there would still be a need to lower expenses?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there would be perhaps more of a desire than -- or a want than a need, but we would still focus on that. And I think that, that's a lesson that we've learned through the last 2 downturns is that it's human nature, when times are good, to kind of r
componenttext: I think there would be perhaps more of a desire than -- or a want than a need, but we would still focus on that. And I think that, that's a lesson that we've learned through the last 2 downturns is that it's human nature, when times are good, to kind of relax the purse strings and do things, do the nice-to-haves. But I think as a firm, we've grown up and realized that we need to be disciplined so that we don't get into those situations where we have to have massive layoffs or something in the downturn and disrupt the business. So...

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: But I would also add. I mean, your question, just beyond what are the obvious issues the active manager faces in today's marketplace with -- and changes in the distribution model and regulatory environment even in a robust environment, you'd probably, yes
componenttext: But I would also add. I mean, your question, just beyond what are the obvious issues the active manager faces in today's marketplace with -- and changes in the distribution model and regulatory environment even in a robust environment, you'd probably, yes, be looking for more efficiencies, but I'd also say you don't cut your way to prosperity. And we have always felt like there are times when we have to continue to invest, to be strategic, to do M&A, to bring out new products. I mean, I think it's a changing world. And just trying to cut your way to maintaining margins, you'll be out of business at some point.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if I could just have a little discussion with you, following up on the matter of share classes and the DOL. I find it almost a full-time job keeping track of share classes. A, B, C, R, L, I, adviser class, investor class, admiral class. It goes on and
componenttext: And if I could just have a little discussion with you, following up on the matter of share classes and the DOL. I find it almost a full-time job keeping track of share classes. A, B, C, R, L, I, adviser class, investor class, admiral class. It goes on and on. The lexicon differs by company. I'm wondering whether one of you could maybe make it a little bit easier for us by offering any general comments you think hold true as to what is going to happen here. In other words, are there -- can we say just as a general statement that irrespective of what the share class is called, A, B, C, R, L, I, whatever, that lower expense ratio share classes will be doing better as a result of DOL? That's what I'm sort of looking for, some general guidance on how to think about this.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think that's right. I don't -- I think there's more pressure, especially for newer business, to utilize what we call an R6 class. But again, I think it -- there's still a lot of work to be done before you can draw any conclusions on how fas
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think that's right. I don't -- I think there's more pressure, especially for newer business, to utilize what we call an R6 class. But again, I think it -- there's still a lot of work to be done before you can draw any conclusions on how fast that'll move. And certainly, you can conclude that the lower end of the market will be more passive robo and less people-intensive or advice-driven. That's just -- that -- those conclusions you can kind of draw. How quickly the pace moves to specific classes, I think, as you said, there's a lot of work to be done in the meantime before you can just say x percent is going to be there at this -- by this date.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of John Dunn with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of John Dunn with Evercore ISI.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sitting in for Glenn, Glenn Schorr. Can you guys give us a little more color on the composition of the sales and distribution fee line? Maybe what's the recurring piece versus the 12b-1, et cetera?
componenttext: I'm sitting in for Glenn, Glenn Schorr. Can you guys give us a little more color on the composition of the sales and distribution fee line? Maybe what's the recurring piece versus the 12b-1, et cetera?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can. So I think it was -- let me get your reference there. I think that we included a slide -- I think it was 27-ish or something; it's in the back --that kind of breaks down. So there is a component of the -- of those 2 lines, the distribution, re
componenttext: Yes, I can. So I think it was -- let me get your reference there. I think that we included a slide -- I think it was 27-ish or something; it's in the back --that kind of breaks down. So there is a component of the -- of those 2 lines, the distribution, revenue and expense that is sales-based. And we've talked a lot about what percentage of the assets are sales-based is very small. And then the percentage that's asset-based. And so -- yes, part of the reason that the net line has been going down is because of the assets under management had been going down. So if you look forward a couple of quarters, I would expect that the net number would be a little bit less than it has been. I think it's been -- I'm going to guess, like $115 million, something like that. And then probably, it might go -- we're thinking now, flat markets might go down to like $105 million net per quarter.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Patrick Davitt with Autonomous.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Patrick Davitt with Autonomous.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: With the understanding that DOL is really focused on the relationship between the broker and the client, is -- do you guys think there's any risk of increased expense load at the manufacturer level, at your level, as a result?
componenttext: With the understanding that DOL is really focused on the relationship between the broker and the client, is -- do you guys think there's any risk of increased expense load at the manufacturer level, at your level, as a result?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think there's an increase in just your -- I don't know if I'd call it on your -- specifically, on your share class, but certainly, a potential for an increase in how we did business versus how we're going to do business and in terms of compliance
componenttext: Well, I think there's an increase in just your -- I don't know if I'd call it on your -- specifically, on your share class, but certainly, a potential for an increase in how we did business versus how we're going to do business and in terms of compliance costs and just -- and how we assist the adviser. I think all of that is still. We have a close partnership with many have been delivering this. And a lot of that has to be done, but there's no question that there's a major cost burden of compliance to -- between all of the disclosures and sign-offs and -- that has to be done that will increase costs.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is any of that in your expectations right now?
componenttext: Is any of that in your expectations right now?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think it's too early to try to budget that or figure out how that's going to be worked. But I think we would anticipate that based on what -- everything we've seen.
componenttext: No. I think it's too early to try to budget that or figure out how that's going to be worked. But I think we would anticipate that based on what -- everything we've seen.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Okay, and just one last one. It looks like, for some of the larger funds that have been underperforming, that short-term performance is starting to bleed into the 3- and 5-year numbers. Any large platforms or consultants that may be more focused on t
componenttext: Yes. Okay, and just one last one. It looks like, for some of the larger funds that have been underperforming, that short-term performance is starting to bleed into the 3- and 5-year numbers. Any large platforms or consultants that may be more focused on those longer-term numbers that you could be worried about right now?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you always worry about that. But as I said earlier, I think what people -- the -- if you can understand that performance in relation to the market, simple, whether it's value growth or different exposures in portfolios, and then look at more near
componenttext: I think you always worry about that. But as I said earlier, I think what people -- the -- if you can understand that performance in relation to the market, simple, whether it's value growth or different exposures in portfolios, and then look at more near term, and just I don't think I've seen a better 6-week period of relative performance for our flagship holdings. And so that's going to bleed in pretty quickly, too, when you have 500, 800 basis points of outperformance in a 6-week period. That's going to help pretty quickly. And I think that's the momentum, certainly, with Templeton Energy dollar. More recently, some financials. All of that moves the numbers pretty quickly. So I would be more encouraged about the 6-week trend than I would worrying about bleeding into the 3 and 5 because that's going to be more important. And as I said, that will bleed in, too, pretty quickly.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Bedell with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Bedell with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just -- I think you mentioned, either Ken or Greg, on the pre-recorded call about the fee rate being different on a simple monthly average versus an average daily average. I think you said a basis point differential. I just want to sort of get color on th
componenttext: Just -- I think you mentioned, either Ken or Greg, on the pre-recorded call about the fee rate being different on a simple monthly average versus an average daily average. I think you said a basis point differential. I just want to sort of get color on the go-forward fee rate given the mix. Is that then, therefore, fairly stable with that with the fourth quarter? Or do you see that lower?

componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, it's a great question, and I don't -- I couldn't tell you how much in terms of quantifying risk. I think we did our best in a -- for us, in a world where we have omnibus and assets we don't see to come up with fair guesstimate around how much
componenttext: Yes. I mean, it's a great question, and I don't -- I couldn't tell you how much in terms of quantifying risk. I think we did our best in a -- for us, in a world where we have omnibus and assets we don't see to come up with fair guesstimate around how much is in 401(k) and how much is an IRAs, and we didn't include VA [ph]. That number's probably $180 billion of exposed assets, breaking out between about $50 billion in VAs and $28 billion in 401(k) investment only, and the rest in IRAs. So I don't think there's a big -- certainly, there's more risk that an average account because of the changes that are being imposed on the industry, but I don't know how I could possibly quantify that right now, Bill.

Good morning, and welcome to Franklin Resources' Earnings Conference Call for the Quarter Ended June 30, 2016.
Statements made in this commentary regarding Franklin Resources Inc. which are not historical facts are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements involve a number of known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from any future results expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements.
These and other risks, uncertainties and other important factors are described in more detail in Franklin's recent filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including in the risk factors and MD&A sections of Franklin's most recent Form 10-K and 10-Q filings.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Matt, and I'll be your co-operator today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. I'd now like to turn the call over to Franklin Resources Chairman and CEO, Mr. Greg Johnson. Mr. Johnson, you may begi
componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Matt, and I'll be your co-operator today. [Operator Instructions] 
As a reminder, this call is being recorded. I'd now like to turn the call over to Franklin Resources Chairman and CEO, Mr. Greg Johnson. Mr. Johnson, you may begin.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, hello and good morning, everyone. We appreciate you joining Ken Lewis, our CFO, and me for this call today. The good news that our results are pretty straightforward for this quarter. So hopefully, the commentary we made available earlier this morni
componenttext:
Well, hello and good morning, everyone. We appreciate you joining Ken Lewis, our CFO, and me for this call today. The good news that our results are pretty straightforward for this quarter. So hopefully, the commentary we made available earlier this morning provided much what you're looking for.
To quickly recap, although we experienced another quarter of net outflows, we did see encouraging signs with redemptions continuing to slow and improving investment performance, particularly Franklin Income Fund that as of July ranks in the top quartile against peers for the trailing 1-year period.
Financial results and capital management were solid as operating income increased 11%, and the trailing 12 months payout was $2 billion.
Now we'll be happy to take your questions.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our first question comes from Glenn Schorr from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our first question comes from Glenn Schorr from Evercore ISI.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess a question on both sales and redemptions. On the sales side, it's good to see an increase in international sales for the first time in 2 years. I'm curious what the biggest drivers of that are. And then on the redemption side, I guess it's a simil
componenttext: I guess a question on both sales and redemptions. On the sales side, it's good to see an increase in international sales for the first time in 2 years. I'm curious what the biggest drivers of that are. And then on the redemption side, I guess it's a similar question. It's a really big drop in redemptions and curious if you think that was a point in time or we had a different level of redemption because that can make a really big difference.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Sorry. Sales outside of the U.S.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think a couple of things. I think the global bond, which is a bigger driver of flows outside of the U.S., we did see an improvement, significant improvement in redemptions, and that led to the major improvement in net flows. I think the -- last quarter,
componenttext: I think a couple of things. I think the global bond, which is a bigger driver of flows outside of the U.S., we did see an improvement, significant improvement in redemptions, and that led to the major improvement in net flows. I think the -- last quarter, we did have some lumpy redemptions in that number versus this quarter. And I still think that's the one area that continues to be under pressure where we are seeing improvements in a lot of other areas in terms of flows, but the global bond, that's the one that continues to be under pressure. And I think if you look at the other area that I would call out just in terms of flows, because I think it is a little bit confusing, is the global equity net flows that increased, and redemptions increased there. And I want to point to there were 3 lumpy one-time institutional redemptions within that, that totaled $3.5 billion out of global equity. So otherwise on the retail side, it's an improving trend there as well.

componenttext: Okay. And then you mentioned the launch of LibertyQ and LibertyShares, and you talked about 3 multi-factors funds, I think. But can you just expand a little bit more on what channels you're going to be selling that through and what kind of uptake we should expect, say, over the next year?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I wouldn't -- I think we have moderate expectations within the next year as far as flows going into that. I think we have made a major commitment to that segment as far as resources and exposure and marketing dollars to get the message and brand o
componenttext: I mean, I wouldn't -- I think we have moderate expectations within the next year as far as flows going into that. I think we have made a major commitment to that segment as far as resources and exposure and marketing dollars to get the message and brand out there, but it will take a little bit of time. And right now, they've been up and running, doing well, performing well, and it's a matter of just getting on platforms. Now we can do that probably faster than a lot of firms because of the relationships hopefully that we have built with our broker dealers and advisers out there and hopefully get some demand putting them on. But again, it's a start for us in the new segment, and it will take a bit of time as these records get out there. I hope it won't take 3 years, but we are getting a lot of calls and a lot of interest on them. And I think in the meantime, we'll also look at expanding the lineup beyond just [indiscernible]

componenttext: There's about $8 million of severance in this quarter. And then looking forward -- and it's dependent upon a one-time item that may or may not hit next quarter. But inclusive of that, we do expect to see increases next quarter in most of the line items. I think comp would be more or less flat, but the G&A will be up. So we're expecting possibly a charge related to the windup of U.K. benefit plan, and that should be in the neighborhood of $25 million. It may hit next quarter, it may hit the quarter after that.

componenttextpreview: This is Will filling in for Ken. Cash outside the U.S. continues to grow. What are your latest thoughts on utilizing cash outside the U.S.? How realistic are investments M&A to utilize the cash? And how much are you placing on new administration performin
componenttext: This is Will filling in for Ken. Cash outside the U.S. continues to grow. What are your latest thoughts on utilizing cash outside the U.S.? How realistic are investments M&A to utilize the cash? And how much are you placing on new administration performing the tax code?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And that last point is a key point in the discussion. There's been -- it's a current topic in Washington. It's been a current topic. It continues to kind of move a step forward then stop, move a step forward then stop, so we're keeping an eye on that
componenttext: Yes. And that last point is a key point in the discussion. There's been -- it's a current topic in Washington. It's been a current topic. It continues to kind of move a step forward then stop, move a step forward then stop, so we're keeping an eye on that. We think -- well, the consensus we hear is probably sometime in 2017, there might be something that involves corporate tax reform. And I would point out that was a long time ago but 2005 when they had that, they can look to see what we did there. So depending on -- it all depends on what we think is the best long-term interest of shareholders, what they do. But in 2005, we did repatriate some money, and so that's not an unreasonable thing to expect, but it depends on what the law is. The cash continues to grow, and we're just planning to continue our capital management strategy that we've been doing over the last 2 [ph] years. And now essentially, our payout ratio is more than cash-generated or net income, and that means we're using U.S. cash, but U.S. cash is still healthy number, so we don't expect any material change in our strategy.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would just add, I think my sense is meetings in Washington that you are getting momentum on both sides for tax reform. It's clearly Paul Ryan and something that he feels very strongly about. So obviously, we're in election cycle right now. When we g
componenttext: And I would just add, I think my sense is meetings in Washington that you are getting momentum on both sides for tax reform. It's clearly Paul Ryan and something that he feels very strongly about. So obviously, we're in election cycle right now. When we get past that, we'll have a lot more clarity in seeing how the House and Senate and presidency looks, but we are still hopeful that that's something that's coming. But I think in the meantime, as we've said before, the M&A probability and certainly with some of the currency chips in Europe and the sterling make M&A activity that much more attractive to something that we have had on our wish list. So I would say, again, as I said in prior calls, that that's the most probable area for us.

componenttext: I think as I alluded to in the prior question, I think next quarter we should see an uptick in probably all the lines, the most notable one would be G&A for the charge that I talked about. Comp, I think could be flat. It could even be down a little bit next quarter. That's what we're looking for, for next quarter.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Carrier from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Carrier from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, just given you had more time go through the DOL new rule and have discussions with the distributors with the industry, just wanted you to get your take on how you feel like Franklin is positioned. And for some of the potential changes, whether it's
componenttext: Greg, just given you had more time go through the DOL new rule and have discussions with the distributors with the industry, just wanted you to get your take on how you feel like Franklin is positioned. And for some of the potential changes, whether it's 12b-1 or positions, how Franklin will try to position for the retail channel going forward.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think it, obviously, has been the area of greatest focus with our distributors. Certainly, since the announcement, I would say trying to make sense of the 1,100 pages. It's a little bit like a Rubik's cube where we're making progress and realize we
componenttext: Yes. I think it, obviously, has been the area of greatest focus with our distributors. Certainly, since the announcement, I would say trying to make sense of the 1,100 pages. It's a little bit like a Rubik's cube where we're making progress and realize we've got 2 other problems. So I think we're getting some clarity around where it's heading. We talked about a standard class of shares. That's something that within the best interest contract can work. I think we're seeing some broker-dealers committed to doing the brokerage side and others saying it's not something they're going to do. I think the initial reaction that you're going to have a ton of money moving into the advisory side, I think once we really look at what that means, there's other implications of the rule that may mean monies that are held that paid a front-end sales charge should stay where they are and not move to the advisory because that would actually increase cost. So I think we are making a lot more sense of the rule. I think the net results are also that there'll be less funds on platforms. We're seeing that, again, more of that consultant gatekeeper approach and narrowing the funds that any broker-dealer follows. So I think that puts pressure on smaller funds out there to get distribution and ultimately, less advisers. I think you'll see more retirements as this transition will be too much. And then just issues, simple things that sound -- again, I mean having a robo adviser for a small account, but can you have your own ETFs within that robo advise under the rule? I mean these are the kind of problems that I think are coming up. And obviously, the lawyers are trying to clarify that, and we're working with many in the meantime. But I think the net effect for us is have some kind of standardized pricing. We -- obviously, we don't want to have 100 different pricing structures out there and are trying to come to some new standards that works for most of our -- most broker-dealers and advisers, and that's really where we are.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. Just as a follow-up. So the quarter, there is a lot the volatile events in markets all over the place, but we've got some improvement and you mentioned July. When you look at those redemption trends in terms of the improvement, was i
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. Just as a follow-up. So the quarter, there is a lot the volatile events in markets all over the place, but we've got some improvement and you mentioned July. When you look at those redemption trends in terms of the improvement, was it pretty consistent throughout and maybe into July? Or are you starting to see more improvement, particularly given some of the performance trends that you mentioned?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think we're always careful how to talk about flows beyond the quarter. I think the big one for us that, as I stated before, that tends to snap back of the fastest is the Franklin Income Fund which you look at that category just 2 quarters a
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think we're always careful how to talk about flows beyond the quarter. I think the big one for us that, as I stated before, that tends to snap back of the fastest is the Franklin Income Fund which you look at that category just 2 quarters ago, we had a hybrid $5.6 billion in net redemptions and last quarter, $2.2 billion. So I think that, that trend, we hope, will continue as people the -- even in the last quarter, the 3-year number or the 5-year number actually improved to back to the second quartile. And hopefully in another -- the end of this month, hopefully, we'll be back in the second quartile for the 1 year. And as we stated earlier, we're at the 80% [ph] year-to-date. So that's a pretty big recovery there I think that that's where you'll see the improvement flows. I think we have some good stories as well on the equity side with one of our largest funds at Franklin Rising Dividend funds, $17 billion, $18 billion fund doing extremely well right now and getting a lot of attention for its performance, which is first quartile for the 1 year, second quartile for 3 and 5. Franklin Growth also very strong. So I think those are areas where we could see a turnaround in flows. And I think as long as the market is stable, the other trends should continue as well.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Dan Fannon from Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Dan Fannon from Jefferies.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the prerecorded call, you talked about a platform loss. I think you mentioned that at other points in time the last 12 months, and I think insurance was an area of weakness a few quarters ago. I was just curious if there's like a channel of any consist
componenttext: On the prerecorded call, you talked about a platform loss. I think you mentioned that at other points in time the last 12 months, and I think insurance was an area of weakness a few quarters ago. I was just curious if there's like a channel of any consistencies and some of these platforms in which you are seeing market share losses being taken off or is it just kind of performance-specific?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the main driver to what we talked about a platform change was one of our large broker-dealers that we worked with building it in-house sub-advice platform and was moving some assets, and it was $1.1 billion out of our mutual discovery fund. So tha
componenttext: I think the main driver to what we talked about a platform change was one of our large broker-dealers that we worked with building it in-house sub-advice platform and was moving some assets, and it was $1.1 billion out of our mutual discovery fund. So that's a one-off event. That's not performance-related that drove that. We did have -- I think the other one on the -- just in general, I talked about the varied annuity business and how that's going to change. And certainly, with the DOL, we'll have more changes. But we have seen some groups get out of that business, so they're really going to wind down. So it kind of changes what they're looking for on their platform. And we, with our solutions group, we're doing our best to transition those assets. But they're the ones still you have a pipeline of redemptions over the next, say, 2 years as those groups are transitioning out of that business. So I would guesstimate that you probably have $5 billion-plus in assets over the next 2 years that will transition. Hopefully, we can capture some of that, but it will go out of the traditional funds into a lower fee type solution to meet whatever liability they have. So those would be the big changes that have driven the lumpier redemptions, and we think will continue to create some headwinds in the next 2 years on the VA side.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Brennan Hawken from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Brennan Hawken from UBS.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Chris Harris from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Chris Harris from Wells Fargo.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in your prepared commentary, you did talk a little bit about Franklin's history being able to adapt to the changes in the industry, and that's certainly well-documented. When you think about the situation we're in now, this period certainly feels a lot
componenttext: So in your prepared commentary, you did talk a little bit about Franklin's history being able to adapt to the changes in the industry, and that's certainly well-documented. When you think about the situation we're in now, this period certainly feels a lot different just because it appears like you have a lot of investors out there that just don't want to own active funds or at least in uncertain areas, anyway. So I guess what we're wondering here is what's you're kind of long-term strategy to manage around of that or manage that type of an environment. And we know you guys have K2 and the ETF initiative going on, but that just doesn't quite seem like enough. So any commentary you can give in that regard would be helpful.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, again, as we've stated in prior calls, continuing to look at alternatives, continuing to look at solutions where we can add value outside of this market traditional beta, as I again stated before, to come into the market and offer passive t
componenttext: Well, I think, again, as we've stated in prior calls, continuing to look at alternatives, continuing to look at solutions where we can add value outside of this market traditional beta, as I again stated before, to come into the market and offer passive today doesn't make a whole lot of sense for us as we've seen the raise to the bottom in fees continue to drive down close to 2 basis points. So that doesn't seem like an attractive alternative. I think we also believe that active -- that there are forces at work over the last 5, 10 years that have contributed to the passive strategies. And once active outperforms and that tends to be in a more of a rising rate environment, historically, I think that conventional wisdom could shift pretty quickly, and that's something we firmly believe. But in the meantime, we have built out our solutions. We're looking at our multi-asset capabilities. We're getting a lot of interest in that, and that's just another area how we can add value to investors by combining different asset classes over time. So that's going to be an important growth area. Whether it's real estate alternatives, long/short hedge funds, those are all private equity things that we plan on continuing to expand outside of your traditional U.S. large cap stocks.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have -- we do -- if we know something is being redeemed, we try to call it out. I've done that on past calls. And we do have a large institutional low-fee account that was redeemed, I think, this month, about $1.2 billion, $1.3 billion in the glo
componenttext: Well, we have -- we do -- if we know something is being redeemed, we try to call it out. I've done that on past calls. And we do have a large institutional low-fee account that was redeemed, I think, this month, about $1.2 billion, $1.3 billion in the global equity area. I don't have anything to call out. I think the institutional pipeline, again, we feel like it looks good. As far as the opportunities that were identified -- have identified and RFPs that we're responding to. And I know one area that would be a new growth area for us but one that we've had excellent numbers, it could be on the Franklin global growth side and we are -- hopefully, we'll see some nice wins there over the next year.

componenttext: Okay. And that's one-time or something that's potentially can ongoing?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then just lastly, Greg, just your view. You talked a little bit about M&A and that looking a little better, given the build-up of non-U.S.  Cash. Maybe if you could talk to some more broadly about -- you've been in the industry a long tim
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then just lastly, Greg, just your view. You talked a little bit about M&A and that looking a little better, given the build-up of non-U.S.  Cash. Maybe if you could talk to some more broadly about -- you've been in the industry a long time your view of to what extent will potentially see more consolidation in the industry if active continues to underperform and product needs to get rationalized. And then from your angle, do you see yourself as more a participant in acquiring firms or combining with another large firm?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I make the -- as I stated before, I think any industry that is maturing and gets larger, you hit the point where consolidation makes sense. I mean I'm not sure we're there yet, but certainly you, have some outside forces at work that we haven't seen befor
componenttext: I make the -- as I stated before, I think any industry that is maturing and gets larger, you hit the point where consolidation makes sense. I mean I'm not sure we're there yet, but certainly you, have some outside forces at work that we haven't seen before. So I think that, that contributes. I think the other point I stated when asked about this is that it's not the easiest industry to do large mergers and consolidations with funds are, U.S. separate contracts and boards. It's very time-consuming and difficult to do mergers. So I think for us, we again are open to anything we think enhances the line of shareholder value over time. We try to build as many relationship across our industry to be able to act on things that makes sense, and that's where we are today. And I wouldn't state one way or another. I think we're always out looking on behalf of shareholders and trying to create value if that's a merger, that's an acquisition, we're open to any and all.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Alex from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Alex from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: A follow-up around expenses. This year, there's a lot of moving pieces a bunch of onetimers. Severance was a big part of that and it sounds like as we another charge with the $25 million. So all in all can you guys help us understand kind of as we look fo
componenttext: A follow-up around expenses. This year, there's a lot of moving pieces a bunch of onetimers. Severance was a big part of that and it sounds like as we another charge with the $25 million. So all in all can you guys help us understand kind of as we look for 2016 as a whole, how much of some of these onetime items when you're on expenses and I guess more importantly as we look out into next year, I guess presumably, these will not repeat, how should be start thinking about next year's expense run rate?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe that's a better approach instead of listing all the one-offs and trying to estimate what one-offs will be next year, I think we could just like take a higher view of it. So we've been talking on this call about all the changes in the industry and be
componenttext: Maybe that's a better approach instead of listing all the one-offs and trying to estimate what one-offs will be next year, I think we could just like take a higher view of it. So we've been talking on this call about all the changes in the industry and because of all that, we're continually examining all of our strategies. So if we look forward to next year we're looking at -- and I mentioned this in previous calls as well, we're looking at every facet of our business model to determine if we have in the business models and service capabilities that we need for the future, and that may include structural expense increases or decreases over the next few years. So that's kind of a long way to answer your question that we are currently looking at our cost structure, but it's a little too early to kind of give definitive guidance because some of these initiatives are multiyear. But I can tell you that based on what I know now if I look towards 2017, it looks like expenses would be flat to slightly down compared with the current year or the estimate of the current year expenses.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then I wanted to go back to the DOL discussion for a second. As you guys discussed the change among the distributors and more decision-making processing in place, more in a kind of gatekeeper way and more consolidated type of decision-
componenttext: That's helpful. And then I wanted to go back to the DOL discussion for a second. As you guys discussed the change among the distributors and more decision-making processing in place, more in a kind of gatekeeper way and more consolidated type of decision-making and I guess more centralized. What do you guys think will be the criteria for active fund placement in that environment? And I guess more importantly, how do you think you are positioned in that backdrop?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we're positioned well because the first driver is going to be assets you have that are on their books with their clients, so you're not going to eliminate those. And the other performance and risk-adjusted returns and relationship, the size of the
componenttext: I think we're positioned well because the first driver is going to be assets you have that are on their books with their clients, so you're not going to eliminate those. And the other performance and risk-adjusted returns and relationship, the size of the company, I think those are all factors. I think each firm will have their own. Clearly, we will not have every one of our funds on those lists, and it may need more consolidation of funds within our own lineup as we rationalize. And that's been an emphasis on our firm is to streamline the lineup and number of products that we're servicing. And I think in this environment that that's going to probably accelerate that process of closing some smaller funds that wouldn't get the shelf space.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. And then maybe just squeeze one more. Around the rate dynamic, it seems like at least more recently there's been a little book more leverages between domestic product versus national product, and especially given your comments about redemptions i
componenttext: Got you. And then maybe just squeeze one more. Around the rate dynamic, it seems like at least more recently there's been a little book more leverages between domestic product versus national product, and especially given your comments about redemptions in the hybrid side of the business. Is there a meaningful difference between the hybrid product domestic equity product versus the global bond and international equity product that could, given the slow trends result and actual shift in the mix in the fee rate or not very meaningful?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think that if you look at the fees across those different categories, they're actually fairly aligned. Probably the hybrid one is a little bit lower obviously than international equity, but I don't think it would have a meaningful shift in your expe
componenttext: No. I think that if you look at the fees across those different categories, they're actually fairly aligned. Probably the hybrid one is a little bit lower obviously than international equity, but I don't think it would have a meaningful shift in your expected fee rate at all.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Robert Lee from KBW.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Robert Lee from KBW.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Curious about in the alternatives business. Obviously, you have K2 and you've launched some liquid strategies, which had some early success. Could you maybe, I guess, first update us on the progress with some of your liquid alternatives? And then may be a
componenttext: Curious about in the alternatives business. Obviously, you have K2 and you've launched some liquid strategies, which had some early success. Could you maybe, I guess, first update us on the progress with some of your liquid alternatives? And then may be also your thoughts about building out a broader alternatives capability where you would be particularly interested and then maybe update us on what your current capabilities are maybe outside of K2?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the K2 is working well as planned in bringing liquid alts to the retail channel. I mean in the last year, we expended the lineup and added a long/short credit fund and a global macro fund, and I think those can be nice complements again to di
componenttext: Yes. I think the K2 is working well as planned in bringing liquid alts to the retail channel. I mean in the last year, we expended the lineup and added a long/short credit fund and a global macro fund, and I think those can be nice complements again to diversifying a portfolio. Outside of that, we have a lot of areas, whether it's a real estate and private equity, and it's really trying to build more scale within those. So I think we are looking at considering acquisitions on that side and continuing to build out our capabilities and just think it's a national extension of what we do. So I think we are open. I think as I've stated in the past, it is difficult just to go out and buy a hedge fund or buy companies that have done well in the alternative space because they are so driven by a specific person, but we are looking actively in that area. And whether, again, it's real estate private equity or traditional headphones, those are all on the table.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And maybe just a follow-up on the global bond, global fixed income, I mean you talked in the past about seeing the institutional channels a big opportunity for those strategies broadly. And can you maybe update us on that, given maybe some of the performa
componenttext: And maybe just a follow-up on the global bond, global fixed income, I mean you talked in the past about seeing the institutional channels a big opportunity for those strategies broadly. And can you maybe update us on that, given maybe some of the performance challenges in the past year that's slowed down, but where do you think that opportunity exists currently for the -- on the global bond side institutionally?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's -- the institutional market, I think they are less sensitive. And because this bond -- just to benchmark it against global bond, I think is not -- it really is more of a Global Macro-type fund, and it doesn't fit really against any one g
componenttext: Yes, I think it's -- the institutional market, I think they are less sensitive. And because this bond -- just to benchmark it against global bond, I think is not -- it really is more of a Global Macro-type fund, and it doesn't fit really against any one given category. I think the standpoint of diversifying from local currency and local sovereign debt, there is still a big appetite for that. I don't think that's changed. And I think also when people sophisticated investors look at the portfolio and look at how its it's positioned, it is very different. It does offer something very different, and that will be one of the few games in town if rates actually do go up at some point. And I think the risk certainly from the perspective of an individual country's currency depreciating at some cases, it is still very much there. So we are getting institutional interest, and that really hasn't changed. So hopefully, we'll get some significant wins in there.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And one last question if I can on the distribution, retail distribution. I mean you've talked at length as have peers about changes there, maybe approved list shrinking and a number of products having any platform moving around. At the same time, you had
componenttext: And one last question if I can on the distribution, retail distribution. I mean you've talked at length as have peers about changes there, maybe approved list shrinking and a number of products having any platform moving around. At the same time, you had a lot of new product initiatives, LibertyShares, K2, your whole broad line of traditional products. So within that kind of mix, I mean are you thinking or have you thought that there's some kind of change you need to make in terms of your own distribution capabilities? Is it shrinking it or is it changing the type of personnel, given the changing product mix? I'm just kind of curious how you feel about strategic changes in your capabilities.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that's already been happening, and it's been really an effort probably in the last 3, 5 years for us transitioning traditional retail sales force into a more institutional quality level, especially at that gatekeeper level, the people callin
componenttext: Well, I think that's already been happening, and it's been really an effort probably in the last 3, 5 years for us transitioning traditional retail sales force into a more institutional quality level, especially at that gatekeeper level, the people calling on the home office, those are really more of your traditional consultants, that kind of background there to talk about metrics that are very different from how we viewed funds, I think, in the traditional way. So that's already happening, I think, as far as even our sales force, and we made changes there over the last year, focusing specifically more on having a targeted group for the advisory side that's a little bit different again than your traditional. So we've been evolving as the market has been changing, and we will continue to do that. And hopefully, at some level, you'll get some efficiencies out of that as we get better at providing useful information on a realtime basis through digital side, which has been a big emphasis in trying to reach more advisers in a more efficient way. And I think that again as the model changes, the use of technology and information getting to advisers can create a lot of efficiencies from the traditional way that we've done it. So I think that's happening as well.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Eric Berg from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Eric Berg from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The improvement in the redemptions took place, it seems pretty much everywhere across the complex except, of course, for global equity. And I understand that there has been improvements in various significant improvements in your flagship hybrid product.
componenttext: The improvement in the redemptions took place, it seems pretty much everywhere across the complex except, of course, for global equity. And I understand that there has been improvements in various significant improvements in your flagship hybrid product. But it was also an extraordinary quarters in so many respects, what with the Brexit vote and terrorism and interest rates declining and extreme volatilities in currency. I mean it's a long list of factors that made a remarkable 3-month period. To what do you attribute this company-wide decline, not just in certain categories but company-wide decline in redemptions? That's my first question.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it -- the effect for us and again, we stated we had more exposure to energy rolled up through probably 4 different entities, and we don't do any top-down risk management each individual firm. We look at it separately. And so you had an overe
componenttext: Well, I think it -- the effect for us and again, we stated we had more exposure to energy rolled up through probably 4 different entities, and we don't do any top-down risk management each individual firm. We look at it separately. And so you had an overexposure to energy, had an overexposure to Europe. Those were trending nicely until Brexit. And even if you look at the trend in equities to quality away from more of your traditional momentum, strong balance sheets, Rising Dividends, quality earnings, those were all trends that fit nicely into our -- generally, into our philosophy with many of our equity funds. You did see an improvement in rotation happening, a rotation into value as well. And if you look at the quarter, I mean Brexit kind of hit right at the end of the quarter. So at the beginning, maybe it would be a little bit of a different story, but what we had captured a lot of good relative performance during the quarter, which unfortunately in the last couple of weeks when you had more of a risk of environment, you lost some of that which has been gained back in July. So I think it's really just looking at the flagship products for us and also munis, that's a strength area for us. Munis are very attractive in this environment and should continue to be, so I think that that's counter to what is happening and a result of a lot of the, I think, uncertainty in equity markets, money moving into munis right now. So that's another factor as well.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The second and final question I have relates to fixed income, in general, and you just touched on it a little bit, but maybe you could expand in that responding to the following questions. I have been struck that not only the fact your company is having v
componenttext: The second and final question I have relates to fixed income, in general, and you just touched on it a little bit, but maybe you could expand in that responding to the following questions. I have been struck that not only the fact your company is having very stable, not growing but very stable fixed income growth sales and so were many of your competitors. It's surprising to me, given that there is no yield and that the duration risk is very substantial good interest rates rise over the next couple of years. My question, given all that, the absent of yield, the duration, the loss of principal risk, why do you think fixed income across the industry is doing as well as it is in terms of gross inflows?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a great question, but I do think fixed income always has a place in a diversified portfolio and does reduce risk. I think you are correct that where we sit in a cycle, I think many would argue that there's a greater risk from rates going up, that's
componenttext: That's a great question, but I do think fixed income always has a place in a diversified portfolio and does reduce risk. I think you are correct that where we sit in a cycle, I think many would argue that there's a greater risk from rates going up, that's certainly the position within our Global Bond Fund. But at the end of the day, it's very hard to take a portfolio and just ignore fixed income. It -- you put a lot more risk into that given portfolio if you go 100% equities. But at the end of the day, you look at something like munis. It still has an attractive yield relative to the treasury market, certainly on an after-tax basis. And the general consensus right now, right or wrong, is that rates are not going up. So I think there's a sense of security that even with small yields, they're going to be fine for X number of years.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Pacha Davitt from Autonomous.
