componenttextpreview: Okay. And then more broadly, I know you're probably tired of talking about capital. But if we're in a situation where there is no tax holiday, either because of the continued impasse in D.C. and you can't find an M&A target, is it just the status quo, you
componenttext: Okay. And then more broadly, I know you're probably tired of talking about capital. But if we're in a situation where there is no tax holiday, either because of the continued impasse in D.C. and you can't find an M&A target, is it just the status quo, you will continue to build a cash or are there other options that you would consider if we get into that kind of situation next year?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's always other options. And I guess I would respond to that as a pretty big hypothetical there with 3 or 4 possibilities. So it's hard to predict what will happen. We just -- maybe we have like an 18-month time view when we look at these things. I t
componenttext: There's always other options. And I guess I would respond to that as a pretty big hypothetical there with 3 or 4 possibilities. So it's hard to predict what will happen. We just -- maybe we have like an 18-month time view when we look at these things. I think it's going to be status quo. We don't plan on changing anytime soon.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we don't like to feel like we have a timetable to do a big deal that you have to do something by X. And I'm a firm believer that once we get past this cycle that some form of repatriation will come through. But that doesn't mean in the meantime, t
componenttext: I think we don't like to feel like we have a timetable to do a big deal that you have to do something by X. And I'm a firm believer that once we get past this cycle that some form of repatriation will come through. But that doesn't mean in the meantime, that we're not looking at opportunities especially with some of the currency devaluation [indiscernible] .

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess on that point, you touched on a few questions ago, but your tone on M&A ebbs and flows in the last few years. What is kind of the primary reason that you have was it just something lack of businesses that really fit there is it more price? What do
componenttext: I guess on that point, you touched on a few questions ago, but your tone on M&A ebbs and flows in the last few years. What is kind of the primary reason that you have was it just something lack of businesses that really fit there is it more price? What do you think the overarching reason this?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's probably those 2 items and more. I mean we're pretty active every year looking at properties. And some of us come to us, some of us  were proactive on. And for the ones that we haven't done, it tends to be they don't really meet our criteria.
componenttext: I think it's probably those 2 items and more. I mean we're pretty active every year looking at properties. And some of us come to us, some of us  were proactive on. And for the ones that we haven't done, it tends to be they don't really meet our criteria. So quality, repeatable investment process, culture, price. Price could be an issue. It has been in some cases. As Greg mentioned earlier, it's not the easiest industry to integrate. We think about that and also a lot -- we come across situations where there's ownership structural challenges as well. So it's kind of runs the gamut of why those go through. But those are some of the things that we felt.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think like anything in life, the best ones are not for sale right now, and we're going to continue to build relationships. And I think if both firms see the benefits, then you can have a successful merger acquisition, and that's what we're hopeful
componenttext: Yes. I think like anything in life, the best ones are not for sale right now, and we're going to continue to build relationships. And I think if both firms see the benefits, then you can have a successful merger acquisition, and that's what we're hopeful for. But at the end of the day it's not -- we don't feel like that's necessary to be successful either. And I think that's an important point, too.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Cyprys from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Cyprys from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up on the M&A point. I hear you're not necessarily in the industry for M&A. At the same time, realize it sounds like you're ripe about now. Just curious how you think about the value benefit that could potentially be derived from l
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up on the M&A point. I hear you're not necessarily in the industry for M&A. At the same time, realize it sounds like you're ripe about now. Just curious how you think about the value benefit that could potentially be derived from large-scale M&A or potential consolidation.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've done it in the past, and it's added a lot of value to this firm. I think we have experienced. We recognize some of the pros and cons and large-scale deals just from a branding standpoint and product and disruption are difficult and are making
componenttext: Well, we've done it in the past, and it's added a lot of value to this firm. I think we have experienced. We recognize some of the pros and cons and large-scale deals just from a branding standpoint and product and disruption are difficult and are making a big bet, but they're also the ones that are going to move the needle the most. So I think for us, it's really looking at what areas we can strengthen our lineup, and there are certain firms that do that out there, but we also don't want to get to the point where we have so much brand and product that it becomes confusing in the marketplace, too. So I think those are all issues that it's challenging to get 2 big firms to view what's right for the future I think in a consistent way, but we're going to keep trying to do that.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just as a follow-up. Just diving a little bit on the digital front. Just curious how you're thinking about your digital strategy. I know some of your competitors have acquired certain capabilities in that area. I think maybe how you're thinking about that
componenttext: Just as a follow-up. Just diving a little bit on the digital front. Just curious how you're thinking about your digital strategy. I know some of your competitors have acquired certain capabilities in that area. I think maybe how you're thinking about that. I think you mentioned a little earlier in terms of platforms looking for more of that.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that we're looking and even with the DOL having some capability and whether that's built internally or we go out and rent the capability or buy the capability, those are all things that we are exploring. And I think the traditional model of
componenttext: Well, I think that we're looking and even with the DOL having some capability and whether that's built internally or we go out and rent the capability or buy the capability, those are all things that we are exploring. And I think the traditional model of saying, we'll go out and buy a robo adviser for us. Again, unless you have a large-scale ETF business, we're not sure that makes a whole lot of sense. But we do need some form of allocation for existing clients within that would be helpful for smaller accounts within the fiduciary rule as well. So it is something that we're looking at, seeing how those capabilities looking out on the low horizon makes sense one way or another for us as well. And there's a lot of different ways we can do it, and it's really the stage where we're in right now meeting with as many of them and deciding whether to buy or build.

componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Franklin Resources' Earnings Conference Call for the Quarter Ended June 30, 2016.
Statements made in this commentary regarding Franklin Resources Inc. which are not historical facts are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These forward-looking statements involve a number of known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from any future results expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements.
These and other risks, uncertainties and other important factors are described in more detail in Franklin's recent filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including in the Risk Factors and MD&A sections of Franklin's most recent Form 10-K and 10-Q filings.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Matt, and I'll be your co-operator today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. I'd now like to turn the call over to Franklin Resources Chairman and CEO, Mr. Greg Johnson. Mr. Johnson, you may begi
componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Matt, and I'll be your co-operator today. [Operator Instructions] 
As a reminder, this call is being recorded. I'd now like to turn the call over to Franklin Resources Chairman and CEO, Mr. Greg Johnson. Mr. Johnson, you may begin.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, hello and good morning, everyone. We appreciate you joining Ken Lewis, our CFO, and me for this call today. The good news is that our results are pretty straightforward for this quarter. So hopefully, the commentary we made available earlier this mo
componenttext:
Well, hello and good morning, everyone. We appreciate you joining Ken Lewis, our CFO, and me for this call today. The good news is that our results are pretty straightforward for this quarter. So hopefully, the commentary we made available earlier this morning provided much what you're looking for.
To quickly recap, although we experienced another quarter of net outflows, we did see encouraging signs with redemptions continuing to slow and improving investment performance, particularly Franklin Income Fund that, as of July, ranks in the top quartile against peers for the trailing 1-year period.
Financial results and capital management were solid as operating income increased 11%, and the trailing 12 months payout was $2 billion.
Now we'll be happy to take your questions.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our first question comes from Glenn Schorr from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our first question comes from Glenn Schorr from Evercore ISI.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess a question on both sales and redemptions. On the sales side, it's good to see an increase in international sales for the first time in 2 years. I'm curious what the biggest drivers of that are. And then on the redemption side, I guess it's a simil
componenttext: I guess a question on both sales and redemptions. On the sales side, it's good to see an increase in international sales for the first time in 2 years. I'm curious what the biggest drivers of that are. And then on the redemption side, I guess it's a similar question. It's a really big drop in redemptions. I'm curious if you think that was a point in time or are we at a different level of redemption because that can make a really big difference.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Glenn. Let me just -- I'm just trying to be clear on the question. You said global sales. Is that referring to global bond, global equity or sales outside of the U.S.?
componenttext: Yes, Glenn. Let me just -- I'm just trying to be clear on the question. You said global sales. Is that referring to global bond, global equity or sales outside of the U.S.?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry. Sales outside of the U.S.
componenttext: Sorry. Sales outside of the U.S.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the -- a couple of things. I mean the global bond, which is a bigger driver of flows outside of the U.S., we did see an improvement, significant improvement in redemptions, and that led to the major improvement in net flows. I think the -- la
componenttext: Yes. I think the -- a couple of things. I mean the global bond, which is a bigger driver of flows outside of the U.S., we did see an improvement, significant improvement in redemptions, and that led to the major improvement in net flows. I think the -- last quarter, we did have some lumpier redemptions in that number versus this quarter. And I would -- I still think that's the one area that continues to be under pressure where we are seeing improvements in a lot of other areas in terms of flows, but the global bond, that's the one that continues to be under pressure. And I think if you look at the other area that I would call out just in terms of flows, because I think it is a little bit confusing, is the global equity net flows that increased, and redemptions increased there. And I want to point to there were 3 lumpy one-time institutional redemptions within that, that totaled $3.5 billion out of global equity. So otherwise on the retail side, it's an improving trend there as well.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then you mentioned the launch of LibertyQ and LibertyShares, and you talked about 3 multi-factors funds, I think. But can you just expand a little bit more on what channels you're going to be selling that through and what kind of uptake we shoul
componenttext: Okay. And then you mentioned the launch of LibertyQ and LibertyShares, and you talked about 3 multi-factors funds, I think. But can you just expand a little bit more on what channels you're going to be selling that through and what kind of uptake we should expect, say, over the next year?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean I wouldn't -- I think we have moderate expectations within the next year as far as flows going into that. I think we have made a major commitment to that segment as far as resources and exposure and marketing dollars to get the message and bra
componenttext: Yes. I mean I wouldn't -- I think we have moderate expectations within the next year as far as flows going into that. I think we have made a major commitment to that segment as far as resources and exposure and marketing dollars to get the message and brand out there, but it will take a little bit of time. And right now, they've been up and running, doing well, performing well, and it's a matter of just getting on platforms. Now we can do that probably faster than a lot of firms because of the relationships hopefully that we have built with our broker dealers and advisers out there and hopefully get some demand putting them on. But again, it's a start for us in the new segment, and it will take a bit of time as these records get out there. I hope it won't take 3 years, but we are getting a lot of calls and a lot of interest on them. And I think in the meantime, we'll also look at expanding the lineup beyond just a smart beta.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from William Katz from Citigroup.
componenttext: Your next question comes from William Katz from Citigroup.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just on your P&L, you didn't call too much out on your prerecorded comments and I think you had some softness relative to, I think, prior expectations, particularly on the [indiscernible]. Can you give us a sense maybe this quarter how much was still in s
componenttext: Just on your P&L, you didn't call too much out on your prerecorded comments and I think you had some softness relative to, I think, prior expectations, particularly on the [indiscernible]. Can you give us a sense maybe this quarter how much was still in severance in the comp line, how do we sort of think about that going forward and then maybe some of the other line items just given you have some seasonal and/or some core to core dynamics?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Bill. There's about $8 million of severance in this quarter. And then looking forward -- and it's dependent upon a one-time item that may or may not hit next quarter. But inclusive of that, we do expect to see increases next quarter in most of the l
componenttext: Sure, Bill. There's about $8 million of severance in this quarter. And then looking forward -- and it's dependent upon a one-time item that may or may not hit next quarter. But inclusive of that, we do expect to see increases next quarter in most of the line items. I think comp would be more or less flat, but the G&A will be up. So we're expecting possibly a charge related to the windup of U.K. benefit plan, and that should be in the neighborhood of $25 million. It may hit next quarter, it may hit the quarter after that.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, Greg, you mentioned some nice detail on the -- sort of how you position on the other side of Brexit. Can you talk a little bit about what you might be seeing in July or maybe before and after Brexit in terms of sales volumes, just to get a sense
componenttext: And then, Greg, you mentioned some nice detail on the -- sort of how you position on the other side of Brexit. Can you talk a little bit about what you might be seeing in July or maybe before and after Brexit in terms of sales volumes, just to get a sense of what's going on, on the platform?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean I don't think there's been any effect on our flows. I think the July performance has been very strong and worth mentioning as the market has kind of settled back, and even global bond had a very strong July. So hopefully, that will help sales.
componenttext: Yes. I mean I don't think there's been any effect on our flows. I think the July performance has been very strong and worth mentioning as the market has kind of settled back, and even global bond had a very strong July. So hopefully, that will help sales. But we didn't -- I don't think there was much of a disruption anywhere. Munis continue to be very strong for us.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ken Worthington from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ken Worthington from JPMorgan.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Will Cuddy filling in for Ken. Cash outside the U.S. continues to grow. What are your latest thoughts on utilizing cash outside the U.S.? How realistic are investments or M&A to utilize the cash? And how much are you placing on the new administrat
componenttext: This is Will Cuddy filling in for Ken. Cash outside the U.S. continues to grow. What are your latest thoughts on utilizing cash outside the U.S.? How realistic are investments or M&A to utilize the cash? And how much are you placing on the new administration reforming the tax code?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks for that. And that last point is a key point in the discussion. There's been -- it's a current topic in Washington. It's been a current topic. It continues to kind of move a step forward then stop, move a step forward then stop, so we're keepi
componenttext: Yes. Thanks for that. And that last point is a key point in the discussion. There's been -- it's a current topic in Washington. It's been a current topic. It continues to kind of move a step forward then stop, move a step forward then stop, so we're keeping an eye on that. And we think -- well the consensus that we hear is probably sometime in 2017, there might be something that involves corporate tax reform. And I would point out it was a long time ago but 2005 when they had that, you can look to see what we did there. So depending on -- it all depends on what we think is the best long-term interest of the shareholders, what we do. But in 2005, we did repatriate some money, and so that's not an unreasonable thing to expect, but it depends on what the law is. The cash continues to grow, and we're just planning to continue our capital management strategy that we've been doing over the last few years. And essentially, our payout ratio is more than cash generated or net income, and that means we're using U.S. cash, but U.S. cash is still a healthy number, so we don't expect any material change in our strategy.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would just add, I think my sense is in meetings in Washington that you are getting momentum on both sides for tax reform. It's clearly Paul Ryan and something that he feels very strongly about. So obviously, we're in an election cycle right now. Whe
componenttext: And I would just add, I think my sense is in meetings in Washington that you are getting momentum on both sides for tax reform. It's clearly Paul Ryan and something that he feels very strongly about. So obviously, we're in an election cycle right now. When we get past that, we'll have a lot more clarity on seeing how the House and Senate and presidency looks, but we are still hopeful that that's something that's coming. But I think in the meantime, as we've said before, the M&A probability and certainly with some of the currency chips in Europe and the sterling make M&A activity that much more attractive to something that we have had on our wish list. So I would say, again, as I said in prior calls, that that's the most probable area for us.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. On expenses, expense growth seems to be coming in better than your guidance. Are expenses at -- this past quarter a good rate to use in 4Q as we move into the next calendar year?
componenttext: Great. On expenses, expense growth seems to be coming in better than your guidance. Are expenses at -- this past quarter a good rate to use in 4Q as we move into the next calendar year?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think as I alluded to in the prior question, I think next quarter, we should see a little uptick in probably all the lines. The most notable one would be G&A for the charge that I talked about. Comp, I think, could be flat. It could even be down a littl
componenttext: I think as I alluded to in the prior question, I think next quarter, we should see a little uptick in probably all the lines. The most notable one would be G&A for the charge that I talked about. Comp, I think, could be flat. It could even be down a little bit next quarter. That's what we're looking for, for next quarter.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Carrier from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Carrier from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, just given that you had more time to go through the DOL new rule and have discussions with the distributors with the industry, I just wanted to get your take on how you feel like Franklin is positioned. And for some of the potential changes, whether
componenttext: Greg, just given that you had more time to go through the DOL new rule and have discussions with the distributors with the industry, I just wanted to get your take on how you feel like Franklin is positioned. And for some of the potential changes, whether it's 12b-1 fees or commissions, just how Franklin will try to position for the retail channel going forward.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think it, obviously, has been the area of greatest focus with our distributors. Certainly, since the announcement, I would say trying to make sense of the 1,100 pages. It's a little bit like a Rubik's cube where we're making progress and then turn
componenttext: Yes. I think it, obviously, has been the area of greatest focus with our distributors. Certainly, since the announcement, I would say trying to make sense of the 1,100 pages. It's a little bit like a Rubik's cube where we're making progress and then turn it over and realize we've got 2 other problems. So I think we are getting some clarity around where it's heading. We talked about a standard class of shares. That's something that within the best interest contract can work. I think we're seeing some broker-dealers committed to doing the brokerage side and others saying it's not something they're going to do. I think the initial reaction that you're going to have a ton of money moving into the advisory side. I think once we really look at what that means, there's other implications of the rule that may mean monies that are held that paid a front-end sales charge should stay where they are and not move to the advisory because that would actually increase costs. So I think we are making a lot more sense of the rule. I think the net results are also that there'll be less funds on platforms. We're seeing that, again, more of that consultant gatekeeper approach and narrowing the funds that any broker-dealer follows. So I think that puts pressure on smaller funds out there to get distribution and ultimately, less advisers. I think you'll see more retirements as this transition will be too much. And then just issues, simple things that sound -- again, I mean having a robo-adviser for a small account, but can you have your own ETFs within that robo advise under the rule? I mean these are the kind of problems that I think are coming up. And obviously, the ERISA lawyers are trying to clarify that, and we're working with many in the meantime. But I think the net effect for us is to have some kind of standardized pricing. We -- obviously, we don't want to have 100 different pricing structures out there and are trying to come to some new standard that works for most of our -- most broker-dealers and advisers, and that's really where we are.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then just as a follow-up. So the quarter, there were a lot of, I don't know, volatile events and markets were all over the place, but we've got some improvement, and you mentioned July. Just when you look at those redemption tren
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then just as a follow-up. So the quarter, there were a lot of, I don't know, volatile events and markets were all over the place, but we've got some improvement, and you mentioned July. Just when you look at those redemption trends in terms of the improvement, was it pretty consistent throughout in -- maybe even into July? Or are you starting to see more improvement, particularly given some of the performance trends that you mentioned?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean I think we're always careful of how to talk about flows beyond the quarter. I think the big one for us that, as I stated before, that tends to snap back the fastest is the Franklin Income Fund, which you look at that category just 2 quarters a
componenttext: Yes. I mean I think we're always careful of how to talk about flows beyond the quarter. I think the big one for us that, as I stated before, that tends to snap back the fastest is the Franklin Income Fund, which you look at that category just 2 quarters ago, we had a hybrid $5.6 billion in net redemptions and last quarter, $2.2 billion. So I think that, that trend, we hope, will continue as people the -- even in the last quarter, the 3-year number or the 5-year number actually improved to back to the second quartile. And hopefully in another -- the end of this month, hopefully, we'll be back in the second quartile for the 1 year. And as we stated earlier, we're at the 80th percentile for year-to-date. So that's a pretty big recovery there, and I think that that's where you'll see the improvement flows. I think we have some good stories as well on the equity side with one of our largest funds, a Franklin Rising Dividend fund, a $17 billion, $18 billion fund doing extremely well right now and getting a lot of attention for its performance, which is first quartile for the 1 year, 3 -- second quartile for 3 and 5. Franklin Growth, also very strong. So I think those are areas where we could see a turnaround in flows. And I think as long as the market is stable, the other trends should continue as well.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Dan Fannon from Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Dan Fannon from Jefferies.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the prerecorded call, you talked about a platform loss. And I think you mentioned that at other points in time over the last 12 months, and I think insurance was an area of weakness a few quarters ago. I was just curious if there's like a channel, if t
componenttext: On the prerecorded call, you talked about a platform loss. And I think you mentioned that at other points in time over the last 12 months, and I think insurance was an area of weakness a few quarters ago. I was just curious if there's like a channel, if there's any consistencies at some of these platforms in which you're seeing market share losses are being taken off or is it just kind of performance and fund specific?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think they're -- the main driver when we talked about a platform change was one of our large broker-dealers that we worked with building it in-house sub-advice platform and was moving some assets, and it was $1.1 billion out of our mutual discovery
componenttext: Yes. I think they're -- the main driver when we talked about a platform change was one of our large broker-dealers that we worked with building it in-house sub-advice platform and was moving some assets, and it was $1.1 billion out of our mutual discovery fund. So that's a one-off event that's not performance related that drove that. We did have -- I think the other one on the -- just in general, I talked about the variable annuity business and how that's undergoing change. And certainly, with the DOL, we'll have more changes. But we have seen some groups get out of that business so they're really going to wind down. So it kind of changes what they're looking for on their platform. And we, with our solutions group, we're doing our best to transition those assets. But they're the ones that still you have a pipeline of redemptions over the next, say, 2 years as those groups are transitioning out of that business. So I would guesstimate that you probably have $5 billion-plus in assets over the next 2 years that will transition. Hopefully, we can capture some of that, but it will go out of the traditional funds into a lower fee type solution to meet whatever liability they have. So those would be the big changes that have driven the lumpier redemptions, and I think we'll continue to create some headwinds in the next 2 years on the VA side.

Was that opportunistic, just given some of the volatility or a potential indication that your capital allocation policies may be shifting ex, of course, any momentum on reform and in the tax code as you laid out for?

componenttext: Yes, it's truly opportunistic. We take advantage of price dislocations as they occur, and it doesn't represent any change in strategy.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Chris Harris from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Chris Harris from Wells Fargo.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in your prepared commentary, you did talk a little bit about Franklin's history being able to adapt to changes in the industry, and that's certainly well-documented. When you think about the situation we're in now, this period certainly feels a lot dif
componenttext: So in your prepared commentary, you did talk a little bit about Franklin's history being able to adapt to changes in the industry, and that's certainly well-documented. When you think about the situation we're in now, this period certainly feels a lot different just because it appears like you have a lot of investors out there that just don't want to own active funds or at least in certain areas anyway. So I guess what we're wondering here is what's you're kind of long-term strategy to manage around that or manage that type of an environment. And we know you guys have K2 and the ETF initiative going on, but that just doesn't quite seem like enough. So any commentary you can give in that regard would be helpful.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, again, as we've stated in prior calls, continuing to look at alternatives, continuing to look at solutions where we can add value outside of this market traditional beta, as I again stated before, to come into the market and offer passive t
componenttext: Well, I think, again, as we've stated in prior calls, continuing to look at alternatives, continuing to look at solutions where we can add value outside of this market traditional beta, as I again stated before, to come into the market and offer passive today doesn't make a whole lot of sense for us as we've seen the raise to the bottom in fees that continue to drive down close to 2 basis points. So that doesn't seem like an attractive alternative. I think we also believe that active -- that there are forces at work over the last 5, 10 years that have contributed to the passive strategies. And once active outperforms and that tends to be in a more of a rising rate environment, historically, I think that conventional wisdom could shift pretty quickly, and that's something we firmly believe. But in the meantime, we have built out our solutions. We're looking at our multi-asset capabilities. We're getting a lot of interest in that, and that's just another area how we can add value to investors by combining different asset classes over time. So that's going to be an important growth area. Whether it's real estate alternatives, long/short hedge funds, those are all private equity things that we plan on continuing to expand outside of your traditional U.S. large cap stocks.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have -- we do -- if we know something is being redeemed, we try to call it out. I've done that on past calls. And we do have a large institutional low-fee account that was redeemed, I think, this month, about $1.2 billion, $1.3 billion in the glo
componenttext: Well, we have -- we do -- if we know something is being redeemed, we try to call it out. I've done that on past calls. And we do have a large institutional low-fee account that was redeemed, I think, this month, about $1.2 billion, $1.3 billion in the global equity area. I don't have anything to call out. I think the institutional pipeline, again, we feel like it looks good as far as the opportunities that were identified -- have identified and RFPs that we're responding to. And I know one area that would be a new growth area for us but one that we've had excellent numbers, it would be on the Franklin global growth side and we are -- hopefully, we'll see some nice wins there over the next year.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

componenttext: $6 million. Okay. And that's -- you view that as onetime or something that's potentially ongoing?

componenttext: No. I think that's onetime. There's a little bit left of it that we might get next quarter, but essentially onetime.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then just lastly, Greg, just maybe your view. I mean you talked a little bit about M&A and that looking a little better given the build-up of non-U.S. cash. Maybe if you can talk sort of more broadly about -- you've been in the industry a
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then just lastly, Greg, just maybe your view. I mean you talked a little bit about M&A and that looking a little better given the build-up of non-U.S. cash. Maybe if you can talk sort of more broadly about -- you've been in the industry a long time, your view of to what extent we'll potentially see more consolidation in the industry if active continues to underperform and product needs to get rationalized. And then from your angle, do you see yourself as more of a participant in acquiring firms or potentially even combining with another large firm?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I make the -- and as I stated before, I mean, I think any industry that is maturing and gets larger, you hit a point where consolidation makes sense. I mean I'm not sure we're there yet, but certainly you have some outside forces at work that we haven't s
componenttext: I make the -- and as I stated before, I mean, I think any industry that is maturing and gets larger, you hit a point where consolidation makes sense. I mean I'm not sure we're there yet, but certainly you have some outside forces at work that we haven't seen before. So I think that, that could contribute. I think the other point that I stated when asked about this is that it's not the easiest industry to do large mergers and consolidations with funds are -- you have separate contracts and boards. And it's very time-consuming and difficult to do mergers. So I think for us, we again are open to anything that we think enhances the lineup and to create shareholder value over time. And we try to build as many relationships across our industry to be able to act on things that makes sense, and that's where we are today. And I wouldn't state one way or another. I think we're always out looking on behalf of shareholders and trying to create value, and if that's a merger, if that's an acquisition, we're open to any and all.

componenttext: Yes. I think we're talking about 2 different things. Overall, GAAP income, we could say 50-50 is not a bad. But on a taxable basis, it's a completely different ballgame there. Taxable income and booking are completely different.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Alex Blostein from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Alex Blostein from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: As follow-up around expenses, this year, there's a lot of moving pieces, a bunch of onetimers. Severance, obviously, was a big part of that and it sounds like there's, obviously, another charge with the $25 million. So all in all, can you guys help us und
componenttext: As follow-up around expenses, this year, there's a lot of moving pieces, a bunch of onetimers. Severance, obviously, was a big part of that and it sounds like there's, obviously, another charge with the $25 million. So all in all, can you guys help us understand kind of as we look for 2016 as a whole, how much of some of these onetime items been weighing on you on expenses? And then I guess more importantly, as we look out into next year, I guess presumably, these will not repeat. How should we start thinking about next year's expense run rate?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, maybe that's a better approach instead of listing all the one-offs and trying to estimate what one-offs will be next year. I think we could just like take a higher view of it. So we've been talking on this call about all the changes in the industry a
componenttext: Yes, maybe that's a better approach instead of listing all the one-offs and trying to estimate what one-offs will be next year. I think we could just like take a higher view of it. So we've been talking on this call about all the changes in the industry and because of all that, we're continually examining all of our strategies. So if we look forward to next year, we're looking at -- and I mentioned this in a previous call as well, we're looking at every facet of our business model to determine if we have the business models and service capabilities that we need for the future, and that may include structural expense increases or decreases over the next few years. So that's kind of a long way to answer your question that we are currently looking at our cost structure, but it's a little too early to kind of give definitive guidance because some of these initiatives are multiyear. But I can tell you that based on what I know now, if I look towards 2017, it looks like expenses will be flat to slightly down compared with the current year or the estimate of the current year expenses.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful. And then I wanted to go back to the DOL discussion for a second. As you guys discuss the change among the distributors and more decision-making processing in place, more in a kind of gatekeeper way, more consolidated type of decisi
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful. And then I wanted to go back to the DOL discussion for a second. As you guys discuss the change among the distributors and more decision-making processing in place, more in a kind of gatekeeper way, more consolidated type of decision-making and I guess more centralized. What do you guys think will be the criteria for active fund placement in that environment? And I guess more importantly, how do you think you are positioned in that backdrop?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we're positioned well because the first driver is going to be assets you have that are on their books with their clients, so you're not going to eliminate those. And the other performance and risk-adjusted returns and relationship, the size of the
componenttext: I think we're positioned well because the first driver is going to be assets you have that are on their books with their clients, so you're not going to eliminate those. And the other performance and risk-adjusted returns and relationship, the size of the company, I think those are all factors. I think each firm will have their own. Clearly, we will not have every one of our funds on those lists, and it may need more consolidation of funds within our own lineup as we rationalize. And that's been an emphasis of our firm is to streamline the lineup and number of products that we're servicing. And I think in this environment, that's going to probably accelerate that process of closing some smaller funds that wouldn't get the shelf space.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. And then maybe just squeeze one more around the fee rate dynamic. It seems like at least more recently, there's been a little book more of a widening divergence between domestic product versus international product, and especially given your comm
componenttext: Got you. And then maybe just squeeze one more around the fee rate dynamic. It seems like at least more recently, there's been a little book more of a widening divergence between domestic product versus international product, and especially given your comments about slowing redemptions in the hybrid side of the business. Is there a meaningful enough of a difference between the hybrid product domestic equity product versus the global bond and international equity product that could, given the slow trends, result in actual shift in the mix that's big enough that we can kind of see it in the fee rate or not very meaningful?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I don't -- I think that if you look at the fees across those different categories, they're actually fairly aligned. Probably the hybrid one is a little bit lower, obviously, than international equity, but I don't think it would have a meaningful shift
componenttext: No. I don't -- I think that if you look at the fees across those different categories, they're actually fairly aligned. Probably the hybrid one is a little bit lower, obviously, than international equity, but I don't think it would have a meaningful shift in your effective fee rate at all.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Robert Lee from KBW.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Robert Lee from KBW.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Curious about in the alternatives business. Obviously, you have K2 and you've launched some liquid strategies, which had some early success. Can you maybe, I guess, first, update us on the progress with some of your liquid alternatives? And then maybe als
componenttext: Curious about in the alternatives business. Obviously, you have K2 and you've launched some liquid strategies, which had some early success. Can you maybe, I guess, first, update us on the progress with some of your liquid alternatives? And then maybe also your thoughts about building out a broader alternatives capability where you would be particularly interested and then maybe update us on what your current capabilities are maybe outside of K2?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the K2 is working well as planned in bringing liquid alts to the retail channel. I mean last year, we expended the lineup and added a long/short credit fund and a global macro fund, and I think those can be nice complements, again, to diversi
componenttext: Yes. I think the K2 is working well as planned in bringing liquid alts to the retail channel. I mean last year, we expended the lineup and added a long/short credit fund and a global macro fund, and I think those can be nice complements, again, to diversifying a portfolio. Outside of that, we have a lot of areas, whether it's a real estate and private equity, and it's really trying to build more scale within those. So I think we are looking at considering acquisitions on that side and continuing to build out our capabilities and just think it's a national extension of what we do. So I think we are open. I think as I've stated in the past, it is difficult just to go out and buy a hedge fund or buy companies that have done well in the alternative space because they are so driven by this specific person, but we are looking actively in that area. And whether, again, it's real estate private equity or traditional hedge funds, those are all on the table.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And maybe just a follow-up on the global bond, global fixed income. I mean you talked in the past about seeing the institutional channel as a big opportunity for those strategies broadly. And can you maybe update us on that, I mean, given maybe some of th
componenttext: And maybe just a follow-up on the global bond, global fixed income. I mean you talked in the past about seeing the institutional channel as a big opportunity for those strategies broadly. And can you maybe update us on that, I mean, given maybe some of the performance challenges over the past year that's been -- that slowed down, but where do you think that opportunity exists currently for the -- on the global bond side institutionally?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's -- the institutional market especially, I think they are less sensitive. And because this bond -- just to benchmark it against global bonds, I think, is not -- it really is more of a global macro-type fund, and it doesn't fit really well
componenttext: Yes, I think it's -- the institutional market especially, I think they are less sensitive. And because this bond -- just to benchmark it against global bonds, I think, is not -- it really is more of a global macro-type fund, and it doesn't fit really well into any one given category. I think the standpoint of diversifying from local currency and local sovereign debt, there is still a big appetite for that. I don't think that's changed. And I think also when people -- sophisticated investors look at the portfolio and look how it's positioned, it is very different. It does offer something very different, and that it will be one of the few games in town if rates actually do go up at some point. And I think the risk certainly from the perspective of an individual country's currency depreciating, in some cases, is still very much there. So we are getting institutional interest, and that really hasn't changed. So hopefully, we'll get some significant wins in there.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And one last question, if I can, on the distribution, retail distribution. I mean you've talked at length, as have peers, about changes there, maybe approved list shrinking and a number of products you have at any platform moving around. At the same time,
componenttext: And one last question, if I can, on the distribution, retail distribution. I mean you've talked at length, as have peers, about changes there, maybe approved list shrinking and a number of products you have at any platform moving around. At the same time, you've had a lot of new product initiatives, LibertyShares, K2, your whole broad line of traditional products. So within that kind of mix, I mean, are you thinking or have you thought that there's some kind of change you need to make in terms of your own distribution capabilities? Is it, I don't know, shrinking it or is it changing the type of personnel given the changing product mix? I'm just kind of curious how you feel about strategic changes in your capabilities.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that's already been happening, and it's been really an effort probably in the last 3, 5 years for us transitioning your traditional retail sales force into a more institutional quality level, especially at that gatekeeper level, the people c
componenttext: Well, I think that's already been happening, and it's been really an effort probably in the last 3, 5 years for us transitioning your traditional retail sales force into a more institutional quality level, especially at that gatekeeper level, the people calling on the home office, those are really more of your traditional consultants, that kind of background there to talk about metrics that are very different from how we viewed funds, I think, in the traditional way. So that's already happening, I think, as far as even our sales force, and we made changes there over the last year, focusing specifically more on having a targeted group for the advisory side that's a little bit different again than your traditional. So we've been evolving as the market has been changing, and we will continue to do that. And hopefully, at some level, you'll get some efficiencies out of that as we get better at providing useful information on a realtime basis through digital side, which has been a big emphasis in trying to reach more advisers in a more efficient way. And I think that again as the model changes, the use of technology and information getting to advisers can create a lot of efficiencies from the traditional way that we've done it. So I think that's happening as well.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Eric Berg from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Eric Berg from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The improvement in the redemptions took place, it seems pretty much everywhere across the complex except, of course, for global equity. And I understand that there has been improvements, very significant improvement in your flagship hybrid product. But it
componenttext: The improvement in the redemptions took place, it seems pretty much everywhere across the complex except, of course, for global equity. And I understand that there has been improvements, very significant improvement in your flagship hybrid product. But it was also an extraordinary quarter in so many respects, what with the Brexit vote and terrorism and interest rates declining and extreme volatility in currency. I mean it's a long list of factors that made it a remarkable 3-month period. To what do you attribute this company-wide decline, not just in certain categories but company-wide decline in redemptions? That's my first question.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it -- the effect for us, and again, we've stated we had more exposure to energy rolled up through probably 4 different entities, and we don't do any top-down risk management each individual firm. We look at it separately. And so you had an o
componenttext: Well, I think it -- the effect for us, and again, we've stated we had more exposure to energy rolled up through probably 4 different entities, and we don't do any top-down risk management each individual firm. We look at it separately. And so you had an overexposure to energy, had an overexposure to Europe. Those were trending nicely until Brexit. And even if you look at the trend in equities to quality away from more of your traditional momentum, strong balance sheets, rising dividends, quality earnings, those were all trends that fit nicely into our -- generally, into our philosophy with many of our equity funds. You did see an improvement in rotation happening, a rotation into value as well. And if you look at the quarter, I mean, Brexit kind of hit right at the end of the quarter. So if it was at the beginning, maybe it would be a little bit of a different story, but what we had captured a lot of good relative performance during the quarter, which unfortunately in the last couple of weeks, when you had more of a risk off environment, you lost some of that which has been gained back in July. So I think it's really just looking at the flagship products for us. And also munis have been -- that's a strength area for us. And munis are very attractive in this environment and should continue to be. So I think that that's counter to what is happening on -- and a result of a lot of the, I think, uncertainty in equity markets, money moving into munis right now. So that's another factor as well.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The second and final question I have relates to fixed income, in general, and you just touched on it a little bit, but maybe you could expand in responding to the following question. I have been struck by not only the fact that your company is having very
componenttext: The second and final question I have relates to fixed income, in general, and you just touched on it a little bit, but maybe you could expand in responding to the following question. I have been struck by not only the fact that your company is having very stable, not growing, but very stable fixed income growth sales and so were many of your competitors. It's surprising to me given that there was no yield and that -- and the duration risk is very substantial should interest rates rise over the next couple of years. My question, given all that, the absence of yield, the duration, the loss of principal risk, why do you think fixed income across the industry is doing as well as it is in terms of gross inflows?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean. That's a great question, but I do think fixed income always has a place in a diversified portfolio and does reduce risk. I think you are correct that where we sit in a cycle, I think many would argue that there's greater risk from rates going up,
componenttext: I mean. That's a great question, but I do think fixed income always has a place in a diversified portfolio and does reduce risk. I think you are correct that where we sit in a cycle, I think many would argue that there's greater risk from rates going up, that's certainly the position within our Global Bond Fund. But at the end of the day, it's very hard to take a portfolio and just ignore fixed income. It -- you put a lot more risk into that given portfolio if you go 100% equities. But at the end of the day, you look at something like munis. It still has an attractive yield relative to the treasury market, certainly on an after-tax basis. And the general consensus right now, right or wrong, is that rates are not going up. So I think there's a sense of security that even in these -- with these small yields, they're going to be fine for X number of years.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Patrick Davitt from Autonomous.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Patrick Davitt from Autonomous.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Cohen & Steers just recently announced they had hired Dennis Rothe, too, I guess, was your head of consultant relations. Was that separation your decision? And I guess what are the plans, I guess, for replacing him and has it caused any kind of dislocatio
componenttext: Cohen & Steers just recently announced they had hired Dennis Rothe, too, I guess, was your head of consultant relations. Was that separation your decision? And I guess what are the plans, I guess, for replacing him and has it caused any kind of dislocation in that part of your group?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it hasn't. And we really don't -- we will not comment on the surrounding circumstances of departure, but it has not been disruptive, and it's been replaced.
componenttext: No, it hasn't. And we really don't -- we will not comment on the surrounding circumstances of departure, but it has not been disruptive, and it's been replaced.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then more broadly, I know you're probably tired of talking about capital. But if we're in a situation where there is no tax holiday, either because of the continued kind of impasse in D.C. and you can't find an M&A target, is it just the status
componenttext: Okay. And then more broadly, I know you're probably tired of talking about capital. But if we're in a situation where there is no tax holiday, either because of the continued kind of impasse in D.C. and you can't find an M&A target, is it just the status quo then you'll continue just to kind of build the cash or are there other options that you would consider if we get into that kind of situation next year?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's always other options. And I guess I would respond to that as a pretty big hypothetical there with 3 or 4 possibilities. So it's hard to predict what will happen. We just -- maybe we have like an 18-month time view when we look at these things. I t
componenttext: There's always other options. And I guess I would respond to that as a pretty big hypothetical there with 3 or 4 possibilities. So it's hard to predict what will happen. We just -- maybe we have like an 18-month time view when we look at these things. I think it's going to be status quo. We're not going to -- we don't plan on changing anytime soon.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean I think the -- we don't want to feel like we have a timetable to do a big deal that you have to do something by X. And I'm a firm believer that once we get past this cycle that some form of repatriation will come through. But that doesn't mean in t
componenttext: I mean I think the -- we don't want to feel like we have a timetable to do a big deal that you have to do something by X. And I'm a firm believer that once we get past this cycle that some form of repatriation will come through. But that doesn't mean in the meantime that we're not looking at opportunities especially with some of the currency devaluation in Europe right now.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess on that point, you touched on a few questions ago, but your tone on M&A have kind of ebbed and flowed over the last few years. What is kind of the primary reason that you haven't found something? Has it just been a lack of businesses that really f
componenttext: I guess on that point, you touched on a few questions ago, but your tone on M&A have kind of ebbed and flowed over the last few years. What is kind of the primary reason that you haven't found something? Has it just been a lack of businesses that really fit? Or is it more price? What do you think the overarching kind of reason for that is?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's probably those 2 items and more. Each -- I mean we're pretty active every year in looking at properties. And some of us come to us, some of us we're proactive on. And for the ones that we haven't done, it tends to be they don't really meet ou
componenttext: I think it's probably those 2 items and more. Each -- I mean we're pretty active every year in looking at properties. And some of us come to us, some of us we're proactive on. And for the ones that we haven't done, it tends to be they don't really meet our criteria. So quality, repeatable investment process, culture, price. Yes, price could be an issue. It has been in some cases. As Greg mentioned earlier, it's not the easiest industry to integrate. We think about that and also a lot -- we come across situations where there's ownership structural challenges as well. So it kind of runs the gamut of why a deal doesn't go through. But those are some of the things that we found.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I think like anything in life, the best ones are not for sale right now, and we're going to continue to build relationships. And I think if both firms see the benefits, then you can have a successful merger acquisition, and that's what we're hope
componenttext: Yes. And I think like anything in life, the best ones are not for sale right now, and we're going to continue to build relationships. And I think if both firms see the benefits, then you can have a successful merger acquisition, and that's what we're hopeful for. But at the end of the day, it's not -- we don't feel like that's necessary to be successful either. And I think that's an important point, too.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Michael Cyprys from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Michael Cyprys from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up on the M&A point. I hear you're not necessarily in the industry for M&A. At the same time, realize it sounds like you're open to anything right about now. I'm just curious how you think about the value benefit that could potenti
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up on the M&A point. I hear you're not necessarily in the industry for M&A. At the same time, realize it sounds like you're open to anything right about now. I'm just curious how you think about the value benefit that could potentially be derived from large-scale M&A or potential consolidation.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we've done it in the past, and it's added a lot of value to this firm. I think we have experience. We recognize some of the pros and cons and large-scale deals just from a branding standpoint and product and disruption are difficult and are making a
componenttext: Well, we've done it in the past, and it's added a lot of value to this firm. I think we have experience. We recognize some of the pros and cons and large-scale deals just from a branding standpoint and product and disruption are difficult and are making a big bet, but they're also the ones that are going to move the needle the most. So I think for us, it's really looking at what areas we can strengthen our lineup, and there are certain firms that do that out there, but we also don't want to get to the point where we have so much brand and product that it becomes confusing to the marketplace, too. So I think those are all issues that it's challenging to get 2 big firms to view what's right for the future, I think, in a consistent way, but we're going to keep trying to do that.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just as a follow-up. If we could just -- diving a little bit on the digital front. Just curious how you're thinking about your digital strategy. I know some of your competitors have acquired certain capabilities in that area. If you could maybe just
componenttext: Okay. Just as a follow-up. If we could just -- diving a little bit on the digital front. Just curious how you're thinking about your digital strategy. I know some of your competitors have acquired certain capabilities in that area. If you could maybe just elaborate on how you're thinking about that. I think you mentioned a little earlier just in terms of platforms looking for more of that.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that we are looking and even with the DOL having some capability and whether that's built internally or we go out and rent the capability or buy the capability, those are all things that we are exploring. And I think the traditional model of
componenttext: Well, I think that we are looking and even with the DOL having some capability and whether that's built internally or we go out and rent the capability or buy the capability, those are all things that we are exploring. And I think the traditional model of saying, we'll go out and buy a robo-adviser for us. Again, unless you have a large-scale ETF business, we're not sure that makes a whole lot of sense. But we do need some form of allocation for existing clients within that would be helpful for smaller accounts within the fiduciary rule as well. So it is something that we're looking at, and seeing how those capabilities looking out on the long horizon makes sense one way or another for us as well. And there's a lot of different ways we can do it, and that's really the stage we're in right now is meeting with as many of them and deciding whether to buy or build.
