headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hello, and good morning. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO, along with Ken Lewis, our CFO. And we're here to provide our commentary on third quarter results. As a quick reminder, our 10-Q was also filed this morning and additional details on results can be found ther
componenttext:
Hello, and good morning. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO, along with Ken Lewis, our CFO. And we're here to provide our commentary on third quarter results. As a quick reminder, our 10-Q was also filed this morning and additional details on results can be found there. The June quarter was challenging for the industry as the introduction of new regulations by the Department of Labor and the United Kingdom vote to exit the European Union led to increased uncertainty. 
On the positive side, we are seeing encouraging developments on the investment performance front where we saw improvements across all major categories over the trailing 1-year period. Equity and hybrid fund performance improved across 1-, 3-, 5- and 10-year periods. We continue to experience net outflows that we did see an improvement in flows from nearly all investment objectives as redemptions have steadily declined over the past several quarters.
Financial results were solid with operating income of almost $600 million and 11% increase from Q2. We also continue to demonstrate strong capital management as we repurchased an additional 9 million shares in the quarter, bringing our fiscal year to date repurchases to over 29 million. Our Board of Directors authorized the repurchase of an additional 50 million shares to ensure we have the flexibility to execute our capital management strategy going forward.
This quarter also marked an exciting milestone for us, the introduction of Franklin LibertyShares, a new exchange traded fund platform. In June, we launched our first suite of strategic beta ETFs under the name Liberty Q. The new suite includes 3 multifactor core portfolio funds and one with a dividend focus. This launch was supported by a significant marketing push demonstrating our commitment to this new initiative. We continue to build out our ETF team and plan to launch additional funds in the months ahead, including some active strategies.
Turning to aggregate long-term performance on Slide 6, I'm encouraged by our improved relative performance across equity and hybrid funds, most notably, Franklin Income Fund had another strong quarter with year-to-date relative performance ranking in the 8th percentile driven by positive returns across asset classes and sectors, but most notably, by the recent recovery in energy markets. As of quarter-end relative performance for the 1- and 3-year periods were still below the peer average, but 5-year performance has recovered to the top 2 quartiles. Performance in July continues to be strong and trailing 1-year performance against its Morningstar and Lipper peers was nearly in the top quartile again. We've also seen a strong rebound in performance of Franklin Rising Dividends Fund, which now ranks in the top 2 quartiles across all time periods and contributed to an improved 3-year number.
Fixed income performance remained solid for the 5- and 10-year periods, however, near-term performance softened a bit. The primary driver of bond performance rankings remains our global strategies, which were negatively impacted by our relatively short duration and certain currency position specifically their net short position in the end, which has rebounded nicely in July. Assets under management ended the quarter at $732 billion as was previously disclosed. Monthly average assets increased a bit. However, daily average assets actually increased 1.5%. Our asset mix remain stable with a near 50-50 split between equities and bonds. We assume a similar split in hybrid assets though our mix clearly skews towards global.
From a sales region perspective, we remain roughly 2/3 U.S., 1/3 international. It's worth reiterating that our sales region disclosure represents where the sale occurred, not the investment strategy, nor where the products are managed or domiciled.
There have been a number of questions on the potential impacts of the Brexit vote on our business and while much remains unknown, we do not believe it will have a major impact on the way our firm operates in the U.K. or the services we provide to our customers there. Furthermore, we have other regulated subsidiaries across continental Europe should there be future restrictions on cross-border trade and financial products and services between the U.K. and Continental Europe. Currently, we do not anticipate any significant impact to the distribution of our funds because our flagship cross-border fund vehicle is a Luxembourg domiciled CCAD range, which is distributed in 39 countries worldwide including the U.K. and Continental Europe. Our U.K.-based open-end investment company ranges targeted to U.K. investors only and is not passported into the EU. If in the future, European clients wish or need to contract a management company based in the new EU, we already have the regulated entities to service our need there. We've heard a number of concerns over the Department of Labor's new fiduciary rule and the strength of our business in the broker dealer channel, as well as the amount of assets under management currently in Class A shares. We believe this has led to some notable misunderstandings.
We've been successful over the past 65 years because we work hard to develop strong relationships with the clients who trust our track record with the brand we built neither of which will be affected by this rule. Product structure and pricing has been evolving for decades, and we're confident that we can continue to evolve with it. We are actively engaged with all of our primary clients and partners to understand the impact of this rule, which will be different for each firm so it's not possible to generalize on the impact of the rule for the industry or for us at this time. Not only will each of our partners pursue the most appropriate response to the rule for their own business, but that decision will have very different impacts on our business because of the nature of our relationship with each partner bearings.
Looking at the component changes and assets under management, long-term net new outflows improved this quarter and were $19.2 billion as redemptions dropped at the lowest level since the second quarter of 2013. Market appreciation of $10 billion partially offset the impact of outflows this quarter. While ongoing volatility, concerns over energy prices and performance challenges continue to negatively impact our retail business, we are encouraged by the continued decline in redemptions in both the U.S. and internationally. While overall sales remain under pressure, international retail sales increased for the first time since the second quarter of 2014. Global equity outflows increased to about $8 billion this quarter due to a $1.7 billion institutional redemption from our Canadian business. Some of our retail global equity funds also saw increased redemption activity this quarter as a platform changed by one of our key distributors resulted in a $1 billion redemption from the mutual global discovery fund. Global fixed income redemptions declined for the U.S. and cross-border versions of the Templeton global bond and total return funds leading to net outflows of about $7 billion for the quarter.
However, sales have not yet rebounded due to short-term performance challenges. We've been working hard to communicate the global macro team's positioning and strategy via the new global macro shifts hub, which serves as an educational resource for investors and fits more broadly into our What's Next for bond markets marketing campaign.
We saw a rebound in U.S. equity sales this quarter, led by Franklin utilities and Franklin Biotech Funds, which reduced net outflows to $1.6 billion. Hybrid net outflows improved again this quarter. The key driver of hybrid flows remains Franklin Income Fund, which has seen redemptions eased and a modest rebound in sales since February. Improving sales and redemption trends, along with net exchanges back into the fund over the past 4 months have yielded a significant reduction in monthly net outflows from the fund. Sustained performance and a rebound of the net asset value should support a rebound in sales.
Tax-free fixed income was a clear positive in the quarter with about $400 million in net inflows. Performance of our larger tax refunds has been good. And we're seeing increased interest in the asset class with a number of our funds in positive territory. U.S. taxable fixed income remains under pressure with $1.6 billion in outflows driven by net redemptions from several high-yield funds, but to the positive redemptions declined again this quarter. 
Now I'll turn it over to Ken for financial results.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q3 2016 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Greg. Third quarter financial results were strong as we started to see prior quarters cost saving initiatives reflected in the results. Compared to the prior quarter, operating income increased 11% to $595 million and net income increased to $4
componenttext:
Thank you, Greg. Third quarter financial results were strong as we started to see prior quarters cost saving initiatives reflected in the results. Compared to the prior quarter, operating income increased 11% to $595 million and net income increased to $446 million. Earnings per share of $0.77 was a 26% increase from last quarter and 2% ahead of net income growth due to the lower share count.
Total revenues of $1.6 billion were slightly higher the last quarter. Investment management fees were essentially flat compared with the second quarter as the impact of higher daily average assets under management was offset by lower performance fees. Excluding performance fees of $1.5 million, the effective fee rate base on the daily average assets under management was unchanged. Sales and distribution fees were $450 million reflecting increased commissionable sales from our U.S. and cross-border funds and increased asset base fees in the U.S. 
Shareholders service fees were flat while higher consolidated sponsored investment product revenue led to the increase in other revenue.
Operating expenses decreased 4%, with the most expense categories flat or down with exception of sales, distribution and marketing expense, which was higher due to increases in related revenue, as well as adjustments impacting the amortization of deferred sales commissions.
Compensation expense decreased by nearly $50 million due to lower severance costs this quarter as well as other factors such as lower payroll taxes and other variable expenses due in part to lower headcount. IT and occupancy expense were relatively flat and general and administrative expense decreased to $75 million with most of the variance related to the prior quarters intangible asset impairment and the mark-to-market of the contingent liability.
Looking at Slide 19, the decrease in expenses edge the fiscal year-to-date operating margin up to 35.7% and the tax rate for the quarter was 29% as our projected rate for the fiscal year decreased 120 basis points. This decrease was largely due to a change in estimated earnings mix to lower tax jurisdictions. Assuming a similar mix in the fourth quarter, we currently anticipate a fiscal year tax rate of around 31%. Investment and other income net of noncontrolling interests was $68 million, an increase of more than $50 million since of the second quarter due to a number of factors that illustrated on Slide 20 and described in more detail in our 10-Q.
Turning to capital management. As Greg mentioned, we repurchased 9.3 million shares during the quarter, taking advantage of lower prices in June, more so than in the first 2 months of the quarter. For the fiscal year-to-date period, we repurchased 29.4 million shares or about 5% of shares outstanding. This represented virtually all of the additional shares authorized for the repurchase back in October so our board authorized an additional 50 million shares at their most recent meeting in June. When we announced the share repurchase authorization, we saw a number of conclusions drawn from that announcement, and I just want to clarify that it did not reflect a change in our capital management approach or our priorities. Combined with dividends, the trailing 12 months payout was $2 billion, representing a total payout ratio that once again exceeded 100%.
And that concludes our comments on this quarter's results. We look forward to speaking with you on the call later today.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Franklin Resources' Earnings Conference Call for the Quarter and Fiscal Year Ended September 30, 2016. Please note that the financial results presented in this commentary are preliminary. Statements made in this commentary reg
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Franklin Resources' Earnings Conference Call for the Quarter and Fiscal Year Ended September 30, 2016. Please note that the financial results presented in this commentary are preliminary. Statements made in this commentary regarding Franklin Resources, Inc. which are not historical facts are forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995.
These forward-looking statements involve a number of known and unknown risks, uncertainties and other important factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from any future results expressed or implied by such forward-looking statements. These and other risks, uncertainties and other important factors are described in more detail in Franklin's recent filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including in the Risk Factors and MD&A sections of Franklin Templeton's most recent Form 10-K and 10-Q filings.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Brenda, and I will be your operator today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. And at this time, I would like to turn the call over to Franklin Resources Chairman and CEO, Mr. Greg Johnson.
componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Brenda, and I will be your operator today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. 
And at this time, I would like to turn the call over to Franklin Resources Chairman and CEO, Mr. Greg Johnson. Mr. Johnson, you may begin.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, hello, and thank you for joining us this morning. In addition to Ken Lewis and myself, we have Tom Regner with us today. And Tom is the Head of our U.S. Advisory Services, responsible for both the retail and institutional business in the U.S.Fisca
componenttext:
Well, hello, and thank you for joining us this morning. In addition to Ken Lewis and myself, we have Tom Regner with us today. And Tom is the Head of our U.S. Advisory Services, responsible for both the retail and institutional business in the U.S.
Fiscal 2016 was challenging in many respects as performance headwinds led to elevated outflows, but expense management and capital return were clearly positive. I'm encouraged by improving performance trends with several flagship funds. As I mentioned in my comments this morning, Franklin Income Fund was ranked in the top decile of its peer group on a 1-year basis, and we saw improvements in all major asset classes over all primary time frames this quarter. 
Furthermore, the Global Bond Fund has had significant outperformance in the month of October month-to-date, returning over 5% through the 25th, beating its benchmark by over 800 basis points and its peer group by more than 600 basis points. 
I'd like to now open it up for your questions. Thank you.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: Our first question comes from the line of Michael Carrier with Bank of America.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, maybe, first, for you just on the Department of Labor. You mentioned on the prerecorded call, you guys in the industry are focused on some strategies around the DOL. I think you said 2 potential kind of paths [ph]. Just wondered if you can provide m
componenttext: Greg, maybe, first, for you just on the Department of Labor. You mentioned on the prerecorded call, you guys in the industry are focused on some strategies around the DOL. I think you said 2 potential kind of paths [ph]. Just wondered if you can provide more color on the likely options and then any update on your exposure on the retirement channel and maybe how this uncertainty has been weighing on flows. So whether it's the sales or the pickup in redemptions.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think it's tough to really estimate what effect it could have on sales, but I think it clearly has been very disruptive to the advisers business right now in sorting out what is going to happen. I think from the last call, we continue to ma
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think it's tough to really estimate what effect it could have on sales, but I think it clearly has been very disruptive to the advisers business right now in sorting out what is going to happen. I think from the last call, we continue to make a lot of progress, a lot of work being done on getting ready for April. I think the good news is that there seems -- our concern has always been that it's not workable to come out with a different pricing structure for every broker-dealer out there, and we seem to be narrowing those options down to, hopefully, two. And then you saw the recent announcement around a clean share class or superclass [ph] or whatever you want to call them and having more of a stripped-down version available at some point in the future. That could be an option as well where you have the pricing handled at the broker-dealer level. All of that, I think, is happening. The question about what effect will it have, I think the net effect -- there were some surveys done. It said -- one said that you'll have 10% to 15% less advisers out there. I think that some would retire. The transition is going to be very difficult to go to the new model. So I think that, that can be disruptive as well. And I just think overall, our sense is once we get past this, you'll get to a more normalized environment. But right now, it is very disruptive force for the adviser. And I'll ask Tom Regner who's been involved more day to day if he has anything to add there.

componenttext: All right. Thank you. So we're spending a lot of time getting ready for next April. On the retail side, we're doing a lot of training and kicking off some internal training for both the internal team and the external sales team because we're moving towards an advisory business, which is really selling funds within a portfolio context, which is different than we have and our competitors have been doing in the past. So we're getting ready as fast as we can for that change.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. And then just as a follow-up. I guess, just on the cash. So you guys have been active this year with buybacks and the dividend. But for the non-U.S. cash, if we do get at a repatriation holiday next year or the year after -- and this is, I g
componenttext: Okay. Got it. And then just as a follow-up. I guess, just on the cash. So you guys have been active this year with buybacks and the dividend. But for the non-U.S. cash, if we do get at a repatriation holiday next year or the year after -- and this is, I guess, for Greg or Ken, just what would be either the plan or the options with that cash? And then if not, have you thought about ways that you can maybe create some value with that non-U.S. cash given that you don't tend to get much credit for sitting outside the U.S.?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess, my -- the way I would answer this question is it's hard to say exactly what we would do because we would have to see what the new rules are if and when they come out. But I'd just point back to what we did the last time, which was probably
componenttext: Well, I guess, my -- the way I would answer this question is it's hard to say exactly what we would do because we would have to see what the new rules are if and when they come out. But I'd just point back to what we did the last time, which was probably over 10 years ago now, where we repatriated the cash and then I think we've paid a special dividend. So those are all the options, but we would definitely try to take advantage of whatever was in the best interest of shareholders based on the law.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would just add, I mean, how we think about it, I mean -- I think we all would maybe agree now that the probability is higher as we get past the election on having some form of repatriation. And you look at that offshore cash, and you could discount
componenttext: And I would just add, I mean, how we think about it, I mean -- I think we all would maybe agree now that the probability is higher as we get past the election on having some form of repatriation. And you look at that offshore cash, and you could discount it. Well, it'd be probably a 20% haircut or so if you take it back to the U.S. So as -- I think as far as how the board and management thinks about it is if you have an opportunity offshore, it's 20% cheaper than the one onshore. So we continue to look at anything that would be accretive and additive to our lineup offshore first.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: I guess, Greg, you highlighted the variable annuity outflows that have been occurring and are, I guess, slated to occur over the next couple of quarters. Can you talk a bit about why that's occurring again, just to refresh us, and if it's DOL related? And then ultimately, what's the AUM left in those buckets that maybe longer term might be at risk?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll start, and again, I have Tom because I -- we figured those questions would come up with DOL and, specifically, VA. And we have a very strong business in that area, sub-advising as well as separate funds that are for the annuity business. And rea
componenttext: Yes, I'll start, and again, I have Tom because I -- we figured those questions would come up with DOL and, specifically, VA. And we have a very strong business in that area, sub-advising as well as separate funds that are for the annuity business. And really, many of the large players that we grew, I think, at a high of about $70 billion in assets in that category, the -- many of the big names have gotten out of that business. And as they wind down the assets, many are going to in-house and pass it over low volatility strategies. And we're trying to capture as much as that transition is possible, but it has put a large block of business in transition at risk. I think for next quarter, we're estimating another $2.6 billion in outflows. And today, we're at $40 billion -- $35 billion approximately in assets that are remaining. And I'll let -- Tom, if you have anything to add on the business itself?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Greg covered what's going on. Well, what we're doing in response is we have established a dedicated insurance solutions group within our overall solutions portfolio group, and we're developing portfolios that are -- that have less basis risk. [ph] I
componenttext: Yes. Greg covered what's going on. Well, what we're doing in response is we have established a dedicated insurance solutions group within our overall solutions portfolio group, and we're developing portfolios that are -- that have less basis risk. [ph] I mean, one of the issues is with the insurance companies that there was a high basis risk in some of their underlying portfolios for the VA contracts. So we're working on reducing that. And I think you'll see in the next 4 or 5 days one of the top 5 insurance companies by sales is going to be announcing a new VA living benefit [ph] that's backed by a customized Franklin Templeton portfolio. So we're working very hard to make sure that we stay relevant with the firms that are staying in the business.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as of quarter-end, we had $46 billion remaining in VA assets.
componenttext: And as of quarter-end, we had $46 billion remaining in VA assets.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just a follow-up, I guess, maybe Tom for you on the DOL. It seems as if the industry is facing a gross sales issue today because of the uncertainty. I guess, as you kind of -- we get closer to the implementation date, are you guys assuming
componenttext: Great. And then just a follow-up, I guess, maybe Tom for you on the DOL. It seems as if the industry is facing a gross sales issue today because of the uncertainty. I guess, as you kind of -- we get closer to the implementation date, are you guys assuming -- or as you talk to advisers, is there assumption -- is there going to be a step function higher in terms of assets in motion, whether that -- whether we see redemptions pick up or, obviously, gross sales [ph] could pick up as well? But I guess, have you -- [ph] where are we, do you think, in this transition phase for adviser behavior at this point?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don't think you're going to see a pickup in redemptions. There are some awfully attractive living benefits out there historically, which frankly hurt some of the insurance companies. I think what you're going to see, though, is initially there's go
componenttext: Yes. I don't think you're going to see a pickup in redemptions. There are some awfully attractive living benefits out there historically, which frankly hurt some of the insurance companies. I think what you're going to see, though, is initially there's going to be a slowdown in sales within the VA business because the commissions are coming down. There's no question about that. There's going to be shorter surrender time. So the VA business is going to be in a state of flux. But we know from working with our clients -- so we work with the top 5 in the industry -- that they're not standing still, right? So they are coming out and will be coming out with new products to stay relevant in the new -- with the new DOL legislation.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, my comment was just on mutual fund sales, not on the VA. So just generally, in terms of the adviser behavior broadly, not just with VA.
componenttext: I guess, my comment was just on mutual fund sales, not on the VA. So just generally, in terms of the adviser behavior broadly, not just with VA.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I mean, I don't know that there's going to be -- I mean, look, people still need to invest; they still need to retire; they still need to provide for college education. As Greg mentioned, that it's going to be difficult for some advisers because a lot
componenttext: No. I mean, I don't know that there's going to be -- I mean, look, people still need to invest; they still need to retire; they still need to provide for college education. As Greg mentioned, that it's going to be difficult for some advisers because a lot of the business is going advisory. I think the number is you need to have about $30 million as an adviser of assets under management to have a viable business. So it's going to be hard for some people to stay in business if they don't have a sizable book. So there will be some transition in the advisers themselves, but there's still a very, very strong demand that's not changing.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I just think it's still early to kind of forecast. There's a lot of people that would argue that the amount of money in motion, it could slow down because of tax considerations, too, if you have taxable gains. And one, [ph] you can't take and then mov
componenttext: And I just think it's still early to kind of forecast. There's a lot of people that would argue that the amount of money in motion, it could slow down because of tax considerations, too, if you have taxable gains. And one, [ph] you can't take and then move it to another. And this is obviously outside of the retirement world. And then how the incentives line up post this change as well, that could affect behavior on how assets move if some just stay old versus new. It just won't all move at once.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Worthington with JPMorgan.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, I think earlier this year, you called out that you thought the institutional business had a lot of promise, I think, particularly when it came to FX [ph] exposure management. Each quarter, we tend to hear about these big outflows. And it seems like
componenttext: Greg, I think earlier this year, you called out that you thought the institutional business had a lot of promise, I think, particularly when it came to FX [ph] exposure management. Each quarter, we tend to hear about these big outflows. And it seems like there's broader base sort of institutional redemptions. So I guess, the question is, help us understand what's going on in the institutional side of the business and maybe characterize how you see the outlook.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's been, as you know, I mean, challenging with Templeton and the deep value [ph] philosophy. I mean, that cycle has -- the timing of the market has been working against getting new mandates. So the good news is that we've seen things switc
componenttext: Well, I think it's been, as you know, I mean, challenging with Templeton and the deep value [ph] philosophy. I mean, that cycle has -- the timing of the market has been working against getting new mandates. So the good news is that we've seen things switching, moving in the right direction for performance. So hopefully, that's -- that, historically, has been our area where we had the strongest institutional business and still have the largest assets. So it's been more defense and offense as far as wins. I think the opportunities we're seeing in local debt around the globe, especially in Asia, we continue to work hard on those and have, I think, a lot of opportunities that are still there in the pipeline. We've gotten a few in the field, [ph] but we still think that will be in the strongest area of growth. Then [indiscernible] -- Tom, if you want to add any.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, what we're seeing in the U.S. is a re-risking of portfolios. If you look at the public pension plans, they're severely underfunded. They need higher return. So they're starting to look at portfolios or asset classes that provide a high risk-a
componenttext: Yes. I mean, what we're seeing in the U.S. is a re-risking of portfolios. If you look at the public pension plans, they're severely underfunded. They need higher return. So they're starting to look at portfolios or asset classes that provide a high risk-adjusted return. So I think that speaks well for some of the capabilities that we have on a global basis in fixed income. And as Greg pointed out, with value coming back, that speaks well for Templeton and Templeton Group, too. But they have to rerisk [ph] those portfolios, and we want to participate.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then I think just a follow-up on Mike's question earlier on repatriation. How much time do you think it will take to evaluate the chances of repatriation or a repatriation holiday after elections? Is it something that you think is sort of appar
componenttext: Great. And then I think just a follow-up on Mike's question earlier on repatriation. How much time do you think it will take to evaluate the chances of repatriation or a repatriation holiday after elections? Is it something that you think is sort of apparent pretty quickly? Or it's just going to take 2 or 3 years? And if it does take 2 or 3 years, as long as the chances of a repatriation holiday aren't 0, do you think it's just best to sit on the cash and wait? Or do you start to get frustrated and make it a priority to maybe better utilize the cash?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Ken. As Greg mentioned, we're always looking for opportunities to grow the business, and that won't change internationally. Greg mentioned that all things being equal, it's -- an acquisition is cheaper for use [ph] offshore cash. And so that
componenttext: Yes. This is Ken. As Greg mentioned, we're always looking for opportunities to grow the business, and that won't change internationally. Greg mentioned that all things being equal, it's -- an acquisition is cheaper for use [ph] offshore cash. And so that -- it's not that we're sitting and we're not doing anything else waiting for repatriation. So I do want to make that clear. We are looking for opportunities. And so that's one of the strategic advantages of having all that cash, we'll be able to move when something you the opportunity presented itself. But regarding the time line for repatriation, there's been a lot of momentum, and we feel like it's gaining momentum. Congress is working on the issue. We feel like when they come back in January, they might be talking about it. Our advisers us all the time that 4 of the last 5 presidents enacted tax reform by August of the first year, so we are optimistic a bit about it, and we're also looking for other ways to use that cash.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of William Katz of Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of William Katz of Citigroup.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: Ken, maybe one for you to get started. You gave some guidance on expenses for fiscal '17 over '16, so thank you for that. Within that construct, you also talked a little bit some investments pick up on the tech line. Stepping back more broadly if we were to sort of replicate 2017 -- 2016, '17, we assume 5 [ph] choppy market some sluggish organic growth. How much expense of flexibility do you have at this point? I think the question are you reaching a point now where you get a little more limited on expenses absent some maybe revenue-generating point of the company.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there's still flexibility on the expense, all the expenses. But having said that, I do think we're in a phase where those opportunities take longer to execute. They tend to be more linked with strategic initiatives, so we continue to look at all t
componenttext: I think there's still flexibility on the expense, all the expenses. But having said that, I do think we're in a phase where those opportunities take longer to execute. They tend to be more linked with strategic initiatives, so we continue to look at all that. Is the business the right size, et cetera? Are we leveraging technology the best we can? So I do think this opportunities but I don't think there's a lot of quick hits that would move the dial.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Greg, so curious, merger of equals between Jazz and Henderson. I think you go up against the various geographies around the world. Does that transaction in and of itself, the implication of the transaction is that shift at the little bit an
componenttext: Okay. And then Greg, so curious, merger of equals between Jazz and Henderson. I think you go up against the various geographies around the world. Does that transaction in and of itself, the implication of the transaction is that shift at the little bit and may be with allocation within repatriation between acquisitions versus buyback versus dividends?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I mean I don't think it changes the mindset. I think in that case, there was clear benefits for the 2 firms to get into 2 different markets and leverage the distribution of each side to do that. I think the consensus out there of consolidation this do
componenttext: No. I mean I don't think it changes the mindset. I think in that case, there was clear benefits for the 2 firms to get into 2 different markets and leverage the distribution of each side to do that. I think the consensus out there of consolidation this does create a wave of consolidation. Obviously, this is a slower growth business. It's a more mature business, and one way to gain efficiencies is through consolidations. I think companies, as I said before, are going to be much more open to looking at avenue to create value.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Alex Blostein the Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Alex Blostein the Goldman Sachs.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: First to follow up on the, I guess, evolution of the distribution channel and the potential implications for you guys. I heard you on the prepared remarks around potentially your share class and something you guys talked about in the past as well. But any
componenttext: First to follow up on the, I guess, evolution of the distribution channel and the potential implications for you guys. I heard you on the prepared remarks around potentially your share class and something you guys talked about in the past as well. But any thoughts around implications for management fees for you specifically and the industry broadly as we go through this adjustment in the distribution channel.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think as far as the repatriation and effect, I think management piece is something that again this is extremely competitive business. We all see the battle versus passive everyday, so the pressure on management fees is there regardless of D
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think as far as the repatriation and effect, I think management piece is something that again this is extremely competitive business. We all see the battle versus passive everyday, so the pressure on management fees is there regardless of DOL or not. I think the question around your product lineup and it's something that maybe Ken touched on a little bit on just where do we see potential savings in streamlining and what is DOL, I think probably for us pushes us further down that path of trying to simplify the lineup and rationalize funds that may in the post-DOL world may not fit neatly into more of an advisory model versus brokerage model. Those are the debates we're having internally now. That could create some efficiencies. But I think from a cost side this is a business that every basis point is going to matter. And I think the good news on some outcomes on DOLs are going to have a lower front and sales charge that will help with some of the relative rankings. And I think as we said in our announcement at MorningStar is now the a shares is not going to be used most of it is done net net asset value and that's going to make us more competitive where we see a lot of our funds will increase star rating. So I think those are very positive outcomes, and I think our concern of having 35 share classes at least now where we feel like we'll only have to add a few.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then my second question along similar lines, I guess, but historically you, guys were very successful at keeping more assets within the Franklin fund family in the brokerage channel, partially because, I guess, with waved commission once a cli
componenttext: Got it. And then my second question along similar lines, I guess, but historically you, guys were very successful at keeping more assets within the Franklin fund family in the brokerage channel, partially because, I guess, with waved commission once a client paid back commission or one fund moving to another. As you migrate over to the advisory channel, can you help us understand how that could impact asset retention and maybe just from a historical perspective kind of what sort of percentage of the growth sales that has come from one folk switching from one fund to another?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't have that number. You think anytime we go to the adviser type gatekeeper-driven model, it's the pros and cons. I mean you can get significant assets quickly, and you can lose significant assets quickly. I think that's the net effect. I think the a
componenttext: I don't have that number. You think anytime we go to the adviser type gatekeeper-driven model, it's the pros and cons. I mean you can get significant assets quickly, and you can lose significant assets quickly. I think that's the net effect. I think the advantage of the transition, it's like a funnel where there's going to be less funds available in the new model. But if you have large assets, the probability of your fund being included even up in a period of underperformance, it's highly unlikely that is going to be eliminated from that lineup. So I think size matters quite a bit as far as continuing to get shelf space in the new model. But it is higher risk for retention standpoint than your traditional brokerage model where it's more a one-on-one relationship. Here, it's more of the gatekeeper consultant driven, more institutional type relationships and the transition our model think adapt to that have more people with consulting experience point of contact with the home offices.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: I just wanted to follow up on something from earlier in the call. You mentioned looking at the opportunities, you continue kind of pretty consistent with how you've talked about that in past quarters. I'm just curious how you're evaluating some of those opportunities is related to the cash you guys have and maybe what criteria are metrics we might look at base the decision on to potentially grow something versus look to M&A to jumpstart the activity there.

componenttext: I think in previous calls we've talked about the volume of things that we look at every year, and that continues. And I would say the criteria that we use is a lot of it is qualitative. We focus on the institutional process, institutionalized investment process, can it be repeatable, risk because it's a people business and cultural fit, and that quickly and eliminates a lot of respective's. But -- so that really hasn't been changed. And Greg touched on what's some of the criterias that we might look at, so no change to what we said in the past.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then the other question I have is on, first, the liquidity role and then broader regulatory concerns. One, do you have any additional thoughts on the expense associated with compliance with the rule and/or potential performance impacts on your funds that invest in more liquid assets? And more broadly, does your expense guidance for 2017 include any associated expense for becoming compliant with that rule?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean I think it's probably early to answer any clause associated with the rule. I think it hasn't been out very long 2 years to comply by understanding I think it's a much better rule on what's first discussed as far as something that appears to be
componenttext: Yes. I mean I think it's probably early to answer any clause associated with the rule. I think it hasn't been out very long 2 years to comply by understanding I think it's a much better rule on what's first discussed as far as something that appears to be workable. For us, I don't think we have any major concerns on at this stage. I mean we're still studying it, but our first reaction is that would not create issues on the portfolio management side for any of our funds. But again, it's -- we're studying the rule like most right now, but I think it's a better outcome than what was first discussed. And I think liquidity is something that we manage a carefully with our boards, and I feel like that's one of the most important parts of our business is managing liquidity, especially in open and 40 [ph] act type funds.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: Just going back to the DOL and just maybe kind of feels like beating a dead horse a little bit, but you talked a lot about the impact on the fund business, but if there's going to be a movement to advisory, presumably, that should increase demand for the SMA business. So I mean it's not a part of the business that I think in the past you talked about much. Can you maybe update us on how you feel you're positioned maybe with -- in the SMA part of the retail world and if that's a place where you feel like ultimately maybe you need to make some changes or some investment?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Tom. So we -- that's good observation. We've actually added to the SMA business. It has been kind of, if you will, a quiet part of the retail business, but we've added to it over the last 2 years. We moved it into our private wealth division becau
componenttext: This is Tom. So we -- that's good observation. We've actually added to the SMA business. It has been kind of, if you will, a quiet part of the retail business, but we've added to it over the last 2 years. We moved it into our private wealth division because we think that there is a big role for that in the high net worth part of our business, and we're working on adding some ESG screens to that part of the business as well because we're seeing that as kind of an increasing demand in high net worth business. So good observation. We're building it up.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And also second to the DOL, I hear different things from different advisers and different managers. Obviously, you're going to have a level of fee setting and all that. One of the things that seems things on is what happens to things like platform f
componenttext: Okay. And also second to the DOL, I hear different things from different advisers and different managers. Obviously, you're going to have a level of fee setting and all that. One of the things that seems things on is what happens to things like platform fees, things like revenue share so what's your current do you think that in many cases the distributors would be able to charge platform fees or some argue it's going to go up. Some argue it's going to go away, so what do you kind of hear?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: All of the above. That's why I really -- it's almost daily on some of the different opinions on whether -- how do you retain -- how do you have a level platform fee across different groups that have different perspectives, with different levels at differe
componenttext: All of the above. That's why I really -- it's almost daily on some of the different opinions on whether -- how do you retain -- how do you have a level platform fee across different groups that have different perspectives, with different levels at different asset levels and how do you include or exclude the ETFs that wouldn't have that ability? There's all kinds of issues that are still being worked through between, and that's why it could cost us more, it could cost us less, I would answer yes because I'm not really sure this stage. We're working through it.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a great point. We have one very large client that said they're not going to take any revenue sharing post April as they put on the books. And we have another large client who said that they're now going to continue to look at revenue share as part
componenttext: That's a great point. We have one very large client that said they're not going to take any revenue sharing post April as they put on the books. And we have another large client who said that they're now going to continue to look at revenue share as part of the business. So we'll see how it plays out.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could, one more quick question. On the ETF business, you've been investing in. You touched on it, I think, in the prerecorded call, another place that you want to continue to invest. So from the outside looking in, how are you thinking about ultimate
componenttext: If I could, one more quick question. On the ETF business, you've been investing in. You touched on it, I think, in the prerecorded call, another place that you want to continue to invest. So from the outside looking in, how are you thinking about ultimately what's kind of from the landmarks that we should look for for success in that? Do you kind of feel like this is -- we think we can really scale this quickly or that's kind of a slow build and it's hopefully 5 plus years when you'll see an impact. How are you thinking about whether you're going to be successful or not over the next couple of years?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it is a slow build. I think part of it was just getting in the business, understanding the business and getting the right people that can operate a very different product and a very different skill set than what we traditionally have. I think that
componenttext: I think it is a slow build. I think part of it was just getting in the business, understanding the business and getting the right people that can operate a very different product and a very different skill set than what we traditionally have. I think that has been we would call that a success of having a very strong team in place, and it's really building from here and recognizing any new funds or ETFs that we roll out take time. So it's really about building shelf space, awareness, I think we continue to do that. And Tom, if you want to add?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So to Greg's point, we've added significantly to the ETF distribution team, and they're working with our 100 or 90 to 100 wholesalers to leverage up the subject matter experts. So that's on the building brand part of the business, but we're quite exc
componenttext: Yes. So to Greg's point, we've added significantly to the ETF distribution team, and they're working with our 100 or 90 to 100 wholesalers to leverage up the subject matter experts. So that's on the building brand part of the business, but we're quite excited to be able to have as you'll hear that we're going to be building out more of our strategic beta platform because we want the adviser to be able to come to Franklin Templeton, and we want to be able to build a portfolio that is either fully active or is partially strategic beta. Partially fully active, frankly, are agnostic. We want them though to be able to come to us, build out a fully featured, fully diversified portfolio. So we're all in on that initiative.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And expanding it outside the U.S., too, as part of the the initiative, which will take time.
componenttext: And expanding it outside the U.S., too, as part of the the initiative, which will take time.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brennan Hawken with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brennan Hawken with UBS.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: First on DOL, can you -- is the idea that you've got some upward expense pressure next year on technology, is that a function of the indications of working with your distribution partners and as they make those changes to level pricing and some of the adj
componenttext: First on DOL, can you -- is the idea that you've got some upward expense pressure next year on technology, is that a function of the indications of working with your distribution partners and as they make those changes to level pricing and some of the adjustments that you need to make to your own system and, therefore, that piece is somewhat inflexible?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it is not so much that. It's other projects and initiatives that are underway, particularly in the part of the business that does things like fund accounting, pricing and all that, I think that's we're trying to invest in technology to make sure t
componenttext: I think it is not so much that. It's other projects and initiatives that are underway, particularly in the part of the business that does things like fund accounting, pricing and all that, I think that's we're trying to invest in technology to make sure that we can scale that going forward and support all of the product demands that are out there in the industry. So it's more of that and less really of the DOL. I mean we think we have a lot of share classes, and we think we can do that with not -- incremental spend but not too much.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay. And appreciate -- it must be pretty hard to manage all the different distribution partners and all the different approaches, but as you have those discussions and it seems firms are becoming more and more clear in what it is that their policie
componenttext: Okay. Okay. And appreciate -- it must be pretty hard to manage all the different distribution partners and all the different approaches, but as you have those discussions and it seems firms are becoming more and more clear in what it is that their policies are here in recent times, do you have an update to the amount of AUM that you think is exposed to this rule? And as you're having discussions with distribution partners, are you seeing any of those partners actually have an impact in the current iterations and in the prep with the current rule on assets beyond just retirement accounts?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I will start by saying this rule puts all assets in a different place because, again, I think I said this before, but the thought that you could run one pricing structure under retirement and then have the other business at a different pricing structure c
componenttext: I will start by saying this rule puts all assets in a different place because, again, I think I said this before, but the thought that you could run one pricing structure under retirement and then have the other business at a different pricing structure creates all kinds of problems well. So I think many are just thinking about moving to one standard at some point. Again, there's different philosophies on that, different phases. And it's hard to say x percent, but I'll start by saying all a bit at some point, this is a game changer for the traditional way funds are priced. And Tom...

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And you've seen Merrilll Lynch and JPMorgan I think today and came out and we're going to treat the nonretirement business exactly like we're treating the retirement business because it's just too complicated to do something best different. We'll see if t
componenttext: And you've seen Merrilll Lynch and JPMorgan I think today and came out and we're going to treat the nonretirement business exactly like we're treating the retirement business because it's just too complicated to do something best different. We'll see if that trend continues, but it's likely to if you think about it, especially dealing with the same customer with the retirement assets and the nonretirement asset and trying to explain to them why it's different pricing.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And the update to the AUM exposed?
componenttext: Okay. And the update to the AUM exposed?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Actually, I don't -- I think to Greg's point we're going towards an environment where I think it's a exposed. There's going to be very, very little difference between retirement assets and nonretirement assets just because it's going to be difficult a
componenttext: No. Actually, I don't -- I think to Greg's point we're going towards an environment where I think it's a exposed. There's going to be very, very little difference between retirement assets and nonretirement assets just because it's going to be difficult and I think someone asked the question perhaps it was you about the technology associated with trying to keep track of all of this, it's much more difficult for the broker-dealers it is for Franklin Templeton. So when we look at the cost of the administration of 2 different buckets of business, I think they're coming to the conclusion that were going to want 1 bucket of business and leave it at that.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: Well, keep in mind that we do -- we paid 100% of consolidated net income, but part of that is earned outside the United States. So is that sustainable indefinitely? I don't think it's sustainable indefinitely, but we certainly have flexibility in terms of the ability to raise capital or adjust other things.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Bedell with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Bedell with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for the color on the Department of Labor. Maybe just another one on that. Obviously, a lot of confusion where you're hearing that as well. Just as you think from a time frame perspective, do you sense that things of the pretty well buttoned down by
componenttext: Thanks for the color on the Department of Labor. Maybe just another one on that. Obviously, a lot of confusion where you're hearing that as well. Just as you think from a time frame perspective, do you sense that things of the pretty well buttoned down by year-end and advisers will be in a position to sort of make decisions about where they want to allocate, and firms will have everything lined up even if we do have 2 different ends or 2 different spectrums. So by year-end or do you think this will go on for a while? And then, Tom, also maybe just what you're hearing from the wholesalers about the broad desire for advisers to move to products from active.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's start with the last part of the question first. As we move to an advisory business model, if you're charging 1.5%, you want to make sure that you're -- the underlying investment fees are, if you will, cost effective, right? So there is, as Greg poin
componenttext: Let's start with the last part of the question first. As we move to an advisory business model, if you're charging 1.5%, you want to make sure that you're -- the underlying investment fees are, if you will, cost effective, right? So there is, as Greg pointed out, there is a heightened interest in management expenses, and that's going to continue. That's one of the reasons that we launched our strategic beta lineup you have to play in more of an active space with -- within the retail business. What we're seeing from advisers is, frankly, there's a lot of confusion because a lot of advisers have built a commission-based business, and that's why are selling 8 product to a client. Now they're being looked at as having they're being required to build portfolios. That's a very different business model. That's a very different skill set. So we're working -- again, we're doing extensive training internally to be able to work with advisers to help them with that. And as Greg pointed out, we started building out our investment platform team, gosh, 7, 8 years ago because the platforms, if you will, the gate research, gatekeepers become even more important, more powerful going forward. So we're working on it from both ends. And I do note just attending meetings, summer meetings with our clients that they've been working on this for quite some time. And we are not standing still. And I think many of them -- and you're starting to see the announcements are coming out with here's what we're going to do come April. So a lot of them have started to make those decisions already.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. Maybe then just another question on expenses. Ken, you mentioned on the fund accounting side that you're reinvesting in that area, have you looked at that versus outsourcing it? And are you committed to not outsourcing it at this stage?
componenttext: Okay. Great. Maybe then just another question on expenses. Ken, you mentioned on the fund accounting side that you're reinvesting in that area, have you looked at that versus outsourcing it? And are you committed to not outsourcing it at this stage?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have definitely looked at that and probably every 5 or 6 years look at it again and again. And the conclusion, historically, has been the same and currently right now, we think it makes more sense to do it ourselves. And I would say the biggest determi
componenttext: We have definitely looked at that and probably every 5 or 6 years look at it again and again. And the conclusion, historically, has been the same and currently right now, we think it makes more sense to do it ourselves. And I would say the biggest determinant of that is our existing cost structure. So as you know, we have extensive operations in low-cost -- low-cost jurisdictions. And so when we compare the cost of doing it ourselves to what the cost of outsourcing makes economic sense for us to keep it in source that's the current thinking. But things change outsourcing companies get more efficient, so it's a continuous evaluation.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. It sounds for now, you're keeping it in-house.
componenttext: Right. It sounds for now, you're keeping it in-house.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: For now, yes, that's our conclusion.
componenttext: For now, yes, that's our conclusion.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe just last one for Greg. Obviously, the acquisition question is asset especially in the environment. But as you think about the types of firms that would be interesting just from a strategic standpoint would something that enhances you
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe just last one for Greg. Obviously, the acquisition question is asset especially in the environment. But as you think about the types of firms that would be interesting just from a strategic standpoint would something that enhances your distribution capabilities, which are already extremely large and build out different types of products. Would that have a preference over, say, a rationalization and scale type of acquisition where you'd be combining funds into, say, merging weak and performing funds to stronger performing ones to get the track records more like a cost synergy play.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, obviously, there's a lot more opportunities to go out and target a strong investment manager and bolt it on to your existing distribution system, and that's one that's certainly in markets we talked about before and with the pounds so weak,
componenttext: Yes. I think, obviously, there's a lot more opportunities to go out and target a strong investment manager and bolt it on to your existing distribution system, and that's one that's certainly in markets we talked about before and with the pounds so weak, that makes the U.K. a more attractive market despite Brexit. We see that as more of a near-term opportunity to acquire something that would be additive to our lineup and strengthen our presence in the market where we don't really have a strong presence in the U.K. Outside of that, I think the others become much more difficult and larger one, that is much harder to do and much more disruptive obviously to the entire organization but one that in the right situation again is something that you would certainly look at, but I think it is much more difficult to execute.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Harris with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Harris with Wells Fargo.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're looking at your hybrid category here. I mean Redemptions have improved substantially, but sales keep ticking lower. It's kind of interesting that that's happening because performance is improving so much. If you can talk about that a little bit, wha
componenttext: We're looking at your hybrid category here. I mean Redemptions have improved substantially, but sales keep ticking lower. It's kind of interesting that that's happening because performance is improving so much. If you can talk about that a little bit, what was going to take to get sales going here, given the performance already seems to be improving quite nicely?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. It was exactly the question I had to our group early this morning. When I was going through some of the numbers, I thought that stood out on hybrid growth, and there are some other parts of that number because actually, the Franklin Income Fund, its
componenttext: Yes. It was exactly the question I had to our group early this morning. When I was going through some of the numbers, I thought that stood out on hybrid growth, and there are some other parts of that number because actually, the Franklin Income Fund, its growth sales were exactly level quarter-over-quarter despite the number of hybrid declining. It had almost exactly the same level of growth, and that's the key driver some other parts in that. I mean K2 falls into the hybrid category, and that had a little bit of a drop-off quarter-over-quarter, so that contributed to the gross number dropping down. But I think we are very optimistic that, that fund should continue to be a strong driver of our flows in this kind of environment. And I think it takes a little bit of time for people realize that it's back in the top decile for the 1 year and you have a lag effect of energy prices and what that did to a lot of our funds. And I look up across the lineup, and I'm very encouraged right now. I think we talked about it in the past as the value the value discipline you tend to get more energy exposure and then sometimes the market, and a lot of that has come back along with materials and whether it's our high-yield area of the income fund area and the hybrid Templeton area and Mutual Series, all of our rising dividend funds, all those funds now are performing very well. So I hope that we will get some momentum back now on the strong 1 year numbers. And actually, our hybrid and equity assets, 75% of them are in the top 2 quartiles for the 1 year. So I think it's a big change from where we were 6 months ago.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. okay. And then quick one on DOL. I think when we think about those risks, we tend to think about it in terms of flows. But just wondering whether you guys think ultimately this rule might force some management fee changes across the industry.
componenttext: Got you. okay. And then quick one on DOL. I think when we think about those risks, we tend to think about it in terms of flows. But just wondering whether you guys think ultimately this rule might force some management fee changes across the industry.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think I tried to answer that before that I think the pressure on fees is there. I think there's components of your overall fees, which are in the state of flux, and you can look at parts like the revenue share piece, and you do away with that that's goi
componenttext: I think I tried to answer that before that I think the pressure on fees is there. I think there's components of your overall fees, which are in the state of flux, and you can look at parts like the revenue share piece, and you do away with that that's going to make it a little bit easier to lower overall management fees and making you more competitive on that basis. Others -- other areas I think distributor retention, historic number that actually was going away anyway over time but that goes away immediately if you get the pricing at the broker dealer level this new class of shares but as the world was transitioning more to advisory the traditional a share was getting smaller and smaller as part of our business. So that changes as well. TA fees, all those things, sub-TA fees, all of those are again in a state of flux. So I think it's early but just to say it puts everything kind of in play at this stage.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it depends on how you're performing against the passive. I think you're never going to be passive on price if the consensus view like it is today that passive allowed performance. Not of you share. And I think in the next decade they think a
componenttext: Well, I think it depends on how you're performing against the passive. I think you're never going to be passive on price if the consensus view like it is today that passive allowed performance. Not of you share. And I think in the next decade they think acting will do very well. And then if you outperform the passive pricing becomes less of an issue. But I think the world is overly focused today strictly on price, and isn't really looking at anything else. And I think that will change as well but again as I've said before, I think any industry to its slower growth and has a lot of managers out there that's going to be continued pressure on pricing but an active manager, if the consensus view is passive as a way to go, you're not going to increase your business by cutting your fees in half. It's just not going to get there.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you're absolutely right. I think you have to be more flexible. That's something we certainly are doing in the institutional market right now where we're looking at new categories for us and coming with more of a performance-based type fee because
componenttext: I think you're absolutely right. I think you have to be more flexible. That's something we certainly are doing in the institutional market right now where we're looking at new categories for us and coming with more of a performance-based type fee because I think that fits with what people are willing to do to pay for more alpha I think that the openness to consider those is something we have to do right now because of the consensus view on passive versus active. So I think that, that is something that we are studying as well on just making sure our fees are competitive in markets. And whether that means cutting into profits to maintain share, I think that's something you have to consider.

This is going to be new share classes and less breakpoints and some other changes but the business overall, Franklin Templeton homes business has been moving towards on the bus and no load.

I think I spoke about that earlier that the merger of equals is difficult for a lot of reasons, especially as you get this big, but they can be -- when they are done and executed properly could add a lot of value over time. The easier one is just going out and buying a strong player in the market. That's available. That's not always easy to do but specific to that market, that would be attractive to us but again, I just wouldn't rule out any of those scenarios.
