headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hello, and good morning. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO, along with Ken Lewis, our CFO. Thank you for taking the time to listen to our commentary on our fourth quarter and fiscal year results. This was a challenging year in many respects, however, I'm pleased to
componenttext:
Hello, and good morning. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO, along with Ken Lewis, our CFO. Thank you for taking the time to listen to our commentary on our fourth quarter and fiscal year results. 
This was a challenging year in many respects, however, I'm pleased to see that investment performance broadly improved over the course of the year and we made significant progress on our most important strategic initiatives. Improved investment performance has clearly helped to slow redemptions, which were down almost 25% from last year. We did see a modest improvement in international retail flows, but that was offset by some institutional redemptions as well as improved U.S. fixed income flows. 
Financial results were solid, with operating income of $2.4 billion on a 36% operating margin. On the capital management side, we returned over $1.7 billion to investors through dividends and share repurchases, representing more than 100% of net income. For the year, we purchased 36.6 million shares, decreasing shares outstanding by 5.5% on a net basis.
Understandably, the Department of Labor's fiduciary rule has triggered a number of questions from investors, and while it's clear that the rule will greatly impact the financial services firms, I want to assure everyone that we are working closely with our distribution partners to ensure our firm is well positioned once the rule takes effect. 
Many brokers dealers are choosing to apply the best interest contract exemption allowed under the rule, while also building new mutual fund programs to offer levelized pricing and compensation. The industry is moving in the direction of 2 general product types. The first is a more traditional share class structure, with a lower commission and standardized 12B 1 piece, while the second will have more of a transaction-based fee structure. 
There's still a lot of work to be done, but introducing new share classes and responding to evolving regulations is nothing new to us.
Overall, our investment team has continued to deliver solid, long-term performance and importantly we see relative performance improved in several key areas over the last year. Franklin Income Fund, our largest fund by asset, outperformed its benchmark for the year and was a top decile performer in its peer group. Other key funds such as Franklin Rising Dividends, with its focus on dividend growth; and Templeton Foreign, an international equity strategy, experienced very strong rebounds in absolute and relative performance, beating their benchmarks and delivering top quartile relative performance. 
Another positive development on the performance front is the enhancement of Morningstar's making in its rating methodology. Among other changes, Morningstar is removing load adjustments that previously assumed a maximum fee for load investors, even though most investors don't pay any sales charge in an A share class. This change will level out the playing field between share classes and better reflect current state of the industry. 
At the industry level, most funds are expected to keep their current star rating. However, we estimate that nearly 1/3 of our Class A shares will see an increase of 1 star, including key funds like Templeton Global Bond and Franklin Rising Dividends. Assets under management were essentially flat compared to last quarter as we continue to benefit from a diversified mix of assets under management. Long-term outflows continue, while sales were flat this quarter, redemptions increased somewhat, leading to outflows of $22 billion but market appreciation of $22 billion offset the impact of flows for the quarter. 
From a retail perspective, redemptions have been improving since the fourth quarter of last year on the back of improving performance. Sales, overall, continued to be challenged as advisers remain cautious, given the ongoing volatility, historical performance challenges and the upcoming implementation of the DOL rule in the U.S. Consequently, large outflows continue from certain flagship funds. We did, however, see international retail sales improve again this quarter, driven by a pick up in demand from clients in Asia and parts in Europe for range of strategies.
While it may take some time given current economic conditions and market valuations, we remain confident that demand for flagship products will recover as advisers and clients are utilizing a wait and see approach to determine if there's consistency and improved performance.
In the meantime, we continue to keep advisers informed about the current positioning of our portfolios and the prospective behind the portfolio managers' predictions. Our variable annuity business, which is included in U.S. retail flows has been under pressure for that past 2 years as some of our insurance partners exited the business. While others made a shift to passive. Those decisions led to cumulative net outflows of $13 billion since the fourth quarter of last year, including $1 billion this quarter from our variable insurance product and self-advised funds. Those flows have impacted nearly all investment objectives and are illustrated in the flow graphs by investment objective. 
We wanted to provide some additional clarity and background on flows from this business because we expect an additional $2.6 billion of redemption to hit this quarter with most of that expected in October and an additional $4.8 billion to be redeemed in the second quarter. This remains an important business for the company, and we believe that we are now better positioned to meet the evolving asset allocation needs of our insurance partners.
Looking now at flows by investment objective for the quarter. Overall flows into our global strategies remain challenge as redemptions were elevated. However, sales held up and were essentially flat. On the global equity side, a large institutional redemption of about $1.5 billion from an emerging markets strategy increased net outflows as did retail outflows from the U.S. versions of mutual global discovery and Templeton Global Funds. As of quarter end, Templeton Global Bond and Templeton Global Total Return Fund underperformed on an absolute and relative basis due to currency positions, which offset the impact of interest rates strategies and the mutual impact of sovereign credit exposures. As a result, we continue to see net outflows in global fixed income from our retail clients.
Our global macro team believes that a return to a more normalized monetary policy in the U.S. has the potential to catalyze global markets towards a broad fundamental recovery.
The strengthening U.S. economy, along with rising U.S. Treasury yields would magnify the fundamental differences between healthy and vulnerable economies, leading to respective appreciations and depreciations against the U.S. dollar. These events could be significant catalysts for improved performance on our global fixed income strategies. In fact, over the past month through October, the Global Bond Fund recaptured a sizable portion of its year-to-date underperformance due to its currency positions and a slight rise in rates. 
U.S. equity redemptions increased this quarter, which was consistent with the industry leading to net outflows of almost $3 billion for the category. Looking at hybrid flows, we've seen an uptick in sales from Q1 into the Franklin Income Fund due to sustained performance improvements, and the fund has been our highest gross selling product for 7 months in a row. 
While sales have been fairly flat for the past 3 quarters, we've also seen a consistent slowdown of redemptions leading to improved net flows for this fund, although hybrid products remain net outflows overall. 
U.S. fixed income was a clear positive story for us this quarter. Good performance and attractive yields in our tax-free income products, combined with the strong brand and long-standing history in the bond market has generated increased demand for these products in recent quarter, leading to strong sales and net inflows of $600 million for the quarter. Majority of that has been on our California bond funds with a number of them finishing in the top 10 for net flows. 
The U.S. taxable funds, while not quite in positive territory, continue their upward trajectory with the significant increase in sales and a decrease in redemptions this quarter. 
I'd now like to turn it over to Ken to discuss operating results.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg. The financial results for the year reflected some of the challenges that Greg mentioned, but remains solid. Operating income for the year was a strong $2.4 billion. This was due in part to a number of cost management initiatives that resulte
componenttext:
Thanks, Greg. The financial results for the year reflected some of the challenges that Greg mentioned, but remains solid. Operating income for the year was a strong $2.4 billion. This was due in part to a number of cost management initiatives that resulted in sales and distribution expense savings, inclusive of implementation costs of more than 5%. This exceeded the cost savings projections I provided last quarter because we decided not to secure the assets and liabilities of a closed pension fund in Europe. 
In light of the changing economic climate in Europe, it no longer made economic sense to pursue that course of action.
Net income was $1.7 billion, a decrease of 15%, and earnings per share was $2.94, a decrease of only 11% due to a 5% decrease in shares outstanding. Focusing on the fourth quarter, on Slide 15, operating income was almost $580 million, a slight decrease of 3% from the third quarter. Net income was $472 million and earnings per share was $0.82.
Investment management fees increased slightly, reflecting a similar increase in daily average assets under management from last quarter. Excluding performance of these of $3.3 million, the effective fee rate, based on daily average assets under management, was down slightly, offsetting the additional day in the quarter.
Sales and distribution fees decreased to $441 million as a modest increase in asset-based fees were more than offset by lower U.S. commissionable sales. Shareholder servicing fees were $58 million, a 5% decrease from last quarter, due mostly to lower billable accounts following the annual purge of closed accounts in the U.S. during the quarter.
Operating expenses declined 1% as seasonal increase in several expense categories offset lower compensation and sales and distribution expenses.
Compensation and benefits expense was $317 million, a decrease of almost $10 million due to lower severance and payroll taxes in the current quarter. IT, occupancy and general and administrative expenses all experienced a seasonal increase, as typical of the fourth quarter.
Looking towards fiscal 2017, based on the current revenue environment, we are budgeting for non-sales and distribution expenses to be flat to down a couple percent compared with 2016.
We recognize that we cannot cut our way to growth and plan to invest some of last year's cost reductions into growth initiatives, including extending our ETF platform and new product launches as well as new technology. That of course means, from a modeling perspective, we are budgeting for technology expense to increase.
As illustrated on Slide 18, the decline in average assets under management led to a lower but still very strong operating margin of 35.7% for the year. The fiscal year tax rate came in about 150 basis points lower than anticipated at 29.7% in rough terms. About half of this was attributable to discrete items, but the rest reflecting earnings mix.
We're currently forecasting the fiscal year 2017 tax rate to be around 31.5%, with the relative mix of U.S. earnings to that of lower tax jurisdictions expected to push the rate up or down. 
Investment in other income, net of noncontrolling interest, was $65 million, more or less flat compared to the prior quarter with most of the gains coming from equity method investments.
Turning to capital management. We repurchased an additional 7.2 million shares during the quarter at a total cost of $256 million. This brought total repurchases for the year to 36.6 million shares at a total cost of $1.3 billion.
Combined with dividends, the fiscal year payout was over $1.7 billion, representing a total payout ratio of over 100% of net income. This exceeds U.S. earnings and resulted in a $500 million decrease in U.S. net cash and investments since last year. 
This concludes our comments on the quarter's results. Looking forward to speaking with you on the call later today.

This exceeded the cost savings projections I provided last quarter because we decided not to secure the assets and liabilities of a closed pension fund in Europe. In light of the changing economic climate in Europe, it no longer made economic sense to pursue that course of action.
Net income was $1.7 billion, a decrease of 15%. And earnings per share was $2.94, a decrease of only 11% due to a 5% decrease in shares outstanding. Focusing on the fourth quarter, on Slide 15, operating income was almost $580 million, a slight decrease of 3% from the third quarter. Net income was $472 million and earnings per share was $0.82.
Investment management fees increased slightly, reflecting a similar increase in daily average assets under management from last quarter. Excluding performance fees of $3.3 million, the effective fee rate based on daily average assets under management was down slightly, offsetting the additional day in the quarter.
Sales and distribution fees decreased to $441 million as the modest increase in asset-based fees were more than offset by lower U.S. commissionable sales. Shareholder servicing fees were $58 million, a 5% decrease from last quarter, due mostly to lower billable accounts following the annual purge of closed accounts in the U.S. during the quarter.
Operating expenses declined 1% as seasonal increase in several expense categories offset lower compensation and sales and distribution expenses.
Compensation and benefits expense was $317 million, a decrease of almost $10 million due to lower severance and payroll taxes in the current quarter. IT, occupancy and general and administrative expenses all experienced a seasonal increase as typical of the fourth quarter.
Looking towards fiscal 2017, based on the current revenue environment, we're budgeting for non-sales and distribution expenses to be flat to down a couple percent compared with 2016.
We recognize that we cannot cut our way to growth and plan to invest some of last year's cost reductions into growth initiatives, including expanding our ETF platform and new product launches as well as new technology. That, of course, means from a modeling perspective, we are budgeting for technology expense to increase.
As illustrated on Slide 18, the decline in average assets under management led to a lower though still very strong operating margin of 35.7% for the year. The fiscal year tax rate came in about 150 basis points lower than anticipated at 29.7% in rough terms. About half of this was attributable to discrete items, with the rest reflecting earnings mix.
We're currently forecasting the fiscal year 2017 tax rate to be around 31.5%, with the relative mix of U.S. earnings to that of lower tax jurisdictions expected to push the rate up or down.
Investment and other income net of noncontrolling interest was $65 million, more or less flat compared to the prior quarter, with most of the gains coming from equity method investments.
Turning to capital management. We repurchased an additional 7.2 million shares during the quarter at a total cost of $256 million. This brought total repurchases for the year to 36.6 million shares at a total cost of $1.3 billion.
Combined with dividends, the fiscal year payout was over $1.7 billion, representing a total payout ratio of over 100% of net income. This exceeds U.S. earnings and resulted in a $500 million decrease in U.S. net cash and investments since last year.
This concludes our comments on the quarter's results, looking forward to speaking with you on the call later today.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hello, and good morning. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO, along with Ken Lewis, our CFO. Thank you for taking the time to listen to our commentary on fourth quarter and fiscal year results.This was a challenging year in many respects. However, I'm pleased to see
componenttext:
Hello, and good morning. I'm Greg Johnson, CEO, along with Ken Lewis, our CFO. Thank you for taking the time to listen to our commentary on fourth quarter and fiscal year results.
This was a challenging year in many respects. However, I'm pleased to see that investment performance broadly improved over the course of the year and that we made significant progress on our most important strategic initiatives. Improved investment performance has clearly helped to slow redemptions, which were down almost 25% from last year. We did see a modest improvement in international retail flows, but that was offset by some institutional redemptions as well as improved U.S. fixed income flows.
Financial results were solid with operating income of $2.4 billion on a 36% operating margin. On the capital management side, we returned over $1.7 billion to investors through dividends and share repurchases, representing more than 100% of net income. For the year, we purchased 36.6 million shares, decreasing shares outstanding by 5.5% on a net basis.
Understandably, the Department of Labor's fiduciary rule has triggered a number of questions from investors. And while it's clear that the rule will greatly impact the financial services firms, I want to assure everyone that we are working closely with our distribution partners to ensure our firm is well positioned once the rule takes effect.
Many broker-dealers are choosing to apply the Best Interest Contract Exemption allowed under the rule, while also building new mutual fund programs to offer levelized pricing and compensation. The industry is moving in the direction of 2 general product types. The first is a more traditional share class structure with lower commission and standardized 12b-1 fees, while the second will have more of a transaction-based fee structure. There's still a lot of work to be done, but introducing new share classes and responding to evolving regulations is nothing new to us.
Overall, our investment teams continue to deliver solid, long-term performance and importantly, we've seen relative performance improve in several key areas over the last year. Franklin Income Fund, our largest fund by assets, outperformed its benchmark for the year and was a top-decile performer against its peer group. Other key funds such as Franklin Rising Dividends, with its focus on dividend growth; and Templeton Foreign, an international equity strategy, experienced very strong rebounds in absolute and relative performance, beating their benchmarks and delivering top quartile relative performance.
Another positive development on the performance front is the enhancements that Morningstar is making in its rating methodology. Among other changes, Morningstar is removing load adjustments that previously assumed the maximum fee for load investors, even though most investors don't pay any sales charge in an A share class. This change will level out the playing field between share classes and better reflect current state of the industry. At the industry level, most funds are expected to keep their current star rating. However, we estimate that nearly 1/3 of our Class A shares will see an increase of 1 star, including key funds like Templeton Global Bond and Franklin Rising Dividend.
Assets under management were essentially flat compared to last quarter as we continue to benefit from a diversified mix of assets under management. Long-term outflows continue. While sales were flat this quarter, redemptions increased somewhat, leading to outflows of $22 billion, but market appreciation of $24 billion offset the impact of flows for the quarter.
From a retail perspective, redemptions have been improving since the fourth quarter of last year on the back of improving performance. Sales overall continue to be challenged as advisers remain cautious given the ongoing volatility, historical performance challenges and the upcoming implementation of the DOL rule in the U.S. Consequently, large outflows continue from certain flagship funds. We did, however, see international retail sales improve again this quarter, driven by a pickup in demand from clients in Asia and parts of Europe for a range of strategies.
While it may take some time given current economic conditions and market valuations, we remain confident that demand for our flagship products will recover as advisers and clients are utilizing a wait-and-see approach to determine if there's a consistency in improved performance.
In the meantime, we continue to keep advisers informed about the current positioning of our portfolios and the perspective behind the portfolio manager's convictions. Our variable annuity business, which is included in U.S. retail flows, has been under pressure for the past 2 years as some of our insurance partners exited the business, while others made a shift to passive. Those decisions led to cumulative net outflows of $13 billion since the fourth quarter of last year, including $1 billion this quarter from our variable insurance product and sub-advised funds. Those flows have impacted nearly all investment objectives and are illustrated in the flow graphs by investment objective.
We wanted to provide some additional clarity and background on flows from this business because we expect an additional $2.6 billion of redemptions to hit this quarter, with most of that expected in October and an additional $4.8 billion to be redeemed in the second quarter. This remains an important business for the company, and we believe that we are now better positioned to meet the evolving asset allocation needs of our insurance partners.
Looking now at flows by investment objective for the quarter. Overall flows into our global strategies remain challenged as redemptions were elevated. However, sales held up and were essentially flat. On the global equity side, a large institutional redemption of about $1.5 billion from an emerging market strategy increased net outflows as did retail outflows from the U.S. versions of Mutual Global Discovery and Templeton Growth Funds. As of quarter end, Templeton Global Bond and Templeton Global Total Return Funds underperformed on an absolute and relative basis due to currency positions, which offset the impact of interest rate strategies and the neutral impact of sovereign credit exposures. As a result, we continue to see net outflows in global fixed income from our retail clients.
Our global macro team believes that a return to a more normalized monetary policy in the U.S. has the potential to catalyze global markets towards a broad fundamental recovery.
The strengthening U.S. economy, along with rising U.S. Treasury yields would magnify the fundamental differences between healthy and vulnerable economies, leading to respective appreciations and depreciations against the U.S. dollar. These events could be significant catalysts for improved performance on our global fixed income strategies. In fact, over the past month through October, the Global Bond Fund recaptured a sizable portion of its year-to-date underperformance due to its currency positions and a slight rise in rates.
U.S. equity redemptions increased this quarter, which was consistent with the industry, leading to net outflows of almost $3 billion for the category. Looking at hybrid flows, we've seen an uptick in sales from Q1 into the Franklin Income Fund due to sustained performance improvements, and the fund has been the firm's highest gross selling product for 7 months in a row. While sales have been fairly flat for the past 3 quarters, we've also seen a consistent slowdown of redemptions, leading to improved net flows for this fund, although hybrid products remain in net outflows overall.
U.S. fixed income was a clear positive story for us this quarter. Good performance and attractive yields in our tax-free income products, combined with a strong brand and long-standing history in the municipal bond market, has generated increased demand for these products in recent quarters, leading to strong sales and net inflows of $600 million for the quarter. Majority of that has been in our California bond funds, with a number of them finishing in the top 10 for net flows.
The U.S. taxable funds, while not quite in positive territory, continue their upward trajectory with a significant increase in sales and a decrease in redemptions this quarter.
I'd now like to turn it over to Ken to discuss operating results.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Pre Recorded Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg. The financial results for the year reflected some of the challenges that Greg mentioned, but remained solid. Operating income for the year was a strong $2.4 billion. This was due in part to a number of cost management initiatives that result
componenttext:

This was due in part to a number of cost management initiatives that resulted in non-sales and distribution expense savings, inclusive of implementation cost of more than 5%. This exceeded the cost savings projections I provided last quarter because we decided not to secure the assets and liabilities of a closed pension plan in Europe. In light of the changing economic climate in Europe, it no longer made economic sense to pursue that course of action.

Shareholder servicing fees were $58 million, a 5% decrease from last quarter, due mostly to lower billable accounts following the annual purge of closed accounts in the U.S. during the quarter.
Operating expenses declined 1% as seasonal increase in several expense categories offset lower compensation and sales and distribution expenses.
Compensation and benefits expense was $317 million, a decrease of almost $10 million due to lower severance and payroll taxes in the current quarter. IT, occupancy and general and administrative expenses all experienced a seasonal increase as typical of the fourth quarter.
Looking towards fiscal 2017, based on the current revenue environment, we're budgeting for non-sales and distribution expenses to be flat to down a couple percent compared with 2016.

The fiscal year tax rate came in about 150 basis points lower than anticipated at 29.7% in rough terms. About half of this was attributable to discrete items, with the rest reflecting earnings mix.
We're currently forecasting the fiscal year 2017 tax rate to be around 31.5%, with the relative mix of U.S. earnings to that of lower tax jurisdictions expected to push the rate up or down.
Investment and other income net of noncontrolling interest was $65 million, more or less flat compared to the prior quarter, with most of the gains coming from equity method investments.
Turning to capital management. We repurchased an additional 7.2 million shares during the quarter at a total cost of $256 million. This brought total repurchases for the year to 36.6 million shares at a total cost of $1.3 billion.
Combined with dividends, the fiscal year payout was over $1.7 billion, representing a total payout ratio of over 100% of net income. This exceeds U.S. earnings and resulted in a $500 million decrease in U.S. net cash and investments since last year.
This concludes our comments on the quarter's results, looking forward to speaking with you on the call later today.

componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Brenda, and I will be your operator today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. And at this time, I would like to turn the call over to Franklin Resources Chairman and CEO, Mr. Greg Johnson.
componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Brenda, and I will be your operator today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. 
And at this time, I would like to turn the call over to Franklin Resources Chairman and CEO, Mr. Greg Johnson. Mr. Johnson, you may begin.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, hello, and thank you for joining us this morning. In addition to Ken Lewis and myself, we have Tom Regner with us today. And Tom is the Head of our U.S. Advisory Services, responsible for both the retail and institutional business in the U.S.Fisca
componenttext:
Well, hello, and thank you for joining us this morning. In addition to Ken Lewis and myself, we have Tom Regner with us today. And Tom is the Head of our U.S. Advisory Services, responsible for both the retail and institutional business in the U.S.
Fiscal 2016 was challenging in many respects as performance headwinds led to elevated outflows, but expense management and capital return were clearly positive. I'm encouraged by improving performance trends with several flagship funds. As I mentioned in my comments this morning, Franklin Income Fund was ranked in the top decile of its peer group on a 1-year basis, and we saw improvements in all major asset classes over all primary time frames this quarter. 
Furthermore, the Global Bond Fund has had significant outperformance in the month of October month-to-date, returning over 5% through the 25th, beating its benchmark by over 800 basis points and its peer group by more than 600 basis points. 
I'd like to now open it up for your questions. Thank you.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our first question comes from the line of Michael Carrier with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our first question comes from the line of Michael Carrier with Bank of America.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, maybe, first, for you just on the Department of Labor. You mentioned on the prerecorded call, you guys in the industry are focused on some strategies around the DOL. I think you said 2 potential kind of paths. Just wondered if you can provide more c
componenttext: Greg, maybe, first, for you just on the Department of Labor. You mentioned on the prerecorded call, you guys in the industry are focused on some strategies around the DOL. I think you said 2 potential kind of paths. Just wondered if you can provide more color on the likely options and then any update on your exposure on the retirement channel and maybe how this uncertainty has been weighing on flows. So whether it's the sales or the pickup in redemptions.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think it's tough to really estimate what effect it could have on sales, but I think it clearly has been very disruptive to the advisers business right now in sorting out what is going to happen. I think from the last call, we continue to ma
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think it's tough to really estimate what effect it could have on sales, but I think it clearly has been very disruptive to the advisers business right now in sorting out what is going to happen. I think from the last call, we continue to make a lot of progress, a lot of work being done on getting ready for April. I think the good news is that there seems -- our concern has always been that it's not workable to come out with a different pricing structure for every broker-dealer out there, and we seem to be narrowing those options down to, hopefully, two. And then you saw the recent announcement around a clean share class or super-class or whatever you want to call them and having more of a stripped-down version available at some point in the future. That could be an option as well where you have the pricing handled at the broker-dealer level. All of that, I think, is happening. The question about what effect will it have, I think the net effect -- there were some surveys done. It said -- one said that you'll have 10% to 15% less advisers out there. I think that some would retire. The transition is going to be very difficult to go to the new model. So I think that, that can be disruptive as well. And I just think overall, our sense is once we get past this, you'll get to a more normalized environment. But right now, it is very disruptive force for the adviser. And I'll ask Tom Regner who's been involved more day to day if he has anything to add there.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Thank you. So we're spending a lot of time getting ready for next April. On the retail side, we're doing a lot of training and kicking off some internal training for both the internal team and the external sales team because we're moving toward
componenttext: All right. Thank you. So we're spending a lot of time getting ready for next April. On the retail side, we're doing a lot of training and kicking off some internal training for both the internal team and the external sales team because we're moving towards an advisory business, which is really selling funds within a portfolio context, which is different than we have and our competitors have been doing in the past. So we're getting ready as fast as we can for that change.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got it. And then just as a follow-up. I guess, just on the cash. So you guys have been active this year with buybacks and the dividend. But for the non-U.S. cash, if we do get at a repatriation holiday next year or the year after -- and this is, I g
componenttext: Okay. Got it. And then just as a follow-up. I guess, just on the cash. So you guys have been active this year with buybacks and the dividend. But for the non-U.S. cash, if we do get at a repatriation holiday next year or the year after -- and this is, I guess, for Greg or Ken, just what would be either the plan or the options with that cash? And then if not, have you thought about ways that you can maybe create some value with that non-U.S. cash given that you don't tend to get much credit for sitting outside the U.S.?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess, my -- the way I would answer this question is it's hard to say exactly what we would do because we would have to see what the new rules are if and when they come out. But I'd just point back to what we did the last time, which was probably
componenttext: Well, I guess, my -- the way I would answer this question is it's hard to say exactly what we would do because we would have to see what the new rules are if and when they come out. But I'd just point back to what we did the last time, which was probably over 10 years ago now, where we repatriated the cash and then I think we've paid a special dividend. So those are all the options, but we would definitely try to take advantage of whatever was in the best interest of shareholders based on the law.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I would just add, I mean, how we think about it, I mean -- I think we all would maybe agree now that the probability is higher as we get past the election on having some form of repatriation. And you look at that offshore cash, and you could discount
componenttext: And I would just add, I mean, how we think about it, I mean -- I think we all would maybe agree now that the probability is higher as we get past the election on having some form of repatriation. And you look at that offshore cash, and you could discount it. Well, it'd be probably a 20% haircut or so if you take it back to the U.S. So as -- I think as far as how the board and management thinks about it is if you have an opportunity offshore, it's 20% cheaper than the one onshore. So we continue to look at anything that would be accretive and additive to our lineup offshore first.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Dan Fannon with Jefferies.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Dan Fannon with Jefferies.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, Greg, you highlighted the variable annuity outflows that have been occurring and are, I guess, slated to occur over the next couple of quarters. Can you talk a bit about why that's occurring again, just to refresh us, and if it's DOL related? And
componenttext: I guess, Greg, you highlighted the variable annuity outflows that have been occurring and are, I guess, slated to occur over the next couple of quarters. Can you talk a bit about why that's occurring again, just to refresh us, and if it's DOL related? And then ultimately, what's the AUM left in those buckets that maybe longer term might be at risk?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll start, and again, I have Tom because I -- we figured those questions would come up with DOL and, specifically, VA. And we have a very strong business in that area, sub-advising as well as separate funds that are for the annuity business. And rea
componenttext: Yes, I'll start, and again, I have Tom because I -- we figured those questions would come up with DOL and, specifically, VA. And we have a very strong business in that area, sub-advising as well as separate funds that are for the annuity business. And really, many of the large players that we grew, I think, at a high of about $70 billion in assets in that category, the -- many of the big names have gotten out of that business. And as they wind down the assets, many are going to in-house and pass it over low volatility strategies. And we're trying to capture as much as that transition is possible, but it has put a large block of business in transition at risk. I think for next quarter, we're estimating another $2.6 billion in outflows. And today, we're at $40 billion -- $35 billion approximately in assets that are remaining. And I'll let -- Tom, if you have anything to add on the business itself?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Greg covered what's going on. Well, what we're doing in response is we have established a dedicated insurance solutions group within our overall solutions portfolio group, and we're developing portfolios that are -- that have less basis risk. I mean,
componenttext: Yes. Greg covered what's going on. Well, what we're doing in response is we have established a dedicated insurance solutions group within our overall solutions portfolio group, and we're developing portfolios that are -- that have less basis risk. I mean, one of the issues is with the insurance companies that there was a high basis risk in some of their underlying portfolios for the VA contracts. So we're working on reducing that. And I think you'll see in the next 4 or 5 days one of the top 5 insurance companies by sales is going to be announcing a new VA living benefit that's backed by a customized Franklin Templeton portfolio. So we're working very hard to make sure that we stay relevant with the firms that are staying in the business.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as of quarter-end, we had $46 billion remaining in VA assets.
componenttext: And as of quarter-end, we had $46 billion remaining in VA assets.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just a follow-up, I guess, maybe Tom for you on the DOL. It seems as if the industry is facing a gross sales issue today because of the uncertainty. I guess, as you kind of -- we get closer to the implementation date, are you guys assuming
componenttext: Great. And then just a follow-up, I guess, maybe Tom for you on the DOL. It seems as if the industry is facing a gross sales issue today because of the uncertainty. I guess, as you kind of -- we get closer to the implementation date, are you guys assuming -- or as you talk to advisers, is there assumption -- is there going to be a step function higher in terms of assets in motion, whether that -- whether we see redemptions pick up or, obviously, gross sales could pick up as well? But I guess, have you -- where are we, do you think, in this transition phase for adviser behavior at this point?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don't think you're going to see a pickup in redemptions. There are some awfully attractive living benefits out there historically, which frankly hurt some of the insurance companies. I think what you're going to see, though, is initially there's go
componenttext: Yes. I don't think you're going to see a pickup in redemptions. There are some awfully attractive living benefits out there historically, which frankly hurt some of the insurance companies. I think what you're going to see, though, is initially there's going to be a slowdown in sales within the VA business because the commissions are coming down. There's no question about that. There's going to be shorter surrender time. So the VA business is going to be in a state of flux. But we know from working with our clients -- so we work with the top 5 in the industry -- that they're not standing still, right? So they are coming out and will be coming out with new products to stay relevant in the new -- with the new DOL legislation.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, my comment was just on mutual fund sales, not on the VA. So just generally, in terms of the adviser behavior broadly, not just with VA.
componenttext: I guess, my comment was just on mutual fund sales, not on the VA. So just generally, in terms of the adviser behavior broadly, not just with VA.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I mean, I don't know that there's going to be -- I mean, look, people still need to invest; they still need to retire; they still need to provide for college education. As Greg mentioned, that it's going to be difficult for some advisers because a lot
componenttext: No. I mean, I don't know that there's going to be -- I mean, look, people still need to invest; they still need to retire; they still need to provide for college education. As Greg mentioned, that it's going to be difficult for some advisers because a lot of the business is going advisory. I think the number is you need to have about $30 million as an adviser of assets under management to have a viable business. So it's going to be hard for some people to stay in business if they don't have a sizable book. So there will be some transition in the advisers themselves, but there's still a very, very strong demand that's not changing.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I just think it's still early to kind of forecast. There's a lot of people that would argue that the amount of money in motion, it could slow down because of tax considerations, too, if you have taxable gains. And one, you can't take and then move it
componenttext: And I just think it's still early to kind of forecast. There's a lot of people that would argue that the amount of money in motion, it could slow down because of tax considerations, too, if you have taxable gains. And one, you can't take and then move it to another. And this is obviously outside of the retirement world. And then how the incentives line up post this change as well, that could affect behavior on how assets move if some just stay old versus new. It just won't all move at once.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Worthington with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Worthington with JPMorgan.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, I think earlier this year, you called out that you thought the institutional business had a lot of promise, I think, particularly when it came to FX exposure management. Each quarter, we tend to hear about these big outflows. And it seems like there
componenttext: Greg, I think earlier this year, you called out that you thought the institutional business had a lot of promise, I think, particularly when it came to FX exposure management. Each quarter, we tend to hear about these big outflows. And it seems like there's broader base sort of institutional redemptions. So I guess, the question is, help us understand what's going on in the institutional side of the business and maybe characterize how you see the outlook.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's been, as you know, I mean, challenging with Templeton and the deep value philosophy. I mean, that cycle has -- the timing of the market has been working against getting new mandates. So the good news is that we've seen things switching,
componenttext: Well, I think it's been, as you know, I mean, challenging with Templeton and the deep value philosophy. I mean, that cycle has -- the timing of the market has been working against getting new mandates. So the good news is that we've seen things switching, moving in the right direction for performance. So hopefully, that's -- that, historically, has been our area where we had the strongest institutional business and still have the largest assets. So it's been more defense and offense as far as wins. I think the opportunities we're seeing in local debt around the globe, especially in Asia, we continue to work hard on those and have, I think, a lot of opportunities that are still there in the pipeline. We've gotten a few, but we still think that will be in the strongest area of growth. Then I'll -- Tom, if you want to add any.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, what we're seeing in the U.S. is a re-risking of portfolios. If you look at the public pension plans, they're severely underfunded. They need higher return. So they're starting to look at portfolios or asset classes that provide a high risk-a
componenttext: Yes. I mean, what we're seeing in the U.S. is a re-risking of portfolios. If you look at the public pension plans, they're severely underfunded. They need higher return. So they're starting to look at portfolios or asset classes that provide a high risk-adjusted return. So I think that speaks well for some of the capabilities that we have on a global basis in fixed income. And as Greg pointed out, with value coming back, that speaks well for Templeton and Templeton Group, too. But they have to re-risk those portfolios, and we want to participate.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then I think just a follow-up on Mike's question earlier on repatriation. How much time do you think it will take to evaluate the chances of repatriation or a repatriation holiday after elections? Is it something that you think is sort of appar
componenttext: Great. And then I think just a follow-up on Mike's question earlier on repatriation. How much time do you think it will take to evaluate the chances of repatriation or a repatriation holiday after elections? Is it something that you think is sort of apparent pretty quickly? Or it's just going to take 2 or 3 years? And if it does take 2 or 3 years, as long as the chances of a repatriation holiday aren't 0, do you think it's just best to sit on the cash and wait? Or do you start to get frustrated and make it a priority to maybe better utilize the cash?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Ken. As Greg mentioned, we're always looking for opportunities to grow the business, and that won't change internationally. Greg mentioned that all things being equal, it's -- an acquisition is cheaper for use offshore cash. And so that -- it
componenttext: Yes. This is Ken. As Greg mentioned, we're always looking for opportunities to grow the business, and that won't change internationally. Greg mentioned that all things being equal, it's -- an acquisition is cheaper for use offshore cash. And so that -- it's not that we're sitting and we're not doing anything else waiting for repatriation. So I do want to make that clear. We are looking for opportunities. And so that's one of the strategic advantages of having all that cash, we'll be able to move on something if the opportunity presented itself. But regarding the time line for repatriation, there's been a lot of momentum, and we feel like it's gaining momentum. Congress is working on the issue. We feel like when they come back in session January or something, they might be talking about it. Our advisers remind us all the time that 4 of the last 5 presidents enacted tax reform by August of their first year. So we are optimistic of it -- about it, and we're also looking for other ways to use that cash.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of William Katz with Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of William Katz with Citigroup.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, maybe one for you to get started. You gave some guidance on expenses for fiscal '17 over '16. Within that construct, you also talked a little bit about some investments getting picked up on the tech line. Stepping back more broadly, if we were to sor
componenttext: Ken, maybe one for you to get started. You gave some guidance on expenses for fiscal '17 over '16. Within that construct, you also talked a little bit about some investments getting picked up on the tech line. Stepping back more broadly, if we were to sort of replicate 2017 -- 2016, '17, we assume, defined by choppy markets and some sluggish organic growth, how much expense flexibility do you have at this point? I guess, the question I'm really asking is, are you sort of reaching the point now where you get a little more limited on expenses absent some maybe that revenue-generating point of the company?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there's still flexibility on the expense -- on all the expenses. But having said that, I do think we're in a phase where those opportunities take longer to execute. They have to -- they tend to be more linked with strategic initiatives. So we cont
componenttext: I think there's still flexibility on the expense -- on all the expenses. But having said that, I do think we're in a phase where those opportunities take longer to execute. They have to -- they tend to be more linked with strategic initiatives. So we continue to look at all that. Is the business the right size, et cetera? Are we leveraging technology the best way we can? So I do think there's opportunities, but I don't think there's a lot of quick hits that would move the dial.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Greg, so curious. It's been sort of a merger of equals between Janus and Henderson, a business that, I think, you go up against in various geographies around the world. Does that transaction in and of itself, or the implication of the trans
componenttext: Okay. And then Greg, so curious. It's been sort of a merger of equals between Janus and Henderson, a business that, I think, you go up against in various geographies around the world. Does that transaction in and of itself, or the implication of the transaction, does that shift the mind-set a little bit? And could you maybe allude that in with the allocation within repatriation between acquisition versus buyback versus dividends?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I mean, I don't think it changes the mind-set. I think in that case, there was clear benefits for the 2 firms to get into 2 different markets and leverage the distribution of each side to do that. I think the consensus out there of consolidation does
componenttext: No. I mean, I don't think it changes the mind-set. I think in that case, there was clear benefits for the 2 firms to get into 2 different markets and leverage the distribution of each side to do that. I think the consensus out there of consolidation does create a wave of consolidation. Obviously, this is a slower growth business; it's a more mature business. And one way to gain efficiencies is through consolidation. So I think companies, as I said before, are going to be much more open to looking at that avenue to create value.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Alex Blostein with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Alex Blostein with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, to follow up on the, I guess, evolution of the distribution channel and the potential implications for you guys. Heard you on the prepared remarks around potentially launching a new share class, and that's something you guys talked about in the pas
componenttext: First, to follow up on the, I guess, evolution of the distribution channel and the potential implications for you guys. Heard you on the prepared remarks around potentially launching a new share class, and that's something you guys talked about in the past as well. But any thoughts around the implications for management fees for you specifically and the industry broadly as we go through this adjustment in the distribution channel?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think as far as the preparation in effect, I mean, think management fees is something that again -- I mean, it -- this is an extremely competitive business. We all see the battle versus passive every day. So the pressure on management fees
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think as far as the preparation in effect, I mean, think management fees is something that again -- I mean, it -- this is an extremely competitive business. We all see the battle versus passive every day. So the pressure on management fees is there regardless of DOL or not. I think the question around your product lineup, and it's something that maybe Ken touched on a little bit on just where do we see potential savings in streamlining and what is DOL, I think it, probably for us, pushes us further down that path of trying to simplify the lineup and rationalize funds that may -- in a post-DOL world, may not fit neatly into more of an advisory model versus a traditional brokerage model. Those are the debates we're having internally now, and that could create some efficiencies. But I think from a cost side, this is a business that every basis point is going to matter. And I think the good news on some outcomes from the DOL is you're going to have a lower front-end sales charge that will help with some of your relative rankings. And then as we said, and I think in our announcement at Morningstar, it's now the A shares is not going to use those maximum charge because most of it's done at a net asset value. And that's going to make us more competitive where we see a lot of our funds will increase its star rating. So I think those are very positive outcomes, and I think our concern of having 35 share classes at least now where we feel like we'll only have to add a few.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then my second question along similar lines, I guess. But historically, you guys were very successful with kind of keeping more assets within the Franklin fund family in the brokerage channel, partially because, I guess, of waived commission o
componenttext: Got it. And then my second question along similar lines, I guess. But historically, you guys were very successful with kind of keeping more assets within the Franklin fund family in the brokerage channel, partially because, I guess, of waived commission once a client already paid that commission in one fund moving to another. As you migrate over to the advisory channel, can you help us understand how that could impact asset retention? And maybe just from a historical perspective, kind of like what's sort of percentage of the growth sales that has come from kind of folks switching from one fund to another?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don't have that number. I think anytime you go to more of the adviser-type, gatekeeper-driven model. It's the pros and cons. I mean, you can get significant assets quickly, and you could lose significant assets quickly. I think that's the net effec
componenttext: Yes. I don't have that number. I think anytime you go to more of the adviser-type, gatekeeper-driven model. It's the pros and cons. I mean, you can get significant assets quickly, and you could lose significant assets quickly. I think that's the net effect. I think the advantage of the transition, it's like a funnel where there's going to be less funds available in the new model. But if you have large assets, the probability of your fund being included, even in a period of underperformance, it's highly unlikely that it's going to be eliminated from that lineup. So I think size matters quite a bit as far as continuing to get shelf space in the new model. But it is higher from a retention standpoint than your traditional brokerage model where it's more a one-on-one relationship. Here, it's more of a gatekeeper-, consultant-driven, more institutional-type relationship. And we've transitioned our model to, I think, adapt to that and have more people with consulting experience at that point of contact with the home offices.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Ken Hill with Barclays.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Ken Hill with Barclays.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up on something from earlier in the call. You mentioned -- looking at the opportunities, you continue [indiscernible] that, but that's kind of pretty consistent with how you've talked about that in past quarters. I'm just curious h
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up on something from earlier in the call. You mentioned -- looking at the opportunities, you continue [indiscernible] that, but that's kind of pretty consistent with how you've talked about that in past quarters. I'm just curious how you're evaluating some of those opportunities is related to the cash you guys have and maybe what criteria or metrics you might look at base the decision on to potentially grow something versus look to M&A to jump-start some activity there.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think in previous calls, we've talked about the sheer volume of things that we look at every year, and that continues. And I would say the criteria that we use is a lot of it's qualitative. We focus on the institutional process -- institutionalize
componenttext: Sure. I think in previous calls, we've talked about the sheer volume of things that we look at every year, and that continues. And I would say the criteria that we use is a lot of it's qualitative. We focus on the institutional process -- institutionalized investment process, can be repeatable [indiscernible] risk, all of that, because it's a people business, and cultural fit. And that quickly eliminates a lot of prospectives. But -- so that really hasn't changed. And Greg touched on what's -- some of the criterias that we might look at. So I think no change to what we said in the past.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Patrick Davitt with Autonomous.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Patrick Davitt with Autonomous.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: First of all, I just wanted to clarify, the $46 billion of VA, is that before or after the $7.4 billion of outflow you talked about in the pre-recorded call?
componenttext: First of all, I just wanted to clarify, the $46 billion of VA, is that before or after the $7.4 billion of outflow you talked about in the pre-recorded call?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's before.
componenttext: That's before.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the other question I have is on, first, the liquidity rule and then broader regulatory concerns. One, do you have any initial thoughts on the expense associated with compliance with the rule and/or potential performance impacts on your fund
componenttext: Okay. And then the other question I have is on, first, the liquidity rule and then broader regulatory concerns. One, do you have any initial thoughts on the expense associated with compliance with the rule and/or potential performance impacts on your funds that invest in more illiquid assets? And more broadly, does your expense guidance for 2017 include any associated expense for becoming compliant with that rule?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think it's probably early to answer any cost associated with the rule. I mean, I think it hasn't been out very long. You have 2 years to comply, my understanding. I think it's a much better rule than when it was first discussed as far as so
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think it's probably early to answer any cost associated with the rule. I mean, I think it hasn't been out very long. You have 2 years to comply, my understanding. I think it's a much better rule than when it was first discussed as far as something that is -- appears to be workable. For us, I don't think we have any major concerns on -- at this stage. I mean, we're still studying it, but our first reaction was that it is -- would not create issues on the portfolio management side for any of our funds. But again, it's -- we're studying the rule like most right now. But I think it's a better outcome than what was first discussed. And I think liquidity is something that we manage very carefully with our boards. And I feel like that's one of the most important parts of our business is managing liquidity, especially in open-end 40 Act-type funds.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Robert Lee with KBW.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Robert Lee with KBW.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just going back to the DOL, and this maybe kind of feels like beating a dead horse a little bit. But you talked a lot about the impact on the fund business. But if there's going to be a movement to advisory, presumably, that should increase demand for the
componenttext: Just going back to the DOL, and this maybe kind of feels like beating a dead horse a little bit. But you talked a lot about the impact on the fund business. But if there's going to be a movement to advisory, presumably, that should increase demand for the SMA business. So I mean, that's not a part of the business that, I think, in the past you talked about much. Can you maybe update us on how you feel you're positioned maybe with the -- in the SMA part of the retail world and if that's a place where you feel like maybe you need -- ought to need to make some changes or some investment?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Tom. So we -- that's good observation. We've actually added to the SMA business. It had been kind of, if you will, a quiet part of the retail business, but we've added to it over the last 2 years. We've moved it into our private wealth divisi
componenttext: Yes. This is Tom. So we -- that's good observation. We've actually added to the SMA business. It had been kind of, if you will, a quiet part of the retail business, but we've added to it over the last 2 years. We've moved it into our private wealth division because we think that there is a big role for that in the high net worth part of our business, and we're working on adding some ESG screens to that part of the business as well because we're seeing that as kind of an increasing demand in the high net worth business. So good observation. We're building it up.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then also sticking with the DOL, I mean -- I hear different things from different advisers and different managers as -- I mean, obviously, you're going to have a level fee setting for doing it back and all that. But one of the things that seems
componenttext: Okay. And then also sticking with the DOL, I mean -- I hear different things from different advisers and different managers as -- I mean, obviously, you're going to have a level fee setting for doing it back and all that. But one of the things that seems to put different themes on is what happens to things like platform fees, things like revenue share. I mean, so what's your current thought? Do you think that in many cases, distributors won't be able to charge platform fees? Or some argue it's going to go up. Others just argue it's going to go away. So what do you kind of hear?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: All of the above. I think that's -- that's why I really -- it's almost daily on some of the different opinions on whether -- how do you retain -- how do you have a level platform fee across different groups that have different perspectives with different
componenttext: All of the above. I think that's -- that's why I really -- it's almost daily on some of the different opinions on whether -- how do you retain -- how do you have a level platform fee across different groups that have different perspectives with different levels and different asset levels and how do you include or exclude the ETFs that wouldn't have that ability. There's all kinds of issues that are still being worked through between. And that's why to sit and say, "Well, it could cost us more, it could cost us less," I would answer yes because I'm not really sure at this stage. We're working through it. Tom, do you have anything...

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, to Greg's point, we have one very large client that said they're not going to take any revenue sharing post April, and they mean new assets they put on the books. And we have another large client who said no, they're going to continue to loo
componenttext: Well, I mean, to Greg's point, we have one very large client that said they're not going to take any revenue sharing post April, and they mean new assets they put on the books. And we have another large client who said no, they're going to continue to look at revenue share as part of their business. So we'll see how it plays out.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Great. And if I could, just maybe one more quick question. On the ETF business, I mean, you've been investing in. And you touched on it, I think, in the pre-recorded call about another place you want to continue to invest. So how are you -- fro
componenttext: All right. Great. And if I could, just maybe one more quick question. On the ETF business, I mean, you've been investing in. And you touched on it, I think, in the pre-recorded call about another place you want to continue to invest. So how are you -- from the outside looking in, how are you thinking about what would ultimately -- what kind of landmarks that we should look for, for success in that? I mean, do you kind of feel like, gee, this is -- we think we can really scale this quickly? Or that's kind of a slow build, and it's hopefully 5-plus years when you'll see an impact? I mean, how are you thinking about whether you're going to be successful or not over the next couple of years?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it is a slow build. I think part of it was just getting in the business, understanding the business and getting the right people that can operate a very different product and a very different skill set than what we traditionally have. I think that
componenttext: I think it is a slow build. I think part of it was just getting in the business, understanding the business and getting the right people that can operate a very different product and a very different skill set than what we traditionally have. I think that has been a -- we would call that a success of having a very strong team in place, and it's really building from here. And recognizing any new funds or ETFs that we roll out take time. So it's really about building shelf space, awareness. I think we continue to do that. And Tom, if you want to add something...

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So to Greg's point, we've added significantly to the ETF distribution team, and they're working with our 100 -- or 90 to 100 wholesalers to leverage up dumba** subject matter experts. So that's on the building brand part of the business. But we're qu
componenttext: Yes. So to Greg's point, we've added significantly to the ETF distribution team, and they're working with our 100 -- or 90 to 100 wholesalers to leverage up dumba** subject matter experts. So that's on the building brand part of the business. But we're quite excited to be able to have as -- and you'll hear that we're going to be building out more of our strategic beta platform. Because we want an adviser to be able to come to Franklin Templeton, and we want to be able to build a portfolio that is either fully active or is partially strategic beta, partially fully active. We, frankly, are agnostic. We want them, though, to be able to come to us and build out a fully featured, fully diversified portfolio. So we're all in on that initiative.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And expanding it outside the U.S., too, is part of the initiative, which will take time.
componenttext: And expanding it outside the U.S., too, is part of the initiative, which will take time.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brennan Hawken with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brennan Hawken with UBS.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, on DOL, can you -- is the idea that you've got some upward expense pressure next year on technology, is that a function of the indications of working with your distribution partners? And as they make those changes to level pricing and some of the a
componenttext: First, on DOL, can you -- is the idea that you've got some upward expense pressure next year on technology, is that a function of the indications of working with your distribution partners? And as they make those changes to level pricing and some of the adjustments that you need to make to your own system, and therefore, that piece is somewhat inflexible?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it is not so much that. It's other projects and initiatives that are underway, particularly in the part of the business that does things like fund accounting and pricing and all that. I think we're -- that's -- we're trying to invest in technology
componenttext: I think it is not so much that. It's other projects and initiatives that are underway, particularly in the part of the business that does things like fund accounting and pricing and all that. I think we're -- that's -- we're trying to invest in technology to make sure that we can scale that going forward and support all of the product demands that are out there in the industry. So it's more of that and less, really, of the DOL. I mean, we think we have a lot of share classes, and we think that we can do that with not -- with just incremental spend but not too much.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay. And then appreciate -- it must be pretty harder to manage all the different distribution partners and all the different approaches. But as you have those discussions and it seems firms are becoming more and more clear in what it is that their
componenttext: Okay. Okay. And then appreciate -- it must be pretty harder to manage all the different distribution partners and all the different approaches. But as you have those discussions and it seems firms are becoming more and more clear in what it is that their policies are here in recent times, do you have an update to the amount of AUM that you think is exposed to this rule? And as you're having discussions with distribution partners, are you seeing any of those partners actually have an impact in the current iterations and in the prep for the current rule on assets beyond just retirement accounts?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I'll just start by saying this rule puts all assets in a different place because -- and again, I think I said this before, but the thought that you can run one pricing structure under retirement and then have the other business at a different pric
componenttext: I mean, I'll just start by saying this rule puts all assets in a different place because -- and again, I think I said this before, but the thought that you can run one pricing structure under retirement and then have the other business at a different pricing structure creates all kinds of problems as well. So I think many are just thinking about moving to one standard at some point. And again, there's different philosophies on that and different phases. And so it's hard to say x percent, but I'd start by saying all of it. At some point, this will -- is a game changer for the traditional way funds are priced. And Tom, do you...

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that you've seen Merrilll Lynch, JPMorgan -- I think today, Commonwealth came out and they said, "Look, we're going to treat the nonretirement business exactly like we're treating the retirement business because it's just too complicated to d
componenttext: Yes. I think that you've seen Merrilll Lynch, JPMorgan -- I think today, Commonwealth came out and they said, "Look, we're going to treat the nonretirement business exactly like we're treating the retirement business because it's just too complicated to do something different." We'll see if that trend continues, but it's likely to if you think about it, especially dealing with the same customer with the retirement assets and then their nonretirement assets and trying to explain to them why there's this different pricing.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And any update to the AUM exposed?
componenttext: Okay. And any update to the AUM exposed?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Actually, I don't -- I think -- I mean, to Greg's point, we're going towards an environment where I think it's all exposed. There's going to be very, very little difference between retirement assets and nonretirement assets just because it's going to
componenttext: No. Actually, I don't -- I think -- I mean, to Greg's point, we're going towards an environment where I think it's all exposed. There's going to be very, very little difference between retirement assets and nonretirement assets just because it's going to be difficult. And I think someone asked the question, but perhaps it was you, about the technology associated with trying to keep track of all of this. It's much more difficult for the broker-dealers than it is for Franklin Templeton. So when we look at the cost of the administration of 2 different buckets of business, I think they're coming to the conclusion that we're going to one bucket of business and leave it at that.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Glenn Schorr with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Glenn Schorr with Evercore ISI.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is John Dunn in for Glenn. One more on repatriation. Let's say it did happen. About how much would you say is spoken for and how much is deployable at this point?
componenttext: This is John Dunn in for Glenn. One more on repatriation. Let's say it did happen. About how much would you say is spoken for and how much is deployable at this point?

componenttext: Well, keep in mind that we do -- we paid 100% of consolidated net income, but part of that is earned outside the United States. So is that sustainable indefinitely? I don't think it's sustainable indefinitely, but we certainly have flexibility in terms of the ability to raise capital or adjust other things.
