componenttextpreview: I guess, Greg, you highlighted the variable annuity outflows that have been occurring and are, I guess, slated to occur over the next couple of quarters. Can you talk a bit about why that's occurring again, just to refresh us, and if it's DOL related? And
componenttext: I guess, Greg, you highlighted the variable annuity outflows that have been occurring and are, I guess, slated to occur over the next couple of quarters. Can you talk a bit about why that's occurring again, just to refresh us, and if it's DOL related? And then ultimately, what's the AUM left in those buckets that maybe longer term might be at risk?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll start, and again, I have Tom because I -- we figured those questions would come up with DOL and, specifically, VA. And we have a very strong business in that area, sub-advising as well as separate funds that are for the annuity business. And rea
componenttext: Yes, I'll start, and again, I have Tom because I -- we figured those questions would come up with DOL and, specifically, VA. And we have a very strong business in that area, sub-advising as well as separate funds that are for the annuity business. And really, many of the large players that we grew, I think, at a high of about $70 billion in assets in that category, the -- many of the big names have gotten out of that business. And as they wind down the assets, many are going to in-house and passive or low volatility strategies. And we're trying to capture as much as that transition is possible, but it has put a large block of business in transition at risk. I think for next quarter, we're estimating another $2.6 billion in outflows. And today, we're at $40 billion -- $35 billion approximately in assets that are remaining. And I'll let -- Tom, if you have anything to add on the business itself?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Greg covered what's going on well. What we're doing in response is we have established a dedicated insurance solutions group within our overall solutions portfolio group, and we're developing portfolios that are -- that have less basis risk. I mean,
componenttext: Yes. Greg covered what's going on well. What we're doing in response is we have established a dedicated insurance solutions group within our overall solutions portfolio group, and we're developing portfolios that are -- that have less basis risk. I mean, one of the issues is with the insurance companies that there was a high basis risk in some of their underlying portfolios for the VA contracts. So we're working on reducing that. And I think you'll see in the next 4 or 5 days one of the top 5 insurance companies by sales is going to be announcing a new VA living benefit that's backed by a customized Franklin Templeton portfolio. So we're working very hard to make sure that we stay relevant with the firms that are staying in the business.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as of quarter-end, we had $46 billion remaining in VA assets.
componenttext: And as of quarter-end, we had $46 billion remaining in VA assets.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just a follow-up, I guess, maybe Tom for you on the DOL. It seems as if the industry is facing a gross sales issue today because of the uncertainty. I guess, as you kind of -- we get closer to the implementation date, are you guys assuming
componenttext: Great. And then just a follow-up, I guess, maybe Tom for you on the DOL. It seems as if the industry is facing a gross sales issue today because of the uncertainty. I guess, as you kind of -- we get closer to the implementation date, are you guys assuming -- or as you talk to advisers, is there assumption -- is there going to be a step function higher in terms of assets in motion, whether that -- whether we see redemptions pick up or, obviously, gross sales could pick up as well? But I guess, have you -- where are we, do you think, in this transition phase for adviser behavior at this point?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don't think you're going to see a pickup in redemptions. There are some awfully attractive looking benefits out there historically, which frankly hurt some of the insurance companies. I think what you're going to see, though, is initially there's g
componenttext: Yes. I don't think you're going to see a pickup in redemptions. There are some awfully attractive looking benefits out there historically, which frankly hurt some of the insurance companies. I think what you're going to see, though, is initially there's going to be a slowdown in sales within the VA business because the commissions are coming down. There's no question about that. There's going to be shorter surrender time. So the VA business is going to be in a state of flux. But we know from working with our clients -- so we work with the top 5 in the industry -- that they're not standing still, right? So they are coming out and will be coming out with new products to stay relevant in the new -- with the new DOL legislation.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, my comment was just on mutual fund sales, not on the VA. So just generally, in terms of the adviser behavior broadly, not just with VA.
componenttext: I guess, my comment was just on mutual fund sales, not on the VA. So just generally, in terms of the adviser behavior broadly, not just with VA.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I mean, I don't know that there's going to be -- I mean, look, people still need to invest; they still need to retire; they still need to provide for college education. As Greg mentioned, that it's going to be difficult for some advisers because a lot
componenttext: No. I mean, I don't know that there's going to be -- I mean, look, people still need to invest; they still need to retire; they still need to provide for college education. As Greg mentioned, that it's going to be difficult for some advisers because a lot of the business is going advisory. I think the number is you need to have about $30 million as an adviser of assets under management to have a viable business. So it's going to be hard for some people to stay in business if they don't have a sizable book. So there will be some transition in the advisers themselves, but there's still a very, very strong demand that's not changing.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I just think it's still early to kind of forecast. There's a lot of people that would argue that the amount of money in motion, it could slow down because of tax considerations, too, if you have taxable gains. And one, you can't take and then move it
componenttext: And I just think it's still early to kind of forecast. There's a lot of people that would argue that the amount of money in motion, it could slow down because of tax considerations, too, if you have taxable gains. And one, you can't take and then move it to another. And this is obviously outside of the retirement world. And then how the incentives line up post this change as well, that could affect behavior on how assets move if some just stay old versus new. It just won't all move at once.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Worthington with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Worthington with JPMorgan.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, I think earlier this year, you called out that you thought the institutional business had a lot of promise, I think, particularly when it came to FX exposure management. Each quarter, we tend to hear about these big outflows. And it seems like there
componenttext: Greg, I think earlier this year, you called out that you thought the institutional business had a lot of promise, I think, particularly when it came to FX exposure management. Each quarter, we tend to hear about these big outflows. And it seems like there's broader base sort of institutional redemptions. So I guess, the question is, help us understand what's going on in the institutional side of the business and maybe characterize how you see the outlook.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's been, as you know, I mean, challenging with Templeton and the deep value philosophy. I mean, that cycle has -- the timing of the market has been working against getting new mandates. So the good news is that we've seen things switching,
componenttext: Well, I think it's been, as you know, I mean, challenging with Templeton and the deep value philosophy. I mean, that cycle has -- the timing of the market has been working against getting new mandates. So the good news is that we've seen things switching, moving in the right direction for performance. So hopefully, that's -- that, historically, has been our area where we had the strongest institutional business and still have the largest assets. So it's been more defense than offense as far as wins. I think the opportunities we're seeing in local debt around the globe, especially in Asia, we continue to work hard on those and have, I think, a lot of opportunities that are still there in the pipeline. We've gotten a few, but we still think that will be in the strongest area of growth. Then I'll -- Tom, if you want to add any.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, what we're seeing in the U.S. is a re-risking of portfolios. If you look at the public pension plans, they're severely underfunded. They need higher return. So they're starting to look at portfolios or asset classes that provide a high risk-a
componenttext: Yes. I mean, what we're seeing in the U.S. is a re-risking of portfolios. If you look at the public pension plans, they're severely underfunded. They need higher return. So they're starting to look at portfolios or asset classes that provide a high risk-adjusted return. So I think that speaks well for some of the capabilities that we have on a global basis in fixed income. And as Greg pointed out, with value coming back, that speaks well for Templeton and Templeton Group, too. But they have to re-risk those portfolios, and we want to participate.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then I think just a follow-up on Mike's question earlier on repatriation. How much time do you think it will take to evaluate the chances of repatriation or a repatriation holiday after elections? Is it something that you think is sort of appar
componenttext: Great. And then I think just a follow-up on Mike's question earlier on repatriation. How much time do you think it will take to evaluate the chances of repatriation or a repatriation holiday after elections? Is it something that you think is sort of apparent pretty quickly? Or it's just going to take 2 or 3 years? And if it does take 2 or 3 years, as long as the chances of a repatriation holiday aren't 0, do you think it's just best to sit on the cash and wait? Or do you start to get frustrated and make it a priority to maybe better utilize the cash?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Ken. As Greg mentioned, we're always looking for opportunities to grow the business, and that won't change internationally. Greg mentioned that all things being equal, it's -- an acquisition is cheaper if we use offshore cash. And so that --
componenttext: Yes. This is Ken. As Greg mentioned, we're always looking for opportunities to grow the business, and that won't change internationally. Greg mentioned that all things being equal, it's -- an acquisition is cheaper if we use offshore cash. And so that -- it's not that we're sitting and we're not doing anything else waiting for repatriation. So I do want to make that clear. We are looking for opportunities. And so that's one of the strategic advantages of having all that cash, we'll be able to move on something if the opportunity presented itself. But regarding the time line for repatriation, there's been a lot of momentum, and we feel like it's gaining momentum. Congress is working on the issue. We feel like when they come back in session January or something, they might be talking about it. Our advisers remind us all the time that 4 of the last 5 presidents enacted tax reform by August of their first year. So we are optimistic of it -- about it, and we're also looking for other ways to use that cash.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of William Katz with Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of William Katz with Citigroup.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, maybe one for you to get started. You gave some guidance on expenses for fiscal '17 over '16. Within that construct, you also talked a little bit about some investment spending pick up on the tech line. Stepping back more broadly, if we were to sort
componenttext: Ken, maybe one for you to get started. You gave some guidance on expenses for fiscal '17 over '16. Within that construct, you also talked a little bit about some investment spending pick up on the tech line. Stepping back more broadly, if we were to sort of replicate 2017 -- 2016, '17, we assume, defined by choppy markets and some sluggish organic growth, how much expense flexibility do you have at this point? I guess, the question I'm really asking is, are you sort of reaching the point now where you get a little more limited on expenses absent eating some maybe that revenue-generating point of the company?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there's still flexibility on the expense -- on all the expenses. But having said that, I do think we're in a phase where those opportunities take longer to execute. They have to -- they tend to be more linked with strategic initiatives. So we cont
componenttext: I think there's still flexibility on the expense -- on all the expenses. But having said that, I do think we're in a phase where those opportunities take longer to execute. They have to -- they tend to be more linked with strategic initiatives. So we continue to look at all that. Is the business the right size, et cetera? Are we leveraging technology the best way we can? So I do think there's opportunities, but I don't think there's a lot of quick hits that would move the dial.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Greg, so curious. It's been sort of a merger of equals between Janus and Henderson, a business that, I think, you go up against in various geographies around the world. Does that transaction in and of itself, or the implication of the trans
componenttext: Okay. And then Greg, so curious. It's been sort of a merger of equals between Janus and Henderson, a business that, I think, you go up against in various geographies around the world. Does that transaction in and of itself, or the implication of the transaction, does that shift the mind-set a little bit? And could you maybe weave that in with the allocation within repatriation between acquisition versus buyback versus dividends?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I mean, I don't think it changes the mind-set. I think in that case, there was clear benefits for the 2 firms to get into 2 different markets and leverage the distribution of each side to do that. I think the consensus out there of consolidation, does
componenttext: No. I mean, I don't think it changes the mind-set. I think in that case, there was clear benefits for the 2 firms to get into 2 different markets and leverage the distribution of each side to do that. I think the consensus out there of consolidation, does this create a wave of consolidation. Obviously, this is a slower growth business; it's a more mature business. And one way to gain efficiencies is through consolidation. So I think companies, as I said before, are going to be much more open to looking at that avenue to create value.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Alex Blostein with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Alex Blostein with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, to follow up on the, I guess, evolution of the distribution channel and the potential implications for you guys. Heard you on the prepared remarks around potentially launching a new share class, and that's something you guys talked about in the pas
componenttext: First, to follow up on the, I guess, evolution of the distribution channel and the potential implications for you guys. Heard you on the prepared remarks around potentially launching a new share class, and that's something you guys talked about in the past as well. But any thoughts around the implications for management fees for you specifically and the industry broadly as we go through this adjustment in the distribution channel?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think as far as the preparation and effect, I mean, think management fees is something that again -- I mean, it -- this is an extremely competitive business. We all see the battle versus passive every day. So the pressure on management fees
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think as far as the preparation and effect, I mean, think management fees is something that again -- I mean, it -- this is an extremely competitive business. We all see the battle versus passive every day. So the pressure on management fees is there regardless of DOL or not. I think the question around your product lineup, and it's something that maybe Ken touched on a little bit on just where do we see potential savings in streamlining and what is DOL, I think it, probably for us, pushes us further down that path of trying to simplify the lineup and rationalize funds that may -- in a post-DOL world, may not fit neatly into more of an advisory model versus a traditional brokerage model. Those are the debates we're having internally now, and that could create some efficiencies. But I think from a cost side, this is a business that every basis point is going to matter. And I think the good news on some outcomes from the DOL is you're going to have a lower front-end sales charge that will help with some of your relative rankings. And then as we said, and I think in our announcement at Morningstar, it's now the A shares is not going to use those maximum charge because most of it's done at a net asset value. And that's going to make us more competitive where we see a lot of our funds will increase its star rating. So I think those are very positive outcomes, and I think our concern of having 35 share classes at least now where we feel like we'll only have to add a few.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then my second question along similar lines, I guess. But historically, you guys were very successful with kind of keeping more assets within the Franklin fund family in the brokerage channel, partially because, I guess, of waived commission o
componenttext: Got it. And then my second question along similar lines, I guess. But historically, you guys were very successful with kind of keeping more assets within the Franklin fund family in the brokerage channel, partially because, I guess, of waived commission once a client already paid that commission in one fund moving to another. As you migrate over to the advisory channel, can you help us understand how that could impact asset retention? And maybe just from a historical perspective, kind of like what's sort of percentage of the gross sales that has come from kind of folks switching from one fund to another?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don't have that number. I think anytime you go to more of the adviser-type, gatekeeper-driven model. It's the pros and cons. I mean, you can get significant assets quickly, and you could lose significant assets quickly. I think that's the net effec
componenttext: Yes. I don't have that number. I think anytime you go to more of the adviser-type, gatekeeper-driven model. It's the pros and cons. I mean, you can get significant assets quickly, and you could lose significant assets quickly. I think that's the net effect. I think the advantage of the transition, it's like a funnel where there's going to be less funds available in the new model. But if you have large assets, the probability of your fund being included, even in a period of underperformance, it's highly unlikely that it's going to be eliminated from that lineup. So I think size matters quite a bit as far as continuing to get shelf space in the new model. But it is higher risk from a retention standpoint than your traditional brokerage model where it's more a one-on-one relationship. Here, it's more of a gatekeeper-, consultant-driven, more institutional-type relationship. And we've transitioned our model to, I think, adapt to that and have more people with consulting experience at that point of contact with the home offices.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Ken Hill with Barclays.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Ken Hill with Barclays.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up on something from earlier in the call. You mentioned -- looking at the opportunities, you continue to do that, but that's kind of pretty consistent with how you've talked about that in past quarters. I'm just curious how you're
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up on something from earlier in the call. You mentioned -- looking at the opportunities, you continue to do that, but that's kind of pretty consistent with how you've talked about that in past quarters. I'm just curious how you're evaluating some of those opportunities is related to the cash you guys have and maybe what criteria or metrics you might look at base the decision on to potentially grow something versus look to M&A to jump-start some activity there.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think in previous calls, we've talked about the sheer volume of things that we look at every year, and that continues. And I would say the criteria that we use is a lot of it's qualitative. We focus on the institutional process -- institutionalize
componenttext: Sure. I think in previous calls, we've talked about the sheer volume of things that we look at every year, and that continues. And I would say the criteria that we use is a lot of it's qualitative. We focus on the institutional process -- institutionalized investment process, can be repeatable, key man risk, all of that, because it's a people business, and cultural fit. And that quickly eliminates a lot of prospectives. But -- so that really hasn't changed. And Greg touched on what's -- some of the criteria that we might look at. So I think no change to what we said in the past.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Patrick Davitt with Autonomous.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Patrick Davitt with Autonomous.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: First of all, I just wanted to clarify, the $46 billion of VA, is that before or after the $7.4 billion of outflow you talked about in the pre-recorded call?
componenttext: First of all, I just wanted to clarify, the $46 billion of VA, is that before or after the $7.4 billion of outflow you talked about in the pre-recorded call?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's before.
componenttext: That's before.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the other question I have is on, first, the liquidity rule and then broader regulatory concerns. One, do you have any initial thoughts on the expense associated with compliance with the rule and/or potential performance impacts on your fund
componenttext: Okay. And then the other question I have is on, first, the liquidity rule and then broader regulatory concerns. One, do you have any initial thoughts on the expense associated with compliance with the rule and/or potential performance impacts on your funds that invest in more illiquid assets? And more broadly, does your expense guidance for 2017 include any associated expense for becoming compliant with that rule?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think it's probably early to answer any cost associated with the rule. I mean, I think it hasn't been out very long. You have 2 years to comply, my understanding. I think it's a much better rule than when it was first discussed as far as so
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think it's probably early to answer any cost associated with the rule. I mean, I think it hasn't been out very long. You have 2 years to comply, my understanding. I think it's a much better rule than when it was first discussed as far as something that is -- appears to be workable. For us, I don't think we have any major concerns on -- at this stage. I mean, we're still studying it, but our first reaction was that it is -- would not create issues on the portfolio management side for any of our funds. But again, it's -- we're studying the rule like most right now. But I think it's a better outcome than what was first discussed. And I think liquidity is something that we manage very carefully with our boards. And I feel like that's one of the most important parts of our business is managing liquidity, especially in open-end 40 Act-type funds.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Robert Lee with KBW.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Robert Lee with KBW.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just going back to the DOL, and this maybe kind of feels like beating a dead horse a little bit. But you talked a lot about the impact on the fund business. But if there's going to be a movement to advisory, presumably, that should increase demand for the
componenttext: Just going back to the DOL, and this maybe kind of feels like beating a dead horse a little bit. But you talked a lot about the impact on the fund business. But if there's going to be a movement to advisory, presumably, that should increase demand for the SMA business. So I mean, that's not a part of the business that, I think, in the past you talked about much. Can you maybe update us on how you feel you're positioned maybe with the -- in the SMA part of the retail world and if that's a place where you feel like maybe you need -- ought to need to make some changes or some investment?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Tom. So we -- that's good observation. We've actually added to the SMA business. It had been kind of, if you will, a quiet part of the retail business, but we've added to it over the last 2 years. We've moved it into our private wealth divisi
componenttext: Yes. This is Tom. So we -- that's good observation. We've actually added to the SMA business. It had been kind of, if you will, a quiet part of the retail business, but we've added to it over the last 2 years. We've moved it into our private wealth division because we think that there is a big role for that in the high net worth part of our business, and we're working on adding some ESG screens to that part of the business as well because we're seeing that as kind of an increasing demand in the high net worth business. So good observation. We're building it up.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then also sticking with the DOL, I mean -- I hear different things from different advisers and different managers as -- I mean, obviously, you're going to have a level fee setting for doing it back and all that. But one of the things that seems
componenttext: Okay. And then also sticking with the DOL, I mean -- I hear different things from different advisers and different managers as -- I mean, obviously, you're going to have a level fee setting for doing it back and all that. But one of the things that seems people have different opinions on is what happens to things like platform fees, setting aside revenue share. I mean, so what's your current thought? Do you think that in many cases, distributors won't be able to charge platform fees? Or some argue it's going to go up. Others just argue it's going to go away. So what do you kind of hear?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: All of the above. I think that's -- that's why I really -- it's almost daily on some of the different opinions on whether -- how do you retain -- how do you have a level platform fee across different groups that have different perspectives with different
componenttext: All of the above. I think that's -- that's why I really -- it's almost daily on some of the different opinions on whether -- how do you retain -- how do you have a level platform fee across different groups that have different perspectives with different levels and different asset levels and how do you include or exclude the ETFs that wouldn't have that ability. There's all kinds of issues that are still being worked through between. And that's why to sit and say, "Well, it could cost us more, it could cost us less," I would answer yes because I'm not really sure at this stage. We're working through it. Tom, do you have anything...

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, to Greg's point, we have one very large client that said they're not going to take any revenue sharing post April in any new assets they put on the books. And we have another large client who said no, they're going to continue to look at rev
componenttext: Well, I mean, to Greg's point, we have one very large client that said they're not going to take any revenue sharing post April in any new assets they put on the books. And we have another large client who said no, they're going to continue to look at revenue share as part of their business. So we'll see how it plays out.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Great. And if I could, just maybe one more quick question. On the ETF business, I mean, you've been investing in. And you touched on it, I think, in the pre-recorded call about another place you want to continue to invest. So how are you -- fro
componenttext: All right. Great. And if I could, just maybe one more quick question. On the ETF business, I mean, you've been investing in. And you touched on it, I think, in the pre-recorded call about another place you want to continue to invest. So how are you -- from the outside looking in, how are you thinking about what would ultimately -- what kind of landmarks that we should look for, for success in that? I mean, do you kind of feel like, gee, this is -- we think we can really scale this quickly? Or that's kind of a slow build, and it's hopefully 5-plus years when you'll see an impact? I mean, how are you thinking about whether you're going to be successful or not over the next couple of years?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it is a slow build. I think part of it was just getting in the business, understanding the business and getting the right people that can operate a very different product and a very different skill set than what we traditionally have. I think that
componenttext: I think it is a slow build. I think part of it was just getting in the business, understanding the business and getting the right people that can operate a very different product and a very different skill set than what we traditionally have. I think that has been a -- we would call that a success of having a very strong team in place, and it's really building from here. And recognizing any new funds or ETFs that we roll out take time. So it's really about building shelf space, awareness. I think we continue to do that. And Tom, if you want to add something...

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So to Greg's point, we've added significantly to the ETF distribution team, and they're working with our 100 -- or 90 to 100 wholesalers to leverage up dumba** subject matter experts. So that's on the building brand part of the business. But we're qu
componenttext: Yes. So to Greg's point, we've added significantly to the ETF distribution team, and they're working with our 100 -- or 90 to 100 wholesalers to leverage up dumba** subject matter experts. So that's on the building brand part of the business. But we're quite excited to be able to have as -- and you'll hear that we're going to be building out more of our strategic beta platform. Because we want an adviser to be able to come to Franklin Templeton, and we want to be able to build a portfolio that is either fully active or is partially strategic beta, partially fully active. We, frankly, are agnostic. We want them, though, to be able to come to us and build out a fully featured, fully diversified portfolio. So we're all in on that initiative.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And expanding it outside the U.S., too, is part of the initiative, which will take time.
componenttext: And expanding it outside the U.S., too, is part of the initiative, which will take time.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brennan Hawken with UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brennan Hawken with UBS.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, on DOL, can you -- is the idea that you've got some upward expense pressure next year on technology, is that a function of the indications of working with your distribution partners? And as they make those changes to level pricing and some of the a
componenttext: First, on DOL, can you -- is the idea that you've got some upward expense pressure next year on technology, is that a function of the indications of working with your distribution partners? And as they make those changes to level pricing and some of the adjustments that you need to make to your own system, and therefore, that piece is somewhat inflexible?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it is not so much that. It's other projects and initiatives that are underway, particularly in the part of the business that does things like fund accounting and pricing and all that. I think we're -- that's -- we're trying to invest in technology
componenttext: I think it is not so much that. It's other projects and initiatives that are underway, particularly in the part of the business that does things like fund accounting and pricing and all that. I think we're -- that's -- we're trying to invest in technology to make sure that we can scale that going forward and support all of the product demands that are out there in the industry. So it's more of that and less, really, of the DOL. I mean, we think we have a lot of share classes, and we think that we can do that with not -- with just incremental spend but not too much.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay. And then appreciate -- it must be pretty hard to manage all the different distribution partners and all the different approaches. But as you have those discussions and it seems firms are becoming more and more clear in what it is that their po
componenttext: Okay. Okay. And then appreciate -- it must be pretty hard to manage all the different distribution partners and all the different approaches. But as you have those discussions and it seems firms are becoming more and more clear in what it is that their policies are here in recent times, do you have an update to the amount of AUM that you think is exposed to this rule? And as you're having discussions with distribution partners, are you seeing any of those partners actually have an impact in the current iterations and in the prep for the current rule on assets beyond just retirement accounts?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I'll just start by saying this rule puts all assets in a different place because -- and again, I think I said this before, but the thought that you can run one pricing structure under retirement and then have the other business at a different pric
componenttext: I mean, I'll just start by saying this rule puts all assets in a different place because -- and again, I think I said this before, but the thought that you can run one pricing structure under retirement and then have the other business at a different pricing structure creates all kinds of problems as well. So I think many are just thinking about moving to one standard at some point. And again, there's different philosophies on that and different faces. And so it's hard to say x percent, but I'd start by saying all of it. At some point, this will -- is a game changer for the traditional way funds are priced. And Tom, do you...

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that you've seen Merrill Lynch, JPMorgan -- I think today, Commonwealth came out and they said, "Look, we're going to treat the nonretirement business exactly like we're treating the retirement business because it's just too complicated to do
componenttext: Yes. I think that you've seen Merrill Lynch, JPMorgan -- I think today, Commonwealth came out and they said, "Look, we're going to treat the nonretirement business exactly like we're treating the retirement business because it's just too complicated to do something different." We'll see if that trend continues, but it's likely to if you think about it, especially dealing with the same customer with the retirement assets and then their nonretirement assets and trying to explain to them why there's this different pricing.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And any update to the AUM exposed?
componenttext: Okay. And any update to the AUM exposed?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Actually, I don't -- I think -- I mean, to Greg's point, we're going towards an environment where I think it's all exposed. There's going to be very, very little difference between retirement assets and nonretirement assets just because it's going to
componenttext: No. Actually, I don't -- I think -- I mean, to Greg's point, we're going towards an environment where I think it's all exposed. There's going to be very, very little difference between retirement assets and nonretirement assets just because it's going to be difficult. And I think someone asked the question, but perhaps it was you, about the technology associated with trying to keep track of all of this. It's much more difficult for the broker-dealers than it is for Franklin Templeton. So when we look at the cost of the administration of 2 different buckets of business, I think they're coming to the conclusion that we're going to one bucket of business and leave it at that.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Glenn Schorr with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Glenn Schorr with Evercore ISI.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is John Dunn in for Glenn. One more on repatriation. Let's say it did happen. About how much would you say is spoken for and how much is deployable at this point?
componenttext: This is John Dunn in for Glenn. One more on repatriation. Let's say it did happen. About how much would you say is spoken for and how much is deployable at this point?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I think that of the, call it, $8 billion or so, maybe $6 billion is international or outside the U.S. Whether that's deployable, that remains to be seen, but the bulk of it should be.
componenttext: Yes. Well, I think that of the, call it, $8 billion or so, maybe $6 billion is international or outside the U.S. Whether that's deployable, that remains to be seen, but the bulk of it should be.

componenttext: Got you. And then just one more on cash. With the amount you guys have, I would think that 100% payout could go on for a long time. Is that  a fair characterization? And what might your willingness to do that be?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, keep in mind that we do -- we paid 100% of consolidated net income, but part of that is earned outside the United States. So is that sustainable indefinitely? I don't think it's sustainable indefinitely, but we certainly have flexibility in terms of
componenttext: Well, keep in mind that we do -- we paid 100% of consolidated net income, but part of that is earned outside the United States. So is that sustainable indefinitely? I don't think it's sustainable indefinitely, but we certainly have flexibility in terms of the ability to raise capital or adjust other things.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Bedell with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Brian Bedell with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for all the color on Department of Labor. It's really good. Maybe just another one on that. Obviously, a lot of confusion we're hearing on that as well. Just as you think as -- from a time frame perspective, do you sense that things will be pretty
componenttext: Thanks for all the color on Department of Labor. It's really good. Maybe just another one on that. Obviously, a lot of confusion we're hearing on that as well. Just as you think as -- from a time frame perspective, do you sense that things will be pretty well buttoned down by year-end and advisers will be in a position to sort of make decisions about where they want to allocate, and all the firms will have everything sort of lined up, even if we do have 2 different ends or 2 different spectrums, say, by year-end? Or do you think this will go on for a while? And then, Tom, also maybe just what you're hearing from the wholesalers about the broad desire for advisers to move to passive products from active.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let's start with the last part of the question first. When -- as you move to an advisory business model, if you're charging 1.5%, you want to make sure that your -- the underlying investment fees are, if you will, cost effective, right? So there is, as Gr
componenttext: Let's start with the last part of the question first. When -- as you move to an advisory business model, if you're charging 1.5%, you want to make sure that your -- the underlying investment fees are, if you will, cost effective, right? So there is, as Greg has pointed out, there's a heightened interest in management expenses, and that's going to continue. That's one of the reasons that we launched our strategic beta lineup because we're going to be able to play in the -- in more of an active space within the retail business. What we're seeing from advisers is, frankly, there's a lot of confusion because a lot of advisers have built a commission-based business, and that's where you're selling a product to a client. Now they're being looked at as having they're being required to build portfolios. That's a very different business model. That's a very different skill set. So we're working -- again, we're doing an extensive training internally to be able to work with advisers to help them with that. And as Greg pointed out, we started building out our investment platform team, gosh, 7, 8 years ago because the platforms, if you will, the gate -- research, gatekeepers become even more important, more powerful going forward. So we're working on it from both ends. And I do note, just attending meetings -- summer meetings with our clients, that they've been working on this for quite some time. They're not standing still. And I think many of them -- and you're starting to see the announcements are coming out with here's what we're going to do come April. So a lot of them have started to make those decisions already.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, just another question on the expenses. Ken, you mentioned on the fund accounting side that you're reinvesting in that area. Have you looked at that versus outsourcing it? And are you committed to not outsourcing it at this stage?
componenttext: I mean, just another question on the expenses. Ken, you mentioned on the fund accounting side that you're reinvesting in that area. Have you looked at that versus outsourcing it? And are you committed to not outsourcing it at this stage?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We have definitely looked at that, and we probably every 5 or 6 years look at it again and again. And the conclusion, historically, has been the same. And currently, right now, we think it makes more sense to do it ourselves. And I would say the bigg
componenttext: Yes. We have definitely looked at that, and we probably every 5 or 6 years look at it again and again. And the conclusion, historically, has been the same. And currently, right now, we think it makes more sense to do it ourselves. And I would say the biggest determinant of that is our existing cost structure. So as you know, we have extensive operations in low-cost jurisdictions. And so when we compare the cost of doing it ourselves to what -- cost for outsourcing, it makes economic sense for us to keep it in source. That's the current thinking. But as things change, outsourcing companies get more efficient. So it's a continuous evaluation.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. It sounds like for now, you're keeping it in-house and certainly for the next few years.
componenttext: Right. It sounds like for now, you're keeping it in-house and certainly for the next few years.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: For now, yes, that's our conclusion.
componenttext: For now, yes, that's our conclusion.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe just the last one for Greg. Obviously, the acquisition question is always asked, especially in this type of environment. But I mean, as you think about the types of firms that you -- that would be interesting, just from a strategic st
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe just the last one for Greg. Obviously, the acquisition question is always asked, especially in this type of environment. But I mean, as you think about the types of firms that you -- that would be interesting, just from a strategic standpoint, would something that enhances your distribution capabilities, which are already extremely large and build out different types of products, would that have a preference over, say, a rationalization and scale type of acquisition, where you'd be combining funds into, say, merging weaker-performing funds into stronger-performing ones to get the track records and looking at more like a cost synergy play?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think obviously, there's a lot more opportunities to go out and just target a strong investment manager and bolt it on to your existing distribution system. And that's one that's certainly in markets that we talked about before. And with th
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think obviously, there's a lot more opportunities to go out and just target a strong investment manager and bolt it on to your existing distribution system. And that's one that's certainly in markets that we talked about before. And with the pound so weak, that makes the U.K. a more attractive market despite Brexit. It's -- we see that as more of a near-term opportunity to acquire something that would be additive to our lineup and strengthen our presence in a market where we don't really have a strong presence in the U.K. Outside of that, I think the others become much more difficult and a larger one that is much harder to do and much more disruptive, obviously, to the entire organization. But one that in the right situation again is something that we would certainly look at. But I think it is much more difficult to execute.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Harris with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Harris with Wells Fargo.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're looking at your hybrid category here. I mean, redemptions have improved substantially, but sales keep ticking lower. It's kind of interesting that, that's happening because the performance is improving so much. As we again talk about that a little b
componenttext: We're looking at your hybrid category here. I mean, redemptions have improved substantially, but sales keep ticking lower. It's kind of interesting that, that's happening because the performance is improving so much. As we again talk about that a little bit, what was it going to take to get sales going here given the performance already seems to be improving quite nicely?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I -- it was exactly the question I had to our group early this morning. When I was, like, going through some of the numbers, I thought that, that stood out on hybrid gross dropping, and there are some other moving parts in that number. Because actual
componenttext: Yes. I -- it was exactly the question I had to our group early this morning. When I was, like, going through some of the numbers, I thought that, that stood out on hybrid gross dropping, and there are some other moving parts in that number. Because actually, the Franklin Income Fund, its gross sales were exactly level quarter-over-quarter despite the number of hybrid declining. It had almost exactly the same level of gross, and that's the key driver with some other parts in that. I mean, K2 falls into the hybrid category, and that had a little bit of a drop-off quarter-over-quarter. So that contributed to the gross number dropping down. But I think it -- we are very optimistic that, that fund should continue to be a strong driver of our flows in this kind of environment. And I think it takes a little bit of time for people to realize that it's back in the top decile for the 1 year, and you have a lag effect of energy prices and what that did to a lot of our funds. And I look at across the lineup, and I'm very encouraged right now. I think we talked about it in the past as the value. With the value discipline, you tend to get more energy exposure than sometimes the market. And a lot of that has come back, along with materials, and whether it's our high-yield area, the income fund area and hybrid Templeton area and mutual series, all of our rising dividend funds, all those funds now are performing very well. So I would hope that we will get some momentum back now on the strong 1-year numbers. And actually, our hybrid and equity assets, 75% of them are in the top 2 quartiles for the 1 year. So I think that's a big change from where we were 6 months ago.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. Okay. And then a quick one on DOL. I think when we all think about those risks, we tend to think about it in terms of flows. But just wondering whether you guys think ultimately, this rule might force some management fee changes across the indust
componenttext: Got you. Okay. And then a quick one on DOL. I think when we all think about those risks, we tend to think about it in terms of flows. But just wondering whether you guys think ultimately, this rule might force some management fee changes across the industry.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think I tried to answer that before that I think the pressure on fees is there. I think there's components of your overall fees which are in a state of flux, and you can look at parts like the revenue share piece, and it -- you do away with that. T
componenttext: Yes. I think I tried to answer that before that I think the pressure on fees is there. I think there's components of your overall fees which are in a state of flux, and you can look at parts like the revenue share piece, and it -- you do away with that. That's going to make it a little bit easier to lower overall management fees and make you more competitive on that basis. Others -- other areas, I think distributor retention, the historic number that actually was going away anyway over time, but that goes away immediately if you give up pricing at the broker-dealer level this new class of shares. But as the world was transitioning more to advisory, the traditional A share was getting smaller and smaller as part of our business. So that changes as well. TA fees, all those things, sub-TA fees, all of those are again in a state of flux. So I think it's early, but just to say, it puts everything kind of in play at this stage.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Craig Siegenthaler with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Craig Siegenthaler with Credit Suisse.

componenttext: Just want to see if you have any early thoughts on how the Global Bond fund, your muni products and also K2 fare with the new highly liquid investment in the SEC's new liquidity risk management rule?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think that's a good question, and I think our initial reaction is it should be okay. But I think again, it's too early for us. This just came out. We're assessing it. And I think that's the obvious one you're going to look at and see how it
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think that's a good question, and I think our initial reaction is it should be okay. But I think again, it's too early for us. This just came out. We're assessing it. And I think that's the obvious one you're going to look at and see how it works. But too early to really give you a definitive answer one way or another.

componenttext: Just as a follow-up. How much of that cash -- excess cash is sitting in the U.S. right now?

componenttext: Excess, I think we're roughly -- in total, about $2 billion and maybe $1 billion of excess.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Cyprys with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Cyprys with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just curious if you could talk a little bit about how you see pricing evolving for active management as more and more assets shift to lower-fee, passive-priced products and DOL going into effect. We're seeing price cuts in ETFs business there that drive m
componenttext: Just curious if you could talk a little bit about how you see pricing evolving for active management as more and more assets shift to lower-fee, passive-priced products and DOL going into effect. We're seeing price cuts in ETFs business there that drive more flows to the ETF players. Just how do you think about the price elasticity of demand for active management products?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it depends on how you're performing against the passive. I think you're never going to beat passive on price. It's the consensus view like it is today that passive will outperform. That's not a view I share. And I think in the next decade, I
componenttext: Well, I think it depends on how you're performing against the passive. I think you're never going to beat passive on price. It's the consensus view like it is today that passive will outperform. That's not a view I share. And I think in the next decade, I think active will very well. And then if you outperform the passive, pricing becomes less of an issue. But I think the world is overly focused today strictly on price and isn't really looking at anything else. And I think that will change as well. But again as I've said before, I think any industry that's slower growth and has a lot of managers out there, there's going to be continued pressure on pricing. But an active manager, you're not -- if the consensus view is passive as a way to go, you're not going to increase your business by cutting your fees in half, which is just not going to get there.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then are there any areas that you could speak to today, where you've reduced fees or put any waivers in effect, and then just how you're thinking about the opportunity and interest for repricing active maybe in some structures with pay for performance
componenttext: And then are there any areas that you could speak to today, where you've reduced fees or put any waivers in effect, and then just how you're thinking about the opportunity and interest for repricing active maybe in some structures with pay for performance perhaps, using some sort of fulcrum fee?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Those -- I think you're absolutely right. I think that you have to be more flexible. That's something we certainly are doing in the institutional market right now, where we're looking at new categories for us and coming with a more of a performance-b
componenttext: Yes. Those -- I think you're absolutely right. I think that you have to be more flexible. That's something we certainly are doing in the institutional market right now, where we're looking at new categories for us and coming with a more of a performance-based-type fee because I think that fits what people are willing to do, they'll pay for more alpha, I think, that the openness to consider those is something we have to do right now because of the consensus view on passive versus active. So I think that, that is something that we are studying as well on just making sure our fees are competitive in markets. And whether that means cutting into profits to maintain share, I think that's something you have to consider.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of William Katz with Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of William Katz with Citigroup.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just 2 follow-ups. So Tom, if you comment on the DOL just one of the specific angle. Can you give us a sense what the mix of your assets are between brokerage and advisory? If you have that kind of look-through lens, as you may know, a lot if it's O
componenttext: Okay. Just 2 follow-ups. So Tom, if you comment on the DOL just one of the specific angle. Can you give us a sense what the mix of your assets are between brokerage and advisory? If you have that kind of look-through lens, as you may know, a lot if it's Omnibus. But just sort of curious, given most likely we have further rotation toward advisory, away from brokerage, what kind of sort of money motion we might be talking about?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the large majority of our business takes place without a commission. I mean, this has been taking -- this trend has been taking place for a number of years now. It's accelerating under the DOL. So it -- we're -- frankly, we're almost there, as Greg
componenttext: Well, the large majority of our business takes place without a commission. I mean, this has been taking -- this trend has been taking place for a number of years now. It's accelerating under the DOL. So it -- we're -- frankly, we're almost there, as Greg pointed out. There's going to be new share classes and less breakpoints and some other changes. But with the business overall, Franklin Templeton's business and the industry's business has been moving towards Omnibus and no load.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And Greg, sort of piqued by your comments about the U.K. market. So when you mentioned that, that's maybe particularly more interesting given the currency dynamic, what kind of framework are we talking about? Are we talking about a market expansion
componenttext: Okay. And Greg, sort of piqued by your comments about the U.K. market. So when you mentioned that, that's maybe particularly more interesting given the currency dynamic, what kind of framework are we talking about? Are we talking about a market expansion type of transaction, a consolidation and roll up some of the redundancies? Or could you be willing to buy something out from a parent that might have a majority stake in a third entity?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Those all sound attractive. I think we would -- we continue to look at anything that would make sense, and I wouldn't rule out any of those different scenarios.
componenttext: Those all sound attractive. I think we would -- we continue to look at anything that would make sense, and I wouldn't rule out any of those different scenarios.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just one follow-up to that. In terms of size, just given where you are, is a merger of equals something that makes sense strategically? Or is it more of a fill in maybe something that might be more complementary to your platform?
componenttext: And just one follow-up to that. In terms of size, just given where you are, is a merger of equals something that makes sense strategically? Or is it more of a fill in maybe something that might be more complementary to your platform?

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think I spoke about that earlier that a merger of equals is difficult for a lot of reasons, especially as you get this big. But they can be -- if they're done and executed properly, they could add a lot of value over time. The easier one is
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think I spoke about that earlier that a merger of equals is difficult for a lot of reasons, especially as you get this big. But they can be -- if they're done and executed properly, they could add a lot of value over time. The easier one is just going out and buying a strong player in the market that's available. That's not always easy to do. But specific to that market, that would be attractive to us. But again, I just wouldn't rule out any of those scenarios.

headline: Franklin Resources, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: We've reached the end of our question-and-answer session. I would like to turn the floor back over to management for any closing comments.
